Here is Kc's reply to Hard Copy.  Apparently his meeting fell through, 
but he composed this letter instead.  Enjoy.

-troy

------------------



The following is a letter we sent to Hard Copy regarding the story.  They
ended up cancelling the meeting for now and made me put my thoughts onto
paper.

They have not responded yet, but have ensured me that they would.  Later
today I will post the "producer" (who was NOT present at the events) name
and fax # so you can send in your own response.

Here's the letter....






                                                                      9 May 1996

XXXXXXXXXXX
Hard Copy
Via Fax  XXXXXXXXXX


RE: Hard Copy report "The Ultimate Bash" 5/8/96



As a producer of DUNE, the "desert-rave" most covered in yesterday's
(5/8/96) Hard Copy "investigation", I am greatly disturbed at the approach
and manner in which you covered the movement.  I understand that not all of
the footage was from DUNE and that the story represented the entire desert
rave movement.  However, the Hard Copy report was presented as a "special
investigation into the ultimate bash" and that "our undercover cameras were
there to capture it all for the first time."  Statements such as these
would indicate that you are reporting on one single event and that all of
the footage in the segment is from that particular event.  The footage is
misrepresentative in this regard.

Here are some brief thoughts, questions and comments regarding this
misrepresentation, misconduct and irresponsibility in your report.  I'm
sure that more issues and clearer thoughts will come around as we in the
DUNE organization have time to discuss this problem in depth.



Questions:
Why did no one from Hard Copy make any attempt to find a DUNE
representative and ask for their thoughts... or even ask for their
permission to cover the event.  We were all (about 30 of us) wearing
prominent laminate tags for easy identification.

Why were we lied to by the "Hard Copy undercover camera" team when we asked
about their use for the footage?  We were insured that the videotape would
be for personal usage only.  Does "personal use" include personal gain at
the expense and defamation of ourselves and our guests at the gathering?

Did the minors who were photographed give waivers to Hard Copy?  Did Hard
Copy ask permission to use our copyrighted graphics on the video screens?
(I'm relatively certain that you would consider matter such as these to
fall under the "fair usage" clause.)

Did Hard Copy make any attempt to cover the story in a different light or
was the "out-of-control-teen-orgy" angle premeditated before the event?  Is
this approach ethical?  Responsible?

Was this material purchased from an independent videographer?

Was the producer (or a staff representative of Hard Copy) even present at
the event?  If so, how could they possibly have overlooked the above
issues.  More importantly, how could they have possibly rendered the
following misinformation about this event.  If not, how could they
substantiate such claims?

Totally inaccurate claims include that the events (implying the one being
pictured) are

        "Deadly teenage orgies of sex and booze <where> there's no way for
        police and parents to help."
AND
        "...far from parents and police and are also far away from medical
        attention for the inevitable casualties from too much booze, too many
        drugs and not enough sleep"

Not only did we invite the police to come, DUNE made extensive (and
expensive) arrangements to have local and federal police officials and an
EMT staffed ambulance present and PAID for the ENTIRE DURATION OF THE
EVENT. We also had port-o-pots and dumpsters brought in so that we wouldn't
repeat the same mistakes made at past events like Woodstock.  We went to
through these exhaustive efforts to combat the very specific (and obvious)
reasons above.  Doesn't that imply something about a level of
responsibility being present at events such as these?  Wasn't this fact
blatantly omitted and misrepresented in your report.

Yes, we had a problem with the current fad of inhaling nitrous oxide.  We
knew it, the police knew it.  And TOGETHER the police and DUNE took action
to keep the problem down to a minimum.  We emptied several tanks and issued
MANY warning citations.


The word "orgy," as in "orgy of sex and booze," infers that sexual
misconduct was the center or even present at this event.  I don't recall
there being ANY out-of-bounds sexual activity.  Furthermore, your report
did not even back-up such an allegation.  So why was such a careless word
used to describe this gathering?  Did the Hard Copy representative see
something that no one else saw?  Why didn't they tape something that
backed-up such a description? The only thing I saw that even remotely
looked orgiastic were people dancing and having the time of their lives.




Misrepresentations:
Having the voice over mention "death" and synchronously showing someone
lying on the ground while pixelating his face implies that the guy pictured
is in fact dead. No one has EVER died at a "rave" in the desert or in Los
Angeles.  (We have been very lucky perhaps.)

It is equally misrepresentative to report that someone at a desert rave
under the influence of psychedelics wandered away from the party who's
"body was found 2 days later."  Where did you get this report?  It wasn't
documented on the local news and none of the 300 people who report details
about LA raves on the internet have ever heard such a story. Nor could
anyone find information to that effect archived anywhere.  Perhaps his body
was found 2 days later at a bar and perhaps he was clean, rested and
shaven?

Hard Copy also states that the rave movement has

        "moved from the city to the desert to escape the violence of the
urban
        raves that have been plagued with gang shootings and deadly fires."

Who did you get this information from?  We only know of 1 instance in the 6
year history of the LA rave culture where there was a gun fired in a gang
related fight.  And there has NEVER been a "deadly fire" at a rave in LA.
(There may not have EVER been a fire at a rave period.... I'm looking into
this).  The only thing that we are escaping are the frustrations of city
dwelling.  We go to the desert to celebrate unbridled life and to be
astonished by the magnificence of nature that is around us.





Irresponsible reports such as yours are killing a very important movement
in the U.S.  Gathering and dancing is not illegal in any way.  I assure you
that it is every ravers dream to be able to cooperate and work with
authorities and the public to make raves safer and more secure and,
therefore, more enjoyable.  This was the effort and purpose of DUNE.  We
cannot begin to make progress in these efforts when "deadly, orgiastic,
out-of-control" misrepresentations are painted by the media in an obvious
attempt at sensationalism, defamation and discredit.  Our efforts have
certainly been set back by your selfishly irresponsible and unethical
report.



We are proud of DUNE.  Apart from there being no fights, no fires, no
medical disasters, no trace of trash or presence/destruction in the desert
(you can look at the Bureau of Land Management report on DUNE to validate
these claims), we blessed many peoples' lives.  My e-mail box and WWW site
are still being bombarded with comments about how DUNE changed their
outlooks on life...  gave them a sense of personal revival.  It surprises
me how 2000 people can walk away from a celebration like DUNE and consider
it to be a highlight of their life while a handful come with ulterior
motives and walk away finding everything BUT beauty and unity.

There is no way to keep the media from profiteering off of our efforts.
Even in your efforts to defame, you made desert raving look like a lot of
fun... Our only hope is that we may be able to better educate ourselves and
bring true understanding to those who (without offering solutions to
problems they see) insist on scrutinizing and discrediting everything
around them.

I hope that you will make an effort to "investigate" your errors.  If you
do, you may uncover a very valuable, beautiful and peaceful spirit on which
rave culture thrives.  Perhaps it may even be something worth reporting!

If you are interested in discovering the true value of rave celebrations, I
would LOVE to escort you through some of the LA underground dance scene and
show you what makes us put so much of our lives into this vital cultural
movement.

Please visit the DUNE WWW site for more information, pictures and reviews
of this event.

http://home.earthlink.net/~sarahtonen






Kirk R. Cameron
DUNE
sarahtonen@earthlink.net






-Kc

Received: from Larry.Catch22.COM (root@Larry.Catch22.COM [204.182.15.11]) by Radar.Catch22.COM (8.7.5/8.6.12) with ESMTP id MAA13729; Fri, 10 May 1996 12:09:12 -0700
X-url: http://www.Catch22.COM/
Received: from Larry.Catch22.COM (jchryslr@localhost [127.0.0.1]) by Larry.Catch22.COM (8.7.3/8.6.9) with ESMTP id MAA29424; Fri, 10 May 1996 12:10:10 -0700

WARNING: spiritual & political theory...

>"...The world is quickly polarizing into those stuck in Fear, control,
>and selfishness, (and who want not just to share their version of the 
>truth, but to legislate it and force others to comply whether or not
>there is a democratic consensus) and those of us who hold the vision
>of a democratic spiritual renaissance on the planet.

The world is as it has always been.  There is no polarization that was not 
already there.  Humanity has always lived with fear, control, selfishness 
and tyranny.  It has always also held hope of a better life, a vision of 
what could be if only everyone would respect and care for each other.  This 
is nothing new.  We can address the here and now, but remember that the here 
and now are the only things you can affect unless you do something very 
large scale with the potential for very long lasting impact.

>Ideology and
>dogma and religion is less important at this moment than whether we
>are visualizing faith, love and spiritual awakening for the world, or
>hate, envy, and collapse.

To tie two threads together, I'm sure the folks in Tibet were visualizing 
faith, love and spiritual awakening when the ideology and dogma of the 
Chinese army rolled right over them.  Thinking happy thoughts is not enough. 
 Action is required at some level that's large enough to be seen by many, if 
not all, something that creates an energy in others and serves as an 
example.  Sitting in the lotus position sending out vibes is useless.  
Identifying those things that we wish to change for the better and making a 
potent effort to change them is what makes a real difference.

S

used to from us.

please come help us celebrate!

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 10 May 1996 09:55:28 -0700 (PDT)
From: KaySEE <kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu>
To: "Eric P. Peterson" <epaul@Synopsys.COM>
Cc: peter fogel <peterbf@ix.netcom.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: socializing at raves


On Fri, 10 May 1996, Eric P. Peterson wrote:

> >I find that sometimes its a struggle to narrow my focus to have a
> >conversation when I'm being swept up into the beauty of all the energy
> >around.  At this time dancing is the best way to relate.
> >
> >I'm most able to feel a oneness with the flow of the vibe, when I'm
> >dancing
> >
> >:)
> >peter
> 
> But there are those of us who feel that, when you do that, you don't WANT
> to relate to us, and we feel ostricized (that's my experience).  It's so
> confusing to find friends, get all excited that we're all sharing in a
> wonderful experience, then see those friends (with whom we were
> anticipating to spend some time socializing) ignore all but the dance floor
> and their own thang.  This happens to me at every party; the most recent
> example would be Nancy at BP: I saw her for all of ten seconds, and that
> was it :(

Eric, I think you have misunderstood Peter's comment.  The dance floor is 
an amazing experience.  Not all communication is found through voice, and 
if you have ever shared space with someone dancing, you will know that 
it is truly an intimiate form of communication.  I have connected in an 
inexplicable way with people while dancing next to them in a state of 
bliss.  When we then mention it to each other, it quickly dissolves 
because it is not something you can explain nor analyze.  It is a 
transcendant communal feeling that just exists.  I don't think you can 
explain this form of communcation, rather you have to experience it.  It 
can take your mind to a new level because it challenges your assumptions 
about how to relate with another human being.  

I spent three straight hours on the dance floor at BP, and I connected 
with people in an amazing way.  It is different than one-on-one 
interactions, but no less legitimate.  I am a firm believer in a 
collective consciousness, where we generate an amazing power as a group, 
but at the same time maintaining the individuality that generates the 
collective experience.  Generating a collective consciousness requires a 
lot of giving from everyone involved, and, IMO, is why it is not 
generated to its fullest potential in most situations.  Most people don't 
know that the more you give, the more you receive.  The amount of giving 
required is very difficult, especially when most people want others to 
make them happy.  

I have been discovering, more and more, the relationship we can share as a 
group. It is my opinion that it is that relationship that keeps people coming 
back.  Some people experience it directly, some are still on the fringes 
and are intrigued enough to eventually find it, and some never find it.  
The ones who don't end up leaving or thinking that the whole experience 
is about drugs and clothes and whatever else.  I would say that I have 
just left the fringes and am starting to step into the center.  However, 
there are many different levels and I can only see the ones behind me and 
not in front of me!

cheers,
kaySEE

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 10 May 1996 13:51:21 -0700
To: epaul@synopsys.com (Eric P. Peterson)
From: rhea@xinet.COM (Rhea Gossett)
Subject: Re: socializing at raves [WARNING: LONG RESPONSE ahead]
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

My name is Rhea & I haven't posted for a _ very long _ time,
but Eric P.'s comments about "socializing at raves" are making
me want to break my silence.

I go to raves for the beautiful balancing point between
the specific/general, individual/group, me/not me....

As Peter Fogel said, it's the "beauty of all the energy around"
that grabs me and holds me - it takes me a while to collect
my thoughts enough to let them go, and surrender them to
dance.  When I'm feeling truly myself, and the music sounds
like the most intense, unbelievably mighty & glorious thing
imaginable, THEN I can't stop smiling, can't stop looking around
me with joy and appreciation.

Some nights the feeling I speak of above happens; some nights
it doesn't happen.  But - above all - when that dance-floor
feeling happens is when I can most feel myself able to reach out,
and share, and take sincere and caring interest in others.

Rave, for me, then, is the moment when I find myself within that
crazy glowing smile, then raise my head up & look around, and
meet the eyes of someone dancing, smiling, crazy next to me !

Eric P. writes:
>But there are those of us who feel that, when you do that, you don't WANT
>to relate to us, and we feel ostricized (that's my experience).  It's so
>confusing to find friends, get all excited that we're all sharing in a
>wonderful experience, then see those friends (with whom we were
>anticipating to spend some time socializing) ignore all but the dance floor
>and their own thang.  This happens to me at every party .....

To sum the experiences I'm speaking of up with the criticism that I
am "ignoring all but the dance floor and my own thang" is really reductive,
I think.

>From your own comments, I could tag socializing, and meeting & greeting
friends as "your thang" and then decide whether or not, as someone who
labels herself a relatively _ un-social _ person, I should feel ostracized
or hurt by your behavior.  I don't want to do that.  It's true, I don't know
you - so in a sense I guess I'm not your friend, but I would hate to be
thinking "this person's my friend, this person's not my friend," as I
looked with joy
over a crowd of people raving.

If you "feel ostracized," that's YOUR feeling; it doesn't "happen
to you" - you choose that interpretation for the confusion you may be
feeling.  Don't put that on people who may be relating to the rave-energy
by dancing.

In a sense, (as Peter said again) dancing _ can _ be the best way to relate -
you're putting your energy into the place, the moment, the music,
the crowd, the building, including everyone & excluding none.

This list itself, right now, is verging away a bit from this
aspect of raving, I think - recent posts about events that happened
over the last two weeks were full of messages from people saying "hi"
to specific friends, posting long lists mentioning people by name who
the writers felt made the event go off for them...though I think it is
incredibly important and exciting when people find each other & become
friends within a shared love of raving, I would still hate to see this
list become exclusively a social circle.

As an interesting aside to the "social" aspect of raves that you
mention, there have been many, many, MANY times that I've been
_roughly_ jostled out of my trance/dance/rhythm by someone
hustling through the dance floor to embrace one of their [official]
friends. What quality of "friendship" is occuring then?

Eric - I really don't want you to feel attacked.  You've just touched
on elements within the whole concept of friendship that I turn over
in my thoughts often. What I really want to express here is the value I see
in remembering to consider as many "perspectives" as I can before I anchor
myself to a specific feeling - the perspectives of others, as well as my own.
Raves have been such a big learning experience for me, showing me
that perspective seems to be what lets us get outside confining social
structures in the first place.

Hopefully smiling at YOU from a dance floor sometime this weekend,

Rhea - who likes to be anonymous, but still likes to have folks
around to talk with when the music ends !

On Fri, 10 May 1996, KaySEE wrote:

> 
> Eric, I think you have misunderstood Peter's comment.  The dance floor is 
> an amazing experience.  Not all communication is found through voice, and 
> if you have ever shared space with someone dancing, you will know that 
> it is truly an intimiate form of communication.  I have connected in an 
> inexplicable way with people while dancing next to them in a state of 
> bliss.  When we then mention it to each other, it quickly dissolves 
> because it is not something you can explain nor analyze.  It is a 
> transcendant communal feeling that just exists.  I don't think you can 
> explain this form of communcation, rather you have to experience it.  It 
> can take your mind to a new level because it challenges your assumptions 
> about how to relate with another human being.  
> 
> I spent three straight hours on the dance floor at BP, and I connected 
> with people in an amazing way.  It is different than one-on-one 
> interactions, but no less legitimate.  I am a firm believer in a 
> collective consciousness, where we generate an amazing power as a group, 
> but at the same time maintaining the individuality that generates the 
> collective experience.  Generating a collective consciousness requires a 
> lot of giving from everyone involved, and, IMO, is why it is not 
> generated to its fullest potential in most situations.  Most people don't 
> know that the more you give, the more you receive.  The amount of giving 
> required is very difficult, especially when most people want others to 
> make them happy.  
> 
> I have been discovering, more and more, the relationship we can share as a 
> group. It is my opinion that it is that relationship that keeps people coming 
> back.  Some people experience it directly, some are still on the fringes 
> and are intrigued enough to eventually find it, and some never find it.  
> The ones who don't end up leaving or thinking that the whole experience 
> is about drugs and clothes and whatever else.  I would say that I have 
> just left the fringes and am starting to step into the center.  However, 
> there are many different levels and I can only see the ones behind me and 
> not in front of me!
> 
> cheers,
> kaySEE
> 
> 


Hi all!
 kaySEE, the collective conciousness you are refering to has been 
experienced in many different enviroments and is a area of (part time) 
study for me. I first came across it at Grateful Dead concerts (before 
they were REALLY big colisium affairs). Bob Weir refered to this 
phenomenon as "Gestalt Linkage".


Ran
                 ( all together now )

powerfull as anything else, and can accomplish as much.

offending any of us Buddhists out here, and once again I appologise for

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 10 14:51:23 1996

Received: from tgrigsby.vip.best.com (tgrigsby.vip.best.com [205.149.169.221]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id NAA06958 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 10 May 1996 13:58:53 -0700
Date: Fri, 10 May 1996 13:58:53 -0700
Message-Id: <199605102058.NAA06958@shellx.best.com>
X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Re: Celestine Prophecy?
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Rick,

Y'know, I kinda had a feeling I'd hear from you on this...

>>Sitting in the lotus position sending out vibes is useless.
>
>I have to say you are wrong here.  You must not do it much yourself, or you
>wouldn't be saying that.  I meditate daily, and I can attest to the fact
>that it is quite useful in all aspects of my existance.

Ok, "useless" was too strong a word.  My focus was on doing something that 
affects the many, not just the one.  And yes, I've meditated.  It gave me 
time to hash out many problems, to center and stabilize myself.  But it did 
little or nothing to solve the problems around me.  It only made me better 
able to handle them.  The initial post implied that spirituality of the self 
was the sole answer to making the world a better place, and I feel that's 
entirely incorrect.

>>Identifying those things that we wish to change for the better and making a 
>>potent effort to change them is what makes a real difference.
>
>This can work as well, but I believe they hold equal weight.

Nothing to add here.  The old saying, "you have to love yourself before you 
can love another" is pretty dead on.  What I was attempting to express -- 
not very well apparently -- was that self-improvement is only one step.  
Becoming actively involved is the next.

Hugging a tree is fine.  Hugging the logger is better.  But if you really 
want change, you have to push the logging company to alter it's business, to 
find other sources of fiber and building materials, to diversify and then 
stop the logging.  And all the spirituality in the world isn't going to 
matter to the top execs who get rich off lumber, or the people whose 
livelihoods rest on the cutting of timber.

Just one example.

S

>Hi all!
> kaySEE, the collective conciousness you are refering to has been 
>experienced in many different enviroments and is a area of (part time) 
>study for me. I first came across it at Grateful Dead concerts (before 
>they were REALLY big colisium affairs). Bob Weir refered to this 
>phenomenon as "Gestalt Linkage".
>
Here is my whole take on this dancefloor/socializing thing. 

Unless you are out dancing, you are being a total lame ass.
Yes, meeting new people is great fun and I try to spend some
time talking to people too.

But I feel that if the DJ is doing a really good job, you
almost owe it to that person to be out dancing! If I was a 
DJ, nothing would be worse than playing to a room full of
boring people. Conversely, if someone really sucks the first
thing I do is go sit down. (yes, I do sit down when I'm tired too!)

I feel like unless i am moving, I'm just sitting there being
entertained. But if I am dancing, I am helping to create the 
energy that ultimately makes the party happen or not. It is 
so great to feel that your energy is helping the party to go off!!
It makes the whole experience really worth it to me. 

Luv-
Ms Phunk

> Eric, I think you have misunderstood Peter's comment.  The dance floor is 
> an amazing experience.  Not all communication is found through voice, and 
> if you have ever shared space with someone dancing, you will know that 
> it is truly an intimiate form of communication.  I have connected in an 
> inexplicable way with people while dancing next to them in a state of 
> bliss.  When we then mention it to each other, it quickly dissolves 
> because it is not something you can explain nor analyze.  It is a 
> transcendant communal feeling that just exists.  I don't think you can 
> explain this form of communcation, rather you have to experience it.  It 
> can take your mind to a new level because it challenges your assumptions 
> about how to relate with another human being.  
> ...
> I have been discovering, more and more, the relationship we can share as a 
> cheers,
> kaySEE

I like your explaination kaySEE! 

Another perspective that I was reminded of by this discussion, related
to trance in groups, is the experiences I've had in zen
meditation. I've only been to zen-do's (a zen-do is a zen church, or a
place where you do zen meditation) a few times, but a simular question
came to mind when I first tried it; why do all these people need to
get together in a room together just to be peaceful and ignore each
other?

After trying it, I understood. The energy of being in a room full of
others meditating is enriching, satisfying, secure, and
transforming. It is actually easier to meditate with others around
you. Or, perhaps with nature around you. After all, we are human, and
humans are very close animals ( dictated by a dependancy of our young
that exceeds most any other animal). I would compare dancing/trancing
alone to a plant trying to grow out of it's soil. Humans are as
conected to other humans as plants are to their soil.

In Zen, true spiritual thought can not be expressed in words (I know
I've read that somewhere). In meditation you empty your mind. Your
only concern is your breathing. Your eyes are closed.

At raves, my only concern is the beat (the breath of the room), my
eyes are so over stiulated by lasers and fast movement (I hope) that I
am effectivly blinded. Words are unimportant and meaningless at this
time. What is there to say? The music says it all for me. 

=Darrel
darrele@netcom.com

>Rick,

>>wouldn't be saying that.  I meditate daily, and I can attest to the fact
>>that it is quite useful in all aspects of my existance.
>
>Ok, "useless" was too strong a word.  My focus was on doing something that
>affects the many, not just the one.  And yes, I've meditated.  It gave me
>time to hash out many problems, to center and stabilize myself.  But it did
>little or nothing to solve the problems around me.  It only made me better
>able to handle them.  The initial post implied that spirituality of the self
>was the sole answer to making the world a better place, and I feel that's
>entirely incorrect.

As the ripple from a pebble thrown into a pond reverberates and spreads out
so does the energy one taps into when one meditates.  Sometimes we are the
pebble, other times the water.

If one's desire is to change the world around them and to have an impact on
nature of the reality that we chose to exist in, one must initiate that change
within themselves.

There is never just a sole answer to most situations.  Variables and
permutations
in energies and one's actions, whether immediately tangible or not also
have an impact,
at times immediately tangible, at times not.

Peace!

Tigger

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 10 16:30:44 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA19040; Fri, 10 May 1996 16:30:44 -0700
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA19031; Fri, 10 May 1996 16:30:41 -0700
Received: from uclink2.berkeley.edu (uclink2.berkeley.edu [128.32.136.72]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.5/8.6.12) with ESMTP id QAA26043 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 10 May 1996 16:30:41 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from krok@localhost) by uclink2.berkeley.edu (8.7.5/8.6.12) id QAA18555; Fri, 10 May 1996 16:25:18 -0700
Date: Fri, 10 May 1996 16:25:17 -0700 (PDT)
From: Kyung Rok <krok@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Rave/Media Essay (Super Long)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9605101643.A10733-0100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Though perhaps better sent on a Tuesday instead of a Friday afternoon, 
this is about 1/4 of a cultural studies piece titled "Moral Panic, the 
Media and British Rave Culture."  Written by Sarah Thornton, the rest of 
this essay can be found in "Microphone fiends : Youth Music & Youth 
Culture / edited by Andrew Ross & Tricia Rose. Routledge, 1994.

I had some free time a while back and thought i'd scan this article in 
and then disseminate it, but I didn't because it would have taken way too 
long, and because of the slight ethical dilemma I had about sending the 
entire essay out without the permission of the writer, especially since 
this list is archived (mixed blessing if you ask me).  Though several 
words and characters were mistranslated, most of it is accurate and 
intelligible.  

Read it and make up your own mind.  -Rok.
___
The idea that authentic culture is somehow outside media and commerce is a 
resilient one. In its full-blown romantic form, the belief imagines that 
grass-roots cultures resist and struggle with a colonizing mass-mediated 
corporate world. At other times. the perspec- tive lurks between the 
lines, inconspicuously informing parameters of research. definitions of 
culture and judgments of value. Either way, scholars of youth and music 
culture are among the most tenacious holders of the idea. One explanation 
for this is undoubtedly that their studies reproduce the anti-mass-media 
discourses of the youth formations they study. While youth celebrate the 
"underground," academics venerate subcultures where one group denounces 
the "commercial," the other criticizes "hegemony": where one laments 
"selling out," the other theorizes "incorporation."
Every music scene has its own specific set of media relations. "Acid 
house. ' a dance club culture which, after sensational media coverage 
about drug use, mutated into ' rave a movement said to be bigger than 
punk and akin to the hippie revolution. offers a particularly revealing 
case. In exploring this case, this article finds no opposition between 
subcultures and the media, except for a dogged ideological one. It 
uncovers no pure origins or organic homologies of sound, style and 
ritual, nor does it vilify a vague monolith called "The media." Instead, 
it examines how various media are integral to youth's social and 
ideological formations. Micromedia like flyers and listings are means by 
which club organizers bring the crowd together; niche media like the 
music press construct as much as they document subcultures; while mass 
media like the tabloids develop as much as do youth movements. Contrary 
to youth discourses, then, subcultures do not germinate from
seed and grow by force of their own energy into mysterious movements to 
be belatedly ingested by the media. Rather, media are there and effective 
right from the start.  They are integral to the processes by which, in 
Bourdieu's terms, we "create groups
To understand the relations between youth subcultures and the media, one 
needs to pose and differentiate two questions. On the one hand, how do 
youth's subcultural dis-courses position the media? On the other hand are 
the media instrumental in the congregation of youth and the formation of 
subcultures? The two questions are entwined but distinct. Youth's 
"underground" ideologies infer a lot but understand little about cultural 
production. Their views of the media have other agendas to fill. They are 
a means by which youth imagine their own and other social groups, assert 
their distinctive character, and affirm that they are not just " 
attention spans " to be bought and sold by advertisers, nor faceless 
members of an undifferentiated mass.
Even the most political subcultures are also taste cultures. Given that 
the vast majority of British youth subcultures, past and present, do not 
espouse overt political projects, nor even constitute "subcultures" in 
more stable sociological senses of the term issues of taste and 
distinction deserve attention. Rather than depoliticizing youth 
subcultures, this move actually gives fuller representation to the 
complex and not always progressive politics of popular culture. While 
difference is not necessarily resistant, it is always caught up in 
systems of distinction.
Similarly, the second question about how the media do not just represent, 
but mediate within, subculture can only be fully understood in relation 
to subcultural ideologies. For !he positioning of various media 
outletsQprime-time chart shows versus late-night narrowcasts, BBC versus 
pirate radio, the music press versus the fanzines, flyers versus 
magazinesQas well as discourses about "hipness," "selling out" and "moral 
panic," are crucial to the ways young people receive these media and, 
consequently, to the ways that media shape subcultures.

The "Subcultural Capitals" of the "Underground"

The term "underground" is the expression by which clubbers refer to 
things subcultural. ,lore than fashionable or trendy, underground sounds 
and styles are "authentic," and pitted against the mass-produced and 
mass-consumed. Underqrounds denote exclusive worlds whose main point is 
not elitism. but whose parameters often relate to particular crowds. They 
delight in parental incomprehension, negative newspaper coverage and that 
best blessing in disguise, the BBC ban. More than anything else, then, 
undergrounds define themselves against the mass media.
Undergrounds are nebulous constructions;4 their crowds shun definitive 
social categorization. Mostly they are said to be " mixed " and, although 
the subcultural discourses cross lines of class, race and sexuality, the 
people who hold these ideas are less likely to
physically traverse the relevant thresholds.5 Generally, underground 
crowds are attached to sounds. As one label manager put it: "There are 
records out there that are more radical and, at this moment, have a more 
radical audienceQa smaller, more selective audienceQ but the sounds in 
that area will be the next generation of sounds we're all used to.... 
That's what I mean by underground."6Undergrounds define themselves most 
clearly by what they're notQthat is "main stream." Although there is 
variation, the oft-repeated expression by which they refer to mainstream 
clubs is that these are places where "Sharon and Tracy dance around their 
handbags." This mainstream is decried as passive, indiscriminate and 
uncommitted to dance culture; it is ridiculed for its " herd instinct" 
and " bandwagon mentality. " Undoubtedly
a residual version of the mass, this mainstream points to the relevance 
of Andreas Huyssen's "mass culture as woman" thesis. but here the 
traditional divide between virile high art and feminized low 
entertainment is replayed within popular culture itself.7
Though the discourses of the underground are anti-mass culture, one 
should not confuse them with those of the art world. Certainly. both 
criticize mass culture for being derivative, \/e commercial, shallow and 
femme. But they differ insofar as subcultures romanticize "the street" 
and the crowd, not artists' studios and individual genius. Moreover, 
rather than the dreaded "trickle down," the problem for underground 
subculture is popularization by a gushing up to the mainstream. These 
metaphors are not arbitrary, for they betray a sense of social place. 
Subcultural discourses implicitly give alternative interpretations and 
values to young people's, particularly young men's, subordinate status; 
they reread the social world.
The main currency of the underground might be called "subcultural 
capital." Pierre Bourdieu's distinction model, from which the term is 
borrowed and amended, describes a total system which concentrates on the 
tastes of the middle-aged.8 Perhaps more than gender, race or ethnicity, 
age differences and aging in time throw a spanner into the workings of 
class-based distinctions.9 This may be because youth. whatever their 
class enjoy a momentary reprieve from "necessity."'! In other words, 
youth are exempt from adult commitments to the accumulation of economic 
capital. They temporarily enjoy what Bourdieu argues is normally reserved 
for the bourgeoisie; that is, a "taste of liberty or luxury. "
Subcultural capital can be accumulated, but not over a lifetime. It is a 
capital with built in obsolescence, which either gets converted into 
cultural capital proper (for example jazz was turned into " Ph.D. music 
)l ~ or depreciates in subcultural value (sometimes not without a fight; 
for example, Bob Dylan). Of course, "adult" cultural capital is also 
subject to obsolescence, but it isn't built in, so to speak. Bourdieu 
characterizes the avant-garde as the young bourgeois producing knowledges 
that eventually become ' classic.  But subcultural capital is different 
from this nascent cultural capital, insofar as its main antagonist is not 
established art culture but mass culture, and graduating up is not its 
standard route Subcultural capital deteriorates with age and in this way, 
maintains its position as prerogative of the young.                    
	As a result, clubber subcultural capital is not as class-bound as 
cultural capltal After age, the social difference along which it aligns 
most systematically is, in fact, gender.  Girls and women often opt out 
of the game of "hipness," refusing to compete. and conceding

___

>Well, yeah, talk is cheap...anyway, I like a balance between dancing (and
>all that includes, which I'm still discovering) and socializing, with old
>friends and new.  If I spent all my time dancing, I wouldn't meet anyone,
>but if I didn't dance at all, I'd be denying myself the experience.  Do ya

>raves; that's mine, for now.  Thanks, Jim, and thanks to everyone who

Yeah, I tend to agree on that one.  I like my raves to be a good mix of
dancing *and* socializing with my friends.  If I spend the whole time
hanging in the chill room talking with people, I really feel like I missed
out on an important aspect of the party, & the evening feels incomplete.
However, the only parties that I dance 100% of the time are the ones that
are totally lacking in friendly people & vibe.  The individuals that attend
a party are also very important to me, I love all you guys & I wanna talk to
ya upon occasion! :)  So, like in almost every other aspect of my life I can
think of, it is never 100% one way or the other, the very best raves really
consist of a good healthy mix of dancing my ass off *and* socializing in the
chill room.  The only time you'll see me doing just one is if the party
entirely lacks the other, i.e. the music's great but no vibe- I'll be on the
dance floor the whole time; the music sucks but the vibe rages- I'll be in
the chill area the whole time.  I love that feeling of being on the dance
floor & making eye contact with some other raging dancer & neither of you
needs to talk, you both just *know*! :)  But I just love those nifty chill
room encounters too.

See y'alls on the dance floor/chill room!


Love,
Shawna

SteveOSac@aol.com wrote:
>First off, I hope there aren't any Beavises out there that are going to try
>to make e from these directions, they seem vague and incomplete.  I'm not
>opposed to home chemistry, just be smart.

Did we get the same message?  I didn't do more than glance at it, because 
I have the book it was taken from, but I think the instructions were 
quite clear.  But I didn't get X info (though it's in the book), just the 
MDOH that you mention from the "second half".  In any case, it's still a 
very good idea for anyone not experienced in organic synthesis to just 
forget about it.  Just because the instructions are clear and detailed 
doesn't mean that they're simple, and you probably can't get the 
ingredients anyway.

>Secondly, Thanks for this info THX, it seems very interesting especially the
>second half regarding MDOH. I however, have very poor comprehension quality
>when the reading gets that technical.  Is there anyone out there can that can
>interpret the general gist of that document.  If I am understanding correctly
>MDOH is a new sythesetic similar to MDA...

The info is excerpted from a book called PIKHAL, a pseudo-autobiography 
of Alexander Shulgin.  Shulgin is a chemist who has spent the past twenty 
or thirty years researching the chemistry underlying human 
psychopharmacology, with emphasis on the phenethylamine family of 
compounds to which X, mescaline, and the other psychedelic amphetamines 
belong.  The first part of the book is the story, describing his life and 
how he came to pursue these studies, while the second gives a synopsis of 
his results in exploring the phenethylamine family.  He presents several 
hundred compounds, including X, mescaline, 2CB (bromomescaline), and STP, 
in the format given here for MDOH, with syntheses and results of human 
experimentation.  Most of these compounds are variations on a theme 
created by systematic structural modification of natural or already-known 
phenethylamines.  Most are not, based on his experimentation, 
psychopharmacologically interesting.

I gather the book is available in a WWW version.

anarch@scruznet.com

On Fri, 10 May 1996, Eric P. Peterson wrote:

> >Others have said it better so I will be brief: it is on the dance floor
> >that we all come together in unity, it is on the dance floor where the
> >vibe get created, it is on the dance floor where the really important
> >stuff happens. So SHUT UP AND DANCE! ;-)

> >Peace,
> >Jim
> 
> Well, yeah, talk is cheap...anyway, I like a balance between dancing (and
> all that includes, which I'm still discovering) and socializing, with old
> friends and new.  If I spent all my time dancing, I wouldn't meet anyone,
> but if I didn't dance at all, I'd be denying myself the experience.  Do ya
> see where I'm coming from?  Everyone has a slightly different approach to
> raves; that's mine, for now.  Thanks, Jim, and thanks to everyone who
> shared their insights!
> 
> Dancin' shoes on,
> 
> - E

And if that ain't enough,
 Hi! As some of you may recall I do live ambience of the atmosphere 
variety. That is with very few, if any, beats. My goal is to create the 
complimentry opposite to the kinetic energy of the dance floor(s). This 
is done in an effort to create foward motion through balance of 
energy(s). Not many people can dance for 8- 12 hours straight ;) through 
and rest and refreshments are a good thing. Also it is nice to say hi to 
those you wish to. A calm chill room provides this kind of a space and 
ideally tries to help support the vibe from the other side.
 In some ways this is an easier job than the dance DJ's as you are not 
locked into a beat groove. But in some ways it is harder to maintain an 
interesting sound without beats and one must really stretch that creative 
muscle in order to keep up with those beats. Not to mention that the 
space should be cozy, safe and nice for folks to relax and catch their 
breath (or a snooze).
 Just some change.


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams


                       ( what was that masked sound? )

Rio de janeiro, Brazil
>
>Yes, the thought of what the rest of the world must think of Americans
>frightens me.  If they look at the mass media of any indication...it's
>totally repulsive, that's why I and everyone I know detests television.  We
>only export the worst of pop culture.  Yeah, Baywatch,  HardCopy and the
>Enquirer - that's what it means to be American!

The TV and american cinema kinda brings to the third world countries this idea of "american way of life", which i do not consider very valid. There are many good things about America, like more freedom of speech, but there are also many bad things such as commercialism, rascism towards latins, asians, blacks, indians ( sorry, I am not P.C.), foreigners in general, when they come from the 3rd. world... i experienced it even in the EAst Coast rave scene.

But the communism failed, and we are now in the rise of an even fiercer capitalism, with corporations running the countries' minds, decisions and funds. The whole world is now seen as markets, not countries...who cares if China has no human rights, when they have $$$ to buy our goods???"

>
>And America's and the First World's unchecked consumerism is causing mass
>problems for the rest of the world (environment, poverty, resources).  It
>can't go on for much longer.  Advertising is just a symptom of a
>consumerist mind-set (and the tyranny of capitalism) -- a mind-set that I
>hope is changing before we kill the earth and most of her inhabitants.

You are right. Although we are surely a minimal voice in the middle of this sea of "capitalism slaves", in my case I can only hope to have a few hours of fun, dancing and interacting ith people, without even bothering with the way media talks about raves.   ( in here, it is considered a place for crackheads and crusties )

Dear Friends & Family,

My computer tells me that on Wed, 8 May 1996, SDream shared:

> >Would anyone think it a good idea to respond to that HardCopy segment
> >formally?
> 
> Well, I didn't find a URL for Hard Copy, but I did find the following, which 
> lists URLs for just about any TV station that has a web page of any kind.  
> Just FYI...
> 
> http://www.tvnet.com/

	Anybody who would like to tape (or see) Hard Copy's piece on 
raves may call me at (415) 626-3036.
	After watching (and taping) this complete piece of trash, I 
called KRON TV Channel 4, which aired the segment.  KRON did not produce 
the Hard Copy segment, but they share responsibility for misinforming the 
public and prejudicing them against raves and ravers.
	After a couple tries, I got the number for Al Holzer, their Vice 
President of news and programming.  You'll probably just get his 
secretary, but I hope she gets lots of messages to deliver for him.
	His number is 561-8768.  Use it!  
	I also taked to Pat Law, Channel 4's Viewer Liaison.  She told me 
that the night previous to the Hard Copy broadcast, a mere "6 or 7" 
complaints to the station resulted in them *pulling from the air* a Jack 
In The Box commercial.  
	This shows that if we can generate a significant number of 
critical calls on Hard Copy, it will have a real impact on decisions at KRON.

	But don't stop at calling Channel 4.  Pat told me that Hard Copy 
is produced by Paramount.  Paramount also produces Entertainment Tonight, 
which has a toll-free number, (800) 421-0476.  You can call this number 
and ask to be transfered to the producers of Hard Copy, and save yourself 
the charges of calling them direct at (213) 956-5808.
	I was told by the folks at Hard Copy that the "Desert Rave" segment 
of Wednesday's Hard Copy was produced by a Frank Feldinger.  His answering 
machine says to leave him a message and he'll return your call.  So far 
he has not returned mine, but I plan to be persistant.  8)
	
	I think it is important that we mobilize effectively against this 
type of anti-rave slander.  We are *not* powerless to affect media 
coverage of our scene.  Speaking up loudly and sharply gets the message 
across.
	I want them to understand that a pack of lies, stereotypes, and 
dangerously wrong images like Hard Copy broadcast about us is the 
equivalent of them doing a segment on black welfare mothers eating 
watermelons and fried chicken, shooting crack, and getting pregnant; i.e. 
being prejudiced against our scene is as wrong as being racist.
	This understanding on the part of the media will only evolve to 
the extent that we get involved and make ourselves heard.
	
Let's make some noise!

				<<< Starchild >>>

>>>>> COULD SOMEONE WHO HAS THE ADDRESSES OF THE OTHER REGIONAL RAVE 
LISTS FORWARD THIS AND MY PREVIOUS MESSAGE ABOUT HOW TO GET IN TOUCH WITH

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Dear Friends & Family,

My computer tells me that on Thu, 9 May 1996, Be 99 shared:

> >>Would anyone think it a good idea to respond to that HardCopy segment
> >>formally?
> well, before anyone goes off half-baked, i think we should compose a letter
> as a whole.
> 
> points to be included could be:
> 
> -refution (is that a word?) of the alcohol and nitrous issue.
> -an explaination of the principals behind raving.
> -an explaination of the effects of 'common' rave drugs and why they are used
> -how raving has positive effects on life outside raving, and why would they
> want to    destroy something positive with negative press?
> -responsibility of the media
> -lots more. ideas?

	The following are a few of the things about the segment that 
might be mentioned.  The quoted material is from the narrator, the 
material in brackets are my comments on what's wrong with what they said:

"the ultimate zoo for serious party animals"
[The "party animals" wording is slanderous and not in the spirit of raves 
at all.]

(we crashed the desert rave and got) "all the madness on tape"
[A nice way of saying they deceived their subjects about their purpose in 
filming.  Also, the word "madness" is highly judgmental.]

"besides dancing, they do lots and lots of alcohol (pause) and drugs"
[Alcohol *is* a drug. Also, undue focus on drugs, again.  And most raves 
do not feature much alcohol use.  No comparison is given to other scenes, 
such as clubs, bars, and concerts.]

"taken improperly it (nitrous oxide) can cause siezures, brain damage, 
and even death"
[Focuses on the negative effects of a drug without any balance or 
comparison to the risks of using legal substances.  No statistics are 
given of these occurences, compared to the overall number of users, which 
would probably show risks to be smaller than the TV spot would lead 
viewers to believe.]

(nitrous oxide seemed to be) "the drug of choice"
[Wrong.  Nitrous oxide is just more visible because of the balloons, and 
thus presents a more effective visual image for TV]

(the main attraction of desert raves is that they are) "far, far away 
from parents and police"
[this is just false.  In all my years raving, I've never heard anyone 
mention this as the main reason they were at a rave.  And many raves, 
sadly, have lots of police present.]

(mention of people passing out from nitrous)
[undue focus on drug use and its dangers]

(mention of person taking a halucinogenic drug and wandering away from 
the party) "They found his body two days later."
[again, focusing on drug use and its dangers]

"temperatures can drop to near freezing"
[contributes to making our parties seem dangerous]

"drug-addled crowds"
[more negative imagery of drugs]

"right back to the dancing, the drugs"
[another mention of drugs in a negative context]

"...last party animals staggering away"
[another offensive use of the term "party animals" in reference to ravers]

"they, and the desert, have a little time to heal before it starts all 
over again"
[implies that raves are damaging the desert environment.  If true, this 
needs to be put in context, i.e. compared to other human activity.  Also, 
the statement implies that people's bodies are being harmed, and need 
"healing" after a party.  The dancing *is* healing!]

(raves moved to the desert) "to escape the violence of urban raves, which 
have been plagued by gang shootings and deadly fires."
[This is false.  I've never heard those concerns cited as a reason for 
having an outdoor party.  Another negative assumption on the part of the 
producers.  And again, no context comparing "urban raves" to other 
late-night activities]

(dawn struggles over the horizon) "like a bloodshot eye"
[this distasteful metaphor reinforces the focus on drugs 
and their negative effects]

"dangerous fallout" (of rave parties) 
[this statement went along with the visual of someone climbing on some 
steep rocks, the word "fall" creating the image of danger from falling.  
Coincidental?  Maybe, but I doubt it.]

"the police say their biggest obstacle in shutting (rave parties) down is 
trying to find them."
[the premise of this statement is that they *should* be shut down.  No 
opposing view is given.]

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Other general critical points:

	In the whole segment, which lasted maybe five minutes, the only 
statement included that promoted a positive, responsible view of our 
scene was when a girl directing traffic (probably one of the promoters of 
the party they filmed) was asked why people couldn't park just anywhere 
and she said it was because of the need to protect the desert environment.
	There was the gratuitous sex element, with shots of attractive 
young women in bare midriffs dancing, which would be fine if presented in 
a positive way, but in the context of Hard Copy's coverage, it was 
obviously designed to say "raves are about drugs, underage sex, people 
getting hurt, destruction, and lack of control."
	No mention was made of adults being at the parties also, which is 
almost always the case.  I can't remember being at a party without people 
over 21, and in many cases a good number of people in their 30's and above.
	The one person in the segment who mentioned age was talking about 
just turning 18.  The narrator's references were to young people, 
partying without parental control, not responsible drivers, voters, and 
adults having fun in a positive, spiritual atmosphere.
	The word "spiritual" aired once, in a quote from a young female 
participant, but it was given no context or explanation -- the girl's 
quote was not made to seem credible to the audience.
	The word "celebration" also aired once, also with no supporting 
information.
	Generally, participants who were interviewed were either 
obviously high, or were talking about getting "loaded," "passing out," 
etc.  
	From my experience, this is not at all typical of a rave.  But I 
don't need to tell any of you that...

Peace, Love & Grooviness,
				<<< Starchild >>>

[ to sfraves list ]

 Some Thoughts On Bass Instinct -

 Great! Friendly! Roomy! No annoying eye-level strobe lights - heck, no
strobes! They did have a black light fixture. Little smoke , warm without 
being stifling. Free water and oranges , smart drinks for $3/2 drinks for $5.
If the "b.a.s.s. kru" do another event , I would recommend checking them out.

 I arrived at the site at around 11:30PM , after a ticketing delay at the
map point. Thad was spinning some excellent music , but the gathering crowd 
was shy about dancing. Some kind of threshold was broken sometime just after
Stareyes took over , and more folks moved into the dance area and started
twiching and stepping.

 For awhile , DJ Abstract joined Stareyes at another ( third? ) turntable
for some pairs mixing. Sounded good to me.

 My footwear experiment had mixed results. Many years ago I had bought a
pair of cowboy boots from a thrift store for a Halloween costume, and I
decided to try 'em on for the night! My toes were aching, but the smooth
leather soles gave me different move options on the smooth concrete floor
that the gripping type of soles athletic shoes have. Also , the hard high
heels were fun to balance on. 

 I don't know the trends in jungle/drum n' bass , but I haven't heard the
4/4 plus jungle mixes I heard last night. How common is this?  Techno/jungle
hybrid .

 It was nice to meet and re-meet some "new" SFRavers - Jess , Garbled 99 and
his friend Alec from Wash. DC, "Shroom" Alec, Leslie Ayers, a-French-guy-whose-
name-excapes-me-at-this-time, an-Asian-American-guy-whose-name-I-couldn't-hear-
over-the-music. I had to leave at around 2AM , so I didn't get to see if the
rumored appearence by Goldie happened or not - one of the other folks I listed
here will have to report!

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Subject: the something free story - long
To: Happy Ravers <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.88.9605112100.A3885-0100000@svpal>

dear family and friends,
off with a slow start, we made our way to the location of our party, 
skaggs island, in marin. we were in three seperate cars, each 
anticipating on arriving at different times. after my friend isac and i 
picked up a generator, we headed up to marin to meet up with Le Le, carl 
with some sound,water, and other stuff, jon carel w/ sound, and ethan. 
when i arrived, carl was at the spot already. but there was something 
more. apparently, some of the local kids decided to gather there and have 
a little drinking party. we think, hmm, alcohol a negative, but we'll see 
what we can do. with some acceptions, the kids were generally friendly or 
oblivious to what we wanted to do, ie. have a rave. some were even 
excited, and wanted to see what this "rave" stuff was about. so carl and 
i proceded to set up teh monitors, tables, and some torches for light. as 
some of the kids said, go ahead, set up, since everyones drinking they'll 
be out of your hair soon and leave in an hour or two. as were setting up, 
tho, the "attitude" factor was on a large upswing, and some began 
expressing their dilike of what we were doing, while most of the kids at 
this time still said dont worry theyre just drunk, keep setting up. so 
half of our stuff out of carls truck, one of the kids expressing their
dislike of us took one of our torches and broke it. from this point the 
situation turned real nasty. 	
	we decided it best to leave, and started loading everything 
back. some of them where now throwing rocks at carls truck, and a torch 
or two more got wrecked, as well as dents and scratches from said rocks, 
and a busted tail lite. so we sped out of there, carl took off to change 
something on teh vmail, while isac and i followed, then noticed jons van 
going to the site, turning around, we flagged him down, stopping some 
ways down teh road past the site. we explained what happened and went 
back for carl, flagging down another car going to the site, and luckily 
that was ethan. the three of us went back to where jon was. during all 
this Le Le had arrived, and carl came back as well. we thought about what 
to do, during which time the kids causing teh trouble walked over to 
cause more. with a unanomous decision to try the marina as another 
locale, we took of, but not before they had a chance to swing at our cars 
with something. they took out a back lite on isacs car. it was really sad 
that most of them were quite receptive to what we wanted to do, there wes 
just a handfull who wanted trouble.
	down to the marina everything went, and isac and i stayed behind 
at a cross roads to flag down ravers going to the site. after about an 
hour we left for teh marina as well, getting stuck in unbelivable back up 
on bay bridge, we got to marina at about 4.3o am. no one in sight. we 
called our vmail and found out the party was busted early on. we went to 
carls house to crash.
	basically, we want to express our appreciation for those who did 
want to come, and sincerely appologize if we got your hopes up for a 
party. we appreciate all of you who have come in teh past, and would like 
to say that we want to continue to do what weve been doing. hopefully 
things will go more smoothly in the future, and we look forward to seeing 
many of you! were planning a little something, and we'll keep ya posted. 
thankyou for listening. 
	
love,
the something crew

ps. i hope madness fucking rocks!

Dear Friends & Family,

	What Mark says about complaining to the advertisers being most 
effective is probably true.  I taped the segment on raves, but turned my TV 
off immediately thereafter.  Did anybody watch the whole program, or has 
watched previous or subsequent episodes of Hard Copy, to know who these 
advertisers may be?
	My girlfriend Chikako also said there was a phone number 
displayed at the end of the show that you could call to reach Hard Copy, 
but she didn't get a chance to write it down.  I'm wondering if this is 
a better way to reach the people responsible than by calling 
Entertainment Tonight's 800 number... if ET gets a bunch of calls from 
people wanting Hard Copy (which I hope they do!), they may get fed up and 
stop transferring people.
	If anyone got the number from the show, could you post it?  Thanks...

Much love,
				<<< Starchild >>>


On 10 May 1996, Mark Camp* wrote:

>          Reply to:   RE>Hard Copy and the Nature of Mass Media
> 
> Rather than complaining to Hard Copy, maybe complaining directly to the
> advertisers would be a better idea.  If the advertisers become aware of the
> publics outrage over the programs that they buy time on, maybe the next time a
> story like this comes around, they wont want to advertise.
> 
> just a thought......
> 
> -M
> 
> --------------------------------------
> Date: 5/9/96 5:54 PM
> To: Mark Camp*
> From: Nancy
> 
> Michael wrote:
> 
> > Before wasting time in a reply to Hardcopy you might consider Do they
> >even care ?  I suspect that a show like that would only care that you
> >watched at all - NOT whether you agree/disagree.... merely that they are
> >getting through . Their goal is not to inform with TRUTH as much as it is
> >to inform with entertainment ( truth is not really their objective )...
> 
> 
> I agree, but I think that their goal is not to inform at all, but to ensure
> an audience FOR THE COMMERCIALS.  Size of audience share sets the price the
> show can charge for commercial time - the PROFIT behind this show.
> Therefore, they sensationalize and "entertain" and distort and vulgarize as
> much as possible to appeal to the widest amount of people (oops, I mean
> "consumers").
> 
> Most television shows are merely the padding around the true purpose of
> commercial television - agressive advertisement for you to buy, buy, buy.
> Their mind-numbing stupidity (i.e. sit-coms) and their ridiculous
> sensationalizing (i.e. tabloid "news" shows) create a state of mind in the
> viewer that ensure absolute receptivity, NOT conducive to analytical
> thought -- the perfect mind-set to unthinkingly absorb the subliminal/overt
> messages of the commercials.  Therefore, it would be counter-productive for
> a medium intent on creating mindless consuming automatons to encourage
> open-mindedness and thinking for our selves.
> 
> The job of the Hard Copy crew is to scour real life for any situation that
> could possible be exploited.  And illegal, all-night parties with
> teen-agers and drugs is PUUURRFECT for that.  It's "sexy!" (in advertising
> lingo).
> 
> A public  retraction is totally impossible.  Any information would just be
> for the benefit of the Hard Copy crew, who may or may not care - either
> way, it doesn't change the nature of their job, which is to sensationalize,
> which brings in the viewers, who are primed for a barrage of advertising.
> 
> The real issues are addressing why America eats up these shows, how to
> resist excessive consumerism,  how to reform the mass media, and making
> sure those in our own lives hear from us the real story.
> 
> But, it was good for a laugh.  :P
> 
> Back to studying!

X-Sender: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Unverified)
Message-Id: <v02120d07adbc332d443f@[128.32.205.204]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
X-mailer: Eudora 2.1.2
Date: Sun, 12 May 1996 16:51:46 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (michal migurski)
Subject: madness (opinion? review? you decide!)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

All I can say is,

   -> madness went off <-

This was undoubtedly one of the best parties I've ever attended... nice
location, handy outside table n' chair area (could talk to people without
having to holler), beautiful decorations, incredible visuals, good chill
space, cheap ticket, short porto-pottie line and

FREE WATER.

=)

Got there around 11:30, Jon Santos was in the middle of spinning a great
set. Hung out, danced, looked around for people I know. Met some new folks.
etc, etc.

Don't remember what time Ethan came on, but everyone started cheering and
he just *ripped shit up.* I went fucking crazy dancing right from the
beginning, but soon fatigue reduced me to standing in one spot and just
sorta bumping along to the tunes... Around the middle of his set there wa
this extended 20 minute block with areally simple, almost unchanging beat.
Incredible. I've never heard so much in such simple music... people (myself
included) were screaming and cheering and everyone was totally into it. Did
I hear some JUNGLE making its way into and Ethan set? wow.

Later, at about 2 or 3am, Pete Lazonby (sp?) started his set... At first I
wasn't too impressed because the beats were really irregular and hard to
dance to. Like Aphex Twin doing trance or something. I was having problems
even listening to it, it was so "foreign" to me. But later, it got more and
more abstract and "unmusical," and I found myself enjoying it more. Somehow
this rolling, hardcore ambient found its way into my mind and I got totally
into it. Oh yeah... this guy was spinning from CDs! I've never seen a setup
like his. I didn't even know it was possible to beatmatch CDs, but he had
some sort of special CD decks that had pitch control and stuff.

I left around 4-ish, feeling great. Altogether a *perfect* party... thanks
to all the FnF folks and
     HAPPY BIRTHDAY Ethan and Wayne.
(who else had birthdays? weren't there 4 people who had birthdays this week?)

Hello to all the SFR people I ran into there...
Wayne, Ethan, Mike, the other Mike (new guy), Brian, Shawna, Leslie (thanks
again for the ride!), Adam (and friends), Sarah, Todd, Jon, Jonathan, Black
Adder, Claire, and anyone whose name I might have forgotten.

-m.

On Sun, 12 May 1996, JOSHUA MICHAEL ABERANT (i.e. Sarah) wrote:
> alex spun after pete and he tore the place up!!!! yes- the party was PHAT 
> to the very last little drop. there weren't too many of us left by the 
> end, but we sure were having fun. i'm not sure exactly what time it ended...
> pretty late.

I think it was Joe Rice who finally finished the night (until 7:30am!)... 
The music just seemed to get better and better, although at the end it
really seemed like a marathon!  ;)  It was pretty surreal when they
started passing out danishes and orange juice to the folks still dancing
around 6:30!  People munching, dancing, smiling, .... :)  Many kudos for
the abundant free water and friendly management. The owner even came out
and danced with us in the wee hours! 

I was a little confused by Peter Lazonby's beats, since for a while it
seemed (to me) to be a pretty slow, grating, and un-danceable, although
pretty interesting to just listen to. Someone told me that this is the
only thing people dance to in England, which I found implausible. 
Unfortunately, I think I lot of people left instead of waiting it out,
since the dance-factor improved a lot afterwards.. 

Madness was just one big happy wacky smile-fest for me.  Hopefully we'll
see more events in this space soon... it was perfect!  The only thing I
could've asked for were more black lights, since I brought some
fluorescent markers.  

:)
paul
(smiley)

Well I really never have given a review before, I don't plan on to. because
usually most of the events I've gone to have been great and words wouldn't
do it justice. Well Madness went beyond that. I have hit a new level. I can
not believe how much love and energy I felt at Madness. Thank you to

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May 13 01:53:57 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id BAA13933; Mon, 13 May 1996 01:53:57 -0700
Received: from cats.ucsc.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id BAA13923; Mon, 13 May 1996 01:53:54 -0700
Received: from ese.UCSC.EDU by cats.ucsc.edu with SMTP
	id BAA26534; Mon, 13 May 1996 01:53:54 -0700
Received: by ese.UCSC.EDU (8.6.13/4.7) id BAA24879; Mon, 13 May 1996 01:53:53 -0700
Date: Mon, 13 May 1996 01:53:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: Randy C Cone <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Harmony at the Beach (long)
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9605130158.A23303-0100000@ese.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi all!

 Well, Harmony did it again! This phatness went down at good ol' Bonny 
Doone Beach (man, how many parties HAS that beach seen?!?). This was my 
first party out since I started posting at sfraves. I like to thank each 
and every one of you who have shared a bit of themselves with us here at 
sfraves. I was able to see so many more things than I have ever 
seen before at a rave, in part due to everyone's input right here!
 
 Things started a little late (3:30pm) but it was well worth the wait. 
The sound system was absolutely incredible and was placed in a natural 
accoustic bowl (of the beach) for a perfect symbosis of technology and 
enviroment. I walked to the other side of the beach and could still hear 
everything cleary and feel the bass :) Yet right in front of the DJ 
coffin and on the main dance circle you could still talk to people. NICE!
 I'm sorry for being lousy with DJ names but there were four with # 3 
being Trent and closing out our very own Gregory Sandler. I believe DJ 
Dan was first? And I didn't catch the name of the # 2 DJ.
 All the music was first rate, although I was wondering for moments ;) 
The biggest problem was the wind which absolutely howled (especially on 
the train tracks) but was tolerable on the dance floor. Just before 
sunset the wind died and the tempature was just right. We eventually 
stopped about 8:30 - 9:00 pm (?).

 I managed to get some videotape of the event on s-vhs which I may use 
for a class soon or to work on that anti-H.Copy documentary. I may base 
that upon my Raves as a Rite of Passage essay I wrote. Lots of amazing 
shots of people dancing and smilin' and playin'. :) Some nice sunset 
shots too.

 Recieved a wide variety of response to my videotaping. From worshipful 
to directly threatening (!?!) Intersting to say the least.

 Pleasure to meet so many smiling folks! I met Starchild, Stacey, Tracey 
Dmitry(?), Clinch, remet with Lee (from Harmony) and Jen and some really 
tall cool smiley honcho whose name escapes me. And of course seeing Greg 
made me smile =) Also big hugs to DJ Ceasor!!!!!! (hope i spelt that right)

 I danced, got a little sunburn and had a great time  :) I felt so good 
when I got home  ( especially after the shower ;) ).


 Thank you Harmony!!


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams


                             ( peace on earth )
                                    /
                              -=*=-/
                                *

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May 13 03:45:08 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id DAA28095; Mon, 13 May 1996 03:45:08 -0700
Received: from mh1.well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id DAA27874; Mon, 13 May 1996 03:44:58 -0700
Received: from well.com (phred@well.com [206.15.64.10]) by mh1.well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with ESMTP id DAA00801; Mon, 13 May 1996 03:44:57 -0700
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id DAA22088; Mon, 13 May 1996 03:44:56 -0700
Date: Mon, 13 May 1996 03:44:56 -0700
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.com>
Message-Id: <199605131044.DAA22088@well.com>
To: nw-raves@hyperreal.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: a couple of weekends worth . . .
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Sorta dropped the ball on saying anything about last weekend.

First I should mention Susie's most excellent birthday party, where
the apple and pear cider were definitely better than my mixing :)
I missed Harmony as a result but had a real good time anyway,
especially my periodic geekfest with Laura, one of the chief geeks
at Infogeek, I mean Infoseek :)

Last Saturday was the sfraves picnic, about which nuff said except
the weather was awesome and so was the music and the company.  

I went to Down to Earth, the Pacific/Sunset party, on Saturday night,
in a very interesting gallery/performance art place at 21st and Mission.
There is another party there next week, I think (different organizers).
I didn't have a chance to talk with Polliwog about it since she was
spinning at the time :)  but I gather she is involved with this space
on an ongoing basis.  John Howard was down in the basement playing
really cool jazzy stuff, a real treat for me at 3 am instead of the
usual bang-yer-noggin stuff.  I stuck around for some of Galen's set
and then went to Wicked, but it just didn't do anything for me so
I went home a bit early.

Sunday afternoon was my first Sunset of the year, and fine one, if a
bit on the chilly side.  Alex really impressed me and managed to keep
everything going despite the fact he was playing (techno) at sunset!

Sunday night was like a flashback to my raving past, circa 1992.  Three
places, two and a half misses.  I got to 1190 Folsom (ok, 683 Clementina
since you have to go in the back door) after midnight, after the Ameba
crew had already cleared out.  This was for the Sci Fi Club, where
Brenda and I had a memorable evening a few weeks back.  But this time,
it was Not Happening -- about 20 people in the dance room listlessly
shuffling to the usual hard trance stuff, and five people in the bar --
two DJs, a bartender, another customer and me.  I drank a beer and split.
I missed the Sub Base party down at 290 Howard by a short bit, by the
time I got there it was already closed down.  They had a nice flyer,
has anyone been since?  Finally, since I was nearby, I dropped into Spundae.
I really don't care for the space or the crowd, but James Christian from
NYC, whose records I like quite a bit, was playing so I had a chance to
check him out.  Standard NY club/hard house, nothing spectacular.  I did
have a chance to meet Peter, one of the co-promoters of Spundae.  They're
quite busy now -- doing Nikita on Friday at 1015, Spundae on you-know-when,
and out of town events on Saturday, the first of which was here in Portland
last night.

Monday I shopped for records and found excellent jungle/drum + bass at
Zebra in the lower Haight.  Definitely check them out.  Tweekin continues
to please me with their broad and deep house selection, and they're adding
more techno and jungle as well.  I heard (and passed) on both new albums
by Underworld and Orbital.  Finally checked back in at Ameba and spun a
bit before heading out of town.  Got my cool-as-you-like Tribal Future
tickets, get yers soon!

This past weekend was a bit more restricted as I have a big work project
I'm wrapping up.  But we did our first Portland outdoor event this year,
organized by Jeremy.  This was at a beautiful spot right on the Columbia
River, across from about NE 15th in Portland.  It drizzled but never got
too wet.  Toonz by Cory West, Jeff (who brought out a fine speaker system),
yrs trly and Jeremy, whose was unfortunately shut down due to the generator
running out of gas :-)  I played both LTJ Bukem's "Rain Fall" and Hardkiss'
"River and Rain" in honor of the humidity :)  About 40 people showed up,
many from Seattle, and despite the weather it was a nice way to start up.
Jeremy's got one a month scheduled at various Vancouver area locations
through the summer.  

Last night, Spundae brought their road show to Portland.  Lots of
production,
lasers, big sound, two full rooms of stuff, at Roseland.  I mostly stayed
in the main room where Carlos kicked off a big charge and led into a nearly
three-hour set by the Deep Dish guys, Dubfire and Sharam, who traded off
three-and-three for the entire set.  They spun very well though not like
DJs do, more like record producers do (which they are).  Lots of test
pressings, not much continuity from track to track but lots of excellent
ones.  Vocals, hard house, tracky stuff all mixed together.  Carlos and
Brenda and I had a good time funking out bigtime to some of the tunes
early in the set.  

Very little vibe of any note, but the crowd was relatively relaxed.  I saw
one of the local promoters breaking up a big circle early in the Deep Dish
set.  A half a dozen guys with satin jacket emblazoned with their Breaks
Crew name showed up, one even had a crash helmet on his head.  I guess
they were determined to be the show.  The promoter had other ideas.  He
told them off, they grumbled a bunch and then melted.  This thing about
ravers and circle dancers is like the mods and rockers.  It's a culture
clash that won't go away.  It'll be interesting to see how this progresses.

The Spundae party here is the wave (rave) of the future, I think.  Say
goodbye to warehouse parties.  I haven't been to a one in Portland in
years that really has had much going for it.  Occasional sets -- DRC
a couple of weeks ago, Emma last fall, Derrick Carter's awesome three-deck
mix, Garth a way long time ago -- stand out for me, but I've never had a
*good* time at one of these.  Spundae had a bit more of an age mix and
clearly these big-production affairs in club spaces are where things are
going.  We are about to witness the Americanization of the UK club scene,
and this is the precursor.  Spundae is starting down the path of the
superclub model, where they build up a name, a local crowd, bring in
the big name DJs, and then starting planting their operation all around
the country.  I wish Spundae well but their concept and their crowd are
not what I got into all this for, although I certainly enjoyed the music
last night.  

For $16, everyone got a good deal at Spundae, but I still prefer to haul
equipment across the sand and play outside . . .

phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May 13 08:30:53 1996
