Hmm, I should have listnened to my intuition from my burnout phase that I 
had mentioned last week.  I feel like the black sheep on this one.

I didn't have that good a time at Madness as I do at most of the other 
raves I've attended.  The crowd was just too weird for me.  Don't ask me 
what I mean by that - for I can't put my finger on it, it's just how I 
felt (and others, too from whom I talked to.) Don't get me wrong, it was 
a good vibe, just a really freaky weird vibe.  There was a point 
when I was actually thinking to myself "people in here are cheering too 
loud - I can't even hear the music!"  I guess I wasn't in the right 
mindframe all night long, cause that has never happeded to me before - 
then again, I've always been able to hear the music ove rthe cheering - 
and that place was almost hurtful it was so loud.

Sorry I didn't geta chance to meet and talk to new sfravers.  I just 
wasn't into it that night - I wasn't feeling very social and would not 
want to have brought any of you down.  I did love the space and the 
decorations - especially the big tent on that ledge and the colorful 
poster nearest the bathroom.

I probably won't go out again til Tribal Future - I think Madness was a 
loud and clear message that I need some time off from raving. 

love,
Amy

Mad was extremely energetic.  When Ethan was spinning people were practically
climbing the walls.  Big industrial/goth turnout for a rave.  Around
4am the music got very, um, "experimental".... dramtically changing the
vibe on the dance floor.  It is very difficult to beat-match CDs at 
+160bpms... as was evident from that mix.  Detroit sound sweeping
sf?  boom boom boom boom boom boom.  I miss sound with some funk and house 
influence.  

Saw lots of silly stuff there, making it a particularly entertaining evening.

-troy

Subject: Bass Instinct, Harmony Beach Party
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk


	Wiissshhh... Another not-so-bad week-end! :-)

	It all began on Friday night; once spotted the location for _Bass
	Instinct_ (a little confusion gave me the location before everyone
	else), I go there to listen to that Drum & Bass stuff, and meet
	friendly SFRavers, by order of appearance: Larry, Jess, E, Brendan,
	Erik, Albert, Leslie, Kirsten's very nice friend, and many others...

	Some comments about BI: place ok but not really tremendous, friendly
	people, sound system correct and lights... well... only one black
	light, some people like that but I usually prefer something more
	elaborate (e.g. last BP was perfect: lazer, shining stuff, etc.
	-- but everything was perfect at _Beautiful People_, so...)
	Overall, the music at BI was good but sometimes a little, mmh,
	choppy. Even Jess, awarded Jungle Dance Queen of the Year, and in spite
	of her provoking statements ;-), seemed to have problems getting
	into the music,	so we decided to take off, direction _Something Free_.
	Oops. This was definitely an error, as you might have guessed from
	previous posts; we spent one hour and a half on the Bay Bridge,
	stuck into the traffic, to finally land to the Berkeley Marina,
	in the middle of nowhere: no sound, no people, no party :-(
	*Urgh*.	After minor adventures, we went back home a little
	disappointed.

	But full of energy for the Harmony beach party on Sunday!
	The location was really great: a kind of natural cirque,
	with the waves crashing far away, plenty of room for as many 
	people as possible, beautiful weather, *perfect* sound...
	Of course, as any beach party, it was better than anything else:
	people were dancing friendly everywhere, you could have a walk near
	the sea or climb the rocks... So cool!
	I love that, jumping in the sand, feeling the beat in your feet,
	lay down in the sun, chewing the sand friendly people throw at
	you (just joking, it was quite windy). I also met John who is a real
	cool dude!
	Much respect to the Harmony crew! I tried to give as much help as
	possible, but they deserve my deepest congratulations!
	Encore ! ;-)

						Renaud


Very soon: a comparison between the Techno scene in SF and on the
French Riviera.

Hi everyone-
Well I missed Madness and everything else this weekend because I have 
been busy 
pretending to be a responsible adult... therefore I was glad for the 
opportunity 
to go to the beach for a while and blow off some steam!

We arrived around 4 pm and the weather was really nice, just a bit windy. 
I found
that if I was sitting down the sand would blow into my eyes, so... 
perfect excuse
to dance. I danced pretty solidly for 3 hours, but dancing on the sand is 
like being
on some kind of a hellish Stairmaster, boy are my legs tired today! The 
music was
great, I don't know who was spinning when because I am just krazy & mixed 
up.
There were lots of smiles and happy faces from everyone.

I didn't meet too many sfravers, just a few. I guess I was pretty 
absorbed in 
what I was doing. :-) For those of you who don't know me, I was wearing a 
black
bikini top, shorts and (sometimes) a Fukengruven t-shirt. There, now you 
can say
a post dated hi!

We left around 7 pm, ran amok on the beach picking up trash, including 
lots of
balloons... my public service announcement for today: Give a hoot, don't 
pollute!
Balloons are not biodegradable. Sorry if this is too PC for you 
litterbugs...

It looks like I may not see anyone until Tribal Future, so take care and 
be good.
And thank U Harmony for coming through again for us. Can't wait 'till 
your next party.

Luv, 
Woodsy Owl

I'm not a usual reviewer but the party that was Madness needs to be exulted!

There was not a thing to complain about and everything to rave about! The space
the music, the people, the candies...all perfect! I have never felt quite so
fulfilled. This is a strange feeling for me because I always want more tunes 
and, body permitting, more dancing. This was THE best rave I have checked out
in the Bay Area so far...

Most memorable image: At around 7am orange juice and danishes were brought out!The few of us still dancing stopped very briefly to take a drink and then pick
up some food to have while dancing. I looked around and people were tapping outthe beat with their danishes. For some reason I found this incredibly cute. No
time to stop moving so we'll make our food dance too!

Thanks Paul, Sarah, Jeff, John, Adam and Philip for the energy and near 8hrs of
groovin'. plus Big O and James for the Ben Gay.

Huge thanks and Happy Birthdays to the crew from Madness. I think you guys made
my month! Let's see it happen again!

luv Sarah

I'll second everything Renaud said about the weekend.  We certainly did go
through a miserable bridge commute, and in Berkeley found Nothing Free.  I
was glad that we rescued Moshe and his friend there, though, as they had
even worse luck that night.
The vibe at Bass Instinct was harder than what I'm used to, but was
interesting.  It also took a while to find the groove in jungle, but it was
fun when I did.  Great to see some friends there; it was amusing/mildly
annoying to have many people come up to me asking if I had this or that,
but not bad...
The beach party was "all that," as JSL might say.  Friendly, playful people
(TONS of friends at this one; thanks to the beautiful gal who came over and
tweaked my toes as stretched out on the sand to watch the dancers for a
while!), outstanding music (I haven't heard Greg spin in ages, and
thoroughly enjoyed his set), and *aw, shucks* another kiss from Laurie
(sp?), the tongue-pierced gal who kissed me at BP (my head's still in the
clouds) :)
Everyone there made the party what it was.  It was so cool to see some
mothers out there with their children for Mother's Day, some of whom even
danced!
Well, now my back is very sore, and my neck and calves are burned, but I
had a wonderful time, and thought the party went off like a mutha!!!  See
y'all next time...

Love,

- E

up in the response letter by the promtoers of the party

that Paramount supports a program that lies about the deaths of people

ESPECIALLY minors that were taped and shown on TV

And also about the fact that they repeatedly blatently lied
during the report, (like saying police/medical help was inaccessible
but in fact an ambulance was there along with several rangers/sheriffs)

I think complaints will be more readily received and acted upon
if they are about the quality of the program or the ethics they
use as a news (type) program in their research/reporting

Here's my short story.  Preface:  I'm straight, but all three of my best male
friends are gay.  

Three years ago, I was invited by a friend to dance on the Sisters of Perpetual
Indulgence float at the Parade -- If you don't know them, this is a wild and
wonderful group of gay men who dress in outrageous campy nun-drag and party a
lot -- they also support a wide range of gay community causes and issues, and
they're a cool and playful (obviously) group.  

I had never even BEEN to the parade, but I dressed in my craziest costume (which
was a lot less crazy than it would be now!), and had the TIME OF MY LIFE!  We
had loud speakers, awesome music, and as we travelled down the road, people
yelled and smiled and danced with us, I LOVED IT!  The energy at this even is
amazing, total happiness and freedom being felt by people, many of whom live
their lives with caution and criticism, out partying with abandonment and joy.  

The past two years, I've gone and volunteered for a while, then partied, danced
in the street, and I have to say met amazing people -- I met my best friend Sara
at the parade two years ago (you may have met her yesterday at Harmony or at the
SFR picnic with me) on a day that was a life-changing experience for me  -- 

To know about the parade:  1. Not everyone is gay -- it's not about being gay to
be there, it's about supporting people's freedom to be who they are, and 2. The
vibe is happy and upbeat, like a big smilin' community ....

Plus, as I hope we all know, there are a lot of gay ravers out there, and we're
all part of the same family! If we had a float or a marching/dancing group on
foot (and honestly I don't know if there's a huge bureaurcratic process in order
to even get in), we could make a sign that shows support of freedom in general,
not specifically for sexual orientation -- something that represents all of us,
straight/gay/bi/abstinent whatever!

Whichever we do, Bay to Breakers or Gay Pride, I'm happy to partipate!

Leslie  : )     Dance on!

Update on my (seemingly aborted) ambitions to drag a sound system along
for BTB... 

I have laryngitis, can't speak, and feel pretty crappy.  So it's going to
be very hard for me to make the 'trance float' happen for Bay to Breakers. 
I got several nice messages of support, though, so if you are very
motivated and would like to take the reins on this one, please send me
some more mail and I'd be glad to see what we can do! 

In any case, we should definitely have a meeting place at the end (the 'R'
section), and probably at the beginning too for those who want to hang out
during and after the 'race'. 

For all of those who asked:  Bay to Breakers is a 7+ mile event (more like
a parade than a race) in San Francisco on Sunday morning, May 19.  It
starts south of Market and ends in Golden Gate Park.  Lots of the 100,000
people dress up in crazy costumes and it's really fun. 

Sarah (sjslay) and I are planning to dance all night and then hit BTB --
if anyone would like to join us please speak up!  :) 

Take care, and please send some positive energy to my vocal cords!!

From: Kc <sarahtonen@earthlink.net>

Subject: Hard Copy retaliation #1

Please copy the following text "Society for Professional Journalism Code of
Ethics" and fax it to the following name/number with the information
provided.  If you can, you may want to send it several times over the next
couple of weeks and you should cross post this to other mailing lists
encouraging them to voice their concern as well.

-----------------------------Start Copy Here----------------------------


TO: Frank Feldinger/Hard Copy
Via fax: 213/862-1068
From:(YOUR NAME) A disgusted desert raver

RE: A reminder for your commitement to ethics in journalism

As a reminder of your responsibilities in professional journalism, please
review the items starred below





               The Society of Professional Journalists
                           Code of Ethics

Code of Ethics

The Society of Professional Journalists, Sigma Delta Chi, believes the duty
of journalists is to serve the truth.

We BELIEVE the agencies of mass communication are carriers of public
discussion and information, acting on their Constitutional mandate and
freedom to learn and report the facts.

We BELIEVE in public enlightenment as the forerunner of justice, and in our
Constitutional role to seek the truth as part of the public's right to know
the truth.

We BELIEVE those responsibilities carry obligations that require journalists
to perform with intelligence, objectivity, accuracy and fairness.

To these ends, we declare acceptance of the standards of practice set forth:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

I. Responsibility

The public's right to know of events of public importance and interest is
the overriding mission of the mass media. The purpose of distributing news
and enlightened opinion is to serve the general welfare.

***Journalists who use their professional status as representatives of the
public for selfish or other unworthy motives violate a high trust.***
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

II. Freedom of the Press

Freedom of the press is to be guarded as an inalienable right of people in a
free society. It carries with it the freedom and the responsibility to
discuss, question, and challenge actions and utterances of our government
and of our public and private institutions. Journalists uphold the right to
speak unpopular opinions and the privilege to agree with the majority.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

III. Ethics

Journalists must be free of obligation to any interest other than the
public's right to know the truth.

  1. Gifts, favors, free travel, special treatment or privileges can
     compromise the integrity of journalists and their employers. Nothing of
     value should be accepted.
  2. Secondary employment, political involvement, holding public office, and
     service in community organizations should be avoided if it compromises
     the integrity of journalists and their employers. Journalists and their
     employers should conduct their personal lives in a manner that protects
     them from conflict of interest, real or apparent. Their
     responsibilities to the public are paramount. That is the nature of
     their profession.
**********************************************************************
**3. SO-CALLED NEWS COMMUNICATIONS FROM PRIVATE SOURCES SHOULD NOT BE
PUBLISHED
     OR BROADCAST WITHOUT SUBSTANTIATION OF THEIR CLAIMS TO NEWS VALUES.
**********************************************************************
 *4. Journalists will seek news that serves the public interest, despite the
     obstacles. They will make constant efforts to assure that the public's
     business is conducted in public and that public records are open to
     public inspection.
  5. Journalists acknowledge the newsman's ethic of protecting confidential
     sources of information.
  6. Plagiarism is dishonest and unacceptable.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

IV. Accuracy and Objectivity

Good faith with the public is the foundation of all worthy journalism.

 *1. Truth is our ultimate goal.
 *2. Objectivity in reporting the news is another goal that serves as the
     mark of an experienced professional. It is a standard of performance
     toward which we strive. We honor those who achieve it.
 *3. There is no excuse for inaccuracies or lack of thoroughness.
 *4. Newspaper headlines should be fully warranted by the contents of the
     articles they accompany. Photographs and telecasts should give an
     accurate picture of an event and not highlight an incident out of
     context.
  5. Sound practice makes clear distinction between news reports and
     expressions of opinion. News reports should be free of opinion or bias
     and represent all sides of an issue.
  6. Partisanship in editorial comment that knowingly departs from the truth
     violates the spirit of American journalism.
  7. Journalists recognize their responsibility for offering informed
     analysis, comment, and editorial opinion on public events and issues.
     They accept the obligation to represent such material by individuals
     whose competence, experience, and judgment qualify them for it.
  8. Special articles or presentation devoted to advocacy or the writer's
     own conclusions and interpretations should be labeled as such.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

V. Fair Play

*Journalists at all times will show respect for the dignity, privacy, rights,
and well-being of people encountered in the course of gathering and
presenting the news.

 *1. The news media should not communicate unofficial charges affecting
     reputation or moral character without giving the accused a chance to
     reply.
 *2. The news media must guard against invading a person's right to privacy.
  3. The media should not pander to morbid curiosity about details of vice
     and crime.
 *4. It is the duty of news media to make prompt and complete correction of
     their errors.
 *5. Journalists should be accountable to the public for their reports and
     the public should be encouraged to voice its grievances against the
     media. Open dialogue with our readers, viewers, and listeners should be
     fostered.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

VI. Pledge

Adherence to this code is intended to preserve and strengthen the bond of
mutual trust and respect between American journalists and the American
people.

The Society shall -- by programs of education and other means -- encourage
individual journalists to adhere to these tenets, and shall encourage
journalistic publications and broadcasters to recognize their responsibility
to frame codes of ethics in concert with their employees to serve as
guidelines in furthering these goals.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Code of Ethics adopted 1926; revised 1973, 1984, 1987
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Society of Professional Journalists also has published an ethics guide
called "Doing Ethics in Journalism, A Handbook with Case Studies" by Jay
Black, Bob Steele and Ralph Barney (1993). For information on how to get the
book, contact the Society at P.O. Box 77, 16 South Jackson St., Greencastle,
IN 46135-0077. The Telephone number is (317) 653-3333.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Related Links

Northern California Pro Chapter's Ethics Page
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

                          Return to San Diego SPJ

----------------------------------------------------------------------------



-Kc


Memories of DUNE at
http://home.earthlink.net/~sarahtonen

Cc: John_W._Stuart@livewire.com

Precedence: bulk

Dear Promoters of the Harmony, Gateway Systems, and Friends & Family parties,

        This message concerns a recent thread of discussion on sfraves
about coffee.  My roommate (and friend of over ten years), John Stuart, has
a relative who's an executive of a large coffee company based in southern
California.  Thus, John is able to acquire coffee beans at very low cost.
He and I are interested in setting up and running a coffee station at
parties for whoever is interested.  The promoters of the events where the
coffee station would be set up would be paid a percentage of coffee sales,
to be agreed upon by both parties.  Due to positive comments about the idea
of having a coffee station at parties, we feel that, by maintaining a
coffee station, we would be providing a service that would be appreciated,
and we would want to sell the coffee at a reasonable, easily affordable
price.  It would be a very simple operation, and wouldn't take up much
floorspace (the best place for such a coffee station would be in the chill
area).  We would provide all the necessary materials, and would take as
much responsibility as possible for the waste (cups, stirring sticks, etc).
        I apologize for making this public via the list, but I don't have
the e-mail addresses of the proper people to contact, and hopefully posting
this way will generate more support (anyone?).  Please e-mail me, privately
if you wish, if you have an interest in discussing this further.  On behalf
of John Stuart and myself, I thank you for your attention.

Very truly yours,

- Eric P.

> 
> In a sense, (as Peter said again) dancing _ can _ be the best way to relate -
> you're putting your energy into the place, the moment, the music,
> the crowd, the building, including everyone & excluding none.
> 
> This list itself, right now, is verging away a bit from this
> aspect of raving, I think - recent posts about events that happened
> over the last two weeks were full of messages from people saying "hi"
> to specific friends, posting long lists mentioning people by name who
> the writers felt made the event go off for them...though I think it is
> incredibly important and exciting when people find each other & become
> friends within a shared love of raving, I would still hate to see this
> list become exclusively a social circle.

I read Rhea's post and have been pondering this aspect of it all 
weekend.  As someone who posted a short list of sfravers of whom I had 
met at BP, what she is saying above struck me.  After being here for any 
amount of time (for me it's been about 10 months), you begin to want to 
meet the people with whom you converse.  Raves are a communal experience, 
and the "rave" experience is arguably best shared with others rather than 
doing it alone or in a small, limited group of friends.  Conversing with 
"strangers" and sharing something with them, be it as simple as a smile, 
adds to the communal spirit.  So, it is in this context that I want to 
discuss Rhea's comments.

Speaking from my own feelings, I would post the names of people I had met 
*not* to exclude anyone, but rather to include more people into the 
family.  Although some may disagree, I feel it is hard to be a part of a 
group if you are anonymous.  How can your individuality be enjoyed if no 
one knows who you are?  Of course, this can be carried to the extreme.  In 
which case you would get a small exclusive clique; something akin to a 
high school hierarchy.  I imagine this is what Rhea was alluding to.  

If I could meet all 400 people on this list and then be able to give each 
one written acknowledgment, I would be overjoyed.  It is nice 
when someone appreciates you.  And, I think, appreciation and acknowledgment 
of each human's individuality is the highest form of compliment.  This 
only adds to the communal experience, and this is where I disagree with 
Rhea when she talks about "hating to see this become a social circle."   
Because, I don't think that's what this list is nor what it will ever 
become.  If we can meet one another, it adds faces to print and, thereby, 
enhances many people's experiences because it makes everything more 
personal.

What makes this list "look" like a social circle is that you get people 
who are less "shy" (for lack of a better word) or busy, or whatever, that 
post frequently.  So, you start to read stuff from the people who post 
all of the time.  The remedy for this is that more people should post.  
If someone doesn't post, they won't be known and they aren't necessarily 
adding to the communal vibe of this "raving" list.  Rhea, herself, added 
a perspective that made me stop and think from a different angle.  How 
does that happen if people don't post?  I think I am more specifically 
speaking about people who might be intimidated to post something rather 
than those who are too busy.  Isn't this a Do-It-Yourself culture where 
you need to make it what you want it instead of sitting around talking 
about how it could be better?  I'll be the first to admit that I have fun 
being on this list.  It is like a rave away from a rave, and isn't raving 
what we are all here about?  

I'd like to see more people come forward and speak up (hopefully with 
tolerance and understanding in mind!), epecially those among us who are 
shy.  A rave is a great place to lose your shyness because we all seek a 
common goal of creating a marvelous vibe, and in order to do that we must 
respect and acknowledge every single one of us.   

Rhea says, 
> Raves have been such a big learning experience for me,showing me 
> that perspective seems to be what lets us get outside confining social 
> structures in the first place.

Words to live by!! :)


-kaysee

Subject: bass instinct & madness
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Friday - - - >

Bass Instinct was a fun little underground party at the same space as
Chrysalis' 420.  It looked to me like they had a great sound system, but it
was
woefully underamplified.  No bass, ironically enough.  No big deal, I can kick
it without pristine sound.  There were a number of people thoroughly getting
into the music.  I really enjoyed Tomas' set especially; he should have gone
on
earlier when there were more people there.
Saturday - - - >

Madness.  This was a great party in a number of ways and yet it never really
hit critical mass for me.  The space was the biggest plus.  Nice sized
warehouse bordered by a thoughtfully decorated indoor chill area with a couch
and mattresses and a big outdoor patio area with chairs and tables.  The one
downside to the huge chill area was that I think it drew a lot of people away
from the dance floor.  I will attest to the earlier reports of the crowd being
"weird".  I couldn't quite put my finger on it either.  Maybe it came from the
fact that everyone seemed really out of their heads and yet not terribly
social
or open to unfamiliar people (namely ME!).  The music, during primetime
anyway,
seemed pretty undancey.  I wasn't really too aware of who was spinning after
Jon Santos finished his set.  Was Peter Lazonby the only one who played CDs?
If so, he was the main culprit for me.  Most of his mixes broke down into long
ambient transitions, questionably beatmatched.  Not that it was his fault, but
the CDs kept skipping also, something that tends to kill any trance set.  Then
there was the gabber-jungle segment which sent me on another journey into the
chill areas.  Certainly I think everyone can appreciate the niche that Mad has
carved out for itself with its techno-only foundation, but I had several
people
express their reluctance to go to Madness simply to hear the same regulars at
Mad all in a row.  Surely there are more techno dj's in San Francisco to build
a lineup from.  Sho and James Dee come to mind as two overtalented underbooked
SF techno dj's.  Overall it was a nice party though, no question about it.

inhuman

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 13 May 96 15:48:42 PST
From: BRAD BURLINGHAM <brad_burlingham@studio.disney.com>
To: Aleph One <aleph1@dfw.net>
Subject: DUNE: The real story 

Hi Aleph,

Did you ever see a post from me w/ the header: DUNE the real story?

If not, would you mind forwarding it to sfraves.  for some reason i don't think
its gone through.

Thanks,

Brad

Hello friends to the north,

As you know by now, the slime show that is Hard Copy did a piece on a
desert rave last night.  A VERY negative piece.

The rave that they showed (with the exception of a few clips) was DUNE, a rave
put on by several socal ravers including myself.  We are deeply saddened that
the media (if you can call Hard Copy media) has once again choosen to
misrepresent our scene.

We are very, very proud of DUNE and feel you should hear the real story.

DUNE happened on March 23rd and was the brainchild of several people from the
socal raves list.  All involved in DUNE felt like they had gotten so much out of
the scene that we wanted to give something back. We were also fed up with greedy
promoters and an increase in the number of parties being busted.  

So, instead of bitching about it, we decided to take action. We accomplished
this by putting on an legal (not for profit) party in the desert with an amazing
atmosphere, spirituality and vibe.   Los Angeles' top DJ's (Christopher
Lawrence, Lee, Doran and Thee-O) understood what DUNE was about and volunteered
their substantial services.  We also hired one of LA's top sound companies to
provide 4 speaker stacks of the most amazing sound i've ever heard.

The party was 100% legal.  We worked closely with the Bureau of Land Management
to ensure that this party would not be busted.  We paid the overtime salaries
(not cheap) of 4 Sherriffs so that they could be at the party all night.  We
paid to have an ambulence at the party the entire time.  We wanted to show
ravers that not all authority figures are against us, while at the same time
proving to the Rangers that raves are not the evil parties that the media paints
them to be.  They were impressed with the party and days later, commented that
the site we used was cleaner than before we got there.

The location about 2.5 hours out of L.A. in the middle of the desert.  The site
was surrounded by an enormous U-shaped grouping of rocks that created a
spectacular natural rock ampatheather. We had two huge projection screens with
incredible visuals as well as lighting projected directly on the rocks and
ground.  

The party officially went from 11pm-noon (from 9-11 we let some djs from the
socal list spin) and we charged only $5 with the hope of possibly breaking even. 
Over 2,000 happy people showed up to help make it an incredible experience for
all.  To top it off, the comet was overhead and was mind-blowingly beautiful to
say the least (it was the size of the moon and the tail went 1/3 of the way
across the sky).

We encourage you to check out our website which now includes pictures and
reviews of the event. Http://home.earthlink.net/~sarahtonen

Also, we hope to do another DUNE sometime in Sept., so if you'd like to be a
part of this positive event, send me an email and i'll put you on our mailing
list. We'd love to include our brothers and sisters from other cities in this
plurry event. 

Peace and don't believe the hype,

Brad 

ps thanks to the sf ravers that attended our event.  It was great having you
down in L.A.



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May 13 16:15:03 1996

Yeah, Moshe and his buddy told us what happened.  It totally sucks!  Jess,
Renaud, Erik, and I passed through the trials of the bridge from SF to get
to the Marina (over an hour to cross the bridge!).  They must have gotten
there just after you left, and we got there after they'd looked all around
the Marina, and were sitting on a curb, not knowing what to do.  We all
kicked it there till the sun came up, Jess driving them home to Oakland and
then returning for the rest of us.

yours.  Keep your energy up!  We love that you did what you could, and hope
your losses were minimal.

From: Kc <sarahtonen@earthlink.net>

Subject: Bad Rave PR coming to a theater near you!

This is in today's Hollywood Reporter....

ZIELINSKI, BOBER FIND 'ECSTASY'

by Rick Hanson

CANNES- Director Rafal Zielinski, whose "Fun" picked up two awards at the
Sundance Film Festival two years ago, is set to direct the techno-themed
'Ecstasy.'

Philippe Bober, a producer and sales agent with the Berlin based
Co-Production Office, described it as a tragic love story set in Berlin's
techno-music scene. Bober says he has begun putting together the financing
on the $2.5 million project.

'Ecstasy' concerns an aging classical musician who becomes tragically
obsessed with a 20-year-old woman. He lets her drag him into the dangerous
drug scene that surrounds techno music.






Sounds like we're gonna be misrepresented yet again.



-Kc

Subject: Re: Gay  Freedom Parade Story

Precedence: bulk

I second all Leslie has to say about the Gay pride parade.  It's an amazing
event and you want to talk about vibe?!?!  Even without black lights and
posters, lasers or drugs, the rally is one of the most powerful events I've
every been to.  It's truly about life, liberty and the pursute of happiness
and non-prosecution.  For all people.

Imagine a sea of people all dancing to loud house music.  You can handle
that right, now double, triple, quadruple the largest rave you've ever been
to and that's what the end of the rally is like.  I climbed on a bus stop
to take a picture and as far as I could see there were people the entire
street wide in both directions dancing to the music (also did the hand wave
and had the most intense rush as all these people started waving their
hands in the air.).  It was an ocean of brothers and sister, all creeds,
colors, and orientations.  Freaks?!  Fuck yeah!  Nudity?  Some of that too.
Leather, piercings, tatoos, gratuitous displays of wild abandon?  Yup, and
then some!

I can understand if you're uncomfortable, Eric, but let me assure you this
wouldn't be like walking into a gay bar for the first time.  It's much more
profound than that.

I will help organize a SFR meeting place, but would be far more into
supporting/helping organize Vince's idea of putting together a float (It's
late to start that now).  Maybe we could even try and get one of our
favotrite DJs to spin (the street party), but I'd be suprised if they
didn't have DJs already lined up.  In fact, it might be super hard to get
into the parade.  Anyone involved with the rally in here?

Peace!

Tone

P.S.  In terms of numbers, I think about 300,000 people might go to the
rally (probably more), and I'd say that about (guessing here) 50,000 are
dancing in the street after the parade.  Little ole you Eric, will not
stand out as a lone hetrosexual male in the group, I promise.  Hell, I'll
be there and I'm straight, but if you want, I'll hold your hand to make you
feel more comfortable.  ;^)  (J/J)

>_______________________________________________
>
>Here's my short story.  Preface:  I'm straight, but all three of my best male
>friends are gay.
>
>Three years ago, I was invited by a friend to dance on the Sisters of
>Perpetual
>Indulgence float at the Parade -- If you don't know them, this is a wild and
>wonderful group of gay men who dress in outrageous campy nun-drag and party a
>lot -- they also support a wide range of gay community causes and issues, and
>they're a cool and playful (obviously) group.
>
>I had never even BEEN to the parade, but I dressed in my craziest costume
>(which
>was a lot less crazy than it would be now!), and had the TIME OF MY LIFE!  We
>had loud speakers, awesome music, and as we travelled down the road, people
>yelled and smiled and danced with us, I LOVED IT!  The energy at this even is
>amazing, total happiness and freedom being felt by people, many of whom live
>their lives with caution and criticism, out partying with abandonment and
>joy.
>
>The past two years, I've gone and volunteered for a while, then partied,
>danced
>in the street, and I have to say met amazing people -- I met my best
>friend Sara
>at the parade two years ago (you may have met her yesterday at Harmony or
>at the
>SFR picnic with me) on a day that was a life-changing experience for me  --
>
>To know about the parade:  1. Not everyone is gay -- it's not about being
>gay to
>be there, it's about supporting people's freedom to be who they are, and
>2. The
>vibe is happy and upbeat, like a big smilin' community ....
>
>Plus, as I hope we all know, there are a lot of gay ravers out there, and
>we're
>all part of the same family! If we had a float or a marching/dancing group on
>foot (and honestly I don't know if there's a huge bureaurcratic process in
>order
>to even get in), we could make a sign that shows support of freedom in
>general,
>not specifically for sexual orientation -- something that represents all
>of us,
>straight/gay/bi/abstinent whatever!
>
>Whichever we do, Bay to Breakers or Gay Pride, I'm happy to partipate!
>
>Leslie  : )     Dance on!

hey everybody! after reading the reviews of madness, i felt obliged to
add my comments on it too. i agree with most people that the vibe was
good. i was glad that there were no circle dancers. i wish that my ride
had decided to stay until the end so that i could heave enjoyed the
finale. i was too pumped up to leave but had to. the ambient(ish) set in
the middle at around 3 a.m. was excellent chill out kind of music but
hard to dance to. the wait for more danceable music paid off as soon as
the jungle like beats kicked in. i hope that i will attend more raves
with a crowd of this sort. this was the best indoor party that i have
ever been to. was glad to meet crunch again after f-8. hope to see some
of you at Sprockets on wednesday in san jose. 


love 
dhiren & ionX

>>>  ------- Forwarded Message Follows -------
>>>
>>> "Just yesterday B'nai B'rith's annual report (Canada) on
>>> hate and racism located the net as the one source of
>>> exploding and uncontrollable dissemination of hate mail.
>>> I feel strongly that every NO vote on the formation of a
>>> neo-Nazi newsgroup is a public and civilized blow
>>> against a pernicious, evil movement. Please vote to
>>> affirm society's rejection of neo-Nazis.  Please
>>> distribute the following message as you deem
>>> appropriate.
>>>
>>> A group of neo-nazis are trying to form a newsgroup on
>>> Usenet called rec.music.white-power, so that they can
>>> get their message of hate out to young people using the
>>> Internet.  Newsgroups are public discussion areas on the
>>> Internet and their formation requires enough support
>>> from the Internet community.
>>>
>>> EACH AND EVERY ONE OF YOU HAS ONE VOTE when it comes to
>>> creating a new Usenet group. I hope you will vote NO and
>>> thereby tell these Nazis you don't want their stuff on
>>> the net. Below is the procedure, please repost my plea
>>> and get the NO vote out.   This is my personal opinion.
>>> If you want to see the official call for votes, you can
>>> read in news.group or ask me for a copy of the notice
>>> calling for votes.
>>>
>>> Do not vote twice - that would constitute voting fraud.
>>>
>>> HOW TO VOTE:
>>>
>>> Send E-MAIL (posts to a newsgroup are invalid) to:
>>>
>>>         music-vote@sub-rosa.com
>>>
>>> This is an impartial, third-party vote taker.
>>>
>>> Do not REPLY to THIS message, if you are trying to vote.
>>>  Please do not assume that just replying to this message
>>> will work. Check the address before you mail your vote.
>>> Your mail message should contain only one statement:
>>>
>>>         I vote NO on rec.music.white-power
>>>
>>> I REALLY HOPE YOU VOTE NO!
>>>
>>> Vote counting is automated.  Failure to follow these
>>> directions may mean that your vote does not get counted.
>>>  If you do not receive an acknowledgment of your vote
>>> within three days contact the votetaker about the
>>> problem.  It's your responsibility to make sure your
>>> vote is registered correctly.
>>>
>>> Here's what Canada's George Burdi, of the neo-Nazi
>>> Heritage Front, had to say about this vote, on February
>>> 21, on his RESISTANCE mailing list:
>>>
>>>         "There is a call for votes         coming on
>>>         rec.music.white-power in the next         week
>>>         or so, and you will be notified in a
>>>         special issue of RREN exactly what to do.
>>>           FOLLOW THE INSTRUCTIONS TO THE LETTER.  Let me
>>>                 be perfectly blunt and state that we
>>>         have more         than enough "net-nazis" to win
>>>         this thing         hands-down. But every one of
>>>         you must vote YES!
>>>          And just voting yes means nothing unless you
>>>               do it properly.
>>>         So you have been forewarned.          The
>>>         instructions are coming to your email box
>>>          soon, and they are not complicated.  Just
>>>            follow them as told, and we will have a WP
>>>                 music newsgroup
>>>         finally!"
>>>
>>> If Mr. Burdi's confidence disturbs you, please give this
>>> letter the _widest_ possible distribution, and help us
>>> deliver the largest NO vote in the history of UseNet. If
>>> you would like more detailed information on why you
>>> should vote no, check out http://nizkor.almanac.bc.ca -
>>> although it should be noted that the Nizkor Project has
>>> no connection to this personal plea."

Precedence: bulk

>
>Madness.  This was a great party in a number of ways and yet it never really
>hit critical mass for me.

Ditto. I actually would have liked a few more people there. I really liked
the crowd, even though it was a bit "freaky". To tell you the truth, I prefer
a crowd with a bit of an "edge" like that. I loved BP, but sometimes all
the sweetness makes me feel sticky.

>I will attest to the earlier reports of the crowd being
>"weird".  I couldn't quite put my finger on it either.

Well, as one of my friends reminded me there (was it you Troy?):
"The name of the party _is_ Madness."

I stayed until 5:30 AM when some guy in the chill room told me to look
into his eyes and he would "read me". He sung some freaky songs into my 
ears and looked into my eyes and told me far more about me than any stranger
should be able to tell. Or so I thought at the time. It freaked me out
enough that I left. But it was time anyway.

This party was kind of a breakthrough for me in that I really wanted to go,
but couldn't contact any friends beforehand. So I decided to go not knowing
if anyone I knew would be there for sure. Of course, I knew something like
20 people there and had a great time. That was cool. Thanks to all of you
that went for helping make it happen!

Peace,
Jim

>wasn't into it that night - I wasn't feeling very social and would not 
>want to have brought any of you down.  I did love the space and the 
>decorations - especially the big tent on that ledge and the colorful 
>poster nearest the bathroom.
>
I am glad I got a chance to talk to you. And you definitely didn't bring
me down. But that is like trying to bring down a cloud, anyway.

Hugs,
Jim A.

PS I will miss having you around, but I certainly understand the need to
"take a break." I only really started raving in January, but I am already
doing it less and less. It is hard to go out and expend that much energy
every weekend.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May 13 17:56:32 1996

I think there's a misunderstanding about the "Detroit sound."  Detroit 
producers put plenty of funk and house in their tracks because it's part
of what they come from.  I certainly hear those influences in tracks by
Jeff Mills, Red Planet, Aux 88, Octave One and the other Detroit material
coming out now, not to mention Richie Hawtin who is closely allied with
the Detroit sound but has his own unique direction.

If anything, Chicago seems to have lost a lot of the funky feel, although
it seems to be coming back now with a resurgence led by Glenn Underground
and Cajmere.  But for a while, it seemed like every Chicago track with
the word "funk" in it had nothing of the sort.  At least not to these
ears, trained in the art of the funk by Professor James Brown and Doctor
George Clinton.

phred

I remember noting a while back that people were curious as to the number of

list of everybody who is currently subscribed by sending an email to
majordomo@hyperreal.com with
WHO SFRAVES typed in the body of the message.  It popped right back with a
complete list within minutes of me sending it off!

Received: from shellx.best.com (shellx.best.com [206.86.0.11]) by mail1.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id UAA02895 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 13 May 1996 20:05:18 -0700
Received: from tgrigsby (tgrigsby.us.dhl.com [199.41.137.104]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id UAA24028 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 13 May 1996 20:05:05 -0700
Date: Mon, 13 May 1996 20:05:05 -0700
Message-Id: <199605140305.UAA24028@shellx.best.com>
X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Limiting the number of tickets sold
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

PROMOTERS:  The last two really good raves I went to, the promoters set a 
predetermined limit on the number of tickets to be sold and advertised this 
number.  Then both times less people showed up than anticipated.  In the 
case of Mad, this seemed to result in a rather thin turn-out.  I have a 
theory about the reason, and it goes like this:

Limiting the number of tickets is a GREAT idea -- there's nothing worse than 
going to a rave that's overcrowded -- but you might specify a number that's 
about 200 more than you really want.  See, when there's a limit, I think 
people assume that after a certain hour the party will be sold out, so they 
don't bother to go.  If the promoter had based the price on that number so 
as to come out even, s/he may end up losing money due to the poor turnout.

Just a thought.

S


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May 13 20:05:37 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA28058; Mon, 13 May 1996 20:05:37 -0700
Received: from mail1.best.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id UAA28039; Mon, 13 May 1996 20:05:30 -0700
Received: from shellx.best.com (shellx.best.com [206.86.0.11]) by mail1.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id UAA02888 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 13 May 1996 20:05:15 -0700
Received: from tgrigsby (tgrigsby.us.dhl.com [199.41.137.104]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id UAA23925 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 13 May 1996 20:04:54 -0700
Date: Mon, 13 May 1996 20:04:54 -0700
Message-Id: <199605140304.UAA23925@shellx.best.com>
X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Review: Mad
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Another Mad review (long):

The situation: 
        Saturday night
        My entire crew missing in action (read "flaked")
        Three hamsters missing in action (read "liberated by a friend's 
children")
       
Psychological condition:
        Less than favorable (read "crappy mood")

The disguise:
        Black baggies
        white t-shirt
        Fimo medallion with a smiley on one side and "SFR" on the other
        A red and white Dr. Seuss hat

Additional equipment:
        Grapes
        Lotion
        Tums
        Water
        Stickers
        Camera and several rolls of film
        etc.

The mission, should I choose to accept it:
        To locate a large group of indigenous rabble and assist them in
        releasing as much energy as possible via ritualistic rhythmic
        undulation of bodies, hugs, massages, and large grins.

The phone burst into flames five seconds after the voice message completed.  
I removed my wetsuit and got into my disguise.  Don't ask what I was doing 
in a wetsuit.  I chose to accept the mission.  It was either that or 
continue watching the Nick at Night "Mission Impossible" marathon...

I snuck off into the night, alone, late.  I was pretty sure I'd miss out 
since it was 12:30 by the time I found the map point.  I was in luck -- 
tickets were still available.  I was actually giggling to myself as I drove 
off to find the space.

I showed up and was immediately greeted by SFR friends with big grins.  It 
was GREAT!  I saw so many people I knew and met so many more from this list, 
all so friendly, all feeling good and having a good time.

Folks, I have to take a moment and make special mention: My vote for "Raver 
'O The Week" goes to the ever wonderful Shawna McGourty.  In spite of all 
the friendly faces, when I first got there, I was having a bit of trouble 
shaking the horrible week I'd had.  She took care of me and made sure I had 
a *superb* evening, for which I definitely owe her big time. 

As the evening wore on, I danced...and danced...and danced...  geez, I was 
there until after they closed everything down -- a first for me -- and even 
helped pull down some of the decorations in the chill space.  I was a 
bouncing ball of energy, turning all the negative energy from a seriously 
bad week into positive party energy.  YES!!!

COOL MOMENT: Watching the screen in the chill space and seeing, among the 
acid visuals, the silhouettes of two women doing a rather exotic dance.  
Went back inside and saw that it was actually two women dancing in the beam 
of light from the camera.  WOW!  They were good.  I joined them a couple of 
times, but geez, my body just don't move like that...

COOL MOMENT: I don't know who the DJ was, but someone was putting together 
such good jams, the crowd starting getting *noisy*.  I was all over the place...

COOL MOMENT: Wayne: "Can you give me a ride?"

COOL MOMENT: Watching Rikki dancing with glo-sticks.  *Very* cool!

COOL MOMENT: Passing out grapes the next morning.  I put smiles on a lot of 
faces!

COOL MOMENT: Just about every hug I got was a cool moment unto itself, and I 
got a bunch!

COOL MOMENT: Adam (aka R.Lunatic) and I running around with our Dr. Seuss 
hats.  Hey, it was just plain fun being such a goof.  I was skipping and 
jumping and running and being a total kid.

COOL MOMENT: The owner got out and danced with us a couple of times.  This 
guy was doing a kind of James Brown shuffle thing that was cool!  Ya gotta 
like someone that jumps out and parties with the kiddies, flashing just as 
big a smile as any raver.

COOL MOMENT: Smiling and getting instant smiles back!

COOL MOMENT: Aw heck, there's too many to name...  I'll add this though: 
cramps in my legs.  What's that you say?  Cramps don't sound like a cool 
moment?  Well, by that time it was 7:30am and it was my body telling me it 
was getting close to spent.  I have never danced quite that much.  WOW!

FUNNY MOMENT: Sneaking up on Tim (Knucklehead) as he slept in a large, 
comfortable looking chair, removing all his clothes, posing him in lurid 
positions with a couple of squirrels and a glo-stick, and taking pictures!  
Got his clothes back on and he didn't even wake up!  Soon as I get those 
developed I'll post them on a new Web page...

WELL DONE:  Free water and juice.  Danishes too, which looked *yummy*, but I 
wasn't up for any...  There was also fruit cocktail available, equally yummy 
looking.  Plenty of toilets, plenty of indoor chill space, *wonderful* 
outdoor space with tables, chairs, and even a couple of love seats!  Art 
work from Beautiful People, including that fantastic sun & moon painting, 
hung inside and outside.  I hope we get to use that space again!!!

WEIRD CHARACTERS:  Yeah, there were a few people there that I suspect had 
access to far better chemicals than most.  But then, most parties have a few 
of those.  I just leave them to explore the modified world they've created 
and wander back into the dance space.

If there was a downside to this party, it was the weird ambient stuff that 
came on late in the party.  For me at least, it just wasn't danceable.  So I 
hung outside and waited for it to change, which of course gave me time to 
meet more people.  I'm not saying it was bad, in fact it was good music, 
just not very danceable in my case.

I had a damn good time and I've got the pictures to prove it...  And I'll 
give up the negatives for the right price...

I did have a good time, and I feel bad for those that didn't.  If I'd found 
you, I'd have done all I could to bring you up to my level, promise.  

NEXT TIME: The next time you're at a rave and you're having trouble getting 
with the groove, come find me.  If I have energy and a smile to spare, 
you've got it.

I would name off all the people I met and saw, but dang, there were so many! 
 I love you all!  Hasta, kiddies...

S

Hiya All;

        I was hanging outside Experience where some of my fav DJ's were
spinning, Mars, & Eric. So why was I out side; because it was so hot inside.
I eventually got tired of the negative tweekee children/staff causing chaos
inside & out ruining it for everyone. Also, the fact that one of our other
promoters called the police on the party; which in my book unless there's a
risk of loss of life, limb, or property that this should never happen.

        I'm personally fed up with all ages events, and am never ever going
to another one again, with the exception of  these few
people/groups/promoters C^3, Frequency 8, Compound I, Full Moon, New Moon,
SPAZ and Harmony.

        Between the gangs, the children, the poor venues and the sociopathic
greedy promoters that over crowd these venues, that I'm more than happy to
be over charged by the clubs. At least they have  HVAC(heating, ventilation,
and air conditioning system).

        Ya now what does it take to purchase a few industrial grade
fans/blowers?    I'll tell ya, a promoters who's more concerned about the
people attending the event, than their pocket books. I'm sorry SF, because
we just don't have that kind of promoter here.

        You can get multiple such devices from any building supply house for
a couple of hundred dollars, and/or rent them from equipment rental places.
Ya now the same places you get your generators from. I'll be happy to
purchase them myself and make them available to our promoters for a deposit
and a very small fee if I have a written commitment from our promoters
saying they will use them. But it will never ever happen, because most of
our promoters would rather purchase a stupid flashing light that no one will
notice because they can rent that to another promoter.

Totally Disgusted With The Greed & Lack of Concern
THX1138

    I just wanted to say that the vibe I get from this city is awesome!  I
love to be able to smile at random people on the street and not get a "What
the fuck are you looking at" return look... but an even bigger smile back! 
 
  And during my first week here I met some truely beautiful people...  
 
Renaud "The Frenchman" is even cooler than I first thought (considering he
ditched me on our apartment agreement).   And he's actually as funny as he
thinks he is. 
 
Then I met Brendan... Only a minute after I posted my "don't know shit in
San Fran", he called me up and wanted to show me around Haight street. 
Holy shit was I surprised!  And I had a hell of a time.  Thanks Brendan. 
 
  And thanks for introducing me to the energy goddess herself, Jess.  When
she's partying she holds the key to ecstasy.  An awesome woman.  She's
definately one of a kind! (Partying while attending Med school?  Didn't
know it was possible) 
 
Then there's Eric Peterson.  I always wanted to meet the "10 posts a day
makes my work day go faster" man.   A beautiful person--Ask him for a
hug... you won't be disappointed. 
 
Later on at Bass Instinct I met Leslie (who I will definately be partying
with in the future.  She just eminated beautiful vibes!) and Albert and
others who I can't remember their names, sorry.  I RARELY forget faces,
though. 
 
The SFravers are beautiful people.  I can only imagine what the Beautiful
People party was like (I hadn't arrived yet.  I've only heard the
testimony).  And I look forward to meeting you all.   Don't hesitate to
call me up.

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: moonpup@hooked.net (DJ Moonpup)
Subject: I think I have contact !!!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi folks,

 I finally found my old friend Rick Webb, and he has helped me out by
letting me use his labtop, so I can communicate with the world, (finally)

I have felt so cut off from my comfort zone, since arriving, as I don't
have daily access to a computer, but now I should be able to check in about
once every week or so.

To any one who complains that there's not enuff trance and techno in S.F.
you should come to London........techno and trance are in major abundance
here.....

here's a basic rundown of some of the shit I've done and heard so far.

Day one.....arrived at noon...no hassles with customs....(to bad I didn't
bring massive amounts of head wear......)    first shock.....prices and
cost to travel.   unfucking believable......I have spent 1/2 my $$ in the
first 10 days of my trip.....bummer....but needed.

day two.....went to my first club....MEGATRIPOLIS thurs nites in Charring Cross.
loads of shit happenin there.........interactive computer area, drum room,
triphop room, main room- (Derrick May played), some guys bring two crates
of records, and a turntable and you can check out and buy records, right
there in the club......cool idea.....

lots of interesting things to do. a massage area, lots of toys to play
with, and most of all loads of people going off......many happy ravers
here.

I have noticed several major differences here, one is how much smoking goes
on here.....to much for my poor little eyes and lungs, and major drinking
going on.

heavy alcahol vibe......loads of smoke machines, it's like walking in a
constant fog.......but I gotta say, a bigger % of people are appearing to
have a great time, lots of smiley happy people.  however when you leave a
club atmosphere, you find the people on the streets to be very sad and make
very little eye contact and smiles are rarely exchanged. I miss that about
S.F

lots of drunken ass holes who abuse womens energy with typical male ego and
neanderthal attitudes.....

however in the clubs, It's completely different. happy smiles and good
vibes all around.

Day three......mostly rested and found some soccer shirts and just kicked
it around the city.

Day four......I woke up at 5am and went out to visit my old haunting
grounds. for those that don't know, I was born and grew up in London, and
moved to America when I was 12 years old, so I went to visit my old
neighborhood and schools etc......very spiritual......I must have walked 15
or more miles that day......I totally exausted my poor old feet, they hurt
for over a week after that (all that walking on concrete).......The Days
are long as hell here......it begins to get light out at 4:45 in the
morning, and if your walking home through a park or something you can
really relate to the orb samples of birds singing and chirping away,(like
on fluffy clouds etc...) thats something I take for granted in S.F.there
are so many different kinds of song birds here.....it's beautiful.....it
stays light out till 9:30 at night, hella long ass days....I didn't realize
how much further north I am, in fact the sun comes up in my bedroom window,
does a horseshoe manuver over my house to the front, and then back to set
in my bedroom window again. It's alost like living in the north pole.

I went to a brilliant underground club called DELIVERANCE, it was a full on
wharehouse party with 3 rooms of total trance and techno.....and people
were goin bonkers.....I personally found it to be to much, I mean if you
are tired of 160 bpm all nite and you want to chill out and find mellower
music (house, ambient,triphop etc....) forget it......all three rooms were
playing 160+ all nite long...........even at 5:30am.........no rest for the
wicked, but again I emphasize......tons of happy people enjoying the
vibe........It is so energizing and fresh to see locals enjoying local DJ's
play the music, it is an infectious feeling, and I find myself to be very
happy, and content. I am so glad I came........It's awsome to get a
different perspective, in fact it's life saving. I recomend everyone come
check it out.......you will learn so much about what is right and wrong
about the S.F scene.....as well as learn how lucky you are to live in a
relatively friendly atmosphere (on the streets).

Day five........I left deliverance at about 8:30am and went to chelsea, I
bought a ticket to a soccer match, and later in the day I saw chelsea play
Blackburn rovers.....cool game, (except Chelsea lost 3-2). I eventually
passed out and finally got some sleep......

Day six........slept all day.....well needed rest


Day seven......went out and started to look for a job, (yes I'll be broke
in 2-3 weeks if I'm not careful)......

Day eight.......I found an old family friend who runs a recording studio,
and he ordered me some cassetes at bulk rate prices (tapes cost an arm and
a leg, not to mention your first born).......and I have been dubbing off
tapes as fast as I can give them out......I got my first booking for june
7th at Mr C's club.."THE END" I am totally stoked.......TripHop is just
beginning to take off here, I could'nt have picked a better time to come
.........

day nine.......interviewed for a job as a bartender and I think I got
hired....only bummer is I have to shave my beard off......I love my stoopid
beard, it's so full now, but I guess I'd rather be hairless than pennyless.

Day ten.......off to Megatripolis again and finally by chance found my
friend Rick Webb hanging out......thus I now have a semi computer contact
and can check in about once a week or so.

Day 11.......I went to "THE END" to see the wierd beats collective, and saw
DEPTH CHARGE perform, fucking brillient........for the first time since
being in London, I was at home.......awsome triphop and west coast
breakbeat all night long......I havn't danced like that for a long
time......fully inspirational and what a great response from the
crowd....WOW!!!    I really am beginning to see the different vibes, and
directions of the music now, not as trance and techno oriented as I had
first thought, many kinds of music are being played here, (albeit trance
and techno are the biggest)......Triphop is making a mark and I predict
soon it will be massive too......I hope so.

I ran into a DJ named MATT B who about four years ago was in L.A and was
dicked around by some promoters, and he needed to get to San Fran to make
some $$, so I rented a van and gave him a ride to S.F. he was grateful and
when he left we said if I ever come to the UK, he would take care of
me.....yeah I know BLAH BLAH BLAH.....
well quite by suprize, he was DJ'ing at "THE END" that nite and we had a
wicked time hanging out, he introduced me to tons of cool people, and told
them all I was the only one in California to treat him well.......I have to
say good karma goes a long way, and I am so glad he remembered me and my
good deed......I felt very special and was welcomed even more by many of
his friends.......I am so happy, some day I will look back on these days as
"the good old days"

I'm am totally meeting the most incredible people here........most say good
things about S.F. and they know we go off in San Fran, and many say they
want to come over....... so if you meet a brit who's visiting, be really
nice to them, it will come back to you someday, when you least expect it.

Day 12.......went to another wild underground party in BRIXTON of all
places. now imagine yourself at a wild undergroud party in a totally black
neighbohood, like hunters point. well 20 years ago you would never see a
bunch of white people dancing the night away in Brixton, but wow what a
difference 20 years makes, not only that....the bouncers (totally tuff
looking brothers) were the nicest and friendliest bouncers I have ever had
the pleasure to meet, absolute respect and total harmony. After 11 years of
DJ'ing I have never been treated so nicely as I was by thee fine
boys.......left an indelible impression on my mind.

well lets see its now the 13th day and I am completely exhausted, yet energized.
I have been given some insane promo triphop and can't wait to come home and
play it.

I guess thats all for now......I miss some of you, but I am loving the vibe
here. I wish I could book more work in San Fran, because the way things are
going here, I am in demand here, and I may never come home........sad but
true..

I wan't to thank publicly Eric D. who has been looking after my pad and my
kitties for me, that has allowed me to be here, and I hope to hear from
some of you soon......just e-mail me at

                                        moonpup@hooked.net

and I will eventually recieve it through the labtop, etc.....Eric will save
all impotant e-mails for me........

I love you all and I miss you, I especially miss those of you who have been
so kind to me over the last year....you know who you are......I will see
you all soon......

                         absolutely dileriously happy ..... moonpup

                                (have beats ....will travel)

p.s. personal note to becca kramer......I don't have your e-mail address
with me, can you send me an e-mail with the address so I can send you a
personal e-mail.......thanks hope to hear from you soon........

BEGINNING OF E-MAIL TO SFRAVES 
 
 
Hi folks, 
 
 I finally found my old friend Rick Webb, and he has helped me out by 
letting me use his labtop, so I can communicate with the world, (finally) 
 
I have felt so cut off from my comfort zone, since arriving, as I don't 
have daily access to a computer, but now I should be able to check in about

once every week or so. 
 
To any one who complains that there's not enuff trance and techno in S.F. 
you should come to London........techno and trance are in major abundance 
here..... 
 
here's a basic rundown of some of the shit I've done and heard so far. 
 
Day one.....arrived at noon...no hassles with customs....(to bad I didn't 
bring massive amounts of head wear......)    first shock.....prices and 
cost to travel.   unfucking believable......I have spent 1/2 my $$ in the 
first 10 days of my trip.....bummer....but needed. 
 
day two.....went to my first club....MEGATRIPOLIS thurs nites in Charring
Cross. 
loads of shit happenin there.........interactive computer area, drum room, 
triphop room, main room- (Derrick May played), some guys bring two crates 
of records, and a turntable and you can check out and buy records, right 
there in the club......cool idea..... 
 
lots of interesting things to do. a massage area, lots of toys to play 
with, and most of all loads of people going off......many happy ravers 
here. 
 
I have noticed several major differences here, one is how much smoking goes

on here.....to much for my poor little eyes and lungs, and major drinking 
going on. 
 
heavy alcahol vibe......loads of smoke machines, it's like walking in a 
constant fog.......but I gotta say, a bigger % of people are appearing to 
have a great time, lots of smiley happy people.  however when you leave a 
club atmosphere, you find the people on the streets to be very sad and make

very little eye contact and smiles are rarely exchanged. I miss that about 
S.F 
 
lots of drunken ass holes who abuse womens energy with typical male ego and

neanderthal attitudes..... 
 
however in the clubs, It's completely different. happy smiles and good 
vibes all around. 
 
Day three......mostly rested and found some soccer shirts and just kicked 
it around the city. 
 
Day four......I woke up at 5am and went out to visit my old haunting 
grounds. for those that don't know, I was born and grew up in London, and 
moved to America when I was 12 years old, so I went to visit my old 
neighborhood and schools etc......very spiritual......I must have walked 15

or more miles that day......I totally exausted my poor old feet, they hurt 
for over a week after that (all that walking on concrete).......The Days 
are long as hell here......it begins to get light out at 4:45 in the 
morning, and if your walking home through a park or something you can 
really relate to the orb samples of birds singing and chirping away,(like 
on fluffy clouds etc...) thats something I take for granted in S.F.there 
are so many different kinds of song birds here.....it's beautiful.....it 
stays light out till 9:30 at night, hella long ass days....I didn't realize

how much further north I am, in fact the sun comes up in my bedroom window,

does a horseshoe manuver over my house to the front, and then back to set 
in my bedroom window again. It's alost like living in the north pole. 
 
I went to a brilliant underground club called DELIVERANCE, it was a full on

wharehouse party with 3 rooms of total trance and techno.....and people 
were goin bonkers.....I personally found it to be to much, I mean if you 
are tired of 160 bpm all nite and you want to chill out and find mellower 
music (house, ambient,triphop etc....) forget it......all three rooms were 
playing 160+ all nite long...........even at 5:30am.........no rest for the

wicked, but again I emphasize......tons of happy people enjoying the 
vibe........It is so energizing and fresh to see locals enjoying local DJ's

play the music, it is an infectious feeling, and I find myself to be very 
happy, and content. I am so glad I came........It's awsome to get a 
different perspective, in fact it's life saving. I recomend everyone come 
check it out.......you will learn so much about what is right and wrong 
about the S.F scene.....as well as learn how lucky you are to live in a 
relatively friendly atmosphere (on the streets). 
 
Day five........I left deliverance at about 8:30am and went to chelsea, I 
bought a ticket to a soccer match, and later in the day I saw chelsea play 
Blackburn rovers.....cool game, (except Chelsea lost 3-2). I eventually 
passed out and finally got some sleep...... 
 
Day six........slept all day.....well needed rest 
 
 
Day seven......went out and started to look for a job, (yes I'll be broke 
in 2-3 weeks if I'm not careful)...... 
 
Day eight.......I found an old family friend who runs a recording studio, 
and he ordered me some cassetes at bulk rate prices (tapes cost an arm and 
a leg, not to mention your first born).......and I have been dubbing off 
tapes as fast as I can give them out......I got my first booking for june 
7th at Mr C's club.."THE END" I am totally stoked.......TripHop is just 
beginning to take off here, I could'nt have picked a better time to come 
......... 
 
day nine.......interviewed for a job as a bartender and I think I got 
hired....only bummer is I have to shave my beard off......I love my stoopid

beard, it's so full now, but I guess I'd rather be hairless than pennyless.

 
Day ten.......off to Megatripolis again and finally by chance found my 
friend Rick Webb hanging out......thus I now have a semi computer contact 
and can check in about once a week or so. 
 
Day 11.......I went to "THE END" to see the wierd beats collective, and saw

DEPTH CHARGE perform, fucking brillient........for the first time since 
being in London, I was at home.......awsome triphop and west coast 
breakbeat all night long......I havn't danced like that for a long 
time......fully inspirational and what a great response from the 
crowd....WOW!!!    I really am beginning to see the different vibes, and 
directions of the music now, not as trance and techno oriented as I had 
first thought, many kinds of music are being played here, (albeit trance 
and techno are the biggest)......Triphop is making a mark and I predict 
soon it will be massive too......I hope so. 
 
I ran into a DJ named MATT B who about four years ago was in L.A and was 
dicked around by some promoters, and he needed to get to San Fran to make 
some $$, so I rented a van and gave him a ride to S.F. he was grateful and 
when he left we said if I ever come to the UK, he would take care of 
me.....yeah I know BLAH BLAH BLAH..... 
well quite by suprize, he was DJ'ing at "THE END" that nite and we had a 
wicked time hanging out, he introduced me to tons of cool people, and told 
them all I was the only one in California to treat him well.......I have to

say good karma goes a long way, and I am so glad he remembered me and my 
good deed......I felt very special and was welcomed even more by many of 
his friends.......I am so happy, some day I will look back on these days as

"the good old days" 
 
I'm am totally meeting the most incredible people here........most say good

things about S.F. and they know we go off in San Fran, and many say they 
want to come over....... so if you meet a brit who's visiting, be really 
nice to them, it will come back to you someday, when you least expect it. 
 
Day 12.......went to another wild underground party in BRIXTON of all 
places. now imagine yourself at a wild undergroud party in a totally black 
neighbohood, like hunters point. well 20 years ago you would never see a 
bunch of white people dancing the night away in Brixton, but wow what a 
difference 20 years makes, not only that....the bouncers (totally tuff 
looking brothers) were the nicest and friendliest bouncers I have ever had 
the pleasure to meet, absolute respect and total harmony. After 11 years of

DJ'ing I have never been treated so nicely as I was by thee fine 
boys.......left an indelible impression on my mind. 
 
well lets see its now the 13th day and I am completely exhausted, yet
energized. 
I have been given some insane promo triphop and can't wait to come home and

play it. 
 
I guess thats all for now......I miss some of you, but I am loving the vibe

here. I wish I could book more work in San Fran, because the way things are

going here, I am in demand here, and I may never come home........sad but 
true.. 
 
I wan't to thank publicly Eric D. who has been looking after my pad and my 
kitties for me, that has allowed me to be here, and I hope to hear from 
some of you soon......just e-mail me at 
 
                                        moonpup@hooked.net 
 
and I will eventually recieve it through the labtop, etc.....Eric will save

all impotant e-mails for me........ 
 
I love you all and I miss you, I especially miss those of you who have been

so kind to me over the last year....you know who you are......I will see 
you all soon...... 
 
                         absolutely dileriously happy ..... moonpup 
 
                                (have beats ....will travel) 
 
 
p.s. personal note to becca kramer......I don't have your e-mail address 
with me, can you send me an e-mail with the address so I can send you a 
personal e-mail.......thanks hope to hear from you soon........ 
 
END OF MESSAGE TO SFR

Hello to all you crazy SFRavers!

This past weekend was absolutely amazing! I had so much fun meeting
most of you from this list at Madness on Saturday and Harmony on Sunday.
I don't have my magic memory names notebook with me so I don't think
I can name the 20+ new brothers and sisters that I met this past 
weekend but all of your happy smiles and faces were permanently etched 
in my memory for eternity. 

Thanks again to all the beautiful people who make these incredible
events possible! You probably know this already but you have changed
my life for the better...I now realize that every single person on
this planet is a beautiful person. Even deep down in the hearts of what
used to be my worst enemies there is a seed of pure goodness and it is
my goal in life to help them see and nurture that both inside and out-
side of the rave scene.

I can't wait to see you all again and to meet new family members...
take care of yourselves!

Peace and Love,
John
