>>>>> I REALLY HOPE YOU VOTE NO!
>it's a freedom of speech thing.

No it is not.  It is a democratic process.  You do not have to consider
freedom of speech issues in this regard if one doesn't want to.  Besides,
they can put up a nice big nasty web page.  FOS is the red herring people
love to use.  Sometimes, against all logic.

>if you hated the cda, then you have no
>choice but to vote yes.

Wrong IMO.  They are two seperate issues.  One was decided by congress, the
other BY THE PEOPLE.  This vote, is BY THE PEOPLE (at least those with
computers).  Since there are other avenues for these nitwits to publish
their hate, they need not be on the Usenet.  You want a race free society,
then always vote no on hate.  You want to discuss race well into the 22nd
century?  Provide as many avanues pas possible for racist thought.  They
can put up a web page, keep the bastards off the Usenet.

>better to not vote at all.

People have died so that I can vote.  Even though this is a less democratic
means (I mean the entire population isn't voting, just tech weenies), I see
it as synonymous with voting rights in general.  If you're a person of
color or a woman, you should ALWAYS vote.  People DIED to ensure that you
have that right.

Just the persepective of a person whose father and mother couldn't vote
when he was born.

>have you ever seen how someone posting large binaries uuencoded into
>millions of parts can disrupt a newsgroup?

Happens every day.  Spam is a way of life.  Especially since the internet
flood gates have opened.  Spams becuase of limited speech?  What is this
extortion...either vote yes or the whole USenet goes down?  Whatever, let
it sink.  It damn near rock bottom anyway.

>i seriously doubt that the group
>will ever have any impact.

Funny, people said the exact same thing about Hitler, Mussolini, and
countless other fascist despots.

>it will either A) escalate into a huge flame war
>on every issue

Very few newsgroups are civilized and without flamage.  I always thought
Usenet == flame war.  Try asking a simple question and watch your ass catch
on fire.

>B) get censored by everyone

Censorship CAN be a good thing.  I do not beleive in a free for all where
EVERYTHING goes.  We have to have some standard by which to set a course.
Just because there are pedophiles, does not mean there should be a group
devoted to their eortic binaries.  Just as there are rapists and other
miscreants, does not mean we need to provide a vehicle for their pursuits.
What Americans have yet to understand or grapple with is the RESPONSIBILITY
of free speech.  And responsibility often requires management.  And
management often requires that some things NOT be done.

>C) get spammed so badly that I) sysadmins have no choice but to drop the
>group due to bandwidth concerns  II) it renders the group unreadable  III)
>it gets flooded so badly that messages are lost, destroying the threads.

The s/n ration on usenet is very, very low.  All the items you talked about
are realites now.  Usenet willl not be any worse off by NOT having a bunch
of spuremacists talking about thier music.  Let them put iup very expensive
web pages.  Internet is NOT a democracy, there are millions of people who
are not on the net, as a matter of fact, the majority of the population.
There are plenty of other avenues for racists, and supremacists, to spout
their garabe.  Keep the Usenet in it's presednt state of decay.  Vote NO
for neo-nazi punk bitch mutherfuckers with a 4th grade education, trying to
have thier ideas validated by society.  Skinheads and Nazis, the real
reasons pepper spray was invented.

>so, there really isn't anything to worry about.

I think the survivors of the holocaust would tend to differ.  And I *do*
agree with them in this regard.  Enough is enough.  Stop the hate.  Destroy
it before it ever comes to the surface.  The Usenet will just not be a
media they can exploit.  Vote no for a sane tomorrow.

Peace,
John

P.S.  I wish more people could walk in my shoes, or the shoes of my Jewish
brothers, or the shoes of anyone who has been persecuted for something they
could not help, be it skin color (the most obvious, man we're a limited
species), or a belief system (the least obvious, man we're a limited
species), or gender (man/woman, we're a limited species).  I think if
people did, this world would not only be a better place, but we would
probably have less intellectualization of the harmful things perpetrated in
society.  The only thing I can hope for is as the world becomes more brown
(most of the world *IS* brown, but I'm talkin' about America), the
supremacists of the planet will be relegated to history, where they belong.

Out.

FYI-

---------------Original Message---------------
Hard Copy has turned their fax machine off due to the volume of calls.
There's no point in faxing to that number right now.  As soon as we get
other numbers, I will let you know when to start faxing again!

Because of your efforts, they have FINALLY decided that they need talk to
us and  discuss these issues.



Here's what they had to say...

Attorneys for Hard Copy say that the allegations in the letter and the
breach the Journalists' Code of Ethics are serious and will not go without
serious internal investigation.

Hard Copy attempts to adhere to those Codes of Ethics and are disturbed
that such a large number of them could have been breached in a single
report.

That the producer has been unable to clarify the situation in which the
report was brought to him but that he will meet with the Paramount
attorneys as soon as possible.

It is entirely possible that the "footage" was obtained from a 3rd party
but that it is still the producer's responsibility to substantiate the
relevance and accuracy of the footage.

*****Hard Copy will discuss covering the movement from another angle(see 
below).

They are distressed that I contacted the Society for Professional
Journalism regarding these allegations.

Hard Copy will contact us with a report regarding these issues.

AND LAST BUT DEFINATELY NOT LEAST....

The entire Hard Copy production goes on hiatus in 2 weeks which probably
means they won't be able to do anything for 8-10 weeks! (Can you say "wait
until this all blows over"?)


****** As far as Hard Copy doing another story from a different angle, I am
100% against.  I don't want ANY publicity about our movement anymore...
good or bad.  This will probably start an interesting thread again.  I'm
interested to hear everyone's comments.



Thanks for all of you who called in the 1-900 Hard Copy line.  (They said
that perhaps as much as 75% of the calls they received were defending the
desert-rave movement.)

And thanks to all of you who took the time and faxed in the Code of Ethics!


We've been heard... now let's see if we are listened to.

Please cross post this to all the other mail lists!




-Kc

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue May 14 11:12:57 1996

	id LAA02632; Tue, 14 May 1996 11:12:50 -0700
Date: Tue, 14 May 1996 11:12:50 -0700

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: geoffw@cybetribe.com (Geoff White)
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Re: NRR:Re: Vote NO on neo-nazi-newsgroup (fwd)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

GWhite said to me:
>Do you really think most of the people
>in Nazi Germany were saying "Yeah! Kill ALL JEWS!!" "Yeah!! We'll rule the
>world!!". I bet not,

Be careful how you bet.  There is a raging debate going on right now about
the guilt of Germans in this regard.  A Jewish brother, Daniel J.
Goldhagen, (whose dad survived the Holocaust) wrote a book called "Hitler's
Willing Executioners".  In it he argues that anti-semitism was so ingrained
for the Germans, that to turn them into killing machine state was easy.  He
also counters the argument about people not having ill will toward jews,
and cites, in a most convincing fashion, that the Germans were willing and
eager to rid themselves of the Jews.  Anyway this debate goes on.  I
haven't decided where I stand on this.  Suffice that I do not quickly
beleive in the "I was only following orders" often spouted as a balm for
the marks left by history.

>but I bet most people just went along with the tide,
>they bought into the belief that only criminals, trators and terrorist were
>being
>placed in the "work camps", and it just happened to be that a lot of criminals
>and terrorist HAPPENED to be Jewish (sound familiar folks?). Most folks didn't
>want to know what was going on (this denial exist in the Nazi movement to this
>day), the ones that knew kept quiet least they wind up being branded as a
>dissitant and sent off to a "work camp" themselves, in the end, people
>looked out
>for themselves and their families, remember, Germany was in a state of war,
>the govenment had tremendous power over the population, most people didn't get
>it until they woke up one day and realized they were on a path to Hell. By
>this
>time there cities were being firebombed by the allies and it was too late to
>alter the course.
>

Like I said, there are other trains of thought that dispute the
aforementioned commonly held notion of "following orders".

>So I say folks this is a free country and if I want to talk about LSD or
>MDMA or
>NAZI orientated Rock I should be allowed to.

Oh, I am down with people talking about whatever, and publishing it in
print as well.  But since the Usenet is not part of the public sphere, and
since we can vote against or for it, I stand against them.  And, of course,
vote appropriately.  As for free speech, I have thought about this.  It
seems that the courts have traditionally ruled that free speech has few
limits.  However, taking a look at the medium of said speech, you will find
that free speech right vary depending on the publics capability to respond.
So with TV, you have certain things you can and cannot say, I as a ham
radio operator cannot curse on the air, some restrictions apply to radio
and CATV as well.  But printing is a whole other matter.  In any case,
depending on the medium FOS can be curtailed.  You can't say anything you
want to at work and expect to have a job for instance.  There are limits.

The Internet will be in big trouble in many regards.  And if you *think*
that if portions of CDA are defated they wont return, then I think one
might be mistaken.  The real problem on the net is self-policing.  Right
now it's a free for all, total anarchy in the truest sense.  It doesn't fit
the model of our society, and since it doesn't seem to want to be
self-policing, others wil step in to do the job.  It will happen, it's only
a matter of time, IMO.

>
>People need to first address the racism inside of their own hearts and then
>worry about the exterior manifestation in others.  If you handle the first part
>it makes you stronger when dealing witht the second.
>
>
>                                        G

I agree 100% here G!  Right on!

Subject: Hard Copy RESPONDS!

Hard Copy has turned their fax machine off due to the volume of calls.
There's no point in faxing to that number right now.  As soon as we get
other numbers, I will let you know when to start faxing again!

Because of your efforts, they have FINALLY decided that they need talk to
us and  discuss these issues.



Here's what they had to say...

Attorneys for Hard Copy say that the allegations in the letter and the
breach the Journalists' Code of Ethics are serious and will not go without
serious internal investigation.

Hard Copy attempts to adhere to those Codes of Ethics and are disturbed
that such a large number of them could have been breached in a single
report.

That the producer has been unable to clarify the situation in which the
report was brought to him but that he will meet with the Paramount
attorneys as soon as possible.

It is entirely possible that the "footage" was obtained from a 3rd party
but that it is still the producer's responsibility to substantiate the
relevance and accuracy of the footage.

*****Hard Copy will discuss covering the movement from another angle(see below).

They are distressed that I contacted the Society for Professional
Journalism regarding these allegations.

Hard Copy will contact us with a report regarding these issues.

AND LAST BUT DEFINATELY NOT LEAST....

The entire Hard Copy production goes on hiatus in 2 weeks which probably
means they won't be able to do anything for 8-10 weeks! (Can you say "wait
until this all blows over"?)


****** As far as Hard Copy doing another story from a different angle, I am
100% against.  I don't want ANY publicity about our movement anymore...
good or bad.  This will probably start an interesting thread again.  I'm
interested to hear everyone's comments.



Thanks for all of you who called in the 1-900 Hard Copy line.  (They said
that perhaps as much as 75% of the calls they received were defending the
desert-rave movement.)

And thanks to all of you who took the time and faxed in the Code of Ethics!


We've been heard... now let's see if we are listened to.

Please cross post this to all the other mail lists!

	id QAA22097; Tue, 14 May 1996 16:27:44 -0400
Date: 14 May 96 16:26:31 EDT
From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@CompuServe.COM>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: socializing at raves
Message-ID: <960514202630_71165.755_GHL88-1@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Regarding the conversations about SFR seeming like a "social circle" or "clique"
... some interesting points were brought up ...  and ... surprise, surprise... I
have something to add!

I can see the point that the social aspect of the group can seem alienating if
you didn't go to a certain place, meet certain people, whatever -- There are
lots of people on this list who don't live in the Bay Area, or can't go out
often because of schedules, school, finances, etc.... 

But I for one am VERY THANKFUL for the opportunity to meet so many people with
whom I have one huge thing in common ... we love the music, we love the vibe.  

The SFR picnic for me was an example of that -- it was like going to a family
reunion where you don't really know all the people who are there, but you have
an undeniable common thread, so there's never a question of whether you belong
there or not.  If you're there, you belong.

When I post what I'm wearing, it's my sincere invitation for any SFRaver to come
up to me and introduce themselves, so we can meet face to face.  I love that.
When I post after a party and list the people I met, it's my way of saying
"thank you for being part of one of the most important nights of my week" to
those people (sometimes because I wasn't able to express that in person at the
party for whatever reason, mental incapacity/ sound too loud/ got lost,
whatever).

For those of you who feel like you're on the outside looking into a smaller
group, come on in!  There's no secret password, there's no attitude, everyone is
part of this family if they want to be .. and there's still plenty of room for
your own individuality in the group, too.
 
Don't want to post?  You don't have to, but it's a good idea, because then we
get to recognize your name and know a little about you when we meet in person.
Even if you're not ready to post, seek out someone you recognize as an SFRaver
when you're out, because you'll quickly discover the warm welcome you'll
receive!  

Leslie  : )

Dear John,
        I just wanted to say thank you for making the points you did,
before I got a chance to. I hope that some of the people out there THINK
before forming an opinion. I would just like to add that this is an online
"community" that we are participating in. It is a privilege to be
participating in it, not a right. It is my hard-earned privilege! I
particularly don't want racists and other people filled with hate hogging
up my bandwidth and blabbering in our online community.
I would like to think that this is a community of intelligent people (with
open minds) open to discussing problems and ideas. It is our privilege to
exclude people who we don't think fit into our community, and might
possibly destroy the amazing thing we have going on here. Racism brings
nothing positive to a community.
     By letting them have their own news group we are telling them that it
is ok for them as human beings to be racist and hate. If we as a species
are to evolve and succeed than we must get past these idiotic issues of
race, color and creed.
It takes all of the colors in the rainbow to make a beautiful painting. :-)



Jon

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Tim (knucklehead)" <knucklehead@email.org>
Subject: Weekend decision, RE: Madness
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, it was very clear to me after this weekend, Madness being the one
thing that made up my mind for me. I had one of the best times in my life
at Madness. The love and energy I felt that night completely over whelmed
me. I'm not ashamed to admit that when I was heading home to Sunnyvale, all
I did was think about what an incredible time I had. I put in a mix tape
and just remembered the whole night. I actually got choked up and teary
eyed I was soooo happy and felt sooo good. I have decided that I'm going to
move to SF. Just thinking about it right now makes me so incredibly warm
inside I'm getting choked up now. I have never felt like this ever. I feel
I can move a mountain right now. Saturday night had such an impact on me. I
really don't know why. I have always had a good time at other events.
Madness wasn't even one of the best parties I have went to before. All I
can say is that it was the people and the love I shared with the ones I was
with at Madness that hit me hard. So, I'm moving up here. I want to be a
little closer to what and who I love. I just want to say thank you again to
those that put on Madness and all the people that made this event one for
me to remember and love for a long time. God, I FEEL so good right now. It
is still very overwhelming. I wish Everyone can feel what I'm feeling right
now.


Tim (knucklehead)

John Lee-

You made some excellent, well-articulated points.... after reading your 
posts, I *did* seriously reconsider my position on this issue--

But I did not change it.   I may be new to this list, but I'm not new to 
this sort of debate.   While I was in college getting my poli/sci degree 
in Iowa, I did hardcore battle with the (then blossoming) Christian 
Coalition.   In our student government (UI being a Big Ten school) 
there is a fund of over $1mil of student fees to be allocated to student 
groups by the student senate.  Of course, our rabid rightwinger friends 
had a large presence in this senate, and we did some very serious, 
emotionally-charged debating on the senate floor about this subject:  

should a group of people with a "hate-oriented" agenda be allowed to pull 
resources away from "positive-oriented" groups?  (Replace "resources" 
with the words "bandwidth" or "s/n ratio".)

This is a very healthy, very American debate.  One which should never 
stop being discussed.  Why, as a progressive/radical in the student 
senate, did I vote to allow student groups like the "Heterosexual Rights 
Coalition" or "Young Americans for Freedom" to receive student funds?  
Because as long as this is a free country, EVERYONE must be allowed to 
speak, whether hate-mongering murderers, pedophiles, etc.    

How else can the rest of us "know thy enemy"?   How else can we ensure 
that groups considered "dangerous" by cultural dominators like Newt or
Rush or even Senator Exon are allowed free speech in some future time 
when this country is (even more) dominated by right-wingers?  
(For instance, gays, "one-worlders", the cypherpunks, or the extropians, or 
even deadheads--!)  

Should Dole win, and Congress remain Republican, don't you want the 
ABSOLUTE RIGHT of EVERYONE to be allowed a forum on Usenet?   

Many of the descriptive language you use to villify the skinheads, etc 
(although I agree strongly with you), can and may also be used to 
villify legitimate, positive communities--- if the people doing the 
describing have the attitude of "well, there is a precedent for banning 
this kind of dangerous speech--- like when the Usenet community 
disallowed those disturbed young Aryans a forum".

or how bout this one:   "sure there's free speech, all you need is the 
money to put up a website".   Are you *really* saying that one must have 
money to speak one's mind?   IMHO, this is exactly what makes the net so 
much more empowering than major media outlets like TV stations and radio 
stations:   many-to-many, without the need for good-ol-boy networks of 
rich fatcats, whose asses need kissing for access to "public airspace".

While your points are well thought-out and beautifully articulated, I 
hope you will consider mine before continuing your passionate arguments.

peaceout
cubensis

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: Andrew Knutsen <andrewk@sco.COM>
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Re: Vote NO on neo-nazi-newsgroup (fwd)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>>      By letting them have their own news group we are telling them that it
>> is ok for them as human beings to be racist and hate.
>>
>> >Stop the hate.  Destroy
>> >it before it ever comes to the surface.
>
>        Um...  wouldn't it be more effective just to go over there and shoot
>them all?  Or, we could be humane, and lock them up in camps...  yeah,
>thats the
>ticket.

It all depends on how you interpreted my words.  One can engage in battle
many ways, some peaceful some not.  The more non-peaceful methods can come
into play if all peaceful methods have been exhausted.

Hate, IMO, is not to be tolerated.  This is not an intellectual concept.
Hatred is sheer illogic.  To give it any merit, as if it serves some
function other than the destruction of others, would not allow any
civilization to progress but so far.  History has taught us this lesson all
to well.

I choose to fight racism via my words.  And through my actions I defy it.
But if *they* wish to deprive me the opportunity to live, through *action*,
then I'll have no other choice but to react in kind.  But I digress...

And as for locking people up in camps, so far, some of the victims of this
procedure in America to date have been Native Americans, African Americans,
Japanese Americans, and Chinese Americans, oh yeah Hatians, Cubans...I
think the last thing we have to worry about is a bunch of white
supremacists getting put into concentration camps.

>
>        Be very careful you don't end up playing the same game you started out
>to end...  And remember the tighter you hold the lid on, the faster the water
>boils.

I am very concious of the results of burying racism.  But I find lately too
many all to eager to allow racism a pulpit from which to speak.  I was not
implying keeping any lid on, I wished restraint in one medium.  I do not
believe that all concepts are absolute.  To say that one should be able to
say *ANYTHING* at *ANYTIME* is rubbish.  We KNOW there are boundaries.
What I suggest is that, since we pay to be online, and it is a privilege
not a right, and since things are done by consensus, that people act in a
way that solidifies the community, not destroy it.  It would be like
inviting the worst denizens of the night into a safe neighborhood all for
the sake of diversity.  Even the concept of diversity has limits.

I just say since we do have a choice, reject it.  Without fear that they
will not have a voice.  They can choose other avenues.  Just as mainstream
TV, or public TV rejects this drivel, so should we.  They have other ways
to communicate their message, it shouldn't be on my time, or subsidized
with my dime!

>
>        Let them have their damn newsgroup, then use it to tell them (and
>the rest of the world) what you think of them.
>
>Andrew
>-----------------------------------------
>Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com
>Santa Cruz Operation      (408) 427-7538

I prefer a pre-emptive method.  Your points are well taken, and I agree
with some of what you said.  I just think you characterized my words
incorrectly.

Peace out,
John

Time to put those hours upon hours of useless web surfing experience to work!

area.  Be creative in your search and may it yeild a place worthy to shake
our booties.  At this point I think we're open to cabins, campgrounds,
backwoods resorts, etc.  You'll know what will work when it finds you.

or large groups",  "amenities", "rented by owner" etc.  Keywords that might
help are "Yosemite", "vacation properties", "rentals", "retreats", "group
camping" etc.  BTW: the national parks Yosemite web sight sucks up there with
the worst of em!

Lanier [lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.edu]***

At  4:32 PM 5/14/96 -0700, John S. Lee wrote:
>>>      By letting them have their own news group we are telling them that it

>>> >it before it ever comes to the surface.

>>them all?  Or, we could be humane, and lock them up in camps...  yeah,
>>thats the
>>ticket.
>
>It all depends on how you interpreted my words.  One can engage in battle
>many ways, some peaceful some not.  The more non-peaceful methods can come
>into play if all peaceful methods have been exhausted.
>
>Hate, IMO, is not to be tolerated.  This is not an intellectual concept.
>Hatred is sheer illogic.  To give it any merit, as if it serves some
>function other than the destruction of others, would not allow any
>civilization to progress but so far.  History has taught us this lesson all
>to well.
>
>I choose to fight racism via my words.  And through my actions I defy it.
>But if *they* wish to deprive me the opportunity to live, through *action*,
>then I'll have no other choice but to react in kind.  But I digress...
>
>And as for locking people up in camps, so far, some of the victims of this
>procedure in America to date have been Native Americans, African Americans,
>Japanese Americans, and Chinese Americans, oh yeah Hatians, Cubans...I
>think the last thing we have to worry about is a bunch of white
>supremacists getting put into concentration camps.
>
>>
>>        Be very careful you don't end up playing the same game you started out
>>to end...  And remember the tighter you hold the lid on, the faster the water
>>boils.
>
>I am very concious of the results of burying racism.  But I find lately too
>many all to eager to allow racism a pulpit from which to speak.  I was not
>implying keeping any lid on, I wished restraint in one medium.  I do not
>believe that all concepts are absolute.  To say that one should be able to
>say *ANYTHING* at *ANYTIME* is rubbish.  We KNOW there are boundaries.
>What I suggest is that, since we pay to be online, and it is a privilege
>not a right, and since things are done by consensus, that people act in a
>way that solidifies the community, not destroy it.  It would be like
>inviting the worst denizens of the night into a safe neighborhood all for
>the sake of diversity.  Even the concept of diversity has limits.
>
>I just say since we do have a choice, reject it.  Without fear that they
>will not have a voice.  They can choose other avenues.  Just as mainstream
>TV, or public TV rejects this drivel, so should we.  They have other ways
>to communicate their message, it shouldn't be on my time, or subsidized
>with my dime!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue May 14 20:35:25 1996

>John Lee-
>
>You made some excellent, well-articulated points.... after reading your
>posts, I *did* seriously reconsider my position on this issue--
>
>But I did not change it.   I may be new to this list, but I'm not new to
>this sort of debate.   While I was in college getting my poli/sci degree
>in Iowa, I did hardcore battle with the (then blossoming) Christian
>Coalition.   In our student government (UI being a Big Ten school)
>there is a fund of over $1mil of student fees to be allocated to student
>groups by the student senate.  Of course, our rabid rightwinger friends
>had a large presence in this senate, and we did some very serious,
>emotionally-charged debating on the senate floor about this subject:
>
>should a group of people with a "hate-oriented" agenda be allowed to pull
>resources away from "positive-oriented" groups?  (Replace "resources"
>with the words "bandwidth" or "s/n ratio".)
>
>This is a very healthy, very American debate.  One which should never
>stop being discussed.  Why, as a progressive/radical in the student
>senate, did I vote to allow student groups like the "Heterosexual Rights
>Coalition" or "Young Americans for Freedom" to receive student funds?
>Because as long as this is a free country, EVERYONE must be allowed to
>speak, whether hate-mongering murderers, pedophiles, etc.
>

Depending upon, of course, who owns the medium.  That right is not
instantaneously transferrable.  And that is the real issue here.  By
consensus, everyone on the net owns it, and has a voice.  These people are
not representatives of the public, but a sector of the public.  The medium
is governed by these people, not the public.  The internet is NOT a public
resource, it requires money to maintain and participate in.  I do not think
such a vehicle, since it is not owned by public or public interests (really
just small and large companies), the same rules of free speech do not
apply.  The courts have ruled time and time again on these instances.  It
may be illegal to hand out pamphlets against your company on their lot.
The rules of free speech do not necessarily hold.  You might have to go off
of their property to excersize the right.  The right of freedom of speech
does have some domain limitations.  And *I* think the internet, in its
present form, should be ruled likewise.  At least by some consensus of
behavior by the participants.  This vote is a display of that ideal.

Since I have a say, since I pay for the medium, I vote to exclude, with the
consideration being that they have other means.  Even creating the group
itself, and letting people cancel it at their sites.  Whatever.  The vote
is a symbol of my belief about something that has torn the fabric of
humanity since we started.  And people, still want to talk about it.  Yes,
it needs a forum, but I do not think the notion of hate is legitimate.  It
is like the discussion of a flat earth.  A waste of time.

Hate has no useful purpose.  It is a destroyer.  It has other avenues, the
Use net for now should be spares any more rubbish.


>How else can the rest of us "know thy enemy"?  How else can we ensure
>that groups considered "dangerous" by cultural dominators like Newt or
>Rush or even Senator Ex on are allowed free speech in some future time
>when this country is (even more) dominated by right-winger s?
>(For instance, gays, "one-world-wide", the cypher punks, or the
>extroversion, or
>even deadheads--!)

Through their good use of CATV, Public Access, News Print, radio stations,
videos, training camps, etc.


>
>Should Dole win, and Congress remain Republican, don't you want the
>ABSOLUTE RIGHT of EVERYONE to be allowed a forum on Use net?
>
>Many of the descriptive language you use to villify the skinheads, etc
>(although I agree strongly with you), can and may also be used to
>villify legitimate, positive communities--- if the people doing the
>describing have the attitude of "well, there is a precedent for banning
>this kind of dangerous speech--- like when the Use net community
>disallowed those disturbed young Aryans a forum".

There are few words or phrases that are immune to distortion.  No matter
what is said.  I am not for censoring them, just deny them one medium, one
that I happen to own a small piece of.  I don't want to subsidize their
message or thoughts.  If you want to have the group fine, but excluding
them is an option also.  I think many providers will chose that route.
Remember, there are OTHER avenues and mediums to get their message out.

>
>or how bout this one:   "sure there's free speech, all you need is the
>money to put up a website".   Are you *really* saying that one must have
>money to speak one's mind?

Name the person who doesn't pay for Internet access.  Everyone pays,
somehow, somewhere.  Since it is subsidized by those who pay to use the
services, then they should have rights to exclude what they wish.
Especially if it violates a "community standard".  I think the net
qualifies as a community of sorts.  This is NOT unconstitutional per se.

As for the financial aspect, already answered.  The people in this country
who have a voice have money.  We are not heard due to the noise.
Unfortunately free speech has become bound by the dollar in most cases.
Sad but true.

this is not my ideal however, but it is a reality of the net.  You need
money to get & stay connected.  No money, no net voice.

>IMHO, this is exactly what makes the net so
>much more empowering than major media outlets like TV stations and radio
>stations:   many-to-many, without the need for good-ol-boy networks of
>rich fatcats, whose asses need kissing for access to "public airspace".

I hate that word, it's so overused, empowering that is.  The net is
empowering for those who have some mastery of the technology and have no
phobias.  The net is still too expensive for people on limited incomes, or
the poor.  Most of America is NOT wired.

The empowerment is of those who know the technology and are able to master
it to a degree.  Let's no forget the large number of people, not connected,
who have no voice.  Either on the net, or in real life.

>
>While your points are well thought-out and beautifully articulated, I
>hope you will consider mine before continuing your passionate arguments.
>

I also thought your points were good and valid.  The purpose is not to
necessarily sway your thinking, or change your mind.  Just want to discuss
other components of speech.  Things that make it tricky, at least to me.

Anyway, this thread is getting long.  I think the subject is quite relevant
to raves.  We engage in some provocative discussion here, and I think it is
proper to analyze the many sides of speech and how it might affect us.  For
instance, what happens a larger numbers of people join, and change the
demographic of the net.  What happens when there is a vote to not allow any
more drug discussion.

Lists are immune from this, so far.


>peaceout
>cubensis



Peace,
John

don't claim that you'd like to prevent them from doing so in the name of

> If we as a species are to evolve and succeed than we must get past these

Ok fellow ravers here is where your raver abilities will be tested.  The 
UCSC gate is hard to get through w/out a UCSC parking permit and parking 
on campus is difficult.  However there is a bus stop right outside the 
front gate and if you get on that you can or the UCSC shuttles you can 
get right on the campus.  The shuttles stop running @ 12:00 and the buses 
stop @ 1:00.  Please keep this in mind but DONT LET IT INHIBIT you!

Precedence: bulk

Just thought I'd pass this on for yor information.Seems like DXM
(robotussin) is the main culprit in the fake e's that have been floating
around ( and not MDA, ketamine, speed, heroin, pcp or any other alleged
culprits).

MAPS MDMA Analysis Project

Rick Doblin

In February and March of 1996, people from around the United States and
England sent MDMA for analysis to a licensed testing facility. The purpose of
the study was to gather information about the quality of the MDMA being sold
on the underground market in the United States and England. Information about
the quality of MDMA is necessary in order to estimate the dangers faced by
users of illicitly manufactured and distributed MDMA and to place reports of
adverse effects in some context. 

A total of 33 samples were tested, 22 from the United States, 10 from England
and 1 from South Africa. Quantitative and qualitative analyses were conducted
on all the samples. The total cost of the study was $3,520. Nicholas
Saunders, author of E for Ecstasy, Ecstasy and the Dance Culture and the
forthcoming Dance,Trance and Transformation, donated $1,650 to MAPS for the
study. An additional $1,100 was donated to MAPS for the study from High Times
Magazine. A total of $660 came from MAPS' general fund and the remaining $110
was paid directly by a private individual. 

Technological Limitations
The testing was conducted with a gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer (GC/MS).
The gas chromatograph separates the different components of the sample. The
mass spectrometer identifies the atomic composition of each of the
components. This data is then compared by a computer to a data base of
hundreds of known drugs and other compounds to see if there are any matches.
In this way, many of the ingredients in the samples can be identified.

There are some limitations to the GC/MS technology. Certain inorganic and
some organic compounds may not volatilize and/or chromatograph and therefore
would not be detected. These compounds include baking soda, baby powder and
certain sugars that are sometimes used to dilute cocaine and other drugs in
powder form such as MDMA. There also may be many compounds that can be
detected by the GC/MS technology but are not contained in the computer data
base and therefore cannot be identified. 

United States Samples
We were fortunate to obtain a rather good geographic distribution of the 22
samples from the United States. Five samples came from New York State, of
those 3 came from New York City and 2 from other parts of the state. Three
samples came from near Chicago, Illinois. One sample was from Minneapolis, 1
from Eunice, Louisiana (near Baton Rouge), 1 from Charlotte, North Carolina
and 1 from Sarasota, Florida. Ten samples came from California, of those 3
were from San Francisco and 7 were from the Santa Barbara/Los Angeles area.
Despite the fact that the samples were from around the country, there is no
way to determine if they comprise a representative sample of the MDMA being
sold in the United States. Therefore, the results from this study can be used
only to draw inferences and not conclusions about the content of the pills
and capsules being sold as MDMA in the United States. Furthermore, according
to Nicholas Saunders, "you cannot be sure that any pill that looks similar to
the ones illustrated will have similar contents. When a pill earns a good
reputation, it is frequently exploited by dud lookalikes after a few weeks,
and the same press may be used for completely different ingredients."

Of the 22 samples from the United States, 17 were tablets and 5 were
capsules. Eight out of the 22 samples had no MDMA at all. Interestingly, all
the capsules contained MDMA while only about half of the tablets did so. Of
those samples that did contain MDMA, the highest dose was 119 mg. The lowest
was 45 mg. Of the 14 samples that contained MDMA, the average dose was 79 mg.
This average is significantly lower than the standard dose sold before the
criminalization of MDMA which was in the range of 100-125 mg. Doses lower
than 100 mg. are generally considered to be below the level at which many
people will feel the full effects of MDMA. 

Of the 14 samples that contained MDMA, only 1 also contained another
psychoactive compound identified by the GC/MS. That sample was a tablet from
New York State that contained MDMA and caffeine. In the remaining 13 samples,
MDMA was 100% of only three of those samples, all capsules from San
Francisco. The other samples contained a range of percentages of other
ingredients that were not measured by the GC/MS technology. For example, the
capsule of MDMA from Santa Barbara was only 59% MDMA, the capsule from
Sarasota was 85% MDMA and the tablet from New York City was 25% MDMA. While
these unidentified ingredients could have been another psychoactive
ingredient or a byproduct of manufacturing, they were not cocaine, heroin,
barbiturates, benzodiazapines, tranquilizers, hypnotics, ketamine,
methamphetamine, amphetamine or any of several hundred other compounds. Some
of these unidentified ingredients were fillers or binding agents used in the
manufacture of the tablets. Whether these unidentified ingredients are toxic
cannot be determined. The common rumor that MDMA is frequently cut with
heroin was not substantiated. 

Of the 8 samples that contained no MDMA, 2 contained the psychoactive drug
MDE (3,4-methylenedioxyethylamphetamine), a chemical cousin of MDMA that
generates an emotional reaction that is not quite as profound as that of
MDMA, and 1 contained an unidentified compound. The remaining 5 contained
various combinations of ingredients found in over-the-counter preparations
including dextromethorphan (an ingredient found in cough suppressants that
has an alcohol-like psychoactive effect especially in higher doses),
ephedrine/pseudoephedrine (a stimulant found in many plants, over-the-counter
medicines and Herbal Ecstacy and other similar pseudo-MDMA products),
phenylpropanolamine (a decongestant and mild stimulant found in cold
medicines), and glyceryl guaiacolate (a compound that dries sinuses and is an
expectorant). 
The ingredients in the samples that did not contain MDMA raise some degree of
concern since the interaction of genuine MDMA and ephedrine/pseudoephedrine
could provoke a significant elevation in blood pressure. Such interactions
could occur if someone were to take two different samples at a time, one
containing genuine MDMA and the other containing ephedrine/pseudoephedrine.
In one case, a person who had taken 20 mg. of pseudoephedrine in the morning
and MDMA later in the day reported having transitory severe anginal chest
pain.

England and South Africa Samples

Just like the samples from the United States, the 10 samples from England and
the 1 sample from South Africa are not necessarily representative of the MDMA
being sold in those countries.
Of the 10 samples from England, five contained MDMA. Three of these 5 samples
contained only MDMA, 1 contained a small amount of caffeine in addition to
the MDMA and 1 contained some MDE in addition to the MDMA. The average dose
of MDMA in these five samples was 128 mg., substantially larger than the
average dose of the samples from the United States. The only psychoactive
compound detected in 3 samples was MDE. In 2 samples the only psychoactive
compound detected was caffeine. Thus, 8 out of 10 samples contained some MDMA
or MDE, two drugs with a somewhat similar subjective effect. The 1 sample
from South Africa contained only one psychoactive ingredient, MDMA, and a
very substantial dose of 138 mg.

Conclusion
All the capsules from the United States contained MDMA while only about half
the tablets did so. The samples with MDMA were likely to be weak, averaging
only 79 mg., well below the standard dose generally considered to be in the
range of 100-125 mg. The one capsule from England contained caffeine and only
half the tablets contained MDMA, averaging 128 mg. per tablet. It seems that
the doses of MDMA in the United States are lower than those in England,
perhaps a contributing factor in the virtual absence of MDMA-related deaths
in the United States.

Four out of 10 samples from England contained MDE while only 2 samples out of
22 in the United States contained MDE. Perhaps there are differential
penalties between MDMA and MDE in some countries in Europe, in the United
States both MDMA and MDE carry the same penalty.
While there were no toxic additives found in any of the samples, there were
unidentified ingredients in virtually all the samples. It is possible that
all of these compounds were benign fillers or binders of some sort used in
the manufacturing of the tablets or benign "cuts" used to expand the amounts
of the powder. However, the safety of MDMA tablets and capsules cannot be
determined with certainty. Nevertheless, the claims that MDMA is frequently
mixed with crushed glass, rat poison, heroin and other dangerous substances
has not been substantiated.*

NOTE:  If any MAPS readers are interested in obtaining anonymous,
qualitative-only analyses of samples of illicitly manufactured drugs, Drug
Detection Laboratories will conduct such analyses for $100. Samples should be
sent in a crush-proof manner to DDL, 3117 Fite Circle, Suite 104, Sacramento,
CA 95827, (916) 366-3113. Include a note that indicates what you think the
drug is supposed to be and assign a six-digit code number to your sample so
that you can call  DDL about two weeks after your sample would have been
received to learn the results anonymously. Please indicate that you read
about DDL in MAPS.
marcus@technologik.com

In-Reply-To: <01BB4002.F1B7FDE0@n145.solano.community.net>

Precedence: bulk

Four of us made the trek from Napa down to Experience. There were several 
downsides to the party, mainly fairly dark, minimal lighting, little 
decoration and visuals, and quite a bit of heat, although it was not that 
bad. These were only minor irritations compared to the awesome trance 
that flowed nonstop. The music was totally mental, just the way I love 
it. The real problem came from the water situation. What water they had 
was $2 a bottle and that supply ran out by three AM. After that people 
just had to start leaving or risk severe dehydration. It thinned out 
quickly and cooled down some but when they still had no water at just 
after 5 am my friends and I left. It really was too bad because the music 
was so phenomanal.  This is the second GK production with a solid goa 
room I have been to and because of this I will look for them in the future, 
but the water situation HAS to be better planned. 

Now before everyone thinks this was a terrible event, I have to say in 
the smaller goa room people were going crazy all night, letting the dj's 
know how good the music was, I met many happy people (including some guys 
who just moved here from Chicago, so we welcomed them as best we could, 
they were used to larger parties with more people sitting around i.e. not 
as much dancing), gave out a couple of bananas and a bunch of candy I 
brought. Sounds like madness was excellent but I wouldn't trade my 
"experience" as each event builds toward a collective experience and I 
can't say I have ever been to a terrible one yet.

Til next weekend at Space teddy and the BTB (in rave costume)
  Austin                             
  Tinsau                    

            S.F. Born and Raved!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed May 15 01:23:03 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id BAA13907; Wed, 15 May 1996 01:23:03 -0700

From: Cassandra Ann Thomas <senator@leland.Stanford.EDU>

Subject: Re: a couple of weekends worth (long). . .
In-Reply-To: <199605131044.DAA22088@well.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.93.960515010624.7343A-100000@elaine29.Stanford.EDU>

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear Fred:

My boyfriend who used to rave a few years ago but stopped was expressing 
some of the same sentiments as you were in the text.  In his opinion
there is no such thing as rave anymore becuase for him it has forgotten
its original purpose when it moved into the clubs and out of the
warehouses ( a movement which I fear will only be continued with the
introduction of the stadium in China Basin).  From what I understood the 
increase in the price of admission and the movemment into spaces where
the spectacle of the rave seems to become focused back onto the pony
show of a lot of clubs and not the music and the vibe it creates is
abhorrent.  I began to rave a lot later than him and though I am aware
of the times and the history of Mr. Floppy, Sharon, and so on I was not
ready at the time to be a part of it though I am only a year younger than
him. I understand the scene has changed and in some ways I agree with him
zzzzbut I also know that I have to find my own path as does the scene.  
Change, it should be stated is inevitable as eenergy of any time is not
static but in flux.

I guess what I am wondering from the older timers is why they think the
scene has changed and why they think the change has been ineffective if it
has been.  I was not part of the early rave scene but I still have what I
think have been some tremendously transcendentsl experiances.  I raved at
BI this weekend and though the vibe was at first hard for me to enter I
still tripped solely off the music and at times with the person I was with
:).  I suspect this is a transition time for the scene, maybe it won't
continue but that shouldn't be necessarily bemoaned.  I guess the
question should be if the values are being forgotten.  If the values are
being forgotten than we have a problem.

I was interested in finding out kore about "healing raves" like Mission
Vortex.  I have met people from England who have come to SF simply becuase
because they consider the scene in CA to be more spiritual.  Has anyone
been to one? Is it true?  Just some thoughts . . Maybe it is time to
reexamine what we are doing and try something new .v.vwhat would people
like to see?

Musing,

Cassandra

 On Mon, 13 May 1996, Fred Heutte wrote:

> 
> Sorta dropped the ball on saying anything about last weekend.
> 
> First I should mention Susie's most excellent birthday party, where
> the apple and pear cider were definitely better than my mixing :)
> I missed Harmony as a result but had a real good time anyway,
> especially my periodic geekfest with Laura, one of the chief geeks
> at Infogeek, I mean Infoseek :)
> 
> Last Saturday was the sfraves picnic, about which nuff said except
> the weather was awesome and so was the music and the company.  
> 
> I went to Down to Earth, the Pacific/Sunset party, on Saturday night,
> in a very interesting gallery/performance art place at 21st and Mission.
> There is another party there next week, I think (different organizers).
> I didn't have a chance to talk with Polliwog about it since she was
> spinning at the time :)  but I gather she is involved with this space
> on an ongoing basis.  John Howard was down in the basement playing
> really cool jazzy stuff, a real treat for me at 3 am instead of the
> usual bang-yer-noggin stuff.  I stuck around for some of Galen's set
> and then went to Wicked, but it just didn't do anything for me so
> I went home a bit early.
> 
> Sunday afternoon was my first Sunset of the year, and fine one, if a
> bit on the chilly side.  Alex really impressed me and managed to keep
> everything going despite the fact he was playing (techno) at sunset!
> 
> Sunday night was like a flashback to my raving past, circa 1992.  Three
> places, two and a half misses.  I got to 1190 Folsom (ok, 683 Clementina
> since you have to go in the back door) after midnight, after the Ameba
> crew had already cleared out.  This was for the Sci Fi Club, where
> Brenda and I had a memorable evening a few weeks back.  But this time,
> it was Not Happening -- about 20 people in the dance room listlessly
> shuffling to the usual hard trance stuff, and five people in the bar --
> two DJs, a bartender, another customer and me.  I drank a beer and split.
> I missed the Sub Base party down at 290 Howard by a short bit, by the
> time I got there it was already closed down.  They had a nice flyer,
> has anyone been since?  Finally, since I was nearby, I dropped into Spundae.
> I really don't care for the space or the crowd, but James Christian from
> NYC, whose records I like quite a bit, was playing so I had a chance to
> check him out.  Standard NY club/hard house, nothing spectacular.  I did
> have a chance to meet Peter, one of the co-promoters of Spundae.  They're
> quite busy now -- doing Nikita on Friday at 1015, Spundae on you-know-when,
> and out of town events on Saturday, the first of which was here in Portland
> last night.
> 
> Monday I shopped for records and found excellent jungle/drum + bass at
> Zebra in the lower Haight.  Definitely check them out.  Tweekin continues
> to please me with their broad and deep house selection, and they're adding
> more techno and jungle as well.  I heard (and passed) on both new albums
> by Underworld and Orbital.  Finally checked back in at Ameba and spun a
> bit before heading out of town.  Got my cool-as-you-like Tribal Future
> tickets, get yers soon!
> 
> This past weekend was a bit more restricted as I have a big work project
> I'm wrapping up.  But we did our first Portland outdoor event this year,
> organized by Jeremy.  This was at a beautiful spot right on the Columbia
> River, across from about NE 15th in Portland.  It drizzled but never got
> too wet.  Toonz by Cory West, Jeff (who brought out a fine speaker system),
> yrs trly and Jeremy, whose was unfortunately shut down due to the generator
> running out of gas :-)  I played both LTJ Bukem's "Rain Fall" and Hardkiss'
> "River and Rain" in honor of the humidity :)  About 40 people showed up,
> many from Seattle, and despite the weather it was a nice way to start up.
> Jeremy's got one a month scheduled at various Vancouver area locations
> through the summer.  
> 
> Last night, Spundae brought their road show to Portland.  Lots of
> production,
> lasers, big sound, two full rooms of stuff, at Roseland.  I mostly stayed
> in the main room where Carlos kicked off a big charge and led into a nearly
> three-hour set by the Deep Dish guys, Dubfire and Sharam, who traded off
> three-and-three for the entire set.  They spun very well though not like
> DJs do, more like record producers do (which they are).  Lots of test
> pressings, not much continuity from track to track but lots of excellent
> ones.  Vocals, hard house, tracky stuff all mixed together.  Carlos and
> Brenda and I had a good time funking out bigtime to some of the tunes
> early in the set.  
> 
> Very little vibe of any note, but the crowd was relatively relaxed.  I saw
> one of the local promoters breaking up a big circle early in the Deep Dish
> set.  A half a dozen guys with satin jacket emblazoned with their Breaks
> Crew name showed up, one even had a crash helmet on his head.  I guess
> they were determined to be the show.  The promoter had other ideas.  He
> told them off, they grumbled a bunch and then melted.  This thing about
> ravers and circle dancers is like the mods and rockers.  It's a culture
> clash that won't go away.  It'll be interesting to see how this progresses.
> 
> The Spundae party here is the wave (rave) of the future, I think.  Say
> goodbye to warehouse parties.  I haven't been to a one in Portland in
> years that really has had much going for it.  Occasional sets -- DRC
> a couple of weeks ago, Emma last fall, Derrick Carter's awesome three-deck
> mix, Garth a way long time ago -- stand out for me, but I've never had a
> *good* time at one of these.  Spundae had a bit more of an age mix and
> clearly these big-production affairs in club spaces are where things are
> going.  We are about to witness the Americanization of the UK club scene,
> and this is the precursor.  Spundae is starting down the path of the
> superclub model, where they build up a name, a local crowd, bring in
> the big name DJs, and then starting planting their operation all around
> the country.  I wish Spundae well but their concept and their crowd are
> not what I got into all this for, although I certainly enjoyed the music
> last night.  
> 
> For $16, everyone got a good deal at Spundae, but I still prefer to haul
> equipment across the sand and play outside . . .
> 
> phred
>

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 14 May 1996 21:10:07 -0700 (PDT) 
From: Ariel Meadow Stallings <ameadow@u.washington.edu>
Cc: nw-raves@hyperreal.com
Subject: A great story 


Listen I just have to share this one little bit of a much larger party
story (which, if you'd like the unabridged version, can be found at
http://weber.u.washington.edu/~ameadow/imri.html tomarrow)...

I went to a party in SF last weekend with this guy named Imri.  His deal
is that he travels for a living, selling a bizarre pink industrial cleaser
called "Magic."  His job is just an excuse to travel to as many cities as
possible and enjoy raves all over the country.  So, he and I were dancing
our asses off at this great little soiree called Madness, and he leans
over and says "Don't you feel right at home?"  There I was in S.E. San
Francisco, with 400 people I didn't know (including Imri himself, I met
him by asking a clerk in a store who I could hook a ride with) and yet
strangely, I had to say "Yeah..."  He continued on to say "This is what I
love about this community...no matter what city I'm in, or what the hell
else is going on, once the music starts, and it's me and all these people
dancing, I'm right at home."  It was true.  I was at home.

What a great feeling.

Ariel

     The Something Free crews' experience last weekend really makes me 
     burn, because it reminds me of something very similar that happened to 
     me.  (A couple of gang kids--at least they were flying the colors and 
     tats--were trying to steal my poor Vespa when I came out of an event, 
     and then proceeded to pull a gun on me when I protested. I made a 
     bunch of noise, and they used the gun to put a big dent in the freshly 
     painted cowl. :(
     
     What is the freaking story????  It seems like if you go to an UG these 
     days, you see a bunch of kids hanging in the parking area with no 
     intention of going in, and ready to cause mayhem.  And they all throw 
     out those wonderful "I'm packing an arsenal--don't fuck with me" 
     vibes.
     
     I know that there surely are shining examples of kids who don't pull 
     this poop, and I remember all to well my trials and tribulations when 
     I wanted to get into over 21 clubs.  But it seems like there are more 
     fools with heavy weaponry than ever, and there's not a whole lot that 
     anyone can do about it.  (The rational approach just don't cut it!)
     
     Anyone have a good method of dealing with the kids, and not becoming 
     totally depressed at the state of society???
     
     
     Andrea
     awaters@mfi.com

I just wanted to invite everyone who is itching for something to
do tonight to come out to Wish.

> The Spundae party here is the wave (rave) of the future, I think.  Say
> goodbye to warehouse parties.  I haven't been to a one in Portland in
> years that really has had much going for it.  Occasional sets -- DRC
> a couple of weeks ago, Emma last fall, Derrick Carter's awesome three-deck
> mix, Garth a way long time ago -- stand out for me, but I've never had a
> *good* time at one of these.  Spundae had a bit more of an age mix and
> clearly these big-production affairs in club spaces are where things are
> going.  We are about to witness the Americanization of the UK club scene,
> and this is the precursor.  Spundae is starting down the path of the
> superclub model, where they build up a name, a local crowd, bring in
> the big name DJs, and then starting planting their operation all around
> the country.  I wish Spundae well but their concept and their crowd are
> not what I got into all this for, although I certainly enjoyed the music
> last night.  
> 
> For $16, everyone got a good deal at Spundae, but I still prefer to haul
> equipment across the sand and play outside . . .



You and a lot of others, rick!  Based on my limited observations/experiences
of the past few months, I do see a lot of what you noted above.  I hear a
lot about big production vibe-less clubby raves these days (altho i always
choose to stay away from them & attend our smaller community-oriented
gatherings).  However, at least in SF from what I've seen, there are still a
pretty big number of people who are really interested in preserving the
smaller underground-style warehouse parties that are also still occurring
today.  Assuming what I've been told is correct, folks like the FnF crew &
others got together in order to try and have more of these types of parties,
for reasons like yours above, because the massive clubby vibeless parties
were really becoming prevalent.  I know there are a lot of people here who
fully support that idea and will continue to, because that is what they
really value in our parties.  And as was mentioned in some earlier posts, as
the underground becomes more "mainstream", this will in turn generate a new
underground behind that.  As long as there are enough people who are really
interested in maintaining what we currently have in our
Gateway/FnF/Harmony/etc parties, we will continue to have a thriving
underground consisting of people who really appreciate it & support it.  I
know that these types of parties have fallen by the wayside in other areas
of the country, but because this topic keeps recurring on SFRaves, it leads
me to believe that (as described over & over again by people who visit other
areas & by people who have come from other areas to our scene) at least San
Francisco is different.  San Francisco appears to have a definite large
number of people who are aware of this potential trend and are concerned
about where things may be going in the future.  This puts us in a stronger
position!  We are in the position of knowing what may come down the pike &
being able to prevent it beforehand, rather than wondering "what happened to
our scene" and having to fix what is already wrong.  When I was in Montreal,
the people didn't really seem to care too terribly one way or another for
anything beyond just the music, they had already lost what (I've heard) was
once a wonderful vibe & loving people.  Simply being aware beforehand can
easily prevent our scene from becoming that way.  I guess, to me, it doesn't
seem too difficult to do, as long as we remain aware of what's really
important to us as individuals and to the scene as a whole, and consistently
work towards those goals in the here-now.

Looking forward to more parties where we gotta haul that equipment down to
the beach! :)

Love,
Shawna


"Deedle deedle dee, wubba wubba wubba..."

responding to Cid who feels that neo-nazi discussions and Tracy Lords
discussion's don't belong on SFR....  

I don't agree that these threads are totally off-topic for us -- the neo-nazi
discussion has to do with issues of censorship and rights on the internet --
which affects us, we are a sometimes controversial group, are we not?  ---- and
Tracy Lords is in fact a DJ who spins techno music in addition to other
escapades -- so once again, there is a real connection here... even if some of
us are not personally interested in joining in the debates...  and in fact
couldn't care less...

What I like is when it's clear in the header of a message what it's about so I
can skip it -- e.g., when someone's selling some equipment, I don't read it,
because i'm not a dj and don't have a phat sound setup at home.

And, frankly, I don't want to have to go searching for other news groups to
express an opinion on something that has to do with SFR -- I'd rather hear the
ideas and opinions of the people on here, with whom I have something in
common...   I mean, who do you think is ON a Tracy Lords newsgroup?  I don't
even want to think!

(my 200 pesos)

Leslie  ; )

messages ... you know, "is this message just more of the same on a subject we've
beaten to death already?"  -- if so ......   self...... destr...

On Wed, 15 May 1996, Waterstreet, Andrea wrote:

- I talked to one of the DJ's that was there, and although his car wasn't 
damaged, he was really really angry.  He told me that in order to get out 
of there, they almost had to run some of the kids over, and actually did 
run over one of the kid's feet because he wouldn't move out of the way.  
I'm really glad no one got hurt (even the evil drunken kids), and it was 
only cars that were damaged.  I spent a lot of time reflecting how I 
would react in that situation.  To answer your question, although I do 
see a bad element in our society with violence and guns as the solution, 
(I know this will sound hokey), I think we should fight this solution 
with loving each other the best we can, supporting these fears by setting 
an example ourselves by showing that we have the balls to not resort to 
the cowardly method of using arsenal to show our bravery.  
I say fight the world with love and a happy raver mentality.
Eventually we'll have the rest of the world with us.

Deborah

Hiya All;

        After extensive trial testing of numerous Internet packages
available on da market I've found that NetManage's Internet Chameleon is da
shit.

        Their Full Blown Windows 95 32 bit stack version(non-dos shell) that
allows multiple dial up adapters to be run simultaneously will be available
in about a week. I like this package because it does everything FTP, Archie,
Handles Multiple POP Mail Accounts(Eudora Doesn't do this), Net Browser,
News Reader, Telnet, Gopher, Ping, Whois, Talk, Finger, and it has is own
text tag that allows you to highlight text within most application and mail
that to whomever. They are also a local company, right there in Cupertino.
The company also tells me the package is going to cost $30.00, how can you
go wrong.

        Sorry to take up bandwidth with this but e-mail, the internet, and
it's software are part of every group and person who access the net, and if
you had to do this yourself it would take you months as it did me.

Peace

Here are some dumb jokes for a slow, rainy day!!

Q. How do you catch a unique rabbit?
	A. U-NEEK up on it

Q. How do you catch a tame rabbit?
	A. The TAME way.

Q. What can you catch from kissing a bird?
	A. CHIRPIES, it's an untweetable disease!!

Apples' nerdy programers have nothing to do with this- it's the marketing

DIRECTION the company takes-those  decisions are made by CEO's, MBA's  ect,
people who know business and how it works.  Programmers are simply human
capital that makes investment returns possible.  An idea, no matter how
smart or novel has to make money and its not up to a programmer or
desingner to decide what will make $ and what wont.

Hello all you Goa lovers,

I have created an e-mail list dedicated to the discussion of Goa trance,
and anything else related to the Goa scene in general -- ie track
reviews, event listings, your favorite ingredient for Chai, etc.

This will be unmoderated, but irrelevant subjects (ie drugs, other types
of music, employment announcements, spams, etc) will NOT BE TOLERATED --
keep that stuff on Usenet.  The list is intended to be very low in volume, 
yet high in content. 

For those that are interested, subscribe by sending e-mail to the
following:
	majordomo@party.net
In the subject of the message enter the following:
	subscribe goa
To post to the list, send e-mail to the following:
	goa@party.net

Hope to see some of you there!

Andy

         Reply to:   RE>>Apple Rave in San Jose!

I think you guys are digging a little to deep into this.  Jeez, its just a party for the Word Wide Developers Confrence.  I work for Apple, but have nothing to do with this party. Just because its beeing sponsered by a Major Corportation does not mean its gonna suck.  There will probably be some cool internet and multimedia exhibits there to check out, and there will deffinatly be great music.  How much 'Market Share' do you think Apple plans to increase by throwing a party that *maybe* 200 people will show up at??  Trust me, Apple still has a few bucks in the bank to do bigger and better things to improve sales than throwing a rave in down town SJ.  Has any one seen the Apple "Mission Imposs!
 ibe" Powerbook commercial yet??

FYI-
---------------Original Message---------------

THIS IS A CALL TO ARMS!

On Wednesday 5/8, the tabloid TV show "Hard Copy" nationally
broadcast a slanderous report regarding the current California
desert-rave movement.  The sensationalized report opened up calling
desert raves "deadly teen orgies of sex and booze."  They aired many
images of ravers inhaling nitrous oxide and drinking.  They never
substantiated the claims that raves are deadly and orgiastic in
nature.

The report went on to make bold face lies about matters of safety
and responsibility at raves and falsely claimed that raves have been
forced out into the desert because of a "plague of deadly fires and
gang shootings."



Defaming comments such as these turn public opinion against us which
in turn makes it more difficult for us to obtain locations, permits
and insurance to continue to throw raves.

This was an obvious attempt at sensationalizing our movement for
their profit.  Although we cannot keep the media from profiteering
off of our efforts, we can do two things:

1) Educate ourselves a little better about these situations.  DON'T
start blabbing away to video cameras even if they say it's just for
personal use (This is what we were told at DUNE by the Hard Copy
"undercover team").  Be discrete, be smart, be safe and be
responsible.  Point out safety/medical concerns to promoters and
security personnel at raves. All of this is easy to do even while
you're having fun.

AND

2) Let the media know that we won't allow ourselve to be raped
anymore.  We aren't stupid.  We aren't unorganized. And even through
their efforts to discredit us, we're not going to stop raving!


I encourage you to do a few things

...to cross post this to techno/rave/DJ culture mail lists, newsgroups,
magazines and www sites to make others more aware of this problem.

...to disallow video cameras at ALL rave events.  This will ensure
privacy and tighten leaks to the media.

...to discuss this media relations problem in your locale and come
up with ways to keep this from happening in your scene.

and last

...to call the Hard Copy viewer comments phone # and let them know
that you are outraged by their irresponsible, inaccurate and
unethical report on desert raves. Make them understand that they
MUST be held accountable for the claims presented in their reports.
Remind them that they should be more committed to standards and
ethics of profesional journalism.

The Hard Copy # is 900/268-6868.  The call will be .50 but will be
a worthwhile investment for our movement.


This is OUR future in THEIR hands.  Do not let others who don't
understand our movement dictate to the public what we are about...
who we are.

TAKE CONTROL!

-Kc of DUNE




-Kc


Memories of DUNE at
http://home.earthlink.net/~sarahtonen




----------End of Original Message----------

-------------------------------------
05/15/96 - 17:14:12

Mark Piercy, piercy@toolik.Stanford.EDU wrote:
>Come-on all you hip gen-x 'ers! 
>oh ya, and don't forget your highly disposable incomes...
>Last I checked a rave doen't usally end at 2am, but starts to takeoff
>around then!
>Tell the market research dept. to try harder next time.
>It's sad to see what happens to a movment that started with the "dreggs of
>society"(i.e. the most creative and forward looking people around) get's
>used by the most powerfull and elite members of society  (CEO's and other
>good'ole boys and girls)
>The end is near kids, enjoy it while it lasts!! 

Now, now, don't get all bitchy.  Sad to see?  See what?  This show hasn't 
even happened yet.  And I don't think there are going to be many CEOs 
there.  It's not a product introduction, it's not a media event, it's 
just a celebration for the Apple developer community.  And if you think 
that community doesn't include anyone as cool as you, you can piss right 
off.  This mailing list is home to plenty of Apple and ex-Apple people 
(me, for example) and more, I'm sure, who are connected to the 
third-party community.  There are all kinds of people everywhere.

And it's not like Freaky Chakra is suddenly going to suck because a 
corporation is signing the check.  What would be *genuinely* lame is if 
Apple (or anyone, corporate or not) were to decide to put on a party and 
hired a bunch of shitty DJs in the mistaken belief that they were tapping 
into the real house (or whatever) current.  And if the event were a 
success, *that* would be a genuine sign of the dying, co-opted scene you 
seem to be worried about.  (And of course, this does happen, 
unfortunately).
  
and then he said:
>So you think this is just for fun-Apple is spending a few thousand $
>because they like to throw parties and they just love house music? I really
>DO think the company is doing anything it can to increase market share and
>be at the fore front of any trend they see as profitible .  I thought a
>rave meant a little more than a 5 hour commercial at a night club.  Maybee
>it's time to be realistic.

Maybe it's time for you to relax.  Look, it's A PARTY.  For FUN.  A 
chance for people in the Apple development community to get together and 
enjoy themselves.  Things like this happen at every conference--I didn't 
hear anyone complaining about the Digital Queers bash at MacWorld in 
January.

anarch@scruznet.com

Yeah, be thankful it won't be a Microsoft Rave!
I could imagine all kinds of horrible things at one of those:

	-The voicemail says the party starts at 10pm, but it gets
postponed about twelve times until it finally starts at 11 am the next day
	-They make you buy their own Microsoft Brand water, claiming
that 'all other waters are incompatible with this venue'
	-The sound system inexplicably shuts down every 30 minutes 
	-The visuals consist of slides of Bill Gates superimposed over
Windows wallpaper.bmps
	-After you get into the party and realize it sucks, you find
ticket vendors selling pricey 'ticket-supplements' that grant access to
another, hidden room where the better DJs and better vibe are
	-The promoters run around the party trying to buyout all the
small-scale smoothie vendors

So, support our Apple friends.  They're the last line of defense against
the mediocre hegemony that is Microsoft!

	-jon

Date: 15 May 96 22:00:01 EDT
From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@CompuServe.COM>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Apple Rave in San Jose!
Message-ID: <960516020001_71165.755_GHL181-1@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Why oh why does it have to be such a big suspicious deal whenever a corporation
does something?  

People, stop and think about this "corporate is always bad" mentality that is
spouted off so often ... guess what?  lots of corporations are filled with very
cool people!  And lots of SFRavers are included in that list!  

I mean, get real.... successful businesses mean jobs for people, probably
including you and including myself...  (Apple used to be a major client of my
company, and is very responsible for the beginning of our success -- we named
the PowerBook, Quadra, QuickTake, and more for them) ...   

I bet everyone on this list is dependent in some way on the success of a company
-- whether you're an employee or have your own business, if corporations aren't
profitable, we all lose...  hey, if you wait tables, your customers need jobs to
come to your restaurant.. if you work for a florist, your customers won't buy
your flowers if they're not working ... WE ARE ALL INTERCONNECTED!

...and I'd make some kind of bet here that the event planners took the tastes
and interests of the people they invited into account -- so instead of a "square
dance" theme (which I'm sure all the REAL square dancers would poo-poo as being
insincere and inauthentic) -- they're having a rave-oriented party....  

And look, they have the real thing performing, don't they?  I wish I could go
and see them!  Ooooh, it's not a REAL rave because it starts at 8 and ends at 2?
Hello?  I don't know about you guys, but most people who work corporate jobs go
to work in the morning on the weekdays.  A company-sponsored party on a
weeknight can only be expected to go until 2, that seems pretty generous -- Many
of our own events end then as well on weeknights due the venues.... 

And I hope the CEO is there -- yes, sometimes senior execs are buttheads, but
sometimes they're not.  

And maybe we can be a little less defensive about our music and scene.  Of
course, it's not going to be like an underground party -- but just think, there
will be people there exposed to this great music for the first time!  I was
listening to Freaky Chakra in my car today, and I'm psyched that others will be
hearing it for the first time!  

I hope all you South Bay people have fun there tonight!

Leslie 

...done spouting off for the day .... whew!  that feels better!  ; )



_________________________

My, my, my. Before you start getting all pissy, you should know that 
Apple throws a bunch of parties every year for its' developers. It
just so happens that this one will have a rave theme, so what? I don't
think anyone is expecting it will be like a real rave!! It is sort
of cheesy, but what the heck. Maybe someone will actually have fun.

I wonder how many ravers are now Apple Employees or used to work there,
I know of a bunch myself. I really doubt the CEO's have anything to do
with it, nor do they care. Find something else to gripe about, please.

Amy Felix

On Wed, 15 May 1996 teena@lioness.compute.com wrote:

> 
> ...to disallow video cameras at ALL rave events.  This will ensure
> privacy and tighten leaks to the media.
> -Kc of DUNE

                        FUCK CENSORSHIP!!!
 
 I'm a multi-media artist who works with video occasionally. I'm also 
a performance ambient artist, again multi-media focused.
 
 I have two perspectives on video-taping raves.

 1) Free raves in public on public land: No one has the legal or ethical 
   right to prevent ANY video-taping here! Some may regard the video-taping 
   intrusive yet it is no more intrusive than a bunch of noisy, partying 
   ravers in a public venue. Share and share alike.

 2) Public events in rented venues: A more gray area. Legally the 
    producer has the right to forbid video-taping ( or any other recording 
    process ). I actually have been invited by one rave promoter to come 
    early and set up non-intrusive lighing in order to get some good shots 
    (lights would only be on for minutes). And realistically you will 
    not prevent all video-taping. Just look at all the bootlegs of bands 
    (audio and video). I do feel that if video-taping is occuring at an event
    that the promoter should inform folks at the door with a BIG sign 
    stating such.

 The bottom line is that you cannot prevent video-taping entirely. We 
might as well put out our own material in order to present a balanced 
perspective to the TV audience. Universes video-tape "The Global Dance 
Party" (1993) does a real good job. Besides, the public knows something 
about us already. 
 
 As a video-taper I try to show respect for the situation I'm in. Of course 
not all folks are this way. I do feel it is important that some sort of 
record is created for future generations. And of course, a video can never 
really capture what a rave really is. That is inside each of us Not to 
mention that most of my footage is going to be projected at future raves. 
 
 Censorship is for nazi's. If you want a private party, throw it! Do not 
expect sympathy if you throw a public event affecting large groups of 
people and someome wants to document the event. Saying no is just stupid 
thinking. Sorry if my strong opinion is offensive to some. It is mearly 
my $0.02


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams
            ( your rights are our rights )       
                       /
                 -=*=-/
                   ~

Remember; legally a release needs to signed by any individual whose voice 
or likeness is used for profit (like a "news" broadcast).
