>forum - now don't get me wrong: I am NOT saying that the issues that have been
>discussed, or that are being discussed on SFRAVES aren't important, they are
>just not SFRAVES related.
>Thank you...
>Peace, love, and infinite positive energy...

to raves/parties (since I do not like the word raves...BTW when was the

Hello all you Goa lovers,

I have created an e-mail list dedicated to the discussion of Goa trance,
and anything else related to the Goa scene in general -- ie track
reviews, event listings, your favorite ingredient for Chai, etc.

This will be unmoderated, but irrelevant subjects (ie drugs, other types
of music, employment announcements, spams, etc) will NOT BE TOLERATED --
keep that stuff on Usenet.  The list is intended to be very low in volume, 
yet high in content. 

For those that are interested, subscribe by sending e-mail to the
following:
	majordomo@party.net
In the subject of the message enter the following:
	subscribe goa
To post to the list, send e-mail to the following:
	goa@party.net

Hope to see some of you there!

Andy

If you want to know about Apple just read the many books written about it.
They will be much less biased and slef-promoting than personal accounts
from people only tangentially involved with the company.

Here are ones I found when I searched for "Apple Computer history" on
<www.amazon.com>

-----------
The Mac Bathroom Reader; Owen W. Linzmayer; Paperback; $11.69

The MacIntosh Way; Guy Kawasaki; Paperback; $11.25

Steve Wozniak : A Wizard Called Woz (Achievers); Rebecca Gold; Library
Binding; $18.95

Accidental Millionaire : The Rise and Fall of Steve Jobs at Apple Computer;
Lee Butcher; Hardcover; $19.95 (Special
Order)

The MacIntosh Way; Guy Kawasaki; Hardcover; $21.55 (Special Order)

Odyssey : Pepsi to Apple : A Journey of Adventure, Ideas, and the Future;
John Sculley; Hardcover (Publisher Out Of
Stock)

West of Eden : The End of Innocence at Apple Computer; Frank Rose;
Hardcover (Publisher Out Of Stock)

From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Message-Id: <199605161840.LAA12300@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Subject: Fwd: |NER| Fwd: NYC club owner in 'ecstasy' bust (fwd)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 16 May 1996 11:40:53 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
Content-Type: text
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>From what I have heard about the Tunnel in NYC, it is a less than PLURRY place.
This is still extremely bad news....

-troy

---------------------------------

	NEW YORK, May 15 (UPI) -- A New York City nightclub impresario was  
arrested Wednesday and charged with turning two of his popular hot spots 
into drug dens by distributing the hallucinogen ``ecstasy'' to his young 
patrons. 
	Brooklyn U.S. Attorney Zachary Carter said Peter Gatien transformed  
Tunnel and the Limelight into ``virtual ecstasy supermarkets,'' selling 
up to 2,000 pills per month at $35 to $40 a pop. 
	``What's really remarkable was we determined that dealing drugs was  
not just a lucrative sideline, but was the centerpiece of the operation, 
'' Carter said. ``It could be said that these clubs existed to 
distribute these drugs.'' 
	Carter said an eight-month investigation into the distribution of the  
designer drug in New York led them directly to Gatien. He said Gatien 
hired a director and ``party promoters'' whose duties included guarding 
the door to let ``house dealers'' of the drug inside and then warn them 
when New York City police officers came around. 
	The club also took a cut of the dealers' profits, officials said.  
	The multicolored ecstasy pills -- sold under names like ``fruitloops,''  
``cat's eye,'' ``playboys'' and ``doves'' -- were apparently smuggled 
into the country from Amsterdam, the Netherlands, Montreal, Canada and 
Miami, said Drug Enforcement Administration Special Agent Carlo Boccia. 
	The drug is known to produce a combination of effects, including a  
euphoric high, relaxation and mild hallucinations, Boccia said. High 
doses have been linked to psychosis, brain damage and even death. 
	``The public needs to realize that the high visibility of clubs such  
as these glamorize the use and distribution of these illegal substances, 
'' Boccia said. 
	``Those who sell these drugs, albeit surrounded by the splendor and  
glitz of 'fashionable' nightclubs, are no less the scourge than those 
who hide in the back alleys of the inner city to dispense their poison. 
These people are just as bad, if not worse.'' 
	Gatien and 21 others were arrested in pre-dawn raids and 6,000 pills  
were confiscated. The defendants were charged with conspiracy to 
distribute ecstasy. They face maximum prison terms of 20 years if 
convicted. 
	Carter has also filed a motion to seize any of Gatien's ill-gotten  
assets and other physical property related to the alleged drug 
operation. 
	The clubs can remain open until a judge's ruling on the matter, he  
said.

There are several electronic music releated lists served by hyperreal: 

idm (intelligent dance music)  
ambient 
313 (detroit)  
analogue heaven (analogue equipment) 

For info on any of these lists, send mail to majordomo@hyperreal.com with
"info <listname>" in the body of the message, where <listname> is one of
the lists above.  Or for a listing of all lists served off of hyperreal,
send the command "lists". 

I've also heard there's a trance list somewhere, and a "breaks" (jungle) 
list over at xmission.com.  I'm sure there's others too... Anyone know of
a "house music" mailing list?

Andy

From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@compuserve.com>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Apple Rave in San Jose!
Message-Id: <96May16.123734pdt.4501@godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com>
Date: Thu, 16 May 1996 10:58:03 PDT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Why oh why does it have to be such a big suspicious deal whenever a corporation
does something?  

People, stop and think about this "corporate is always bad" mentality that is
spouted off so often ... guess what?  lots of corporations are filled with very
cool people!  And lots of SFRavers are included in that list!  

I mean, get real.... successful businesses mean jobs for people, probably
including you and including myself...  (Apple used to be a major client of my
company, and is very responsible for the beginning of our success -- we named
the PowerBook, Quadra, QuickTake, and more for them) ...   

I bet everyone on this list is dependent in some way on the success of a company
-- whether you're an employee or have your own business, if corporations aren't
profitable, we all lose...  hey, if you wait tables, your customers need jobs to
come to your restaurant.. if you work for a florist, your customers won't buy
your flowers if they're not working ... WE ARE ALL INTERCONNECTED!

...and I'd make some kind of bet here that the event planners took the tastes
and interests of the people they invited into account -- so instead of a "square
dance" theme (which I'm sure all the REAL square dancers would poo-poo as being
insincere and inauthentic) -- they're having a rave-oriented party....  

And look, they have the real thing performing, don't they?  I wish I could go
and see them!  Ooooh, it's not a REAL rave because it starts at 8 and ends at 2?
Hello?  I don't know about you guys, but most people who work corporate jobs go
to work in the morning on the weekdays.  A company-sponsored party on a
weeknight can only be expected to go until 2, that seems pretty generous -- Many
of our own events end then as well on weeknights due the venues.... 

And I hope the CEO is there -- yes, sometimes senior execs are buttheads, but
sometimes they're not.  

And maybe we can be a little less defensive about our music and scene.  Of
course, it's not going to be like an underground party -- but just think, there
will be people there exposed to this great music for the first time!  I was
listening to Freaky Chakra in my car today, and I'm psyched that others will be
hearing it for the first time!  

I hope all you South Bay people have fun there tonight!

Leslie 

...done spouting off for the day .... whew!  that feels better!  ; )

Apple throws a bunch of parties every year for its' developers. It
just so happens that this one will have a rave theme, so what? I don't

of cheesy, but what the heck. Maybe someone will actually have fun.

I wonder how many ravers are now Apple Employees or used to work there,
I know of a bunch myself. I really doubt the CEO's have anything to do
with it, nor do they care. Find something else to gripe about, please.

On Wed, 15 May 1996 teena@lioness.compute.com wrote:

> 
> ...to disallow video cameras at ALL rave events.  This will ensure
> privacy and tighten leaks to the media.
> -Kc of DUNE

                        FUCK CENSORSHIP!!!
 
 I'm a multi-media artist who works with video occasionally. I'm also 
a performance ambient artist, again multi-media focused.
 
 I have two perspectives on video-taping raves.

 1) Free raves in public on public land: No one has the legal or ethical 
   right to prevent ANY video-taping here! Some may regard the video-taping 
   intrusive yet it is no more intrusive than a bunch of noisy, partying 
   ravers in a public venue. Share and share alike.

 2) Public events in rented venues: A more gray area. Legally the 
    producer has the right to forbid video-taping ( or any other recording 
    process ). I actually have been invited by one rave promoter to come 
    early and set up non-intrusive lighing in order to get some good shots 
    (lights would only be on for minutes). And realistically you will 
    not prevent all video-taping. Just look at all the bootlegs of bands 
    (audio and video). I do feel that if video-taping is occuring at an event
    that the promoter should inform folks at the door with a BIG sign 
    stating such.

 The bottom line is that you cannot prevent video-taping entirely. We 
might as well put out our own material in order to present a balanced 
perspective to the TV audience. Universes video-tape "The Global Dance 
Party" (1993) does a real good job. Besides, the public knows something 
about us already. 
 
 As a video-taper I try to show respect for the situation I'm in. Of course 
not all folks are this way. I do feel it is important that some sort of 
record is created for future generations. And of course, a video can never 
really capture what a rave really is. That is inside each of us Not to 
mention that most of my footage is going to be projected at future raves. 
 
 Censorship is for nazi's. If you want a private party, throw it! Do not 
expect sympathy if you throw a public event affecting large groups of 
people and someome wants to document the event. Saying no is just stupid 
thinking. Sorry if my strong opinion is offensive to some. It is mearly 
my $0.02


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams

[ to sfraves list ]

 Being that I'm writing this during my work hours at a merciless greedy
corporate giant , I'll try to keep it short -

Some Stuff RE: Apple "Sprockets" "Rave"

1. Looked just like a rave when I showed up at the announced opening
time of 8PM - ie nothing ready quite yet, guys running around trying to 
get stuff set up. I must say that they had a DJ working at the turntables at 
least! Although he would be cut off every once and awhile as they tweaked
the system for Freaky Chakra. I think the DJ's name was Alex ( not MAD
Alex ).

2. Nobody that I noticed in suits or nametags. On the whole , the dress
was either California yuppy casual with the occasional individualistic
touch ( unique tie or pin or hairdo ) or what you'd see at a rave ( no
naked people or "costumes" , tho ).

3. Free non-alcoholic drinks and snack food included in the $5 admin.

4. I left 15 minutes before the cops showed up - must have been some
personal 6th sense. Maybe it was the speaker stack placed in front of 
the open window that gave me a hint .... Nobody from Apple that was
arranging this was in suits, so there was no one to impress the police
with, much less Jerry Brown.

5. By the way , thanks to the folks who arranged for the event! I understand
they had to rent the space for over $1000 last night. If I remember, at
least one of them subscribes to SFRaves - so "hello!".

6. South Bay SFRavers - getting together sounds good to me! As Mr.
Knucklehead knows, it's the organizing that's the tough part.

 Gotta get back to looking like I'm working!!!!

Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com ( No , I don't work for NETCOM )

PS - HI! to all the folks I met last night , even if I don't remember
your name(s)! It was great to meet new folks and match faces to email
names.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Andy Kumeda <kumeda@intelenet.net>
To: socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Subject: Goa e-mail list

Hello all you Goa lovers,

I have created an e-mail list dedicated to the discussion of Goa trance,
and anything else related to the Goa scene in general -- ie track
reviews, event listings, your favorite ingredient for Chai, etc.

This will be unmoderated, but irrelevant subjects (ie drugs, other types
of music, employment announcements, spams, etc) will NOT BE TOLERATED --
keep that stuff on Usenet.  The list is intended to be very low in volume, 
yet high in content. 

For those that are interested, subscribe by sending e-mail to the
following:
	majordomo@party.net
In the subject of the message enter the following:
	subscribe goa
To post to the list, send e-mail to the following:
	goa@party.net

Hope to see some of you there!

Andy

Weird!

Cool visuals, but weird spoken word over live music/synths.  Live drummer.
Trippy dancers.  Images of the band layed over and under funky art work,
all swirling and melding and twirling.  Things like putting the drummers
head inside the bass drum, looking like a really old Led Zepplin video or
something.

phone number would speratically appear.  I didn't.

Question is, "was this SPAZ the party./rave promoters?"

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Dear Friends & Family,

	I hope many of you took the time to read this.  It's not in fact 
specifically about the rave scene, but I definitely found it relevant.

My computer tells me that on Fri, 10 May 1996, Kyung Rok shared (in part):

> Though perhaps better sent on a Tuesday instead of a Friday afternoon, 
> this is about 1/4 of a cultural studies piece titled "Moral Panic, the 
> Media and British Rave Culture."  Written by Sarah Thornton, the rest of 
> this essay can be found in "Microphone fiends : Youth Music & Youth 
> Culture / edited by Andrew Ross & Tricia Rose. Routledge, 1994.

A few of the observations I found most interesting, and some comments of 
my own:

> ___
> The idea that authentic culture is somehow outside media and commerce is a 
> resilient one. In its full-blown romantic form, the belief imagines that 
> grass-roots cultures resist and struggle with a colonizing mass-mediated 
> corporate world

Although the problems with media and commercial interests are many, I am 
forced to agree with the author's indictment of our anti-media and 
anti-commercial outlook, as if our culture is somehow pure and real, and 
immune from the greed, mediocrity, and tastelessness we see in media and 
commerce.  The indictment of commerce may be due to the "temporary 
respite" many of us who are young possess from "adult commitments of 
accumulation of economic capital" (see below), but this doesn't make it 
correct.  

> In exploring this case, this article finds no opposition between 
> subcultures and the media, except for a dogged ideological one. It 
> uncovers no pure origins or organic homologies of sound, style and 
> ritual, nor does it vilify a vague monolith called "The media." Instead, 
> it examines how various media are integral to youth's social and 
> ideological formations. Micromedia like flyers and listings are means by 
> which club organizers bring the crowd together; niche media like the 
> music press construct as much as they document subcultures; while mass 
> media like the tabloids develop as much as do youth movements. Contrary 
> to youth discourses, then, subcultures do not germinate from
> seed and grow by force of their own energy into mysterious movements to 
> be belatedly ingested by the media. Rather, media are there and effective 
> right from the start. 

Again, this seems true.  SFRaves is part of the media, although it has 
the advantage of being a better-informed, more personal, and less 
restricted than large mass media outlets, plus the crucial point of being 
truly interactive.  Damning "the media" indiscriminately doesn't reflect 
well on our ability to comprehend that media are an important part of 
any culture, including ours.  Nor do they fit well into neat boxes of 
"mainstream" and "underground" media based on audience size or by whether 
they call themselves underground or alternative.

> The term "underground" is the expression by which clubbers refer to 
> things subcultural. More than fashionable or trendy, underground sounds 
> and styles are "authentic," and pitted against the mass-produced and 
> mass-consumed. Underqrounds denote exclusive worlds whose main point is 
> not elitism. but whose parameters often relate to particular crowds. They 
> delight in parental incomprehension, negative newspaper coverage and that 
> best blessing in disguise, the BBC ban. More than anything else, then, 
> undergrounds define themselves against the mass media.

Fortunately I don't think ravers delight much in "parental 
incomprehension."  From what I've seen, many of us have actually tried to 
bring our parents into the scene, and share the joy with them.  We do 
however, it seems to me, take an unseemly delight in negative media 
coverage:  Ridiculing them for lack of knowledge of our scene, taking the 
attitude "they just don't get it" as if they are incapable of getting it, 
reveling in our perceived superiority -- these attitudes don't reflect 
well on our community.  Which is not to say that we should go along with 
negative coverage -- we should seek to inform and correct it, and to 
fight it when it refuses to be informed and corrected.

> That's what I mean by underground."Undergrounds define themselves most 
> clearly by what they're not, that is "main stream." Although there is 
> variation, the oft-repeated expression by which they refer to mainstream 
> clubs is that these are places where "Sharon and Tracy dance around their 
> handbags." This mainstream is decried as passive, indiscriminate and 
> uncommitted to dance culture; it is ridiculed for its " herd instinct" 
> and " bandwagon mentality. " 

When I find myself dissing mainstream culture, I try to check myself.  I 
do not think it is a good habit, although it is an easy one to fall 
into.  What we are really doing when we dis mainstream culture, 
after all, is dissing humanity at large, saying most people are stupid, 
base, and lack taste and culture.  Now if we hold out the hope of 
reforming mainstream culture by making the underground the mainstream, 
that is different, for that is saying that there is hope for humanity, 
that humanity at large is not to blame, only current social attitudes.
	Note in the paragraph below where the author says that 
popularization is seen as a problem by the underground.  I think 
her observation is correct, and it's unfortunate, because while certainly 
it can have problematic *aspects*, to say that popularization *itself* 
is the problem is truly cynical and elitist.  

> ...subcultures romanticize "the street" 
> and the crowd, not artists' studios and individual genius. Moreover, 
> rather than the dreaded "trickle down," the problem for underground 
> subculture is popularization by a gushing up to the mainstream. 

I have myself noticed this tendency to romanticize "the street."  I think 
this can take several forms, one being the old argument that "If you 
aren't (X) yourself, or haven't done (X) yourself, or haven't been to (X) 
yourself, you aren't qualified to have an opinion on (X)."  Personally I 
have always thought this an extremely weak way of invalidating someone 
else's point of view.  Another way "the street" gets romanticized is by 
dissing "book smarts" in favor of an ill-defined "you've got to go out 
there and experience it, man" approach.
	I once occurred to me after a trip to L.A. that when people there are 
stuck up it seems to be more about how much money they have, who they 
know that's famous, whereas when people in S.F. are stuck up it's more 
often about how much a part of some "underground elite" they are.

> ...youth. whatever their 
> class enjoy a momentary reprieve from "necessity."'! In other words, 
> youth are exempt from adult commitments to the accumulation of economic 
> capital. They temporarily enjoy what Bourdieu argues is normally reserved 
> for the bourgeoisie; that is, a "taste of liberty or luxury. "

	This is troubling to me, because it reminds me that so few 
people, as they grow older, manage to live outside these "adult 
commitments to the accumulation of economic capital."  Just look at our 
cultural forebears, the hippies.  For the most part, the '60s generation 
has blended into the workforce without fulfilling the dreams of their 
youth of social change toward a world of peace, love, harmony, and fun.
	It troubles me that many ravers do not even seem to have such 
noble dreams.  Many of us have no hope of changing the world.  We do 
not think beyond the next party, beyond how great our favorite dance 
music is.  When the music is old, and a new generation seeking its own 
values finds something else to turn to besides raves, with different 
music and perhaps different values, what will we have changed?  If we're not 
even idealistic now, how crassly cynical and materialist may we become in 
thirty years?  I know this is a downer, but I say it not out of cynicism, 
but out of hope that we will make a difference, ravers young and old.

Date: 16 May 96 11:40:53
From:"Troy Sheets " <owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Fwd: |NER| Fwd: NYC club owner in 'ecstasy' bust (fwd)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
X-Orcl-Application: Content-Type:  text
X-Orcl-Application: Sender:  owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Orcl-Application: Precedence:  bulk


>From what I have heard about the Tunnel in NYC, it is a less than PLURRY place.
This is still extremely bad news....

-troy

---------------------------------

	NEW YORK, May 15 (UPI) -- A New York City nightclub impresario was  
arrested Wednesday and charged with turning two of his popular hot spots 
into drug dens by distributing the hallucinogen ``ecstasy'' to his young 
patrons. 
	Brooklyn U.S. Attorney Zachary Carter said Peter Gatien transformed  
Tunnel and the Limelight into ``virtual ecstasy supermarkets,'' selling 
up to 2,000 pills per month at $35 to $40 a pop. 
	``What's really remarkable was we determined that dealing drugs was  
not just a lucrative sideline, but was the centerpiece of the operation, 
'' Carter said. ``It could be said that these clubs existed to 
distribute these drugs.'' 
	Carter said an eight-month investigation into the distribution of the  
designer drug in New York led them directly to Gatien. He said Gatien 
hired a director and ``party promoters'' whose duties included guarding 
the door to let ``house dealers'' of the drug inside and then warn them 
when New York City police officers came around. 
	The club also took a cut of the dealers' profits, officials said.  
	The multicolored ecstasy pills -- sold under names like ``fruitloops,''  
``cat's eye,'' ``playboys'' and ``doves'' -- were apparently smuggled 
into the country from Amsterdam, the Netherlands, Montreal, Canada and 
Miami, said Drug Enforcement Administration Special Agent Carlo Boccia. 
	The drug is known to produce a combination of effects, including a  
euphoric high, relaxation and mild hallucinations, Boccia said. High 
doses have been linked to psychosis, brain damage and even death. 
	``The public needs to realize that the high visibility of clubs such  
as these glamorize the use and distribution of these illegal substances, 
'' Boccia said. 
	``Those who sell these drugs, albeit surrounded by the splendor and  
glitz of 'fashionable' nightclubs, are no less the scourge than those 
who hide in the back alleys of the inner city to dispense their poison. 
These people are just as bad, if not worse.'' 
	Gatien and 21 others were arrested in pre-dawn raids and 6,000 pills  
were confiscated. The defendants were charged with conspiracy to 
distribute ecstasy. They face maximum prison terms of 20 years if 
convicted. 
	Carter has also filed a motion to seize any of Gatien's ill-gotten  
assets and other physical property related to the alleged drug 
operation. 
	The clubs can remain open until a judge's ruling on the matter, he  
said.

Received: from lazlo.steam.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA01550; Thu, 16 May 1996 14:18:50 -0700
Received: from mail-out1.apple.com (mail-out1.apple.com [17.254.0.52]) by lazlo.steam.com (8.7.3/8.6.12) with ESMTP id OAA01230 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 16 May 1996 14:07:18 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from federal-excess.apple.com (federal-excess.apple.com [17.255.0.16]) by mail-out1.apple.com (8.7.1/8.7.1) with SMTP id NAA09208 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 16 May 1996 13:44:41 -0700
Received: from powertalk.apple.com (powertalk.apple.com [17.202.12.200]) by federal-excess.apple.com (SMI-8.6/8.6.12) with SMTP id NAA14268 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 16 May 1996 13:42:35 -0700
Message-ID: <n1379868162.11917@powertalk.apple.com>
Date: 16 May 1996 21:45:58 -0800
From: "Doug Hill" <doug_hill@powertalk.apple.com>
Subject: Re(2): Apple Sprockets/RAVE
Cc: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
X-Mailer: Mail*Link SMTP-PS 3.0.2
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, I for one had a good time there. Hi to all I saw (Larry, Knucklehead,
Andy). As an Apple employee, I was afraid this was going to be a much more
techno-nerd, geek-fest. But, ravers came through and showed a good vibe. It
probably would have been 10X better if more people had showed up and the 
packed the place. The Single Cell/Freaky Chakra duo rocked the house and so
did the first DJ. There were definately some misses, but there were plenty of
good moments. This is actually the kind of events that could be going on more
if not for the the excessive police force.

And speaking of that: I couldn't believe the scene outside the event after the
cops showed up. I actually counted at least *8* squad cars parked down the
preceding two blocks to the warehouse. This is a major flashback to the
mid/late 80's punk scene in SJ when the cops would bust every show. Why did
they need this show of police force? Is it that the half-empty warehouse of
curious engineers and mellow ravers were such a threat? No! It's because
nobody can do any kind of after-hours event in SJ without paying off the
police to do security for you. It is a major fraud! This is precisely why
nothing happens here in SJ and why it will continue to be a completely boring,
uninteresting place. The cops have driven off everyone who isn't into
corporate greed and political scams. Thank god us south bay ravers have the
city to go to at least. 

BTW, as much as people might think that this was a major corporate event, you
should have seen the place and know you were completely wrong. Tiny warehouse
in one of the lousiest parts of town, very cool computer graphics/obscure
videos, groovy music, *no marketing slogans anywhere*, bizarre chill room.
This was a case where the promoters knew how to work the marketing process at
Apple and get funding to create their own thing. Very big thanks for putting
this on. I'm also glad that those who showed up had a good time and I got to
meet a bunch of cool individuals.

And, in true Apple fashion, they gave out shirts for the event, so, even if
you didn't like getting shut down, it wasn't a complete loss. BTW, I would be
curious to hear the story from the promoters to find out why the cops showed
up in the first place and then decided to shut it down.

doug

 ------ From: John Bagby, Thu, May 16, 1996 ------ 


It was fun, after all!   Freaky Chakra was great--- I'd never heard them 
before...  the place was about 1/2 full, but some good vibes were 
generated by the sfravers, for sure!  It was great meeting all the 
wonderful people who came up to me and introduced themselves!  (Boy, 
wearing a recognizable tee-shirt comes in handy!)

I second Amy's idea for those sfravers in the South Bay to get together 
for a drink, or somethin'...!

;-p

love
john

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu May 16 14:22:20 1996

Received: from shellx.best.com (shellx.best.com [206.86.0.11]) by lazlo.steam.com (8.7.3/8.6.12) with SMTP id OAA01166 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 16 May 1996 14:00:41 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from tgrigsby (tgrigsby.us.dhl.com [199.41.137.104]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id MAA06067 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 16 May 1996 12:49:12 -0700
Date: Thu, 16 May 1996 12:49:12 -0700
Message-Id: <199605161949.MAA06067@shellx.best.com>
X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Review: Cinnamon Toasty Apple Raves
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This was a very small (150 people, maybe?) rave.  It was a nice space -- one 
we South Bay Ravers should look into using again sometime soon.  The main 
dance room had nice visuals, free non-alcoholic drinks.  Chill space had a 
black light, some home movies playing, and a couple of Macs with video 
games.  We figured the ambient consisted of a couple of guys who had found a 
synth and a book, "Ambient for Dummys".  I really wonder if someone switched 
the colored stickers on the keyboard so the poor guy was hitting the wrong 
notes.  Interesting, if rather weird, and the guys doing the ambient did 
have their good moments.  The sound system in the main room was not the best 
but adequate for that size room.  The first guy I heard spinning, Alex, was 
*good*.  There were various people throwing vinyl down after that, ranging 
from ok to fairly flat.

I had a pretty good time dancing and chatting with fellow SFRavers.  It's so 
nice to go to something and know that you'll meet up with people you know 
that have a similar drive to party and dance!

I pooped out around 12:30.  There were cops there at that point, but the 
reason I left was because I had to work the next day, and I just couldn't 
really relax knowing that.

MISCONCEPTION #1:  It was NOT put on by Apple.  It was put on by some ravers 
that work for Apple.

MISCONCEPTION #2:  The cops did not originally intend to bust the party.  
Apparently city ordinance in San Jose requires that the promoter for a party 
have a business license if they charge an entrance fee.  I guess the guy 
that put it on thought he'd get around it by putting a bowl at the front 
door labeled "Donations".  Nope.  So the cops cited him.  When I left he was 
arguing with the cops and getting pretty pissed off.  I suspect that shortly 
after I passed them, the cops got fed up and decided to show the guy what 
they *could* do as opposed to what they had intended to do.

FOR FUTURE REFERENCE: This was a good space and the idea of providing a 
cheap party was excellent.  Two things: First, have a map point where you 
can charge the fee or get a business license.  Second, bring in a HUGE fan 
to push/pull air out of the main room.  It gets hot and humid in a hurry and 
the air just doesn't move, but it wouldn't be difficult to remedy this.

And one more thing: do NOT argue with the cops.  They're doing their jobs.  
Just grin and bear it.  You can bet there are about 10 cops that now have a 
less positive view of our scene due to last night's events.  Personally, I'd 
rather work *with* the authorities than against them...

S

Precedence: bulk

Hey everybody. I was glad that I actually drove the five minutes to get
to the Apple Rave. It was a good party. I was a little skeptical at
first but as usual I was proven wrong. The atmosphere was very good. Me
and my friend (whose account this is, coincidentally enough) met a
couple of people from sfraves. We met John Bagby (PLUR), Adam ( Dr.
Seuss hat) and another John from sf who told us about BAY TO BREAKERS. I
saw several people who were at Madness. It was funny watching the cops
come in and try their best to find out what was going on. One of the
cops was watching us dance and he he had a very self assured "thank god
I'm not one of you degenerates" look on his face. The cops proceeded to
walk through the place and try to figure this one out. They even went
behind the Non-alcoholic bar to look for alcohol and any other
paraphernalia that they could. Unfortunately for them, none was to be
found. I saw one of the cops writing a citation of some sort to a young
lady. Me and my friends were wondering what the reason for it was
because she did not seem to be doing anything noticably wrong. I wonder
if it has something to do with the teenage curfew laws in San Jose (?)
Overall I would like to applaud Freaky Chakra and Single Cell Orchestra
for their outstanding effort. The music was really flowing when the cops
busted the party. I was pleasantly surprised when all of us who stayed
until the very end received a free commerative T-shirt. It is obvious to
me why there are no raves in san jose. The law enforcement establishment
was unable to see this party for the peaceful communal gathering that it
wwas. Me and ionX are eager to meet all those sfravers who reside in the
south bay. We would be more than happy to join all of you for a drink
soon.(as suggested by Amy :).


Dhiren, ionX

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu May 16 15:16:04 1996

Precedence: bulk

Hi everybody! Does anybody know what kind of sound equipment was being
used by the djs playing at around 11 at the apple rave. We were sitting
across the room and it looked like the dj was scratching a turntable
with his maglite. Upon closer inspection, we found out that he was
actually waving his maglite like Merlin's wand over what looked like a
circuit board of some sort. It obviously had sensors built in to read
the movements of the light and synthesize a sound similar to that
movement. It was a real trip watching him weave his magic by moving a
torchlight. If anyone knows what instrument that is would they please
post some info about it or send us mail. Thank you


Peace 
Dhiren and ion x

>...It is obvious to
>me why there are no raves in san jose. The law enforcement establishment
>was unable to see this party for the peaceful communal gathering that it
>was.

What makes everyone think San Fran is any different?  An experienced 
promoter will take care of the various requirements for having an event in 
whatever city they decide to throw the party in.  I was standing outside 
listening to the police officer trying to explain to the promoter that 
*nothing at all* would have happened if he hadn't had the donations bowl 
sitting there.  The promoter came back whining about how the cop had the 
badge so there was nothing he could do.  What the heck is that supposed to 
mean?  It tells me the guy wearing the badge has a job to do, regardless of 
whether or not he enjoys doing it.  What turned it into a bust was a cop 
that got tired of getting badgered for trying to go easy and decided to just 
shut it all down.

Put it this way: I've partied in various venues with various themes and 
music for a long time.  When people follow the rules and respect the 
authorities, it's a good night.  When they don't, it's a bad night.  Simple.

>One of the
>cops was watching us dance and he he had a very self assured "thank god
>I'm not one of you degenerates" look on his face.

I was dancing right in front of that guy wearing my Dr. Seuss hat.  I'm sure 
he was actually thinking, "Geez, where can *I* get a hat like that?"  Ok, 
maybe not...

S

Hey Joel,  

sorry if you got this twice.  This came in on SFRaves.  I thought it was funny
-M

Yeah, be thankful it won't be a Microsoft Rave!
I could imagine all kinds of horrible things at one of those:

	-The voicemail says the party starts at 10pm, but it gets
postponed about twelve times until it finally starts at 11 am the next day
	-They make you buy their own Microsoft Brand water, claiming
that 'all other waters are incompatible with this venue'
	-The sound system inexplicably shuts down every 30 minutes 
	-The visuals consist of slides of Bill Gates superimposed over
Windows wallpaper.bmps
	-After you get into the party and realize it sucks, you find
ticket vendors selling pricey 'ticket-supplements' that grant access to
another, hidden room where the better DJs and better vibe are
	-The promoters run around the party trying to buyout all the
small-scale smoothie vendors

So, support our Apple friends.  They're the last line of defense against
the mediocre hegemony that is Microsoft!

	-jon

I have one thing to say about what belongs on sfraves.  Raving is, to a 
certain extent, a limited topic.  If you start subdividing the whole 
thing into different  music genres/ different spiritualities/ etc. etc., 
the result will be  VERY watered down.  I would hate to see that.  I am 
not knocking the Goa list at all, but why not talk a little about that 
stuff here?  Raving is  about music and I would  certainly enjoy picking the 
brains of people who know a hell of a lot more than I do.  If you dislike 
something, DELETE it!  It's not hard.

-kaySEE

> I agree totally.  Why put the Goa messages on a separate list?

Becuase sfraves is a list dedicated to a specific geographical location.
The Goa list is global.

Additionally, have you considered that the creater of the Goa list
would like to just discuss music, without the major distractions that
appear on sfraves?

The list creater, Andy Kumeda, is not even subscribed to sfraves.  He
is a socal-raver.

I don't see whats the big deal.  If you want to get the the goa info, just
subscribe.

-troy

appreciated.

   From my failing memory, I seem to recall that San Jose has a caberet law 
   where _legal_ clubs & parties need to close at 2pm.  I also know that there 
   was a big write-up in the local rag (Metro) sometime ago indicating that 
   promoters/club owners were required to utilize particular security guard 
   firms that actually hire off-duty police.  The article addressed it as a 
   scam.  Perhaps SJ's finest got a bit grumpy 'cause they weren't involved or 
   they wanted to make more of it...wonders never cease, do they?
   
   Having a delicious low-key day,
   Diane

What I find most interesting is the fact that even Apple (Apple!) can't 
throw a party without it being busted.  You would think an event sponsored 
by a corporate giant would not be as prone to busting as say a small 
collective of relative insignificance.  (One making a substantial 
contribution to the local economy, the other making a huge racket all 
night.)

account, so *hopefully* I'll be back within a week...

Anyway, I've met a bunch of you and you're all wonderful people. I'll keep
going to parties and such over summer, so I'll see you around. It'll just
be a lot harder getting rides and BARTing and stuff. =) I guess now I'll
have to meet some south bay SFRavers?

Thanks for the good times,
-m.

The big fun was at Madness last weekend with bumpy techno in a cool
indoor/outdoor space in the city - just the way I like it.  This weekend
features a bunch of out-of-town guests - Pierre, Miss Thing, Reese and
Keoki; Nikita probably also has a big guest DJ but I don't have the list
handy - call the number I guess.  I think there's also a party at 
111 Minna on Friday that I forgot the info for.

Thanks for everyone who sent in updates this week (and past weeks)!


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi

       daily.

     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * the Global Party Network Buzzline - 415.568.1338
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning 3am-6am - "Aural Fixation"
       experimental sounds of ambient and trip hop with a splash of hi
       nrg, from trance to jungle. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 17 00:36:06 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id AAA29948; Fri, 17 May 1996 00:36:06 -0700
Received: from scruz.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id AAA29943; Fri, 17 May 1996 00:36:03 -0700
Received: from [165.227.109.23] by scruz.net (8.7.3/1.34)
	id AAA26671; Fri, 17 May 1996 00:36:44 -0700 (PDT)
X-Sender: anarch@mail.scruznet.com
Message-Id: <v01530503adc1ea39477c@[165.227.109.23]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 17 May 1996 00:38:48 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: anarch@scruznet.com (Anarch)
Subject: Re: Rave/Media Essay (Super Long)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Starchild <star@sfsu.edu> wrote:
>My computer tells me that on Fri, 10 May 1996, Kyung Rok shared (in part):
>> Though perhaps better sent on a Tuesday instead of a Friday afternoon,
>> this is about 1/4 of a cultural studies piece titled "Moral Panic, the
>> Media and British Rave Culture."  Written by Sarah Thornton...
>
>> The term "underground" is the expression by which clubbers refer to
>> things subcultural. More than fashionable or trendy, underground sounds
>> and styles are "authentic," and pitted against the mass-produced and
>> mass-consumed....
>
>Fortunately I don't think ravers delight much in "parental
>incomprehension."...

I think a valid distinction can be made between underground and
non-underground on the basis of the amount of effort (knowledge, cost,
inconvenience, time, etc.) required for an individual to engage oneself in
"the scene."  Of course, a clear line cannot be drawn across the
spectrum...as Chesterton, or whoever it was, had it, though no one may be
able to discern the exact point at which day becomes night, one can
tolerably distinguish the two nonetheless.

>> That's what I mean by underground."Undergrounds define themselves most
>> clearly by what they're not, that is "main stream."...
>
>What we are really doing when we dis mainstream culture,
>after all, is dissing humanity at large, saying most people are stupid,
>base, and lack[ing in] taste and culture.

They are.  Amazingly enough, it's possible to like them all the same.

>I think
>her observation is correct, and it's unfortunate, because while certainly
>it can have problematic *aspects*, to say that popularization *itself*
>is the problem is truly cynical and elitist.

Yes.

>> ...youth. whatever their
>> class enjoy a momentary reprieve from "necessity."'! In other words,
>> youth are exempt from adult commitments to the accumulation of economic
>> capital. They temporarily enjoy what Bourdieu argues is normally reserved
>> for the bourgeoisie; that is, a "taste of liberty or luxury. "
>
>	This is troubling to me, because it reminds me that so few
>people, as they grow older, manage to live outside these "adult
>commitments to the accumulation of economic capital."

The issues here are deeper than acknowledged by Thornton.  *By definition*,
youth is relieved from the responsibilities of adulthood.  In our
contemporary culture, this equates to a relief from the accumulation of
capital and a taste of liberty and luxury, because we live in a capitalist
society that makes accumulation of capital a primary responsibility and
which rewards success along those lines with luxury and liberty.  Youth,
freed of responsibility by the effort of adulthood, can reap adulthood's
rewards without effort.

>Just look at our
>cultural forebears, the hippies.  For the most part, the '60s generation
>has blended into the workforce without fulfilling the dreams of their
>youth of social change toward a world of peace, love, harmony, and fun.

Personally, though I have no factual experience on which to base these
judgements, I think that the popular view of "our cultural forebears" is a
mistaken one, that the prominence of these figures owes more to their
extremity than to their prevalence, and that their apparent lack of effect
on the course of history results simply because they are moving against the
tide, not because their tide has ebbed.  I don't know any sometime
"hippies" who have become their own antitheses by trading the ideals that
motivated them in the past for those they strove against.  I do know some,
however, whose extemity has faded as they have aged and the cultural
spotlight has shifted, who yet continue to work for their old ideals in
subtler, less strident ways: through their children, through their friends,
through their communities.

Of course, I live in Santa Cruz.

anarch@scruznet.com

on Saturday (That's Friday night continued for those of you keeping track 
in that manner :P) on KDVS 90.3fm.  The station can be heard through the 
contral valley, but best in Davis/Sacramento.  
Be sure to also listen to DJ Jericho on KDVS mondays 12-2pm  :)

--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+---
                 "Uncle" Noah Apodaca - napodaca@ucdavis.edu
                    Student, Disc Jockey, Resident Advisor


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 17 01:56:16 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id BAA05165; Fri, 17 May 1996 01:56:16 -0700
Received: from elroy.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id BAA05158; Fri, 17 May 1996 01:56:13 -0700
Received: by elroy.ucdavis.edu (8.7.5/UCD3.5.4)

From: Uncle Noah <napodaca@ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: ez031733@elroy.ucdavis.edu
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: James Brown
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960517015123.29797F-100000@elroy.ucdavis.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Okay, I found out about the show from this list, so I figure it's okay to 
post about going. 
I went to the Thursday night show and I can sum the experience up in two 
words:  James Brown.
An _amazing_ show -- wonderful location, really cool visuals (really!), 
great lighting, awesome sound and a wonderful happy vibe (despite the 
couple of little tiffs).  At one point the Godfather of Soul told us all 
to turn to the person on our right and tell them that we love them and 
then turn to the person on our left and tell them that we love them too.  
How much more could you ask for?!  A great great great show.  And such a 
wonderful diversity of people!  Every kind of person from biker to 
suit-and-tie to 70's retro folks, old, young, fat, skinny, dark, light 
and everything else.  Everyone was there and for the most part just happy 
and out-of-their mind.  If you ever get a chance to go see James Brown, 
don't hesitate.  Just go.  You have appreciated his records, you have 
appreciated manipulation of his samples, but nothing _nothing_ can 
compare to seeing it live.  63 years old and he still stances like a maniac!
Jee wiz.  What a show!
Did any other SFRAVErs go to the Thursday night show?

--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+---
                 "Uncle" Noah Apodaca - napodaca@ucdavis.edu
                    Student, Disc Jockey, Resident Advisor

Tony Rotundo wrote:
> 
> What I find most interesting is the fact that even Apple (Apple!) can't
> throw a party without it being busted.  You would think an event sponsored
> by a corporate giant would not be as prone to busting as say a small
> collective of relative insignificance.  (One making a substantial
> contribution to the local economy, the other making a huge racket all
> night.)
> 
> We shall win the war one battle (and one hug) at a time.  :^)
> 
> Anyone know if any official Apple representatives were there to defend the
> party?  Or were they long gone, home in bed with their wives and
> mistresses, husbands and misters.  :^)
> 
> Tony

AAARRRGGGHHH!!!!!

What the cops told the guy throwing the party was that they had to
shut it down because he did not have a business license and he was
accepting cash at the door. What a crock of shit! Come on, there
a sign on the table which specifically said "Donations". Apparently
the cops didn't buy this, and were determined to shut the party down
right from the start. 

First of all, that party was completely clean. There were no dealers
hanging out at the entrance, no blatant pot smoking, NO ALCOHOL!
Everybody was just having a good time. I personally was really stoked
to see all the Apple people goin' off!. 

What really pissed me off was when I was outside witnessing the cop
harassing the Apple guy, the cop said, "96% of what you were trying to
do tonight was good. We're not going to haul you off the San Quentin,
but you're at least going to receive a citation.". This cop was really
a dick!

[taking a deep breath]

Well, on a positive note, I was glad to see all of you again, as
briefly as it was. I second the motion that us south bay sfraves
should get together sometime. Till then, take care and PLUR.

Hugs,

CT

>>Hey, you guys should ask Captain Crunch about Apple,
>
>John Draper, whaddya say to this???

After I met Woz,  he wanted me to design the telephone interface board.
So I designed a board with an ADC/DAC that controlled the audio,
switch-hook,  and it could send and decode any kind of tones,
as well as differentiate speech from tones,  but would not recognize
speech.   Remember,  this was 1977 (July to be exact).   I have some
of these stores on my WEB site.

http://www.well.com/user/crunch
  Play --> Stories --> Early days

Back then Apple wasn't corperate...  Only Mike Scott (CEO at the time)
and Mike Markula wore suits.   Boy,  have things changed.  This doesn't
have much to so with raving,   but getting back to the subject,  it
appears that Apple didn't pay the San Jose police enough money...  Thats
strange that it got busted...  I bet it was funny,  watching people dance
in suits.... But at the MacWorld Expo,   a few years ago,  they had
a rave,  actually,  it was my 2nd rave (where I danced) and it was
actually the "NextWorld Expo" for Next hackers.   The rave was the
Stone rave,  and was at 1015 Folsom... It was really good,   I get there
about 7 pm  (No rave music playing),  then about 9 pm or so,   the
thumpin beats are gradually mixed in,   and a half hour later,  the
dance floor was filled.  It was really good.

My next rave after that was WICKED at the Sound Factory the following
Saturday...  Then,  I was hooked...   But didn't do ANY drugs then,
but dug it BIG TIME,  so I can contribute my raving very closly with
computers in this sense.    About 3 weeks later....   Let Freedom Rave,
3rd of July,  Livermore racetrack...  Candyflipped....  Went beserk,
Remember the hill fire?

Oh,  one more thing... Forbes ASAP has a piece on me....   June issue,
check it out....Haven't read it yet though

Crunchman

Message-Id: <v03006670adc268dbe844@DialupEudora>
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960517015123.29797F-100000@elroy.ucdavis.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 17 May 1996 10:01:07 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Tony Rotundo <tony@xinet.COM>
Subject: Re: James Brown
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I must have been at the other James Brown show.  I felt you were right-on
in all of your description except for the parts about JB.  The crowd was
cool, the space excellent, the lights (colored oil under an overhead, old
technique I hear) were good.  The sound was at times very piercing, but not
bad.

He never really played a full song.  It was more presented as a
compilation.  I was never really able to bust a move because just as a song
started, it would end about 30-45 seconds later.  The cues were horrible.
He never busted a move as far as I saw.  I was watching too.

Yes, he's extremely charismatic, especially for his age, but I would not go
so far as to tell everyone I know to drop their computers immediately and
go see James Brown.  I saw frustration, more than anything, in the crowd.
It *was* great when he said,  "Turn to the person to your left and tell
them that James Brown loves them."  Pause.  "Now turn to the right and tell
them that James Brown loves them."  I honestly can't remember any moment
where he had a grooving fat, funky JB energy flowing for more than a minute
and a half.  One thing I really found frustrating was that JB never sang
even a smidgen of a song alone, but rather the back-up singers, et al,
would chime in following every line he belted out.  As a non-exact example
he would sing, "This is a man's world..." and the others would be like,
"Man's world; man's world!"  And while that's nice every once in a while,
it would happen with nearly every line he sang.

It was a unique experience, and I'm glad I went, and more glad that some
people had a fantastic time.  Please don't let me discourage you from
checking him out, but again, I honestly can't recommend with as much zeal
as Uncle Noah that you go see the "the man working the hardest at making it
look like he's the hardest working man in show business."

I met SFRer Melissa Woodrow, and that was excellent, though it was hard to
communicate.

Sorry to do this to you Noah, but your malapropism only sums up how I felt
about it:  >compare to seeing it live.  63 years old and he still stances
like a maniac!
                                              ^^^^^^^

Peace and flame retardent suit set at "roast".

Tone

P.S.  The opening band (Sy Klops ?!) was too contrived.

At 1:56 AM  -0700 5/17/96, Uncle Noah wrote:
>Okay, I found out about the show from this list, so I figure it's okay to
>post about going.
>I went to the Thursday night show and I can sum the experience up in two
>words:  James Brown.
>An _amazing_ show -- wonderful location, really cool visuals (really!),
>great lighting, awesome sound and a wonderful happy vibe (despite the
>couple of little tiffs).  At one point the Godfather of Soul told us all
>to turn to the person on our right and tell them that we love them and
>then turn to the person on our left and tell them that we love them too.
>How much more could you ask for?!  A great great great show.  And such a
>wonderful diversity of people!  Every kind of person from biker to
>suit-and-tie to 70's retro folks, old, young, fat, skinny, dark, light
>and everything else.  Everyone was there and for the most part just happy
>and out-of-their mind.  If you ever get a chance to go see James Brown,
>don't hesitate.  Just go.  You have appreciated his records, you have
>appreciated manipulation of his samples, but nothing _nothing_ can
>compare to seeing it live.  63 years old and he still stances like a maniac!
>Jee wiz.  What a show!
>Did any other SFRAVErs go to the Thursday night show?
>
>--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+---
>                 "Uncle" Noah Apodaca - napodaca@ucdavis.edu
>                    Student, Disc Jockey, Resident Advisor

I've debated whether to post this to the group ... but I just have to ....

I brought my best girlfriend to the SFR picnic with me.  Sara, who had just
returned from 3 months in India, was very mellow and transitioning back into
this world...

She met someone there to whom she gave her phone number to, and now she has
subsequently been the victim on some of the most disgusting and horrifying
obscene phone calls ... (which have been recorded fyi)

Last night, she was able to determine, using call return, that it does appear
this was the person she met at the picnic, and now some roommate or something
has also called.  The phone company and police have been notified.

My request:  I don't know if this person is a SFR member, but if you do read
this, PLEASE KNOCK IT OFF!  It is so inhuman and so sick to terrorize someone
with these unwelcome incidents, and Sara is not interested in you.  Please LEAVE
HER ALONE!  She is a kindhearted person and in no way deserves this treatment.

We know who you are, and we will do whatever is necessary to stop this
harrassment, but prefer that it stops because you choose to do so.

Thank you.

Leslie

Pack-a-bowl was really fun.  I highly reccomend it to anyone who can go.  
We had a small, but spirited, group of sfravers.  I guess Leslie is 
right, most ppl are pretty bad bowlers, but I still think I own the crown 
on that one.  I couldn't even hold the ball and kept dropping it (I just 
hope too many ppl weren't watching:)

The music was wonderful.  And quite a crowd showed up.  It was a really 
mellow, fun thing to do on a Thursday night.  My only gripe was the group 
of people who decided to set up a NO2 tank in the girls' bathroom.  

Have a fun weekend, everyone.  I may go out on Saturday night (possibly 
to Fresh Start), so I hope to see some of you around.  I'm headed to the 
JB show tonight......

chau,
kaysee

part is that I beat Renaud - ha! :)  Man you should see that guy bowl.  We
went to packabowl a couple of weeks ago, Renaud having _never_ bowled
before (apparently bowling and raves aren't a good mix in FRANCE) and he
managed to kick my ass. (What me? competitive?  not a chance)  I succeded
in demonstrating my sublime grace by slipping on my ass and sliding down
the lane.  ha, ha, ha!

Wow, I want to express my thanks and appreciation for the huge volume of
responses I got about this horrible episode of obscene calls to my friend.
Reading all of these very quick and loving responses reaffirms my respect for
our group.

Several people asked who specifically this is -- I don't know this person
personally, although I would recognize him if I saw him, and we know his first
name.  However, I don't want to share that because 1) there is a very remote
possibility it is not that person, and 2) there would really be no useful
purpose in it.  However if it continues, we do have a photo of him at the
picnic.

Several people, including Larry Ching, offered personal apologies about this
nastiness.  Thank you all so much for your support. 

Please be assured that in no way do Sara or I think there is any responsibility
or connection to the SFR group at all -- even if this jerk is actively on SFR,
which I'm not sure he is, this is one person with one twisted part of his
personality, and that's not the responsiblity of the organizers of either SFR or
the picnic -- so please don't take this on your shoulders with any guilt or
responsibility -- only the caller is responsible (and apparently his roommate,
another scummy creep obviously) .. and he carries all of that on himself.  

Sara has been a raver for many years, and she knows that this is not about this
group, and it's not about ravers in general ..... it's about one mixed-up creepy
person.  

My hope is that he IS on this list and he'll understand that this behavior has
repercussions, including the worst of karma, not to mention potential legal
penalties, and will simply stop.  If not, we now have LOTS OF PEOPLE in the
posse to stand up for Sara's (and every person's) right not to be harrassed!  

Thanks you all, I'm printing all these messages for Sara!

Much love to everyone,   Leslie  : )

Subject: Interesting SFR Picnic/Party thought
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello!

The timing of this idea may be coming at a bad time, considering the sad
news Leslie has shared with us, but we can't let the actions of one or two
children inhibit our desire to get together on a regular basis.

Last night in the effort to communicate coherently with Melissa at JB, our
conversation got on to how cool the picnic was.  (Lots of nods, two thumbs
up and smiles.)  I said something like, "hell, we should do that once a
month."  I immediately ammended that and though once every other month
would be nice, and a lot less pressure.

Here's the idea.  We (SFR) set-up a spot, organize logistics, do promotion,
and handle as much as possible the leg work of having picnic party, and ask
a different production group to come, with their sound system and DJs.

What's in it for us is that we get a different "feel" of each party, and a
great cross section of the different styles of music in the Bay Area.
What's in it for them?  They get a hassle free, organized event that all
they have to do is show up (I guess and bring a system :) and bring friends.

Any ideas?

Tone

P.S.  I wasn't envisioning the massive BBQ that Knucklehead has, but maybe
a couple Webbers would do.  I have a massive Webber (Big Bertha) that loves
to be used.  ;^)

>...It is obvious to
>me why there are no raves in san jose. The law enforcement establishment
>was unable to see this party for the peaceful communal gathering that it
>was.

What makes everyone think San Fran is any different?  An experienced 
promoter will take care of the various requirements for having an event in 
whatever city they decide to throw the party in.  I was standing outside 
listening to the police officer trying to explain to the promoter that 
*nothing at all* would have happened if he hadn't had the donations bowl 
sitting there.  The promoter came back whining about how the cop had the 
badge so there was nothing he could do.  What the heck is that supposed to 
mean?  It tells me the guy wearing the badge has a job to do, regardless of 
whether or not he enjoys doing it.  What turned it into a bust was a cop 
that got tired of getting badgered for trying to go easy and decided to just 
shut it all down.

Put it this way: I've partied in various venues with various themes and 
music for a long time.  When people follow the rules and respect the 
authorities, it's a good night.  When they don't, it's a bad night.  Simple.

>One of the
>cops was watching us dance and he he had a very self assured "thank god
>I'm not one of you degenerates" look on his face.

I was dancing right in front of that guy wearing my Dr. Seuss hat.  I'm sure 
he was actually thinking, "Geez, where can *I* get a hat like that?"  Ok, 
maybe not...

S

Subject: Fwd: |NER| Fwd: NYC club owner in 'ecstasy' bust (fwd)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
X-Orcl-Application: Sender:  owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Orcl-Application: Precedence:  bulk


>From what I have heard about the Tunnel in NYC, it is a less than PLURRY place.
This is still extremely bad news....

-troy

---------------------------------

	NEW YORK, May 15 (UPI) -- A New York City nightclub impresario was  
arrested Wednesday and charged with turning two of his popular hot spots 
into drug dens by distributing the hallucinogen ``ecstasy'' to his young 
patrons. 
	Brooklyn U.S. Attorney Zachary Carter said Peter Gatien transformed  
Tunnel and the Limelight into ``virtual ecstasy supermarkets,'' selling 
up to 2,000 pills per month at $35 to $40 a pop. 
	``What's really remarkable was we determined that dealing drugs was  
not just a lucrative sideline, but was the centerpiece of the operation, 
'' Carter said. ``It could be said that these clubs existed to 
distribute these drugs.'' 
	Carter said an eight-month investigation into the distribution of the  
designer drug in New York led them directly to Gatien. He said Gatien 
hired a director and ``party promoters'' whose duties included guarding 
the door to let ``house dealers'' of the drug inside and then warn them 
when New York City police officers came around. 
	The club also took a cut of the dealers' profits, officials said.  
	The multicolored ecstasy pills -- sold under names like ``fruitloops,''  
``cat's eye,'' ``playboys'' and ``doves'' -- were apparently smuggled 
into the country from Amsterdam, the Netherlands, Montreal, Canada and 
Miami, said Drug Enforcement Administration Special Agent Carlo Boccia. 
	The drug is known to produce a combination of effects, including a  
euphoric high, relaxation and mild hallucinations, Boccia said. High 
doses have been linked to psychosis, brain damage and even death. 
	``The public needs to realize that the high visibility of clubs such  
as these glamorize the use and distribution of these illegal substances, 
'' Boccia said. 
	``Those who sell these drugs, albeit surrounded by the splendor and  
glitz of 'fashionable' nightclubs, are no less the scourge than those 
who hide in the back alleys of the inner city to dispense their poison. 
These people are just as bad, if not worse.'' 
	Gatien and 21 others were arrested in pre-dawn raids and 6,000 pills  
were confiscated. The defendants were charged with conspiracy to 
distribute ecstasy. They face maximum prison terms of 20 years if 
convicted. 
	Carter has also filed a motion to seize any of Gatien's ill-gotten  
assets and other physical property related to the alleged drug 
operation. 
	The clubs can remain open until a judge's ruling on the matter, he  
said.

Dear Friends & Family,

	I hope many of you took the time to read this.  It's not in fact 
specifically about the rave scene, but I definitely found it relevant.

My computer tells me that on Fri, 10 May 1996, Kyung Rok shared (in part):

> Though perhaps better sent on a Tuesday instead of a Friday afternoon, 
> this is about 1/4 of a cultural studies piece titled "Moral Panic, the 
> Media and British Rave Culture."  Written by Sarah Thornton, the rest of 
> this essay can be found in "Microphone fiends : Youth Music & Youth 
> Culture / edited by Andrew Ross & Tricia Rose. Routledge, 1994.

A few of the observations I found most interesting, and some comments of 
my own:

> ___
> The idea that authentic culture is somehow outside media and commerce is a 
> resilient one. In its full-blown romantic form, the belief imagines that 
> grass-roots cultures resist and struggle with a colonizing mass-mediated 
> corporate world

Although the problems with media and commercial interests are many, I am 
forced to agree with the author's indictment of our anti-media and 
anti-commercial outlook, as if our culture is somehow pure and real, and 
immune from the greed, mediocrity, and tastelessness we see in media and 
commerce.  The indictment of commerce may be due to the "temporary 
respite" many of us who are young possess from "adult commitments of 
accumulation of economic capital" (see below), but this doesn't make it 
correct.  

> In exploring this case, this article finds no opposition between 
> subcultures and the media, except for a dogged ideological one. It 
> uncovers no pure origins or organic homologies of sound, style and 
> ritual, nor does it vilify a vague monolith called "The media." Instead, 
> it examines how various media are integral to youth's social and 
> ideological formations. Micromedia like flyers and listings are means by 
> which club organizers bring the crowd together; niche media like the 
> music press construct as much as they document subcultures; while mass 
> media like the tabloids develop as much as do youth movements. Contrary 
> to youth discourses, then, subcultures do not germinate from
> seed and grow by force of their own energy into mysterious movements to 
> be belatedly ingested by the media. Rather, media are there and effective 
> right from the start. 

Again, this seems true.  SFRaves is part of the media, although it has 
the advantage of being a better-informed, more personal, and less 
restricted than large mass media outlets, plus the crucial point of being 
truly interactive.  Damning "the media" indiscriminately doesn't reflect 
well on our ability to comprehend that media are an important part of 
any culture, including ours.  Nor do they fit well into neat boxes of 
"mainstream" and "underground" media based on audience size or by whether 
they call themselves underground or alternative.

> The term "underground" is the expression by which clubbers refer to 
> things subcultural. More than fashionable or trendy, underground sounds 
> and styles are "authentic," and pitted against the mass-produced and 
> mass-consumed. Underqrounds denote exclusive worlds whose main point is 
> not elitism. but whose parameters often relate to particular crowds. They 
> delight in parental incomprehension, negative newspaper coverage and that 
> best blessing in disguise, the BBC ban. More than anything else, then, 
> undergrounds define themselves against the mass media.

Fortunately I don't think ravers delight much in "parental 
incomprehension."  From what I've seen, many of us have actually tried to 
bring our parents into the scene, and share the joy with them.  We do 
however, it seems to me, take an unseemly delight in negative media 
coverage:  Ridiculing them for lack of knowledge of our scene, taking the 
attitude "they just don't get it" as if they are incapable of getting it, 
reveling in our perceived superiority -- these attitudes don't reflect 
well on our community.  Which is not to say that we should go along with 
negative coverage -- we should seek to inform and correct it, and to 
fight it when it refuses to be informed and corrected.

> That's what I mean by underground."Undergrounds define themselves most 
> clearly by what they're not, that is "main stream." Although there is 
> variation, the oft-repeated expression by which they refer to mainstream 
> clubs is that these are places where "Sharon and Tracy dance around their 
> handbags." This mainstream is decried as passive, indiscriminate and 
> uncommitted to dance culture; it is ridiculed for its " herd instinct" 
> and " bandwagon mentality. " 

When I find myself dissing mainstream culture, I try to check myself.  I 
do not think it is a good habit, although it is an easy one to fall 
into.  What we are really doing when we dis mainstream culture, 
after all, is dissing humanity at large, saying most people are stupid, 
base, and lack taste and culture.  Now if we hold out the hope of 
reforming mainstream culture by making the underground the mainstream, 
that is different, for that is saying that there is hope for humanity, 
that humanity at large is not to blame, only current social attitudes.
	Note in the paragraph below where the author says that 
popularization is seen as a problem by the underground.  I think 
her observation is correct, and it's unfortunate, because while certainly 
it can have problematic *aspects*, to say that popularization *itself* 
is the problem is truly cynical and elitist.  

> ...subcultures romanticize "the street" 
> and the crowd, not artists' studios and individual genius. Moreover, 
> rather than the dreaded "trickle down," the problem for underground 
> subculture is popularization by a gushing up to the mainstream. 

I have myself noticed this tendency to romanticize "the street."  I think 
this can take several forms, one being the old argument that "If you 
aren't (X) yourself, or haven't done (X) yourself, or haven't been to (X) 
yourself, you aren't qualified to have an opinion on (X)."  Personally I 
have always thought this an extremely weak way of invalidating someone 
else's point of view.  Another way "the street" gets romanticized is by 
dissing "book smarts" in favor of an ill-defined "you've got to go out 
there and experience it, man" approach.
	I once occurred to me after a trip to L.A. that when people there are 
stuck up it seems to be more about how much money they have, who they 
know that's famous, whereas when people in S.F. are stuck up it's more 
often about how much a part of some "underground elite" they are.

> ...youth. whatever their 
> class enjoy a momentary reprieve from "necessity."'! In other words, 
> youth are exempt from adult commitments to the accumulation of economic 
> capital. They temporarily enjoy what Bourdieu argues is normally reserved 
> for the bourgeoisie; that is, a "taste of liberty or luxury. "

	This is troubling to me, because it reminds me that so few 
people, as they grow older, manage to live outside these "adult 
commitments to the accumulation of economic capital."  Just look at our 
cultural forebears, the hippies.  For the most part, the '60s generation 
has blended into the workforce without fulfilling the dreams of their 
youth of social change toward a world of peace, love, harmony, and fun.
	It troubles me that many ravers do not even seem to have such 
noble dreams.  Many of us have no hope of changing the world.  We do 
not think beyond the next party, beyond how great our favorite dance 
music is.  When the music is old, and a new generation seeking its own 
values finds something else to turn to besides raves, with different 
music and perhaps different values, what will we have changed?  If we're not 
even idealistic now, how crassly cynical and materialist may we become in 
thirty years?  I know this is a downer, but I say it not out of cynicism, 
but out of hope that we will make a difference, ravers young and old.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 17 14:40:44 1996

[ to sfraves list ]

 Being that I'm writing this during my work hours at a merciless greedy
corporate giant , I'll try to keep it short -

Some Stuff RE: Apple "Sprockets" "Rave"

1. Looked just like a rave when I showed up at the announced opening
time of 8PM - ie nothing ready quite yet, guys running around trying to 
get stuff set up. I must say that they had a DJ working at the turntables at 
least! Although he would be cut off every once and awhile as they tweaked
the system for Freaky Chakra. I think the DJ's name was Alex ( not MAD
Alex ).

2. Nobody that I noticed in suits or nametags. On the whole , the dress
was either California yuppy casual with the occasional individualistic
touch ( unique tie or pin or hairdo ) or what you'd see at a rave ( no
naked people or "costumes" , tho ).

3. Free non-alcoholic drinks and snack food included in the $5 admin.

4. I left 15 minutes before the cops showed up - must have been some
personal 6th sense. Maybe it was the speaker stack placed in front of 
the open window that gave me a hint .... Nobody from Apple that was
arranging this was in suits, so there was no one to impress the police
with, much less Jerry Brown.

5. By the way , thanks to the folks who arranged for the event! I understand
they had to rent the space for over $1000 last night. If I remember, at
least one of them subscribes to SFRaves - so "hello!".

6. South Bay SFRavers - getting together sounds good to me! As Mr.
Knucklehead knows, it's the organizing that's the tough part.

 Gotta get back to looking like I'm working!!!!

Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com ( No , I don't work for NETCOM )

PS - HI! to all the folks I met last night , even if I don't remember
your name(s)! It was great to meet new folks and match faces to email
names.

I don't see whats the big deal.  If you want to get the the goa info, just

I have one thing to say about what belongs on sfraves.  Raving is, to a 
certain extent, a limited topic.  If you start subdividing the whole 
thing into different  music genres/ different spiritualities/ etc. etc., 
the result will be  VERY watered down.  I would hate to see that.  I am 
not knocking the Goa list at all, but why not talk a little about that 
stuff here?  Raving is  about music and I would  certainly enjoy picking the 
brains of people who know a hell of a lot more than I do.  If you dislike 
something, DELETE it!  It's not hard.

-kaySEE

>conversation got on to how cool the picnic was.  (Lots of nods, two thumbs
>up and smiles.)  I said something like, "hell, we should do that once a
>month."  I immediately ammended that and though once every other month
>would be nice, and a lot less pressure.
>

>Tone
>
Excellent idea!  I'm in like phlegm (Flynn?).  Every other or every three
months would be good, as someone mentioned before that every month might be
a burden, and not everyone's schedule is sufficiently friendly.  My
presence and contributions to ongoing picnics will be high (so to speak...
;)).  Who's with us?

- E
