At 02:20 PM 5/17/96 -0800, you wrote:

>Last night in the effort to communicate coherently with Melissa at JB, our
>conversation got on to how cool the picnic was.  (Lots of nods, two thumbs
>up and smiles.)  I said something like, "hell, we should do that once a
>month."  I immediately ammended that and though once every other month
>would be nice, and a lot less pressure.

I was liking that idea as well. I had a great time doing the Picnic. I'd be
up for a monthly thing.
>
>Here's the idea.  We (SFR) set-up a spot, organize logistics, do promotion,
>and handle as much as possible the leg work of having picnic party, and ask
>a different production group to come, with their sound system and DJs.

This is a good idea. I started doing that in the begining, but found few
people that wanted or could show up for a meeting to organize it. I found
myself doing most of it, which I didn't mind doing, and had a few people
help out at the end. It was very scary not knowing for sure if people would
actually do what they said they would. I think if we were to pull off a
monthly BBQ, it would have to be well organized.

>
>What's in it for us is that we get a different "feel" of each party, and a
>great cross section of the different styles of music in the Bay Area.
>What's in it for them?  They get a hassle free, organized event that all
>they have to do is show up (I guess and bring a system :) and bring friends.


Plus, I think everyone would have a Great time and give us a chance to meet
more people on a different level unlike an actual night time party. There is
more time to just kick back in the sun and get to know people.

>Any ideas?
>
>Tone
>
>P.S.  I wasn't envisioning the massive BBQ that Knucklehead has, but maybe
>a couple Webbers would do.  I have a massive Webber (Big Bertha) that loves
>to be used.  ;^)
>

Hey, I'm putting a new grill on it here soon. I highly suggest if we plan on
having more then 100 people, we should use may BBQ. I had alot of people
come up to me and say the loved my big BBQ. I think it gives off a good
little feeling seeing a big old BBQ there, kinda cool, but a bunch of webers
would do it to. I just wanted to add that if anyone want to use it for a
party or whatever just let me know a week or so before hand and you got it.


I'm all up for a monthly BBQ, let make it work!! Throwin in my Buck 2.59

Tim (knucklehead)

[ to sfraves list ]

 I was thinking ( ohoh ), about an idea I had some months ago but never 
followed up on. My idea was , if it was known that an event was going to
be happening in the evening in Santa Cruz or the South Bay , that folks
could get together for a daytime picnic before heading off to the rave!

 Those who remember the SFRaves get together I organized called RadioRadio
a few years ago might remember the park it was held in - Sunnyvale Baylands
Park. That's a nice site - there are some other parks I was thinking of 
as well. 

 Not so much like a Sunset , with a sound system and DJs. Mostly just 
chilling and grilling and kite flying and chatting.

 So - anybody involved with doing Santa Cruz/South Bay events can give
hints about any June events? ( I guess Tribal Future makes the first
weekend in June out of consideration ).

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 17 15:20:31 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA23151; Fri, 17 May 1996 14:53:26 -0700

From: Uncle Noah <napodaca@ucdavis.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: James Brown
MIME-Version: 1.0
Message-Id: <96May17.144534pdt.4953@godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com>
Date: Fri, 17 May 1996 11:06:28 PDT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Okay, I found out about the show from this list, so I figure it's okay to 
post about going. 
I went to the Thursday night show and I can sum the experience up in two 
words:  James Brown.
An _amazing_ show -- wonderful location, really cool visuals (really!), 
great lighting, awesome sound and a wonderful happy vibe (despite the 
couple of little tiffs).  At one point the Godfather of Soul told us all 
to turn to the person on our right and tell them that we love them and 
then turn to the person on our left and tell them that we love them too.  
How much more could you ask for?!  A great great great show.  And such a 
wonderful diversity of people!  Every kind of person from biker to 
suit-and-tie to 70's retro folks, old, young, fat, skinny, dark, light 
and everything else.  Everyone was there and for the most part just happy 
and out-of-their mind.  If you ever get a chance to go see James Brown, 
don't hesitate.  Just go.  You have appreciated his records, you have 
appreciated manipulation of his samples, but nothing _nothing_ can 
compare to seeing it live.  63 years old and he still stances like a maniac!
Jee wiz.  What a show!
Did any other SFRAVErs go to the Thursday night show?

--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+---
                 "Uncle" Noah Apodaca - napodaca@ucdavis.edu
                    Student, Disc Jockey, Resident Advisor

From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

>>Hey, you guys should ask Captain Crunch about Apple,
>
>John Draper, whaddya say to this???

After I met Woz,  he wanted me to design the telephone interface board.
So I designed a board with an ADC/DAC that controlled the audio,
switch-hook,  and it could send and decode any kind of tones,
as well as differentiate speech from tones,  but would not recognize
speech.   Remember,  this was 1977 (July to be exact).   I have some
of these stores on my WEB site.

http://www.well.com/user/crunch
  Play --> Stories --> Early days

Back then Apple wasn't corperate...  Only Mike Scott (CEO at the time)
and Mike Markula wore suits.   Boy,  have things changed.  This doesn't
have much to so with raving,   but getting back to the subject,  it
appears that Apple didn't pay the San Jose police enough money...  Thats
strange that it got busted...  I bet it was funny,  watching people dance
in suits.... But at the MacWorld Expo,   a few years ago,  they had
a rave,  actually,  it was my 2nd rave (where I danced) and it was
actually the "NextWorld Expo" for Next hackers.   The rave was the
Stone rave,  and was at 1015 Folsom... It was really good,   I get there
about 7 pm  (No rave music playing),  then about 9 pm or so,   the
thumpin beats are gradually mixed in,   and a half hour later,  the
dance floor was filled.  It was really good.

My next rave after that was WICKED at the Sound Factory the following
Saturday...  Then,  I was hooked...   But didn't do ANY drugs then,
but dug it BIG TIME,  so I can contribute my raving very closly with
computers in this sense.    About 3 weeks later....   Let Freedom Rave,
3rd of July,  Livermore racetrack...  Candyflipped....  Went beserk,
Remember the hill fire?

Oh,  one more thing... Forbes ASAP has a piece on me....   June issue,
check it out....Haven't read it yet though

Crunchman

>

> throw a party without it being busted.  You would think an event sponsored
> by a corporate giant would not be as prone to busting as say a small
> collective of relative insignificance.  (One making a substantial
> contribution to the local economy, the other making a huge racket all
> night.)
> 
> We shall win the war one battle (and one hug) at a time.  :^)

> Anyone know if any official Apple representatives were there to defend the
> party?  Or were they long gone, home in bed with their wives and
> mistresses, husbands and misters.  :^)

AAARRRGGGHHH!!!!!

What the cops told the guy throwing the party was that they had to
shut it down because he did not have a business license and he was
accepting cash at the door. What a crock of shit! Come on, there
a sign on the table which specifically said "Donations". Apparently
the cops didn't buy this, and were determined to shut the party down
right from the start. 

First of all, that party was completely clean. There were no dealers
hanging out at the entrance, no blatant pot smoking, NO ALCOHOL!
Everybody was just having a good time. I personally was really stoked
to see all the Apple people goin' off!. 

What really pissed me off was when I was outside witnessing the cop
harassing the Apple guy, the cop said, "96% of what you were trying to
do tonight was good. We're not going to haul you off the San Quentin,
but you're at least going to receive a citation.". This cop was really
a dick!

[taking a deep breath]

Well, on a positive note, I was glad to see all of you again, as
briefly as it was. I second the motion that us south bay sfraves
should get together sometime. Till then, take care and PLUR.

Hugs,

CT

On Wed, 15 May 1996 teena@lioness.compute.com wrote:

> 
> ...to disallow video cameras at ALL rave events.  This will ensure
> privacy and tighten leaks to the media.
> -Kc of DUNE

                        FUCK CENSORSHIP!!!
 
 I'm a multi-media artist who works with video occasionally. I'm also 
a performance ambient artist, again multi-media focused.
 
 I have two perspectives on video-taping raves.

 1) Free raves in public on public land: No one has the legal or ethical 
   right to prevent ANY video-taping here! Some may regard the video-taping 
   intrusive yet it is no more intrusive than a bunch of noisy, partying 
   ravers in a public venue. Share and share alike.

 2) Public events in rented venues: A more gray area. Legally the 
    producer has the right to forbid video-taping ( or any other recording 
    process ). I actually have been invited by one rave promoter to come 
    early and set up non-intrusive lighing in order to get some good shots 
    (lights would only be on for minutes). And realistically you will 
    not prevent all video-taping. Just look at all the bootlegs of bands 
    (audio and video). I do feel that if video-taping is occuring at an event
    that the promoter should inform folks at the door with a BIG sign 
    stating such.

 The bottom line is that you cannot prevent video-taping entirely. We 
might as well put out our own material in order to present a balanced 
perspective to the TV audience. Universes video-tape "The Global Dance 
Party" (1993) does a real good job. Besides, the public knows something 
about us already. 
 
 As a video-taper I try to show respect for the situation I'm in. Of course 
not all folks are this way. I do feel it is important that some sort of 
record is created for future generations. And of course, a video can never 
really capture what a rave really is. That is inside each of us Not to 
mention that most of my footage is going to be projected at future raves. 
 
 Censorship is for nazi's. If you want a private party, throw it! Do not 
expect sympathy if you throw a public event affecting large groups of 
people and someome wants to document the event. Saying no is just stupid 
thinking. Sorry if my strong opinion is offensive to some. It is mearly 
my $0.02


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams
            ( your rights are our rights )       
                       /
                 -=*=-/
                   ~

Remember; legally a release needs to signed by any individual whose voice 
or likeness is used for profit (like a "news" broadcast).

Hello all you Goa lovers,

I have created an e-mail list dedicated to the discussion of Goa trance,
and anything else related to the Goa scene in general -- ie track
reviews, event listings, your favorite ingredient for Chai, etc.

This will be unmoderated, but irrelevant subjects (ie drugs, other types
of music, employment announcements, spams, etc) will NOT BE TOLERATED --
keep that stuff on Usenet.  The list is intended to be very low in volume, 
yet high in content. 

For those that are interested, subscribe by sending e-mail to the
following:
	majordomo@party.net
In the subject of the message enter the following:
	subscribe goa
To post to the list, send e-mail to the following:
	goa@party.net

Hope to see some of you there!

Andy

Received: by godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com id <4885>; Fri, 17 May 1996 14:43:04 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: anarch@scruznet.com (Anarch)
Subject: Re: Rave/Media Essay (Super Long)
Message-Id: <96May17.144304pdt.4885@godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com>
Date: Fri, 17 May 1996 10:53:31 PDT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Starchild <star@sfsu.edu> wrote:
>My computer tells me that on Fri, 10 May 1996, Kyung Rok shared (in part):
>> Though perhaps better sent on a Tuesday instead of a Friday afternoon,
>> this is about 1/4 of a cultural studies piece titled "Moral Panic, the
>> Media and British Rave Culture."  Written by Sarah Thornton...
>
>> The term "underground" is the expression by which clubbers refer to
>> things subcultural. More than fashionable or trendy, underground sounds
>> and styles are "authentic," and pitted against the mass-produced and
>> mass-consumed....
>
>Fortunately I don't think ravers delight much in "parental
>incomprehension."...

I think a valid distinction can be made between underground and
non-underground on the basis of the amount of effort (knowledge, cost,
inconvenience, time, etc.) required for an individual to engage oneself in
"the scene."  Of course, a clear line cannot be drawn across the
spectrum...as Chesterton, or whoever it was, had it, though no one may be
able to discern the exact point at which day becomes night, one can
tolerably distinguish the two nonetheless.

>> That's what I mean by underground."Undergrounds define themselves most
>> clearly by what they're not, that is "main stream."...
>
>What we are really doing when we dis mainstream culture,
>after all, is dissing humanity at large, saying most people are stupid,
>base, and lack[ing in] taste and culture.

They are.  Amazingly enough, it's possible to like them all the same.

>I think
>her observation is correct, and it's unfortunate, because while certainly
>it can have problematic *aspects*, to say that popularization *itself*
>is the problem is truly cynical and elitist.

Yes.

>> ...youth. whatever their
>> class enjoy a momentary reprieve from "necessity."'! In other words,
>> youth are exempt from adult commitments to the accumulation of economic
>> capital. They temporarily enjoy what Bourdieu argues is normally reserved
>> for the bourgeoisie; that is, a "taste of liberty or luxury. "
>
>	This is troubling to me, because it reminds me that so few
>people, as they grow older, manage to live outside these "adult
>commitments to the accumulation of economic capital."

The issues here are deeper than acknowledged by Thornton.  *By definition*,
youth is relieved from the responsibilities of adulthood.  In our
contemporary culture, this equates to a relief from the accumulation of
capital and a taste of liberty and luxury, because we live in a capitalist
society that makes accumulation of capital a primary responsibility and
which rewards success along those lines with luxury and liberty.  Youth,
freed of responsibility by the effort of adulthood, can reap adulthood's
rewards without effort.

>Just look at our
>cultural forebears, the hippies.  For the most part, the '60s generation
>has blended into the workforce without fulfilling the dreams of their
>youth of social change toward a world of peace, love, harmony, and fun.

Personally, though I have no factual experience on which to base these
judgements, I think that the popular view of "our cultural forebears" is a
mistaken one, that the prominence of these figures owes more to their
extremity than to their prevalence, and that their apparent lack of effect
on the course of history results simply because they are moving against the
tide, not because their tide has ebbed.  I don't know any sometime
"hippies" who have become their own antitheses by trading the ideals that
motivated them in the past for those they strove against.  I do know some,
however, whose extemity has faded as they have aged and the cultural
spotlight has shifted, who yet continue to work for their old ideals in
subtler, less strident ways: through their children, through their friends,
through their communities.

Of course, I live in Santa Cruz.

anarch@scruznet.com

The big fun was at Madness last weekend with bumpy techno in a cool
indoor/outdoor space in the city - just the way I like it.  This weekend
features a bunch of out-of-town guests - Pierre, Miss Thing, Reese and
Keoki; Nikita probably also has a big guest DJ but I don't have the list
handy - call the number I guess.  I think there's also a party at 
111 Minna on Friday that I forgot the info for.

Thanks for everyone who sent in updates this week (and past weeks)!

       daily.

     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * the Global Party Network Buzzline - 415.568.1338
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning 3am-6am - "Aural Fixation"
       experimental sounds of ambient and trip hop with a splash of hi
       nrg, from trance to jungle. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

The big fun was at Madness last weekend with bumpy techno in a cool
indoor/outdoor space in the city - just the way I like it.  This weekend
features a bunch of out-of-town guests - Pierre, Miss Thing, Reese and
Keoki; Nikita probably also has a big guest DJ but I don't have the list
handy - call the number I guess.  I think there's also a party at 
111 Minna on Friday that I forgot the info for.

Thanks for everyone who sent in updates this week (and past weeks)!


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * the Global Party Network Buzzline - 415.568.1338
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning 3am-6am - "Aural Fixation"
       experimental sounds of ambient and trip hop with a splash of hi
       nrg, from trance to jungle. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Everyone, I don't recall at which party I found this (Gathering?), but it
wanted to be shared:

(Neon pink sheet of paper, folded down: front says "Open with and open
mind, read with an open heart, understand and believe)
Inside reads:

To the wonder in your eyes and the amazement in your sigh take the gifts I
give and pass them down with love.  Receive into yourself all that you
deserve and be sure to deserve all that you receive.  Be selfish in nothing
you do for when you live only for yourself you lose yourself - your soul
and heart - and happiness will never find you rather an emptiness you just
can't seem to fulfill.  Lead yourself into the right mind state that is
true for you.  Believe in yourself and others will believe in you.  Be
confident in all that you do yet do not live in a state of conceit.  That
only turns others away from you and from believing in you.  Don't live on
expectations, instead build your hopes and dreams into reality and focus
your energy in the right direction.  Always remember what you learn so you
can find a way to teach others.  Be positive, think positive, feel positive
and positive things will happen.  Love and respect all who come in contact
with you and all that you come in contact with.  Never lose faith in fate
for everything happens for a reason and there is a reason for everything,
including you.  Find your place here and fulfill it.  Never be afraid and
always be ready to learn and evolve.  Open your hearts, open your minds -
together we _can_ make a change.  Always carry a smile and spread 'd vibe
in any way possible.
>From someone who sometimes forgets.
(TRIPS 'R' US Productions, copyright)

Enjoy, my friends!
Love,
Eric

STOP RIGHT NOW.

to anyone at an SFR event, what is going on here?

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Tony Rotundo <tony@xinet.COM>
Subject: Re: Interesting SFR Picnic/Party thought
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I mentioned some of these things to Tim, maybe other want to share in the fun:

At 2:52 PM  -0700 5/17/96, Tim (Knucklehead) wrote:

>I was liking that idea as well. I had a great time doing the Picnic. I'd be
>up for a monthly thing.

I was thinking that if it's just a couple people, each time, every month
might be too much.  BUT!  What about this idea:

We set a schedule up wherein we have a different couple people set-up the
party each month.  For example, Tim/Tony set-up (coordinate logistics, get
food, BBQ, generator, gas, secure site, ect) June, [Example only here]
Leslie/Jess/Renaud set-up July, SDream/Eric P. set-up August, etc.  That
way, each party will be slightly different, and the work load will be
spread out.

Cash might be a problem, but maybe we could have a tip jar, or something of
that nature.  I think the parties could be done pretty inexpensively.

>This is a good idea. I started doing that in the begining, but found few
>people that wanted or could show up for a meeting to organize it. I found
>myself doing most of it, which I didn't mind doing, and had a few people
>help out at the end. It was very scary not knowing for sure if people would
>actually do what they said they would. I think if we were to pull off a
>monthly BBQ, it would have to be well organized.

As I told Tim, I think people tend to be skeptical at first, but seeing how
the first one went so well, I feel people might be more willing to help
with the next.


>Plus, I think everyone would have a Great time and give us a chance to meet
>more people on a different level unlike an actual night time party. There is
>more time to just kick back in the sun and get to know people.

Exactly!  Variety is key!  :^)

Anyway, it's something to ponder about this weekend while you're all dancing...

Have fun!

Tone

Black Adder said....

My father is a cop, and a pretty nice guy, and I get really sick of all 
the bashing of law enforcement that goes on here by a people that 
have no respect for anyone, although they claim to. If you want to say "This 
particular officer was a prick," fine. But sterotyping people and saying 
"All cops are pricks" is just as bad as sterotyping black people, or 
gays, or any other group of people. In other words it makes you little 
different than a racist or a bigot. 

                                       Black Adder
________________________________________

Once again, folks, a reminder that we are all interconnected, and if we want to
be given the benefit of the doubt, we should give it to others as well.  I'm
pretty thankful to a few cops that have helped me out in my life, just as I'm
pretty disappointed in a few that created havoc unnecessarily for me -- 

But remember ..... (this is what I try to do when I'm driving behind someone
who's reeeeaallly slow and refuses to politely get the heck out of my way) ....
we are all someone's father, mother, daughter, son, sister, brother .... so if
we try to treat that cop like they are our OWN father, or that bad driver like
they're our OWN sister or whatever, we'll probably be a little happier all
around!

Yikes, I need a weekend, don't you!  Much love and positive thoughts to everyone
whose thoughts, ideas and support have helped me make it through another week!

Leslie   : )

Being something of a militant where this kind of bad behavior is 
involved...I suggest that your friend should make public the name of this 
creep, or the creep's room-mates.

Just a weird little story to share:

Several years ago there was an undergraduate female student who was 
working in an immunology lab at Berkeley.  There was another 
undergraduate student- a guy- who was working in the same lab who kept 
bugging this young woman.  He even threatened her a few times.  I think 
he wanted her to go out on a date or something.  

Anyway, she complained to the PI (principle investigator- the guy that 
ran the lab), but he did nothing.  The misery continued until, finally...

A group of graduate students and post-docs took the guy to the stairwell 
and threatened to throw him down the stairs if he did not (a) quit the 
lab and (b) stop harassing their friend.

I took this incident as a lesson that if such a situation ever happened 
to me or to one of my friends that the offending person would get the 
same treatment.  I believe this is called vigilantism and is very 
illegal.  

Such bad behavior is not limited to just men, however.  Once a female 
aquaintance of mine kept harassing one of my housemates, a guy, who could 
NOT get her to leave him alone.  I took her to one side one day and told 
her that I thought she had a problem and that if she came by our 
house anymore there would be hell to pay.  She was pretty pissed, but 
she quit coming around for a few months, until she got involved with a 
wonderful guy and that was the end of her obsession.

It sucks that your friend Sara had to put up with this crap.  The guy 
that was doing it obviously has some kind of a problem and I hope your 
friend hasn't been blaming herself for what happened.  I've had many 
friends who experienced similar things and ended up feeling like dirt 
because of it.  

-Ann

At 7:32 PM  -0400 5/17/96, Leslie Ayres wrote:

>But remember ..... (this is what I try to do when I'm driving behind someone
>who's reeeeaallly slow and refuses to politely get the heck out of my way)
>....
>we are all someone's father, mother, daughter, son, sister, brother .... so if
>we try to treat that cop like they are our OWN father, or that bad driver like
>they're our OWN sister or whatever, we'll probably be a little happier all
>around!

But maybe that's part of the problem.  People in positions of power, have
the opportunity to weild it as they wish, and it's that inconsistency you
see with cops that bothers people.  If cops treated everyone like a
relative, no one would be in jail.  Knowwhatimean?  (With the exception of
when Marge gave Homer a citation for taking her police hat.  :^)

Power is an interesting drug, and I think what a lot of people resent about
cops is their ostentatious display of power.  Then, on the flip-side,
respect, especially immediate, unquestioned respect, is necessary to
control people, and thus cops need to "cop" an attitude in order to garner
that immediate respect.  Some do it well, some do it like utter assholes.
Unfortunately, it seems as if most fall into the later group, but not *I'm
sure* Mr. Black Adder, senior.  ;^)

Interesting paradigm.  When people start treating someone with intense awe,
say a cop, politician, or DJ, that person, trained or not, will be affected
by that fame/power, and will react to it. Again, some do it well, as if
it's natural to them, and some do it not so well.

Whatever...

TR

>actually the "NextWorld Expo" for Next hackers.   The rave was the
>Stone rave,  and was at 1015 Folsom... It was really good,   I get there
>about 7 pm  (No rave music playing),  then about 9 pm or so,   the
>thumpin beats are gradually mixed in,   and a half hour later,  the
>dance floor was filled.  It was really good.

Date: Fri, 17 May 1996 18:08:32 -0700 (PDT)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: HELP!!! I need to get to a RAVE!
In-Reply-To: <199605180046.AAA26736@shgc.Stanford.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.92.960517175534.9498B-100000@darwin.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk


Well folks it's a sad story.  One many of you might of heard or even lived
through before.  Yes I am a Virgin Raver.  While I have been listening to
techno, ambiant (sp?), house, and everything in between, I have never yet
gotten to a rave.  Maybe it's because I am in the working world, or maybe
I just don't have the type of friends that want to get out to raves on a
regular basis, but one thing is for sure, I really want to go to one soon!

Here is the plea!  Is there anyone out there willing to take me under
their shoulder and open the door to the rave scean for a new comer?  I
have a car and can get to the city or I can drive people to the city from
Santa Cruz or other places along the way.  I would like  to go to a really
visual intense rave to dance and smile :-) I'm not against any mind
altering subastance unless I am driving!  I'm not gay and not Straight,
but somewhere inbetween.  23 years under my belt and a Molecular biologist
(actually I'm just a lab tech)  So yes I will laugh at anything biological
in humor.  Tall, lanky, glasses, goatee, long brown hair and ready to
dance into the morning.

So if there are any cool people out there that wouldn't mind letting me in
to their circle and taking me to an experience that could very well change
me for the rest of my life (hopfuly for the better), I would be overjoyed
to hear from you.

At 11:45 PM  -0000 5/17/96, Troy Sheets wrote:

>Wow!  maybe a rant like this should include a detailed description as to
>what Origin did to solicit such an angry response.

Well enough of you asked. Here's my beef:

Those of us that recently put on madness invested a lot of time, energy,
care and respect in developing a relationship with: the space owner, the
space itself, and it's surrounding environs, ie the community, neighbors,
police, etc.

It was and is our opinion that the space and environs could safely and
harmoniously handle 500 - 600 people *once a month* without damaging the
long term viability of the space.

We let these opinions, themselves the result of almost 3 years of
experience throwing parties here in the bay area, guide our behaviour and
planning in regard to our use of the space.

Indeed, my guiding philosophy on "How Not To Get Busted" is:

  --> make sure you are no one's problem

Even applying this philosophy last saturday, we still had two complaints
from the neighbors, which thankfully did not get the party busted.

It was thus our intention to: bring less sound next time, aim the sound
strategically, add sound damping material, and, most importantly, NOT DO
ANOTHER PARTY there for at least a month, once again the intent being to
preserve an amazing space for future, *responsible* use.

All of the above goes right in the trash tomorrow when when mr. and mrs.
fuckhead put 1000 people at $20 a head into the same space only one week
later.

The space can't take it, and the neighborhood can't and *won't* take it,
never mind that the cops seem to be conveniently in Nomad's pocket.

This kind of slash and burn attitude, this total disrepect for the hard won
and carefully laid groundwork that other people have put in place is
bullshit. End of story.

And that's just the beginning of what's really wrong with it. What's really
wrong with it is that it totally betrays the energy that really makes this
*whole thing* -- raving -- work. This scene means so much to so many people
and at the deepest, deepest, levels. And at the end of the day it's about
one thing: building repect, love, and trust between and for each other,
building real community for ourselves and for each other. It's about giving
of yourself to your community.

This has always been the magic of Freinds & Family: the opportunity to come
together, with your friends, with your family, in your community, to give
of yourself, to the group, to help create a safe, magic and sacred space
where we we can let go of our fear and our doubt, all be exactly who we are
with each other.

So I'm sick to my stomach, I'm mad, and I'm deeply saddened that this
*magic* is once again being cashed in for a quick buck and a cheap thrill,
at all of our expense, and in this case, especially mine.

yours always
ethan

-----------------------------( ethan miller )-----------------------------
-------------------( http://www.bass-station.com/FnF/ )-------------------
-------( you're only paranoid if they're not really watching you )--------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

On Fri, 17 May 1996, James Ausman wrote:

> >Black Adder said....
> >
> >My father is a cop, and a pretty nice guy, and I get really sick of all 
> >the bashing of law enforcement that goes on here by a people that 
> >have no respect for anyone, although they claim to. If you want to say "This 
> >particular officer was a prick," fine. But sterotyping people and saying 
> >"All cops are pricks" is just as bad as sterotyping black people, or 
> >gays, or any other group of people. In other words it makes you little 
> >different than a racist or a bigot. 
> 
> Are you "trolling" Black Adder? If so, I would appreciate it if you would
> not do that on this list.
> 

No, I was not "trolling." I honestly meant what I said. I see no 
difference between sterotyping people based on their legitimate 
occupation, and sterotyping people based on race, religion, etc. The 
difference on S.F. Raves however is that it seems acceptable to call cops 
"pigs"(as has been done in the past) and to say that they are all pricks. 
I do not feel this is right, and displays an utter lack of respect for 
people as individuals.  

At any rate, the original poster and I have had a private discussion and 
the matter is cleared as far as I am concerned.

                                            Black Adder

On Fri, 17 May 1996, Tony Rotundo wrote:

> At 7:32 PM  -0400 5/17/96, Leslie Ayres wrote:
> 
> >But remember ..... (this is what I try to do when I'm driving behind someone
> >who's reeeeaallly slow and refuses to politely get the heck out of my way)
> >....
> >we are all someone's father, mother, daughter, son, sister, brother .... so if
> >we try to treat that cop like they are our OWN father, or that bad driver like
> >they're our OWN sister or whatever, we'll probably be a little happier all
> >around!
> 
> But maybe that's part of the problem.  People in positions of power, have
> the opportunity to weild it as they wish, and it's that inconsistency you
> see with cops that bothers people.  If cops treated everyone like a
> relative, no one would be in jail.  Knowwhatimean?  (With the exception of
> when Marge gave Homer a citation for taking her police hat.  :^)
> 
> Power is an interesting drug, and I think what a lot of people resent about
> cops is their ostentatious display of power.  Then, on the flip-side,
> respect, especially immediate, unquestioned respect, is necessary to
> control people, and thus cops need to "cop" an attitude in order to garner
> that immediate respect.  Some do it well, some do it like utter assholes.
> Unfortunately, it seems as if most fall into the later group, but not *I'm
> sure* Mr. Black Adder, senior.  ;^)

As an aside I would like to relate a small personal experience:

A few years back I had the opportunity to work as a "role-player" in the 
final examination of a class of graduating law enforcement students (CHP 
and Dept. of Fish & Game officials.) Well, we got several cadets sent 
back to the academy that day. And the simple reason was that they could 
not take adequate control of a given situation(which resulted in their 
mock shooting.) It is essential that in any unknow situation that the 
officer gain control of the situation. 

There are some power-hungry, little people out there that are employed 
as law enforcement. It would be silly to deny that. My point is that you 
have to look at each person individually, and weigh them on their own 
merits. To do any less is to fall into the trap of sterotyping people. If 
you go into a situation expecting someone to be an utter prick, and treat 
them as such, you are more than likely going to get an utter prick.  


> Interesting paradigm.  When people start treating someone with intense awe,
> say a cop, politician, or DJ, that person, trained or not, will be affected
> by that fame/power, and will react to it. Again, some do it well, as if
> it's natural to them, and some do it not so well.

100% right on. 

                                         Black Adder

in the gritty warehouses of Chicago's infamous southside and have quite
literally seen 'em come and seen 'em go. Ethan dear boy, I definately think
its time for you to go. Three years won't get you through college let alone
enable you to pretentiously assume to inherit the mantle of "high priest" of
raves that you attempt to project. Your comments reek of at least four of the
seven deadly sins. Sloth in allowing the "new kids on the block" to beat you
at your own game. Greed in your reluctance at sharing the "scene" with new
comers. Envy at their successes. Wraith in your obvious and thinly veiled
threat to put the proverbial kabosh on their party plans (and you have the
unmitigated gall to complain about "tactics). 
My allegiance is, and always has been to the music, and yet music and magic
don't pay bills do they. You insult all of our intelligence by pretending
that your events are anything more than commercial endeavors, and
simultaneously implying that only you and not your competitors can possibly
understand the "Art of Rave". Do us all a favor  grow up and move on, the
scene you lay claim to obviosly alreadly has. 
In closing I' d like to remind you of two things. first, spirituality is not
chemically synthesized and dispensed for profit, it comes from the heart,
unfortunately yours seems  noticeably absent. Secondly, profanity makes
ignorance audible, surely you own a thesaurus.

On Fri, 17 May 1996 blkadder@value.net wrote:

> > 
> > Are you "trolling" Black Adder? If so, I would appreciate it if you would
> > not do that on this list.
> > 
> 
> No, I was not "trolling." I honestly meant what I said. I see no 
> difference between sterotyping people based on their legitimate 
> occupation, and sterotyping people based on race, religion, etc. The 
> difference on S.F. Raves however is that it seems acceptable to call cops 
> "pigs"(as has been done in the past) and to say that they are all pricks. 
> I do not feel this is right, and displays an utter lack of respect for 
> people as individuals.  
> 
> At any rate, the original poster and I have had a private discussion and 
> the matter is cleared as far as I am concerned.
> 
>                                             Black Adder
> 

Hi!
 I'm in full support for BA on this issue (sorry to keep this going but 
this is an important issue). Police Officers do one of the most 
difficult jobs around. Helping to keep our communities and society safe 
from destructive chaos. It is a fucked job which many of us would never 
dare do ourselves. Due to the stresses of the job, many subcumb to less 
ethical influences. This does not mean they are inhuman! Officers are 
like any other group of people; some good, some bad, most pretty middle 
of the road. They have good days and bad days like most of us.

  My view is that Officers are like an AC power line; potentially useful 
and needed, potentially lethal if not approached with respect. The best 
thing to do when dealing with an Officer IS to respect them. If you lie 
to them (admittedly sometimes neccesary) and they know it it burns them 
as it is a sign of lack of respect. Most are mearly doing the best job 
they can to help keep us safe so we CAN party and have a good time.

 Granted some Police organizations have nazi-like people in charge which 
lends that department a particularly nauseating flavor. Given the power 
these people wield it is our responsibility to expose this corruption and 
eliminate it. However if we indiscrimanetly go around saying all cops are 
fucked than no one (except other non-discriminate thinkers) will listen 
to us. Remember PLUR; we need to share that vibe with EVERYONE or else we 
are no better than the goons we decry.


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams


                                  (all together now)
                                          /
                                    -=*=-/
                                      ~

Whoa, hold on there a second, buddy. I don't post very often, but your
comments about Ethan Miller have kind of gotten my hackles up. I've known
and worked with Ethan for over a year now, and the fact that you can say
the words "Ethan" and "commercial" in the same sentence shows that you
obviously don't know who he is or what he has done for this scene. I have
yet to see Ethan turn a profit at a party, excluding Madness, where he
pocketed a grand total of 80 dollars - for about 24 hours of straight work.
He is one of the only DJs that I have ever seen moving speakers and
sweeping up, with no regaurd to whose party it is.  He is one of the main
organizers behind Friends and Family, a party which has never charged more
than five dollars. And it's _not_ a five dollar party. I've been to many
$20 and $25 parties that had half the production of FnF. He also throws
Mad, a _three_ dollar party. Now, if you think that he's getting rich off
of that, then think again. I suggest you do more research next time before
posting about shit that you know nothing about.

-john

the Fnf parties. Fnf consists of near 60 people (most of whom are on this
list) who plan and work their asses off for free, just for the music and
the vibe, and personally, I feel that your post is attacking myself, the
entire Fnf crew and everyone involved with MAD (another non-money making
venture), as well as Ethan. Maybe you should redefine your viewpoint of
just what this is about, namely, togetherness and music. Sfraves is a
community, a community that Ethan has contributed a great deal to. You

Dear Friends & Family,

Okay, I'm kind of steamed at this ...

My computer tells me that on Fri, 17 May 1996, SDream shared:

> An experienced
> promoter will take care of the various requirements for having an event in 
> whatever city they decide to throw the party in.  

A few years ago when apartheid was still the law in South Africa, some 
rappers did a song called Sun City.  It was meant to protest the notion that 
it's okay to just follow the rules in whatever city you want to play, 
even if those rules are hurting people.  We'd do well to remember it.

> I was standing outside 
> listening to the police officer trying to explain to the promoter that 
> *nothing at all* would have happened if he hadn't had the donations bowl 
> sitting there.  

Spare us the officer's attempt at justifying himself.  If he'd been cool, 
he would've just advised the promoter to be more discrete and then gone away.

> The promoter came back whining about how the cop had the 
> badge so there was nothing he could do.  What the heck is that supposed to 
> mean?  It tells me the guy wearing the badge has a job to do, regardless of 
> whether or not he enjoys doing it. 

If he doesn't enjoy doing it, and honestly I don't see how anyone with 
compassion can, either he needs to think about doing it differently or 
turning in his badge and finding some honest employment.

> What turned it into a bust was a cop 
> that got tired of getting badgered for trying to go easy and decided to just 
> shut it all down.

The *cop* was getting badgered?  Who came trying to disrupt whose event?
Since when is it illegal to ask for money?  That's fucking freedom of 
speech, and the Apple guy was right to whine, if that's what you want to 
call the sad tale of a citizen who just had his Constitutional rights 
violated.

> Put it this way: I've partied in various venues with various themes and 
> music for a long time.  When people follow the rules and respect the 
> authorities, it's a good night.  When they don't, it's a bad night.  Simple.

I've also partied in various venues with various themes and music, and my 
take on this is rather different.  It is that underground, illegal 
parties, or parties where the promoters don't enforce age laws with 
respect to drinking, don't hassle people for doing illegal drugs at their 
parties, and don't collaborate with the cops in any way are often some of 
the very best events I've been to.  

"Follow the rules" -- which rules, precisely?  Smoke a joint, lose your 
license?  Getting an entertainment license before you can have a poetry 
reading in a cafe?  Not being able to talk about certain subjects on the 
Internet?  No jaywalking?  No skateboard riding in downtown S.F.? No one 
under 18 allowed to dance in S.F. after 2 a.m.? (that last one's no 
longer in effect because a lot of us stood up against it back in '93, but 
you can bet some cops would love to enforce it if it were the law.)

No offense SDream, but "Respect the authorities" is only valid in a 
situation where the authorities are acting in a manner such as deserves 
respect, otherwise it's like licking the boot that's pressing your head 
against the floor.  When they respect the Bill of Rights and stop 
violating our freedoms, I'll respect them plenty.  Until then, no.  I'll 
be nice and polite when it's expedient to do so, i.e. when they threaten 
to arbitrarily exercise their power at my expense, but that's it.  The 
farther away the cops are from our parties, the better.

> >One of the
> >cops was watching us dance and he he had a very self assured "thank god
> >I'm not one of you degenerates" look on his face.

Should I be laughing, or crying, or both?  These are the people we pay 
to be fair and objective in enforcing the law.
> 
> I was dancing right in front of that guy wearing my Dr. Seuss hat.  I'm sure 
> he was actually thinking, "Geez, where can *I* get a hat like that?"  Ok, 
> maybe not...
> 
> S

I do not like blue suits and ham*,  

					<<< Starchild >>>


*Not the ones that deserve the name pigs, anyway, the ones who like to 
bust parties just because they can or because they don't like ravers.  Some 
cops are cool and treat you with respect -- as long as you don't exercise 
certain of your rights in their presence.

Dear Friends & Family,

	After firing off my message responding to SDream's comments on 
the cop at the Apple rave bust, I saw this post from Tony, which I 
felt contained some valuable insights:

My computer tells me that on Fri, 17 May 1996, Tony shared:

> Power is an interesting drug, and I think what a lot of people resent about
> cops is their ostentatious display of power.  Then, on the flip-side,
> respect, especially immediate, unquestioned respect, is necessary to
> control people, and thus cops need to "cop" an attitude in order to garner
> that immediate respect.  Some do it well, some do it like utter assholes.
> Unfortunately, it seems as if most fall into the later group, but not *I'm
> sure* Mr. Black Adder, senior.  ;^)

I grant that in some situations cops need to control people, and when 
they do, they need to command respect in order to get swift cooperation.  
However the only time I can think of where cops have a legitimate need to 
control people is where a crime is being committed and someone or 
something is in physical danger, i.e. a mugging, burglary, riot, etc.

The remainder of the time, they should act humble.  After all, they work 
for us.  The awesome power to arrest, detain, and search that they have 
needs to be counterbalanced by a very healthy respect for the citizen.  
Unless it would put themselves or others in physical jeopardy, cops 
should treat everyone they come into contact with, including those they 
arrest, like they would the mayor of the city.  Because that person is 
legally 100% innocent of wrongdoing until proven otherwise in a court of law.

> Interesting paradigm.  When people start treating someone with intense awe,
> say a cop, politician, or DJ, that person, trained or not, will be affected
> by that fame/power, and will react to it. Again, some do it well, as if
> it's natural to them, and some do it not so well.

Agreed, and this is one good reason to limit the power of cops.

Yours in liberty,
				<<< Starchild >>>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat May 18 04:39:20 1996

like the nazis at Nuremburg. Secondly, the "inflammatory rhetoric" of which
you speak was, and I think this is the most important distinction, an
objective response from an outsider whose been to a  Rave or two. A response
to verbage that was downright hostile and threatening at best, divisive at
worst, and consistent only in its sophmoric whining. Everyone likes a winner,
until they feel, whether real or imagined, that they are the one on the
losing end. Perhaps our subject took his own moniker to heart, mistakenly
confusing Paranoia with the natural progression and refinement of the skills
so many have watched Ethan and other members of Fnf exhibit beautifully,
unencumbered by the need to control it.

"Ahhhh...I love the smell of Napalm=81 in the morning." - Capt. Kilgore

>At 11:45 PM  -0000 5/17/96, Troy Sheets wrote:
>
>>Wow!  maybe a rant like this should include a detailed description as to
>>what Origin did to solicit such an angry response.
>
>Well enough of you asked. Here's my beef:
>
>Those of us that recently put on madness invested a lot of time, energy,
>care and respect in developing a relationship with: the space owner, the
>space itself, and it's surrounding environs, ie the community, neighbors,
>police, etc.
>
>It was and is our opinion that the space and environs could safely and
>harmoniously handle 500 - 600 people *once a month* without damaging the
>long term viability of the space.
>
>We let these opinions, themselves the result of almost 3 years of
>experience throwing parties here in the bay area, guide our behaviour and
>planning in regard to our use of the space.
>
>Indeed, my guiding philosophy on "How Not To Get Busted" is:
>
>  --> make sure you are no one's problem
>
>Even applying this philosophy last saturday, we still had two complaints
>from the neighbors, which thankfully did not get the party busted.
>
>It was thus our intention to: bring less sound next time, aim the sound
>strategically, add sound damping material, and, most importantly, NOT DO
>ANOTHER PARTY there for at least a month, once again the intent being to
>preserve an amazing space for future, *responsible* use.

In other words Ethan & crew had and have built something called respect, in
and around thier party.


>
>All of the above goes right in the trash tomorrow when when mr. and mrs.
>fuckhead put 1000 people at $20 a head into the same space only one week
>later.
>

In other words, someone else has a different idea of what makes a good
party.  Even the person who Ethan was working with (owner of the space
perhaps), had different ideas of success as well.

Just a thought.


>The space can't take it, and the neighborhood can't and *won't* take it,
>never mind that the cops seem to be conveniently in Nomad's pocket.

In other words, someone knows how to work the SF system of graft.  For
those with the time, money and resources, graft is the BEST and ONLY way to
ENSURE your party isn't busted in SF.  I hear it works well in other
cities, like NY, as well.  Is there any suprise about the "big" bust of a
NY party most recently (The Tunnel).  Now, does anyone here think that the
reaon THAT party got busted was due to crowds or drugs.  Nope, it was due
to cops not getting cut in on the action.  In big cities, you gotta pay to
play, or so it seems.


>
>This kind of slash and burn attitude, this total disrepect for the hard won
>and carefully laid groundwork that other people have put in place is
>bullshit. End of story.

Or is it.  I think what the real problem is you are dealing with one set of
ideals, and others are not playing by the same game plan.  Difficult to say
the least.  I have learned to lower my expectations of people in the SF
party scene.  I have found many friends, but find few loyalists.  People,
especially those who decide to make a living by raves/parties, will do
whatever it takes to survive and eat.  Sometimes people have in mind
McDonalds, others want a banquet.  Depending on what the person has in
mind, will determine the extent and type of capitalism.

There has , ALWAYS been a system of construction/destruction in the SF
scene.  One promoter is very careful, dots the i's and crosses the t's.
Others see a spot or an idea and run with it.  Mowing over any and all who
are in their path.  People get upset, then they move onto other venues,
ideas, ideals, etc.  The one thing I have found the most hardcore to have
adopted, is a willingness to move onto the next project, and quickly.

Ethan, despite your vitriol (understandable), I *know* you will get over
this, and move onto bigger and better places and spaces suitable to what
you're trying to do.  This is just a blip.  You've been around long enough
to expect these things to happen from time to time, I know.


>
>And that's just the beginning of what's really wrong with it. What's really
>wrong with it is that it totally betrays the energy that really makes this
>*whole thing* -- raving -- work. This scene means so much to so many people
>and at the deepest, deepest, levels. And at the end of the day it's about
>one thing: building repect, love, and trust between and for each other,
>building real community for ourselves and for each other. It's about giving
>of yourself to your community.

Really?  I respectfully disagree.  You have a set of ideals that someone
else doesn't have.  And when they end up violating your rules, you get
upset.  Oh, there's plenty of historical precendence, the Native American
Genocide by the Europeans being a brief example in time.  B.K.A. what
happens when two worlds collide.

=46or some people it is as you say it is, respect, love, and trust.  For
others, it is all about $$$'s, $$$'s, and MORE $$$'s.  IMO, we need both.
People who chose the, for lack of a better term "Ethan's Way" (ala Guy
Kawasaki :) ) keep the continuum going.  The "other" way ensures that
people get paid enough to do some free or lower cost things.  Not everyone
can work for Apple, and not everyone can survive throwing free parties or
doing low cost events.  It's all a give and take, yin-yang.  It is truly
unfortunate when someone is coming from a a place of generosity and another
from a place of greed.  In our system, on the whole, greed wins.
Unfortunate for many, but true.

Just keep the spirit, and "Keep, keep, keep, pressin' on!" (ala That Kid
Chris - Ernie Munsen works that song like no other!)

>
>This has always been the magic of Freinds & Family: the opportunity to come
>together, with your friends, with your family, in your community, to give
>of yourself, to the group, to help create a safe, magic and sacred space
>where we we can let go of our fear and our doubt, all be exactly who we are
>with each other.
>
>So I'm sick to my stomach, I'm mad, and I'm deeply saddened that this
>*magic* is once again being cashed in for a quick buck and a cheap thrill,
>at all of our expense, and in this case, especially mine.
>
>yours always
>ethan
>
>-----------------------------( ethan miller )-----------------------------
>-------------------( http://www.bass-station.com/FnF/ )-------------------
>-------( you're only paranoid if they're not really watching you )--------
>--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Often times, those of good intentions are crushed by the almighty $$$.  Sf
is about $$$, and these club owners are ALL about $$$.  Trust few, get
papers signed where possible, and throw your gig!

Stay positive, despite feelings to the contrary, and throw your next gig
like it will be your last!  I wish the best for all your efforts, and don't
let the greed of others get you down. Rise above it!

Peace out,
John

>dare do ourselves. Due to the stresses of the job, many subcumb to less

>like any other group of people; some good, some bad, most pretty middle

Oh well, here we go again.  Before this list sinks into the Internet's Hall
Of Flame, I just wanted to chime in, briefly.

The concept of greed is not just about money, it can be applied to many
things.  Is it greed to say "This is MY space?  You can't use it
unless...", is it greed to say, "This is my scene I built up.  You can't
join unless...", is it greed to say "Hey, I bought this records, it's the
bomb, but I can't let you see the label...".

I am not saying that anyone in particular said any of these things.  These
are just some of the things I have heard people say over the years in the
SF Dance Culture Scene, while at the same time aspousing some ethos of
respect, unity, love, and sometimes peace.  I have heard many a promoter
say, "I am all about the good time whne it all boils down to it.  That's
why I do this!"  while at the same time charging $$$'s for an unsafe
unpermitted totallybustablecuzyoudidn'tgreasethefive-oh space?

I see greed in many forms and fashions.  Often dressed to disguise.

And greed pops up in the strangest of places.

Anway, on with the battle.

"Mr. Phelps, this list will self-destruct any minute now.  Your mission,
should you decide to accept it, is to high tail it out of here.  There is
no hope, the natives are restless.  There has been a perceived character
assassination attempt on one of the tribesmen.  In other words Mr.
Phelps....GET THE FUCK OUTTA DODGE WHILE YOU STILL CAN!  This message will
self destruct in 10 seconds...good luck!"

Damn, it's gettin' hot in here.

Keep :),
John

Well, Smarties went off. The crowd was, ok. This crowd was not my type 
of crowd, but there was still some cool people. The Vibe was -ok-. The 
music was GREAT!!! The place was PACKED FULL!! There must have been 
twice as many people there compared to Harmony's Beautiful people. It 
was located at the Jerrold's Deli, once again. 

Good Moment:Dancing all night on the floor where the A/C was actually 
cranked up.

Bad moment:Roaming around feeling sick because it was TOOOOOO HOT!!! 
The only place to be where it was actually COOL was on the the dance 
floor right underneath that a/c.

Good moment:Meeting alot of people that noticed me because of my hat 
and necklace.

Very bad moment: When I finally left to go to back to my car, I found 
out that it was broken into. SHIT. Like I said, not my type of crowd so 
my car had no respect. Or something... Shit happens....

Other than that... It was OK. Yeah... I'm kinda depressed and 
pissed....

Adam

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat May 18 12:07:08 1996

To: Greg2write@aol.com
From: tim@redshift.com (Tim Gotch)
Subject: Re: Ethan
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Firstly, do you have any idea how difficult it is to aquire a location that
can be used more than once? Ethan and the Madness crew put weeks of work
into setting up this particular space so that it could be used again and
again, not only by themselves, but by others who would (hopefully) respect
the space, the owner of the space, the neighborhood around it, and the
continued viability of the space for others to use. Nomad Interactive have
taken advantage of that work, the opening of the door for future use, and
will probably destroy it. The owner of the space in question has only had
experience with Madness, a group of people who respect first and don't try
to abuse a space just to make a buck. Unfortunatly, he is about to see a
wholly different slice of the pie that will probably result in this space
never being available again, to anyone.

         While I realize that $ is the name of the game for some, Nomad
bills itself as an underground party, where money is supposed to be a
secondary issue. I see nothing wrong with making money in this scene, as
long as it is not at the expense of other people. For a lot of us, money
isn't what raving is about, and that's why parties like Fnf happen, and,
frankly, Fnf would not exist in the form that it does without the presence
of Ethan Miller. If you need more evidence, check out the archives to get a
feel for who you are attacking.
Tim

>like the nazis at Nuremburg. Secondly, the "inflammatory rhetoric" of which
>you speak was, and I think this is the most important distinction, an
>objective response from an outsider whose been to a  Rave or two. A response

>worst, and consistent only in its sophmoric whining. Everyone likes a winner,
>until they feel, whether real or imagined, that they are the one on the
>losing end. Perhaps our subject took his own moniker to heart, mistakenly
>confusing Paranoia with the natural progression and refinement of the skills
>so many have watched Ethan and other members of Fnf exhibit beautifully,
>unencumbered by the need to control it.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat May 18 13:47:28 1996

Received: from [128.32.91.91] (mmf21.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.91.91]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.5/8.6.12) with SMTP id NAA20297 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sat, 18 May 1996 13:47:25 -0700 (PDT)
X-Sender: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Unverified)
Message-Id: <v02130500adc3edf24c44@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sat, 18 May 1996 13:45:46 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Farewell, SFR Family
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Graduation.  Everyone keeps saying, "Congratulations!" but all I see is my
beloved life being ripped from me.  Thrust from the idyllic education
experience straight into some meaningless 9-to-5 that's going to suck the
life right out of me.  No more student life dedicated to the pursuit of
knowledge; no more wondrous group discussions in classes, exploring the
dynamics of politics, culture, society; no more learning from the minds of
brilliant professors; no more tight-knit community of coffeehouses and
co-ops.  Good-bye to drunken parties every week-end; gone for me, lazy
afternoons reading books in the sun; good-bye to so many friends I'll
probably never see again.  Good-bye to the life I adored.  I've been in the
"real" world before - for too many years.  I know what it is to see all my
energy drained in the constant struggle just to make ends meet.  I know
enough to cherish the opportunity to get an education at a  place like
Berkeley.

Of the many things I'm losing, my privileges as a student add another blow.
No more entrance to the sophisticated gym, no more access to the
unbelievable resources of the libraries, no more chance to see so many
performances, world-class lectures and symposiums, art and music.  But most
of all, dear SFR family, I am losing you.  Barred from the computer labs,
free e-mail cut off, I have no way to maintain this connection.  I don't
own a computer, nor will I in the foreseeable future.   E-mail right now is
a luxury that I can't afford.

So, against my will, I am tearfully bidding you farewell.  This list has
meant a lot to me in the short time I have been a part of it.  I have
learned so much from all of you.  It's an amazing thing to share
conversations with hundreds of people; it redefines community.  Thank you
for being such a vibrant, intelligent, aware, loving community.  I am sorry
to leave it.

I'll look forward to seeing you at parties - dancing, smiling, massaging!
I intend to dance my summer - and hopefully some of my sadness - away.  But
I will miss the level of conversation possible in this forum, the clarity
that can get muddled in the psychedelic whirl of a rave; the valuable input
of so many more than one chill room can hold.

I wish you all happiness, continued stimulating conversation, and to always
treat each other and each other's ideas with love and respect.

Much Love, Plur Always,
Nancy

P.S. I have access to the computers for the next week, until May 24.  I'd
love to hear from you!

Okay, family members, my internet incarnation may be at an end, but raving
will never die!!

I intend to dance my ass off this summer.  And I intend to keep up contact
with as many of you as possible.  So, come up and say hi if you recognize
me, and I'll do the same!

The Description:
Female.  5'5".  Dark brown hair.  Favorite raving tees: "I Take Candy From
Strangers" and Mickey Mouse from Fantasia.  Usually wear jeans and
backpack.  Hair may be in braids or otherwise pinned up for dancing.
Cookie Monster will probably be in tow.  I adorn myself with blinking
lights, and sometimes a really bright lavendar beanie.  Whenever possible,
I will be the Strawberry Girl, with fresh berries for the family (which is
everyone at the party!).

The Parties:
I'll be at anything thrown by Gateway, Harmony, or F& F (sending those
vibes for spaces!!).  I'll be at Sunsets.  And I might even show up at a
couple of massives.

In the immediate future: next weekend, Chrysalis on Saturday and Spundae on
Sunday.  There are also a few Nikitas in my future (thanks to my clubber
friends).

Much love to all of you!!
Keep Dancin' and Smilin'!
Positivity Always!!
Nancy

>If that is the case, then we really have nothing to complain about 
>except the fact that they were being total pricks; gee, how unusual 
>for a police officer! 

>Amy

Everyone-
This was part of the original message I posted and evidently what has 
caused the major controversy. 

It never ceases to amaze me that something so stupid which I put about
10 seconds thought into is enough to create a thread which will go on
for days. Then 20 other people have to chime in to say "Oh, I agree."

I'm glad there are so many people on this list who are obviously much
more open minded than me and much better people. Sometimes I get
afraid to post *anything* because I'm not in the mood (ever) to start
a major controversy. I almost got fed up and unsubscribed from this
list (again) due to the major amount of verbiage involved. Not to 
mention the "you are not open-minded and full of PLUR statements"
which are obviously designed to make someone else feel like shit.

I got to feeling sorry for Mark the other day about that Apple Rave
thing; I mean, we all make mistakes. How about treating each other
with a little PLUR in our e-mail, that would go a long way in showing
me that SF ravers really do have PLUR and are not just full of shit.
There are gentle ways of telling someone something w/out getting
all emotional or resorting to name-calling. 

I know there are people on this list who are afraid to post because
they don't want to feel stupid after 20 other folks shoot them down...
let's start by treating each other with respect, OK? I don't know why
I even bother saying these things... but sometimes reading sf raves
just seriously disturbs me. Instead of bringing us together as a family
it just makes me less inclined to want to bother meeting anyone. What
purpose does that serve?

Amy

something from personal experience. 
my friends and i have begun throwing parties in december of 95, so i'd 
call us new to the scene. from witnessing the positive energy catalized 
by the efforts of gateway and friends and family, ive come to realize 
that i too would want to contribute to our scene in this way. since our 
first party, weve rescieved much support from said groups, and in no way 
was ethan or anyone else unwilling to share the "scene" with newcomers, 
as stated above. with continuing support, i'd call ethan anything but 
envious - he's always been respectful and willing to help out if he can.

i hope this can shed some lite on your perspective.

Perhaps it would be a good idea to think before you post. I think almost 
all of us(myself *definitely* included) have at some time, said something or 
posted something without putting enough thought into it.... and been 
called on it.  Quite frankly it seems that you are upset because you got 
called on something, and a majority of people agreed. Was the call harsh? 
Yes, however so was the original statement. 

> I'm glad there are so many people on this list who are obviously much
> more open minded than me and much better people. Sometimes I get
> afraid to post *anything* because I'm not in the mood (ever) to start
> a major controversy. I almost got fed up and unsubscribed from this
> list (again) due to the major amount of verbiage involved. Not to 
> mention the "you are not open-minded and full of PLUR statements"
> which are obviously designed to make someone else feel like shit.

Sour grapes. 

I am with JSL(god twice in one week) on this one. PLUR is a tired, 
over-used acronym. People are batted around by others with it. I do 
believe that there are some that really carry these ideals with them, but 
the majority just use it as a weapon to put others down. I did like what 
someone posted a few months back from one of the originators(I think) of 
the term. It went something like:

Peace, *when peace is given*
Love, *when love is given*
Unity, *when unity is desired*
Respect, *when respect is given*
(Apologies for the possible paraphrasing)

This stuff doesn't exist in a vacuum. If the concept of PLUR is included 
in the paradigm of your existance, cool. But you have to give to get. 

> I got to feeling sorry for Mark the other day about that Apple Rave
> thing; I mean, we all make mistakes. How about treating each other
> with a little PLUR in our e-mail, that would go a long way in showing
> me that SF ravers really do have PLUR and are not just full of shit.

It sounds like what happened was indeed unfortunate, and that 
*particular* group of cops may have indeed been pricks. However, that 
does not make it the modus operandi for all police everywhere.  

I also find it ironic that you complain about people using PLUR to make 
you feel like shit in one paragraph, and in the next, use it yourself. 

> There are gentle ways of telling someone something w/out getting
> all emotional or resorting to name-calling. 

You call people names, and then expect people to be gentle?

> I know there are people on this list who are afraid to post because
> they don't want to feel stupid after 20 other folks shoot them down...
> let's start by treating each other with respect, OK? I don't know why
> I even bother saying these things... but sometimes reading sf raves
> just seriously disturbs me. Instead of bringing us together as a family
> it just makes me less inclined to want to bother meeting anyone. What
> purpose does that serve?

Yes, let's start treating people with respect. Make sure your giving it 
when you ask for it.

                                          Black Adder

Right On! So true.

In fact, your statement made me realize something that I was struggling with.
I've tried to get into the Goa-Trance thing, the people seem really nice and
their definitely seems to be some sort of vibe, but try as i may, I can't seem
to catch a groove to the music. Finally, I realize that it is all upper chakras
there isn't anything for my first and second.  House music tends to operate on
your 2nd, 3rd, 4th, 5th and some times 6th. Goa starts at the 5th and 6th,
with some activity at the 3rd.

Just my 2 cents not ment to be dogma or anything.

Disclaimer: I've never been to a ccc party and I'm still open to the experience
but it's hard for me to get into the music if their isn't some sexual exergy
present.

Dear Friends & Family,

My computer tells me that on Sat, 18 May 1996, John S. Lee shared (in part):

> In other words, someone knows how to work the SF system of graft...

> ...People
> especially those who decide to make a living by raves/parties, will do
> whatever it takes to survive and eat.  Sometimes people have in mind
> McDonalds, others want a banquet.  Depending on what the person has in
> mind, will determine the extent and type of capitalism.

	Just a brief point: Graft and greed are not what capitalism is 
about.  There are plenty of businesspeople who are out to make a profit, 
but will not stoop to the use of bribery, nor would they put ethical 
concerns about negating the hard work of others to the wind, as 
apparantly happened here.  I am saddened that so many people seem to have so 
little respect for the system of free enterprise that allows our scene to 
exist in the first place.

> For some people it is as you say it is, respect, love, and trust.  For
> others, it is all about $$$'s, $$$'s, and MORE $$$'s.  IMO, we need both.
> People who chose the, for lack of a better term "Ethan's Way" (ala Guy
> Kawasaki :) ) keep the continuum going.  The "other" way ensures that
> people get paid enough to do some free or lower cost things.  Not everyone
> can work for Apple, and not everyone can survive throwing free parties or
> doing low cost events.  It's all a give and take, yin-yang.  It is truly
> unfortunate when someone is coming from a a place of generosity and another
> from a place of greed.  In our system, on the whole, greed wins.
> Unfortunate for many, but true.

	I agree with John that it is good to have some higher priced 
events, although I see it as more of a necessary evil that need only 
occur because we in society have our standard of living artificially 
lowered by the government to the point where we cannot all afford to 
throw free parties even if we might want to.
	But I don't think that we should assume that anyone charging a 
significant amount of money for an event is greedy and only out for 
money, and anyone throwing a free event is doing it strictly out of 
generosity.  Better to assume the latter than the former though.
	I don't think "greed wins" in our system.  People who "succeed" 
based on greed are not going to be very happy, even if they may produce 
envy and hatred in others who similarly fail to see that the real path to 
happiness and success is not based on the rapacious acquisition of money.

Much love,
				<<< Starchild >>>
