On Sun, 19 May 1996, Starchild wrote:

> Dear Friends & Family,
> 
> My computer tells me that on Sat, 18 May 1996, John S. Lee shared (in part):
> 
> > In other words, someone knows how to work the SF system of graft...
> 
> > ...People
> > especially those who decide to make a living by raves/parties, will do
> > whatever it takes to survive and eat.  Sometimes people have in mind
> > McDonalds, others want a banquet.  Depending on what the person has in
> > mind, will determine the extent and type of capitalism.
> 
> 	Just a brief point: Graft and greed are not what capitalism is 
> about.  There are plenty of businesspeople who are out to make a profit, 
> but will not stoop to the use of bribery, nor would they put ethical 
> concerns about negating the hard work of others to the wind, as 
> apparantly happened here.  I am saddened that so many people seem to have so 
> little respect for the system of free enterprise that allows our scene to 
> exist in the first place.

Capitalism *can* be greed. There are 'rape the earth, take whatever you 
can get' capitalists, just as there are capitalists that work in synergy 
with their communities, enviroments, etc. In it's truest sense capitalism   
would seem to be purely economic Darwinism. If this were not the case 
we wouldn't have the sometimes heavy-handed government regulation of industry. 

I don't think JSL was being disrespectful of capitialism at 
all. Notice he did say it depends on what the person has in mind, which 
determines the type of capitalism they engage in. 

> 	I agree with John that it is good to have some higher priced 
> events, although I see it as more of a necessary evil that need only 
> occur because we in society have our standard of living artificially 
> lowered by the government to the point where we cannot all afford to 
> throw free parties even if we might want to.

Of course without gov't regulation, except for the upper class, we would all
be working 14 hour days, and making .50 a day. We could always live in 
Sweden, where income tax is roughly 50% I am no great fan of the way the 
current gov't is run or the direction it is headed, but we do need some 
gov't regulation, and some taxation in order to survive as a nation.


> 	But I don't think that we should assume that anyone charging a 
> significant amount of money for an event is greedy and only out for 
> money, and anyone throwing a free event is doing it strictly out of 
> generosity.  Better to assume the latter than the former though.
> 	I don't think "greed wins" in our system.  People who "succeed" 
> based on greed are not going to be very happy, even if they may produce 
> envy and hatred in others who similarly fail to see that the real path to 
> happiness and success is not based on the rapacious acquisition of money.

I think there are a lot of CEO's that would argue this point with you. 
While this may not be your or my "real path to happiness to sucess" it 
could well be theirs. 

                                           Black Adder

Hi!
 Just because people are on sfraves does not automatically make them 
"cool", "fresh" or whatever. Yes ,lets treat each others on sfraves with 
respect. Lets also treat others (like officers) with respect also. 
Otherwise we are just as elitist and snobbish as any power-abusing cop.

have troubles communicating and getting along, can you imagine how tough 
it is for most officers (with their sometimes life-threatening stress's) 
to show PLUR?

of crowd, but there was still some cool people. The Vibe was -ok-. The=20
music was GREAT!!! The place was PACKED FULL!! There must have been=20

was located at the Jerrold's Deli, once again.=20

cranked up.

floor right underneath that a/c.

and necklace.

>Dear Friends & Family,
>
>My computer tells me that on Sat, 18 May 1996, John S. Lee shared (in part):
>
>> In other words, someone knows how to work the SF system of graft...
>
>> ...People
>> especially those who decide to make a living by raves/parties, will do
>> whatever it takes to survive and eat.  Sometimes people have in mind
>> McDonalds, others want a banquet.  Depending on what the person has in
>> mind, will determine the extent and type of capitalism.
>
>	Just a brief point: Graft and greed are not what capitalism is 
>about.  There are plenty of businesspeople who are out to make a profit, 
>but will not stoop to the use of bribery, nor would they put ethical 
>concerns about negating the hard work of others to the wind, as 
>apparantly happened here.  I am saddened that so many people seem to have so 
>little respect for the system of free enterprise that allows our scene to 
>exist in the first place.
>

Nor are graft, greed, dominance and totaliarian control what communism is
about, in it's pure sense, the bottom line here is human nature in both
systems and to the extent that a group will be ruthless enough to push
their agenda at the expense of everyone else. Our scene happens to exist in
a system that alledgedly practices some form of "free enterprise", it doesn't
exist because of free enterprise, is exist regardless of free enterprise,
one could set up sound systems, charge admission, evade and even be busted
by the police inside of a communist or socialist company.  Also the concept
of free enterprise or rather open markets is not new, nor was it even
invented by Adam Smith (though he may have codified it for westerners in
his "the wealth of Nations" which was little more than a manual for the
proper operations of plantations), there were large market economies through
out Africa and Asia for at least 2000, but we digress...

>> For some people it is as you say it is, respect, love, and trust.  For
>> others, it is all about $$$'s, $$$'s, and MORE $$$'s.  IMO, we need both.
>> People who chose the, for lack of a better term "Ethan's Way" (ala Guy
>> Kawasaki :) ) keep the continuum going.  The "other" way ensures that
>> people get paid enough to do some free or lower cost things.  Not everyone
>> can work for Apple, and not everyone can survive throwing free parties or
>> doing low cost events.  It's all a give and take, yin-yang.  It is truly
>> unfortunate when someone is coming from a a place of generosity and another
>> from a place of greed.  In our system, on the whole, greed wins.
>> Unfortunate for many, but true.
>
>	I agree with John that it is good to have some higher priced 
>events, although I see it as more of a necessary evil that need only 
>occur because we in society have our standard of living artificially 
>lowered by the government to the point where we cannot all afford to 
>throw free parties even if we might want to.

I assert that even if we were not taxed and if there was "unbridled
capitalism" there would still be greedy people (if not greedy for money
then greedy for power). In a totally free market system, price is always
set by supply and demand, thus, if you can corner the market, and the demand
is high, you can charge whatever price you want. If the governement weren't
there, rest assured that some "greedy bastard" would perceive that if they could
keep free parties from happening then more people will pay to come to their
parties.  We need to first change human nature (which is a very difficult
thing, that no one has be successful at yet)

>	But I don't think that we should assume that anyone charging a 
>significant amount of money for an event is greedy and only out for 
>money, and anyone throwing a free event is doing it strictly out of 
>generosity.  Better to assume the latter than the former though.

No many promoters use the "free party" as a form of promotion or
advertising.  It seems to work.

>	I don't think "greed wins" in our system.  People who "succeed" 
>based on greed are not going to be very happy, even if they may produce 
>envy and hatred in others who similarly fail to see that the real path to 
>happiness and success is not based on the rapacious acquisition of money.

Dude, tell that to Bill (Gates) I'm sure he is quite happy and will be even
happier when he gets a nanocent for ever bit that traverses ever conduit
on the planet :)


                                                geoffw

person?

hi!!

I am new to SFRaves, but from reading the messages posted here, it is apparent 
to me that you are a very close community.

I have been raving / clubbing for the past 5 years now, and I live in London, 
England.  It would be nice if many of our ravers had the sort of mentality that 
you are all showing.

Unfortunately, our summers of love died out by 1993, and most of the raves are 
now big business, pulling in the corporate sharks.  Of course, there are still 
plenty of underground parties and raves (I know cause I have been to them, and 
even organised a few myself!) but with changes in legislation, it is becoming a 
lot harder to throw a decent all nighter- count yourselves lucky you do not have 
the criminal justice act!

Hopefully, I will be over to party in June, and I hope that a good time will be 
had by all- I would appreciate it if someone could tell me a little about what 
to expect from Tribal Future- I will be going to it as soon as my plane lands.  
The police in England have stopped our Tribal Future from taking place, even 
though 20,000 tickets have been sold!

regards

Daryll

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hiya All;

        What is PLUR without tolerance, and I speak of  a tolerance that
approaches acceptance of each other for our differences. We are all human
here, with the exception of a few aliens & holograms like myself. When I
think human; I associate that word with diversity. This is so apparent to me
my simply looking around and noticing that no two of  you are a like, duh.
Yet WE EXPECT each other to be the same, when were elementally not. We are
very much like original works of art, priceless by virtue of our uniqueness,
and a eventual expiration date.

        Yet we get soo pissy when we discover another human, or many humans
that happen to disagree with us. When instead of accepting this as the norm,
our egos freak and go on this character assassinating rampage in order that
we can feel good about ourselves by making the offending humans less the
human. When chances are that the offending humans don't even agree with each
other.

        So what is it that we really want or need when the reality of life
slaps us in the face and said's that hey YOUR UNIQUE IN YOUR VIEWS &
BELIEFS? Only you can answer this question for yourselves.    

        I personally think it's much more productive instead of doing the
knee jerk character assassination thing to privately communicate our
feelings to the offending person/s.  I personally don't care what you thing
about me, or anyone else, because in the end it only matters what you or I
personally think about our respective selves.

        A funny thing happens when I catch myself and do the above
mentioned. I experience a wonderful overwhelming feeling that hey, I won, I
didn't add to the planets negativity, I didn't go down the character
assassination road to hell, I didn't add to the hurt of an already hurtful
situation, and I feel great about myself despite the situation and/or the
person for doing it and not going there. That today I got a little closer to
my own divinity, and approached a truer love. 

        So why waist your time telling someone just what you think of them,
when you know it's just being hurtful, dehumanizing, mean and adding to our
planets negativity all for the benefit of our ego.

        The fact being that any belief system, even personal ones that make
another human less than human are by definition & the root of hatred and
oppression.

Peace
THX1138

Dear Friends & Family,

	Regarding contributing to the vibe, I really sometimes feel I am 
doing this just as intensely when I'm "exploring" as when I'm dancing.  I 
almost always take the time to do this at a party:
	Walk around, and notice things, mostly people who look like they 
have the vibe.  Whoever looks particularly friendly or interesting 
(creatively dressed, neat toys, etc.) I will usually find an excuse to 
talk to.  I also like to pay attention to and appreciate whatever has 
been done to decorate the space and make it beautiful.  Aesthetics are 
very important to me; not just the "visuals" per se, but the whole visual 
environment at a party makes a huge difference to me, nearly as much as 
the "audio environment", i.e. the quality of the music/sound system.
	I love dancing, and those of you who know me know I definitely 
get into it(!), but I don't think not dancing all the time makes you 
"lame".  Sometimes I would simply rather be doing something else.  If the 
DJ is going off, plenty of others will be dancing and showing their 
appreciation of that fact.  I don't think anyone should feel they "owe it 
to the DJ" to dance -- if I were a DJ, I would want to believe that 
people were dancing because they wanted to, not for any other reason.
	When I'm walking around, or just chilling in the ambient area or 
wherever, I feel I am still contributing to the energy of a party, because 
it's then that I will take the time to smile at people, offer water, food, 
or whatever, and generally try to interact with people, which won't always 
happen when I'm dancing.
	Also, some of the most intense moments I've had at raves have 
been talking to people and getting each other totally excited by the 
exchange of energy, thoughts, and information.  You can have connections 
with people without ever saying a word, but the other kind are good too.  
Language is a beautiful thing, and I enjoy using it!  8)  And it's hard 
to have a conversation while you're moving at 120 BPM, especially if you 
have your eyes closed and can't see the other person to read their lips...

Much love, & may the bass be with us,

				<<< Starchild >>>


My computer tells me that on Fri, 10 May 1996, Ms Phink shared:

> >Hi all!
> > kaySEE, the collective conciousness you are refering to has been 
> >experienced in many different enviroments and is a area of (part time) 
> >study for me. I first came across it at Grateful Dead concerts (before 
> >they were REALLY big colisium affairs). Bob Weir refered to this 
> >phenomenon as "Gestalt Linkage".
> >
> Here is my whole take on this dancefloor/socializing thing. 
> 
> Unless you are out dancing, you are being a total lame ass.
> Yes, meeting new people is great fun and I try to spend some
> time talking to people too.
> 
> But I feel that if the DJ is doing a really good job, you
> almost owe it to that person to be out dancing! If I was a 
> DJ, nothing would be worse than playing to a room full of
> boring people. Conversely, if someone really sucks the first
> thing I do is go sit down. (yes, I do sit down when I'm tired too!)
> 
> I feel like unless i am moving, I'm just sitting there being
> entertained. But if I am dancing, I am helping to create the 
> energy that ultimately makes the party happen or not. It is 
> so great to feel that your energy is helping the party to go off!!
> It makes the whole experience really worth it to me. 
> 
> Luv-
> Ms Phunk

Dear all,

I can't believe it...Tom and Stacy ruined the much-hoped for Mad space?  
I'm not involved at all with Mad, and I didn't go to the recent Mad 
party, but I used to go to the weekly when it was still at Bahia.  It was 
an awesome party, and the music was to-die-for.

In support of Ethan and the Friends and Family crew:  for a lot of 
people, they are what is keeping the underground scene going.  And a lot 
of the Friends and Family crew have helped put on other underground 
parties, like the New Moon and the Full Moon.  They've been generous with 
their time and resources, and they do it for the fun of it, not because 
they want to make any money.

Nomad Interactive- the name of Tom and Stacy's party.  Nomad- is someone 
who travels around.  Are Tom and Stacy nomads?  Where did they come 
from?  And does nomad also mean No Mad?  It kind of looks that way.

I hope the Nomads will pick up and go somewhere else soon.

-Ann

Dear Friends & Family,

My computer tells me that on Sun, 19 May 1996, Geoff shared:

(what I previously said):
> >	Just a brief point: Graft and greed are not what capitalism is 
> >about.  There are plenty of businesspeople who are out to make a profit, 
> >but will not stoop to the use of bribery, nor would they put ethical 
> >concerns about negating the hard work of others to the wind, as 
> >apparantly happened here.  I am saddened that so many people seem to have so 
> >little respect for the system of free enterprise that allows our scene to 
> >exist in the first place.
> 
> Nor are graft, greed, dominance and totaliarian control what communism is
> about, in it's pure sense, the bottom line here is human nature in both
> systems and to the extent that a group will be ruthless enough to push
> their agenda at the expense of everyone else. 

Whoa there, Geoff!  Who said anything about communism?

> Our scene happens to exist in
> a system that alledgedly*                          
> practices some form of "free enterprise", it doesn't
> exist because of free enterprise, is exist regardless of free enterprise,
> one could set up sound systems, charge admission, evade and even be busted
> by the police inside of a communist or socialist company.

(*I'm with you there)

Theoretically you could, but I think the odds against this kind of scene 
happening inside a nation with a highly socialist system are high.  
Recall that back in the '60s when they were having protests and be-ins in 
the U.S. and Western Europe, you didn't exactly hear much about the 
hippies behind the Iron Curtain.

> Also the concept
> of free enterprise or rather open markets is not new, nor was it even
> invented by Adam Smith (though he may have codified it for westerners in
> his "the wealth of Nations" which was little more than a manual for the
> proper operations of plantations), there were large market economies through
> out Africa and Asia for at least 2000, but we digress...
 
Geoff, I don't know where you get your info about "The Wealth Of 
Nations," but your slander of Adam Smith is way off.  No, he didn't 
invent free enterprise, far from it, but his classic treatise on free 
markets had nothing to do with slavery.

> >> For some people it is as you say it is, respect, love, and trust.  For
> >> others, it is all about $$$'s, $$$'s, and MORE $$$'s.  IMO, we need both.
> >> People who chose the, for lack of a better term "Ethan's Way" (ala Guy
> >> Kawasaki :) ) keep the continuum going.  The "other" way ensures that
> >> people get paid enough to do some free or lower cost things.  Not everyone
> >> can work for Apple, and not everyone can survive throwing free parties or
> >> doing low cost events.  It's all a give and take, yin-yang.  It is truly
> >> unfortunate when someone is coming from a a place of generosity and another
> >> from a place of greed.  In our system, on the whole, greed wins.
> >> Unfortunate for many, but true.
> >
> >	I agree with John that it is good to have some higher priced 
> >events, although I see it as more of a necessary evil that need only 
> >occur because we in society have our standard of living artificially 
> >lowered by the government to the point where we cannot all afford to 
> >throw free parties even if we might want to.
> 
> I assert that even if we were not taxed and if there was "unbridled
> capitalism" there would still be greedy people (if not greedy for money
> then greedy for power).

I admit that on reading my above sentence over again, my meaning was 
less than clear.  I wasn't saying that greed wouldn't exist in a 
laissez-faire system.  What I meant was, if government wasn't taking so 
much of our money, both directly and indirectly, many more people would 
be able to afford to throw free parties.

> In a totally free market system, price is always
> set by supply and demand, thus, if you can corner the market, and the demand
> is high, you can charge whatever price you want. If the governement weren't
> there, rest assured that some "greedy bastard" would perceive that if they could
> keep free parties from happening then more people will pay to come to their
> parties.  We need to first change human nature (which is a very difficult
> thing, that no one has be successful at yet)

In a true free market, you can't corner the market.  Any time you raise 
prices significantly above cost, someone will come along to compete with you.
 
> >	But I don't think that we should assume that anyone charging a 
> >significant amount of money for an event is greedy and only out for 
> >money, and anyone throwing a free event is doing it strictly out of 
> >generosity.  Better to assume the latter than the former though.
> 
> No many promoters use the "free party" as a form of promotion or
> advertising.  It seems to work.

That was my point -- free doesn't *necessarily* indicate generosity on the 
promoter's part.  But I prefer to give them the benefit of the doubt.  
Many promoters do throw free parties because they like to see people have 
fun, and more power to them.
 
> >	I don't think "greed wins" in our system.  People who "succeed" 
> >based on greed are not going to be very happy, even if they may produce 
> >envy and hatred in others who similarly fail to see that the real path to 
> >happiness and success is not based on the rapacious acquisition of money.
> 
> Dude, tell that to Bill (Gates) I'm sure he is quite happy and will be even
> happier when he gets a nanocent for ever bit that traverses ever conduit
> on the planet :)

	Bill Gates may be wealthy, I don't know if he's happy or not.  
Certainly we have examples of people who were exceedingly wealthy and not 
very happy, like Howard Hughes.

May the bass be with you,   8)

				<<< Starchild >>>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May 20 08:45:27 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id IAA02104; Mon, 20 May 1996 08:45:27 -0700
Received: from franc.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id IAA02097; Mon, 20 May 1996 08:45:25 -0700
Received: from smtp.ucdavis.edu by franc.ucdavis.edu (8.7.5/UCD3.5.4)
	id IAA10466; Mon, 20 May 1996 08:45:22 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Mon, 20 May 1996 08:45:22 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199605201545.IAA10466@franc.ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: szriffle@peseta.ucdavis.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 2.1.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Rick Riffle <rdriffle@ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Fresh Start Review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I had a pretty limited perspective on this one, but I'll do my best.  RE:
was asked to play at Fresh Start this Saturday.  It was pretty last minute,
but we were into it.  We got there around 11.  The space was on Embarcadero
right on the water.  A huge warehouse on a pier.  The ambient room (where we
were to play) was seperated off from the main space by huge cotton bails.
They had built a 15 foot wall to seperate the spaces.  There was massive
amounts of sound bleed, so the only way to hear the music in the ambient
space was to play it really loud, or play stuff with beats.  We set up, and
proceeded to peruse the space which was really nice.  Room for a thousand
easy and comfortable, too bad only a few hundred showed up.  The sound
system was really nice, and the visuals were great as well.  Good
projections.  We met the promoter Todd, and he was very nice and
appreciative of us coming down.  I didn't really dance the whole night, so I
can't comment on the vibe in the dance space.  We ended up going on earlier
than scheduled and played for about 3 1/2 hours.  We had to turn up the bass
and drums on alot of our songs to make them audible over the bleed from the
main room, which made the ambient space not very ambient, but hey, we play
the cards we are delt right?  We had a blast playing.  In the morning, dj
Rig-a-Tony (the man who taught me about records) completely warped my mind
by mixing a couple of songs together that I really love.  He just let them
play together through the entire record.  Soon after, someone opened up the
huge door out to the water, and everyone left at the party went outside to
watch the sunrise...all 30 of us.  I got to hear Orbital's "Belfast" for the
first time at a rave.  The bay was beauitful as well as the sky and the
lights on the bridge and accross the bay.  I felt like I was with family
during that time, even though I only acually knew a few of the people there.
All in all I had a great time, and would definately recommend parties thrown
by these guys again.  It was nice being able to drive right into the space
to load up our equipment as well.  :)

Rick

Ok, I just called the Origin voicemail and I'm getting a bit peeved. Not
only do they swipe the location we worked so hard at securing, but they use
the same map point and have the gall to announce it as a virgin warehouse
location. What utter bullshit. I'd like to know what happened to the
"virgin location" they had printed on their flyers for the past few weeks.
I've not had problems with them in the past, and don't know them well
enough personally to make character judgements but the way they've gone
about this really rubs me the wrong way.

Are Tom & Stacy on the list? I know they've posted before - I'd really like
to hear their side of this.

I do hope their party went without problems, anybody know? Luckily we
(Madness & Gateway) were able to instill in the space owner an awareness of
our concerns and I have hope for future responsible use of this space.

---

Ok, on this whole Ethan name-calling issue. I began to write a fairly
strong worded personal response to whomever this Greg2write person is, but
realized there's nothing I'm going to be able to say to combat his
ignorance of the facts and of who Ethan is since it's obvious he's never
met the man. I've been throwing parties for several years both here and in
LA (where promoter wars are so bad people get shot at) and I've never met
anyone with as much love, positive energy, and respect for the scene and
its members, hands down. I'm honored to have been involved in as many
parties as I have with Ethan and to have become such close friends with
him. Yeah, I think his initial post was overly inflammatory for a public
list, but I, and the rest of the Madness crew, share in his frustration
with this situation and agree with his assessment of what's happening.
Ethan is a man of the highest ideals and purest intentions and I urge
anyone who would doubt that to sit down and have a conversation with him
and actually take the time to get to know him rather than base vitriolic
rants on a solitary post by him.

Joe

tim

noe valley is often thought of as the center of the civilized universe that
is san francisco.....most of the time. good weather, ~cool~ community, and
hamano's (wicked good sushi). what more could you ask for?

however, for those of us who aren't quite ready to live in nirvana, there's
bernal heights. now, don't think i'm partial to this area just because i
live there, but it has be-yoootiful views of the city, good weather, and is
very convenient to downtown. not to say that it doesn't have it's
drawbacks, but you wouldn't be able to get me out of my apartment with a
crow bar....

hope this helps!

peace
melis

Hey, y'all!  RLunatic's story got me to thinkin': car vandals may be hip to
some of the events at which we gather, finding ripe fields of cars waiting
for them to reap a bountiful harvest.  There may be no way to prevent this
from happening, but we may be able to decrease the chances of a car being
broken into.  I suggest driving a vehicle that doesn't look to spiffy,
sporty, shiny, or otherwise suggests the owner's affluence; if you have a
"nice" car, get a ride with someone whose wheels don't look as nice.  Also,
when you park, HIDE Y'ALL'S GOODIES!  If someone can't see anything
attractive inside da ride, he/she may be less likely to have in.  Any other
ideas?  We need to help each other, if we care about each other :)

Peace,

- E

> 
> Hey, y'all!  RLunatic's story got me to thinkin': car vandals may be hip to
> some of the events at which we gather, finding ripe fields of cars waiting
> for them to reap a bountiful harvest.  There may be no way to prevent this
> from happening, but we may be able to decrease the chances of a car being
> broken into.  I suggest driving a vehicle that doesn't look to spiffy,
> sporty, shiny, or otherwise suggests the owner's affluence; if you have a
> "nice" car, get a ride with someone whose wheels don't look as nice.  Also,
> when you park, HIDE Y'ALL'S GOODIES!  If someone can't see anything
> attractive inside da ride, he/she may be less likely to have in.  Any other
> ideas?  We need to help each other, if we care about each other :)

Put a blinking red light in your car.  Alarms are just deterrents anyway,
right?  If they are going to break into your car, they probably won't care
about the alarm anyway.  But, if they have a choice between a car
that may have an alarm, and one that does not... well, you know.

Blinking red LEDS are available at Radio Shack for about 1.90.  You can
install them yourself (they might work at 12 volts?), and your won't
piss off your neighbors with false alarms!

-troy

Everyone-
Well, I unsubscribed from the list the other day, but I just wanted to 
sign back on
to say good-bye and try to explain my sorry ass self. This is not a plea 
for sympathy,
I just didn't want to disappear w/out saying anything.

This has less to do with one individual or a set of individuals than the 
tone of this
mailing list in general. Those of you who know me in real life will know 
that I have a
pretty sarcastic and flippant way of dealing with life. Perhaps my 
personality does 
not translate too well into e-mail. I seriously do not have the time, 
energy or inclination
to spend hours of my day thinking about or composing messages to sf 
raves. This 
includes the hours of deep thought involved in censoring yourself  so 
that anything you 
say does not get taken the wrong way, made fun of, or thrown back in your 
face to make 
you look like a hypocrite. For me personally, arguing over the Internet 
is not a valid way 
of spending my time when there are other aspects of my life that are in 
need of attention.

I would like to apologize to you all for my little outburst on Black 
Adder the other day
regarding my "Our Community" post. I meant what I said sincerley and I 
meant the
comments that I made about "us" to include myself, obviously. This is 
what happens
when my frustration level reaches an all time-high and I find this list 
to be a major
source of depression instead of positivity in my life. Maybe this is my 
problem, I
don't know. I wish you all luck and positive energy in your lives, and I 
hope you find
a way of dealing with these issues better than I.

I would still like to get together a group of SBay people this Friday. If 
anyone is interested,
we will be at the Gordon Biersh Brewery in San Jose starting around 7pm. 
I was there
the other day and they didn't card anyone at the door, but if this 
becomes a problem we
can always move somewhere else. The address is: 33 San Fernando between 
1st & 2nd
Streets and the phone # is: 408.294.6785. If anyone else has had a bad 
experience at
this place, please let me know and we will adjust the plans accordingly.

Amy

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

i probably put my foot in my mouth or something here... oh well. =)

>Theoretically you could, but I think the odds against this kind of scene 
>happening inside a nation with a highly socialist system are high.  
>Recall that back in the '60s when they were having protests and be-ins in 
>the U.S. and Western Europe, you didn't exactly hear much about the 
>hippies behind the Iron Curtain.

err? i thought communism existed behind the iron curtain, not socialism...
besides, canada, and most of the western european countries _are_ socialist
countries. socialism isn't an economic system, it's a social system.
socialism is about people as a group over people as individuals, which seems
fairly similar to PLUR to me.

>> >	I agree with John that it is good to have some higher priced 
>> >events, although I see it as more of a necessary evil that need only 
>> >occur because we in society have our standard of living artificially 
>> >lowered by the government to the point where we cannot all afford to 
>> >throw free parties even if we might want to.
>I admit that on reading my above sentence over again, my meaning was 
>less than clear.  I wasn't saying that greed wouldn't exist in a 
>laissez-faire system.  What I meant was, if government wasn't taking so 
>much of our money, both directly and indirectly, many more people would 
>be able to afford to throw free parties.

anyway, it seems that your argument is based on the dislike of socialist
policies that restrict the individual's monetary freedom.
personally, i would rather devote my money to the good of society as a whole
and hope to bring about change on a great scale for many people rather than
for those few who by genetics, chance, or whatever have been given the
oppurtunity to make oodles of cash.
besides which, aren't free parties socialistic in nature? you throw a free
party because you want to share with others, just like in socialism.
capatalism, as an economic pricipal, does not support the sharing of wealth,
unless it will lead to personal gain. so you could ask a free party
promoter, "do you throw a party so that you will feel good about yourself or
do you throw a party so that others can have a good time?". i suspect most
promoters would say the latter.

>In a true free market, you can't corner the market.  Any time you raise 
>prices significantly above cost, someone will come along to compete with you.
doesn't government control restricting monopolies help keep prices low? as
well as laws against price-fixing? again, capatalism isn't a moral system,
so there are no scruples against something like price-fixing and screwing
other people because you control something they want.

>> Dude, tell that to Bill (Gates) I'm sure he is quite happy and will be even
>> happier when he gets a nanocent for ever bit that traverses ever conduit
>> on the planet :)
>	Bill Gates may be wealthy, I don't know if he's happy or not.  
>Certainly we have examples of people who were exceedingly wealthy and not 
>very happy, like Howard Hughes.
even if he isn't happy, he's laughing at us. =(

> Take a sip from your glass whenever the following topics are mentioned:
>* MDMA/X/ecstacy
>* GHB ( or however you spell that stuff that killed River Phoenix )
>* River Phoenix

GHB did not kill River Phoenix. He hadn't even taken GHB the night he died.
It was just a rumour that got started because there was GHB going around
where he was, and someone mentioned that maybe he had taken some. The
coroner's report showed that he had no GHB in his system, but the media
didn't decide to widely publicize it and instead rode the frenzy about GHB.

Dear Friends & Family,

My computer tells me that on Mon, 20 May 1996, Metered 99 shared:

> err? i thought communism existed behind the iron curtain, not socialism...
> besides, canada, and most of the western european countries _are_ socialist
> countries. socialism isn't an economic system, it's a social system.
> socialism is about people as a group over people as individuals, which seems
> fairly similar to PLUR to me.

	Well, there are as I see it two basic types of socialism.  
Top-down coercive socialism, and bottom-up voluntary socialism.  The 
former type is the type practiced by governments.  There are varying 
degrees of coercive socialism:  The U.S. is partly socialist, Western 
European countries perhaps a little more so overall, and the former 
Soviet bloc "communist" countries were highly so.  Communism is merely an 
extreme form of socialism, which in theory would be voluntary.

> anyway, it seems that your argument is based on the dislike of socialist
> policies that restrict the individual's monetary freedom.

Guilty.

> personally, i would rather devote my money to the good of society as a whole
> and hope to bring about change on a great scale for many people rather than
> for those few who by genetics, chance, or whatever have been given the
> oppurtunity to make oodles of cash.

And in a system where individuals have monetary freedom, you are free to 
do so, in whatever way you personally deem most effective.

> besides which, aren't free parties socialistic in nature? you throw a free
> party because you want to share with others, just like in socialism.
> capatalism, as an economic pricipal, does not support the sharing of wealth,
> unless it will lead to personal gain. so you could ask a free party
> promoter, "do you throw a party so that you will feel good about yourself or
> do you throw a party so that others can have a good time?". i suspect most
> promoters would say the latter.
 
Free parties are voluntary -- if you don't want to devote time or money 
to them, you don't have to.  This is an excellent example of bottom-up 
socialism, which I'm all for.

> doesn't government control restricting monopolies help keep prices low? as
> well as laws against price-fixing? again, capatalism isn't a moral system,
> so there are no scruples against something like price-fixing and screwing
> other people because you control something they want.

Government typically protects monopolies, or runs them itself.  As far as 
price-fixing and screwing people, Uncle Sam is doing a fine job of that 
right now.  Some people will probably continue to act immorally no matter what 
economic system is in place; as Geoff White noted in an earlier message 
to me, we haven't been too successful at changing human nature.

> >	Bill Gates may be wealthy, I don't know if he's happy or not.  

> even if he isn't happy, he's laughing at us. =(

He's not laughing at us, he's laughing with us.  ;)

May the bass be with you,

				<<< Starchild >>>

Noe Valley: good.  Must be alternative-lifestyle friendly, but is 
definitely a rad place to be, if you can afford the rent.

Bayview: bad.  Rent's cheap for a reason- crime, violence.

Bernal Heights: somewhere in between NV and Bayview.

Course this is only my limited experience.  I'm a Richmond/Sunset boy myself.

happy hunting.

Just an FYI, apparantly the Origin party didn't get shut down, although
there were noise complaints and the police did show up more than once.

Points of clarification:

1. When I referred to the Madness crew in my last message, I meant the core
members: Ethan, Alex, Jon Santos, and myself.

2. I have no personal animosity towards Tom & Stacy, only a strong
disagreement with their actions as I've spelled out in previous messages.
Frankly, they're going to keep doing parties, and we're going to keep doing
parties, and the scene's going to survive. It'd be nice if everyone were in
this for the same reasons and liked and respected one another, but as
others have pointed out, that may not always be the case, and that's fine.

Joe

> You wrote: 
> >
> >So who else did the Bay to Breakers this AM ???
> >
> I did it for the first time and also had a great time.  It was great 
> seeing all the creative outfits people were wearing, and hearing all 
> the music along the way.
> I got to hear techno in 2 spots along the way which gave me an extra 
> boost. 
> I found this to be much more fun than the sf marathon.  Very nice wacky 
> vibe throughout the race.
> 
> :)
> peter
> 
There were at one point eight of us at the R during Footstock. Julie, 
Paul, John, two Sarahs, Cruchman, myself and someone else I didn't get 
the name of. We were there til at least noon. Very nice weather for the 
run and yes a wacky conglomeration of people all around. Now I need to go 
check the paper to see if I just barely made it in. Not a bad finish 
to an evening with Space Teddy--very very good music by the way. Keoki 
didn't have any outbursts (he even gave Mars a backrub when he first came 
in) but his set was definately the most average of the night, almost 
everything else was at a higher notch. It never got too hot at the 
Jerrold deli but water was the $2/bottle variety. I liked the lighting 
quite abit and they were playing scrambled movies on the walls upstairs. 
Ended at just after six giving me plenty of time to get over to the 
starting line for the race. Saw Cruchman, the two Sarahs (overflowing 
with vibe) and Paul, as well as a couple that recognized me from Circa 
'96 which was a pleasant surprise, and a group on vacation from Spain 
that thought I was crazy to be going to the race afterwards but wished me 
luck all the same. Now I just need alittle more sleep. : )

have an excellent day everyone

  Austin                             
  Tinsau                    

            S.F. Born and Raved!

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu (Jake Reichert)
Subject: Re: dissing cops, etc.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>I have not got the time to write the hundred pages I would need to go 
>into all the negative experiences I've had with cops.  Lets just say that 
>I am bassing my opinions on personal experience.

I understand how having negative experiences with police officers could
color your view of the profession, but let's face it.  Your experiences with
them do not embody the whole of what they do every day.  I know people that
would not be alive today if it hadn't been for police officers.  Does that
make them all bad?  

I just get scared when I see people extrapolating their personal experiences
into a judgement of a whole group.  What if you had had a lot of negative
personal experiences with african-americans?  Does that then prove that all
of them are inherently evil?  Please, people, remember that personal
experience can only tell you so much.  You are only 1/4.5 billionth of the
population of the earth, and have only had 1/4.5 billionth of those experiences.

And, by the way, without having ever even met Black Adder's father, it seems
VERY closeminded to judge him like that.  If you were to sit down and have a
talk with him, I'm sure your feelings would be different.

Just a thought, 

Jake

Yup!  Keoki spun Sunset.  Suprised no one's mentioend anything about it, I
guess people are just too damn busy trying to find out who the fuck
Greg2write@aol.com is.  ;^)

The reviews seemed mixed.  Personally I though it was pretty good music,
definitely better towards the end, but not necessarily mixed that well.  It
ranmged from deep house to rather fast/technoey stuff.  Sort of all over,
which I heard he does.  It looked like he was having fun, joking around
behind the decks, banging records on his head, spinning in his socks on the
grass.  I was rather happy to have him come to a Sunset, because I'd
probably not go see him at an exspensive club.

Sunset got a late start (read: 4pm the message went up).  It filled up
late.  There were a lot of clubbers, it looked like, but that's fine.

Peace!

"socialism: an economic system in which the government owns the basic =
means of production, determines the use of resources, distributes =
products and wages, and provides social services such as education, =
health care and welfare."=20

>anyway, it seems that your argument is based on the dislike of =
socialist
>policies that restrict the individual's monetary freedom.
>personally, i would rather devote my money to the good of society as a =
whole
>and hope to bring about change on a great scale for many people rather =
than
>for those few who by genetics, chance, or whatever have been given the
>oppurtunity to make oodles of cash.

I would like to do the same, but I disagree that it is the governments =
job to do so. I believe it is the responsibility of each individual to =
make this decision and take the necessary action.

>again, capatalism isn't a moral system,
>so there are no scruples against something like price-fixing and =
screwing
>other people because you control something they want.

and niether is socialism a moral system. trying to use an economic =
system to provide moral guidance won't get us far; our social problems =
are much too complex. it is possible to be a responsible capitalist, to =
recognize that in order to make profits and benefit in the long term, =
you can't take advantage of the people buying your product, or the =
people making it.

>ideas?  We need to help each other, if we care about each other :)
>
>Peace,
>
>- E

>
Ever went to one of the parties that were held at the old One Step Beyond in
Santa Clara a few years back? 
I remember seeing ripe fields of cars at the beginning on the night and
seeing sparkling fields of broken glass in the morning. Oooooh, it was bad.
I was pissed once, cause I lost an illuminating frisbee. A car stereo (even
a car) can be replaced, but not an illuminating frisbee from 1978. Nope,
they got glow-in-the-dark ones available, bot not one with L.E.D.'s around
the rim.

Before I go off on my personal fulfillment, may I first say that these square
one fellas are the shit!  I've worked with them through Groove Trip, &
they're nothin but good.  We arrived @1:30 & Rigatony was ending his set with
"I feel love" (this ties into the story later on), anyway great vibe setting
song.  Because of the smaller crowd (shoulda had me do your flyers boys!) in
a rather large & awesome new space, the energy level remained moderate, but
positive.  The people were the frosting on this cake though, each and
everyone of the peoples I got a chance to interact with were just lovely.
  ......but none,  none  as lovely as the one I had the opportunity of being
there with.  A mystical goddess created somewhere amongst the realm of Tom
Robbin's "Another Road Side Attraction" and Eden.  Let me just say I am in
fear of the intense attraction I have toward this creature of divinity!
WhoaH!  Done with that..
Where was I?, Oh yes, decorations, yeah they were great! Nutralight set the
mood just right and Rick and Eric (Re) were just goin nuts, 5 hours
straight!! of the most beautiful sounds, (minus the bleed through from the
main area)  If any SFRavers want a good taste of quality Digereedooing
(<sp?), check these guys out at RAW foods next Friday. 
So to top it all off, there I stood, warm and loopy, looking out the window
of my new aquantance's 30th floor vacant office window at 6:30AM looking down
unto the bayside warehouse we had just bonded so tightly in.  I could see the
pier upon which all the happy ravers were standing, awaiting the rising sun.
 I thought to myself

A really blissed up Steveo

From: John Kawamoto <jkawamoto@excite.com>
Organization: Excite, Inc.
X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.0 (X11; I; SunOS 5.4 sun4m)
Mime-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Bay to Breakers and the BetaRavers!
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Wow, what a weekend! After going to Space Teddy and dancing to some 
incredible music with other SFRavers and meeting some more new brothers
and sisters I left at about 5:30 or so to go and get ready for Bay to
Breakers. I thought nothing could equal all that fun and excellent music
at Space Teddy but that was before I reached the one mile marker or so
along the race route...where some promoters who call themselves the
BetaRavers had opened up the door to their warehouse and had setup
their sound system with a dj spinning some outstanding techno right
there along the race route on Howard!! The tunes were too good to pass
up so I just stopped right there and danced with the promoters for 
about an hour or so until all the runners/walkers had passed and a
cop came and broke it up :( I wish I would've caught the djs name so I
could check him out at a party sometime, oh well, maybe someone knows
who it was? They were also handing out some really cool neon flyers
which said:

Like electricity
coursing thru wire,
you are a pulse of energy
(Em)POWERING us all

Charge On!

With Love and Light from the BETARAVERS

Some great moments were when one of the Hot Dog on a stick centipede
girls got down with us...boy she must've been to a few raves herself.
One of the Salmon who apparently got separated from his school of fish
swimming upstream against the tide of runners and walkers started 
floundering around with us! (pun intended sorry about that). Most of 
all it was wonderful to see the biggest smile on a handicapped girl 
being pushed by her mother, both of them laughing at us dancing up
a storm! 

After the cop broke that up, I ran and caught up with the rest of the
pack and if an hour+ of great music wasn't enough I stopped again at a
house near the beginning of Golden Gate where a dj from Spundae was
playing more superb music! I talked to one person who was sitting on
the steps of the house and he said they had been at Space Teddy too,
unfortunately, my memory is pretty bad and I forgot his and the djs
name, sorry about that.

I finally made it to the letter "R" at the polo fields a couple hours or
so later where our family members Austin (top 7% finisher!), Julie,
Sarah, Sarah, Paul, and Crunch were hanging out...Thanks for the Jolly
Ranchers, they gave me enough fuel to walk the two miles to Geary to 
catch a bus home!

Thank you to the BetaRavers and the people at the house near Golden Gate
for making Bay to Breakers absolutely the best of the four I've done so
far!

Peace and Love,
John

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: anarch@scruznet.com (Anarch)
Subject: True People
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I picked up a copy of "True People: the Detroit Techno Album" at
yesterday's KFJC record swap.  It's a compilation of twenty Detroit
classics, and it's definitely recommended.  I've only got through the first
dozen or so, and I love it.  I hadn't realized it 'til now, but back in 90
or 91 when I was first getting into the scene, before I knew what to call
it, probably before I'd heard of "rave" at all, it was the old-school
Detroit sound that was drawing me into the whole thing (with a little
cross-pollination from neo-industrial and New Wave).  This album is full of
reminiscences, and it still rocks, and no doubt will keep on rocking for
years to come.  It's available as 5 12" discs or 2 CDs.

I also got a Japanese double CD of Derrick May, "Innovator."  I haven't
listened to it yet, but it looks mighty cool.  Don't know if there's a US
version.

anarch@scruznet.com

[ to sfraves list ]

 Just a short report of yesterday afternoon's show. It seems he does this
theme every few years since 1990. He invites some of the more flamboyant
young club folks in New York City to come on his show and talk about going
out to clubs every night , getting stoned, and dressing strange.

 Some differentiation was made between club kids and ravers (..."baggy
pants...","....club scene..is more gay and lesbian...).

 Geraldo always made sure to mention the topic of drugs and "the dark
side" of being a club kid about every 8 minutes or so.

 The folks on stage were what I'd expected. The audience I wasn't quite
prepared for ... a mix of multicolor hair/tattooed/pierced folks and 
"regular" people in various stages of "look at the freaks!" facial
expressions. I guess I don't watch these shows often enough.

 If anyone's interested, I could look at the videotape again to get the
names of some of the folks onstage. What I remember is Walt Paper and
Richie Rich . There was also a guy who was a NYC DJ/promoter/manager ,
a bunch of former-ravers who had formed a "cyberpunk" band, and a gal
who does photography with the NYC club scene as her main theme.

 Drugs - lots of talk about "K" and exstacy and LSD. Some folks onstage
related their stupidest drug usage story.

 That's it for now!

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

PS - The costumes were cool! I don't go "clubbing" in San Francisco , 
 so I can't do a left coast / right coast comparison, but some of it
did look familiar.

Precedence: bulk

Greetings Friends...

In my view this list is a campfire around which our tribe gathers to
discuss events and issues of import to this community. This is obviously
not the only way to view this list, but it is mine.

The public airing of grievances -- around the campfire -- and censure for
behaviour that threatens the well being of the tribe are both time honored
traditions for regulating behaviour, which I chose, carefully, to invoke.

For those of you that are curious, I did call Tom and Stacy and let them
know how I felt before I took the step of thashing them publicly. I felt
and I stil feel that they earned this thrashing. I view our scene as a
community and I feel that promoters hould be held accountable to and before
the community. I think Tom and Stacy will think twice before they pull this
kind of stunt again, as well they should. I don't prseume to ask that they
throw parties as I would, but I do presume to ask, to demand even, that
they repsect precious and extremely scarce resources.

I could, and perhaps should have, left out the rage and the profanity. But
then perhaps not. Amongst friends and in community it is a blessing to be
able to share yourelf, truly -- however you find yourself -- with your
friends, with your family, if not with them, then who else?. I'm glad that
over the years I've had a lot more joy to share with you than rage, but in
this case that's what I had. My apologies to those of you that it offended,
and my thanks to those of you that offered your kind support, I truly
appreciate it.

love ya
ethan

-----------------------------( ethan miller )-----------------------------
-------------------( http://www.bass-station.com/FnF/ )-------------------
-------( you're only paranoid if they're not really watching you )--------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

> The reviews seemed mixed.  Personally I though it was pretty good music,

	I definitely agree. Real good House/Deep House stuff, mixed the
	House way... Precisely what one could have expected, right?
	I'm not surprised at all.

        The place (Point Molate) was cool as usual, and many people
	showed up, maybe 200?
	The crowd was nicely mixed: many "regulars ravers" and also more
	"club" people, which were there mainly for Keoki I guess. This
	guy seems to have some good fans.
	I looked at him for a moment, and didn't see anything peculiar
	being used except records ;-) And I can definitely assert that
	he didn't finish his set being removed from the "dex" by anybody.

	Trippy moment: after the sunset, everybody got lost in the dark, 
	calling after her/his friends. :-)

I was flipping through a book the other day and I found something that I 
thought was totally true and beautiful-and all though its not exactly 
rave related- I think it after all the negativity being 
posted as of late, I thought we could all use a good dose of something 
positive...  

The guide to what is essential..

1.  Right knowledge:  to supply you with the tools necessary for your voyage

2.  Wisdom:  to assure that you are using the accumulated knowledge of 
the past in a manner that will best serve the dicovery of your presence, 
your "now."

3.  Compassion:  to help you accept others whose ways may be different 
from yours, with gentleness and understanding, as you move with them or 
through them or around them on your own way.

4.  Harmony:  to be able to accept the natural flow of life

5.  creativity:  to help you to realize and recognize new alternatives 
and unchartered paths along the way

6.  Strength:  to stand up against fear and move forward in spite of 
uncertainty, without guarantee or payment.

7.  Peace, to keep you centered

8.  Joy:  to keep you songful and laughing and dancing all along the way.

9.  Love:  to be your continual guide towards the highest level of 
consciousness of which man is capable.

			AND FINALLY, MY FAVORITE...

10.  Unity:  which brings us back to where we started- the place where we 
are at one with ourselves and with all things....


smiles and love,
-jessica

Message-Id: <9605211933.AA28836@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Subject: Funky Techno Tribe
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 21 May 96 12:33:29 PDT

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


(5) Reasons why I might be going to Funky Techno Tribe:

1. It's been a long time since I've been to a commercial massive
so I've forgotten why I usually don't have too great a time at them.

2. The DJs: specifically the Darkhorse/Jonah Sharpe/Professor Smith 
Gardening Club contingent.

3. It's going to be in the City at the roomy Concourse Pavillion,
very convenient for me to get to.  It's been said that we can thank
Mayor Jordan's departure for making this local big site available again.

4. FTT's current reputation for excellent production values, or so I
hear.  I don't think I've ever actually been to a FTT party.

5. If I'm not having a good time I can easily leave knowing that Tribal
Future the following week will make up for it.

Disclaimer: It seems that whenever I post to sfraves that I'm
going to be at a particular party, I usually end up not going for some
reason.  

Also, isn't it true that Darkhorse == Graeme?  Both are listed to spin
at FTT, so I guess he gets paid twice.  I suppose it makes sense for a 
DJ to have different names to cover different styles.  Perhaps there's
a really diverse DJ out there (Markie?) who could play an *entire* party
under a bunch of different pseudynoms.  Of course this might be difficult
if there were 2 separate rooms of music.

ObFlame: Ethan's analogy of sfraves to a campfire gathering brings
to mind the famous campfire scene from Blazing Saddles.  Pass me
some of them beans.

Lee

> >

> > the past in a manner that will best serve the dicovery of your presence,
> > your "now."
> > 
> > 3.  Compassion:  to help you accept others whose ways may be different
> > from yours, with gentleness and understanding, as you move with them or
> > through them or around them on your own way.
> > 
> > 4.  Harmony:  to be able to accept the natural flow of life
> > 
> > 5.  creativity:  to help you to realize and recognize new alternatives
> > and unchartered paths along the way
> > 
> > 6.  Strength:  to stand up against fear and move forward in spite of
> > uncertainty, without guarantee or payment.
> > 
> > 7.  Peace, to keep you centered
> > 
> > 8.  Joy:  to keep you songful and laughing and dancing all along the way.
> >

> > consciousness of which man is capable.
> >

From: George Feil <george@unrrts.com>

Precedence: bulk

Thanks, Ethan, for your apology.

It is very refreshing to see that this list can maintain a signal /
noise ratio that is considerably higher than your average mailing list
or USENET group. The "campfire" metaphor that Ethan suggested is a
very good one to describe what we have here.

Although I have already responded privately to several people already,
I would like to clarify to the list at large where I was coming from
in my objection to y'all, since I feel well connected to you and this
list.

My objections were not aimed at the accusations, judgements, and
opinions that Ethan had toward Tom and Stacy. They weren't even aimed
at the anger and profanity itself. They were aimed at the wonton rage
without anything to qualify or explain it. 

Imagine that campfire scene for a moment, with someone around the
campfire shouting out, "<so and so> is a fucking asshole!" How would
you feel about that? How would you respond? Now, suppose that same
person around the campfire says, "<so and so> is a fucking asshole!
They just exploited of all the work I created for their own personal
gain." Your reaction may be different in that case.

I don't intend, nor do I want, to require anyone to suppress their
emotions here. I only ask that we, as a community, take responsibility
for the listening of the folks around us when we speak. Our words are
very powerful -- the world, and the people around it, are created
every day by our speaking. The very existence of each of us is
made up of the conversations we speak.

And, finally, to follow up on Ethan's point:

> For those of you that are curious, I did call Tom and Stacy and let them
> know how I felt before I took the step of thashing them publicly. I felt
> and I stil feel that they earned this thrashing. I view our scene as a
> community and I feel that promoters hould be held accountable to and before
> the community. I think Tom and Stacy will think twice before they pull this
> kind of stunt again, as well they should. I don't prseume to ask that they
> throw parties as I would, but I do presume to ask, to demand even, that
> they repsect precious and extremely scarce resources.

I wholeheartedly agree!

P&L,
-G-

_____________________________________________________
Jessica said:

Yes, I'll be there!  That will perhaps give me an opportunity for:
receiving my chart, introducing Sara and Cheyenne, giving you a massage,
talking about my difficulty with homosexuality, and sharing more love and
positive vibes (and maybe a puff or two ;))!

I was flipping through a book the other day and I found something that I 
thought was totally true and beautiful-and all though its not exactly 
rave related- I think it after all the negativity being 
posted as of late, I thought we could all use a good dose of something 
positive...  

The guide to what is essential..

1.  Right knowledge:  to supply you with the tools necessary for your voyage

2.  Wisdom:  to assure that you are using the accumulated knowledge of 
the past in a manner that will best serve the dicovery of your presence, 
your "now."

3.  Compassion:  to help you accept others whose ways may be different 
from yours, with gentleness and understanding, as you move with them or 
through them or around them on your own way.

4.  Harmony:  to be able to accept the natural flow of life

5.  creativity:  to help you to realize and recognize new alternatives 
and unchartered paths along the way

6.  Strength:  to stand up against fear and move forward in spite of 
uncertainty, without guarantee or payment.

7.  Peace, to keep you centered

8.  Joy:  to keep you songful and laughing and dancing all along the way.

9.  Love:  to be your continual guide towards the highest level of 
consciousness of which man is capable.

                        AND FINALLY, MY FAVORITE...

10.  Unity:  which brings us back to where we started- the place where we 
are at one with ourselves and with all things....


smiles and love,
-jessica

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue May 21 14:22:08 1996

	id RAA28725; Tue, 21 May 1996 17:21:28 -0400
Date: 21 May 96 17:19:26 EDT
From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@CompuServe.COM>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: OK, ALREADY! ORIGIN REVIEW!!
Message-ID: <960521211926_71165.755_GHL20-6@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, Larry has shamed me into posting my review..   ; )

My hesitation was NOT that I didn't want people to know I went -- for crying out
loud, my greatest pleasure in life is TO GO WHERE I WANT!  And I've paid dearly
for that right!  No fear and no shame!

And where I like to go is to listen to house music!  (yep, when you see me at
trance parties, it's mostly because I love all of you tranceheads enough that I
want to see you, more than the music drawing me there!)

So off I went, hearing first that I was heading to a map point and then a virgin
space.  When I got to the map point and realized where the party was, which was
where Madness was the previous week, I was quite disappointed -- that's not
virgin space, and shouldn't be called that.  Bad start.

Then I was duly frisked by the off-duty cops, had my unopened water bottle
confiscated ...(wouldn't it be nice if THAT was put on the voicemail, no bottles
allowed, or bring a bottle to refill, whatever?)... and went in to find a large
crowd of the sportswear set, the very young kids, gangbangers and dealers.  Not
my favorite beginning, I must say.

In no way did the vibe of this group of people compare to the Madness party,and
the space was not as welcoming in its setup either.  

The music, however, was great -- Rob Doten was finishing up a very good hard
house set, followed by Simon, then Reese from NY, very cool to me -- and Garth
was last -- somewhere in there was supposed to be Ms. Thing, Terry Bristol, but
maybe I was chilling at the time, cuz I never was aware of her spinning.

Big complaint:  Free water promised repeatedly, but there was none (Tom did make
one round giving out bottles, but that's not the same) -- and the one indoor
toilet bit the dust way early, creating a big mess!)  There was however, fresh
fruit cups passed out later.  Nice touch (though those hard crunchy cups ended
up being unusual sound effects as people tried to walk through the chill space
later ... maybe soft plastic or paper ones would have been better?)

Have to say my friend hated the vibe and left at 2:30 -- but I saw a number of
my friends there (most also grumbling about the crowd) -- and so I hung out
until 6am, meeting lots of (very young) nice people (esp the two sweetest
teenage girls, Stephanie and Amber) -- with a crowd this young, I got to be more
of the "rave mom" than ever, a role I don't mind when it's needed.

I did have a chance to talk to Stacey who was upset that she felt they had been
blasted for doing what they had to do to put their party together - I think this
is fundamentally a difference of motivation -- Stacey and Tom want to put on
parties that are fun enough for people to pay the money to come in, and that
way, everyone wins.  Tom asked me what I thought of the party, and I told him I
loved the music, but thought that it was promoted in the wrong places to bring
in the crowd that it did.  They seem to me to be sincere in their efforts.

Stacey promised a post to SFR yesterday, but it hasn't appeared yet (Stacey?
where are you?) -- (It's hard for me to think Greg2write is Stacey, since her
previous response to accusations was so professional and direct and his was so
incendiary and obnoxious)....

The bottom line here, for me, is that I believe we ALL have to stand strong that
PLUR is a real way to live, not just words, and sometimes it isn't easy in the
face of those who seem to stand in our way -- that maybe a quick checklist of
"is what I am about to do in the spirit of peace? love? unity? respect?" would
stop some of the actions that lead to these blowups ---  We can't change other
people, we can only change ourselves ... I just hope we can all get back to
peaceful coexistence soon....

The only side I'm on is the side of all of us who feel that raving brings us
depth, love, connection, happiness and a feeling of family -- and hope that
nothing ever stands in the way of that!

Much love to ALL ...

Received: from [153.37.82.119] (pool055.Max3.Santa-Clara.CA.DYNIP.ALTER.NET [153.37.82.119]) by iceland.it.earthlink.net (8.7.5/8.7.3) with SMTP id OAA10225 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 21 May 1996 14:22:00 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <v01530500adc75d6726b7@[153.37.82.99]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Date: Tue, 21 May 1996 14:22:12 +0200
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: exodus@earthlink.net (Austin)
Subject: Got FINALS but went 2 ORIGINS (review)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello friends and family,

I havn't posted for a while cuz I've been neck deep in studies for my
finals which are this week.  Been work 2 so I haven't checked my mail since
Wednesday.  Which means I didn't even know about all this MADDNESS going on
on the list latly.  I was down and stressed out so I wanted to get out
Saurday and to ORIGINS I went.  Mostly because I forgot the fresh start #
and I didn't feel like going to the deli AGAIN for another party.
   I didn't go to Madness last weekend (regretfully) and so as far I knew
on saturday the warehouse was virgin.  Paid 15 and they were charging 2$
for h2o but provided free cups of ice that you could munch on or fill up in
the bathroom.  Nice space - chill area inside and out, not too hot but you
could feel sweat dripping from the ceiling in the late evening.  Speaker
stacks at the 4 corners which made for good sound in the middle of the
building.  I arived at 1.30 am because I had to work a senior ball (nice
guys at 5 minute walk records).  I don't remember who was up at the time -
I belive it was Teri Bristol - "miss thing" was good but REESE was just
amazing.  He came on around 3 and rocked the house with some great acid
house and hard trance.  I was groovin' all night.  After Reese came Garth
to finish off the night with another great set.
   At first the people were rather straight faced, not smiling much and
there were a lot o' circles ( 3-4 at one time).  I spoke with a friend of
mine visiting from the east coast and he compared the party to an east
coast vibe.  I don't know about that but after 3.30 or so everyone seemed
to be getting into REESE and the vibe picked up.  I had a great time.  Cops
(2 uniformed officers) did show up twice (at least) First time was around
3.30 and everyone paniced and rushed inside.  I thought it helped the party
as everyone came together in the main room for awhile when the cops walked
around.  Then again around 7am.  I spoke with Andy doing security and he
said they show up because of a noise complant, they didn't see a reason to
bust the party as long as the noise didn't get louder and left.  They came
back in the morning to see that the party was ending (same officers) I left
right around this time cuz I was really tired and I need rest to do more
studing on Sunday.
   I had a great time.  I am sorry to hear that there is this hatred for
Tom and Stacy's tatics on throwing a party.  I say no disrespect at the
party by any of the patrons or Stacy her self.  There was little to
complain about and i am sure the space will be avaliable again.  I hope so
I love the location.  I hope everything gets worked out.  Bye bye for now -
back to the books.

See ya at crystalis?

> 
> 10.  Unity:  which brings us back to where we started- the place where we 
> are at one with ourselves and with all things....

I was reading about the Suya Indians and the anthropologist who has 
studied them since the 1970's.  When the author of the story asked the 
anthropologist what *most* threatened the existence of this Brazilian tribe 
of only 158 people, he expected to hear something like "infringement on 
their land" or "destruction of their water".  But, the anthropologist 
said that the thing most threatening the Suya Indians is "individualism." 
There is an increasing tendancy to ignore to greater good of the entire 
tribe, and this threatens their community.  

I find this incredibly thought-provoking, especially since we can relate 
it to ourselves as a community.  So, I just thought I'd throw this out to 
all of you to draw your own conclusions.  

chau,
kaySEE

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 21 May 1996 16:09:35 +1000
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)
Subject: Space Teddy Review / Bay to Breakers
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Space Teddy/ Bay to Breakers review
=================================

Well,  here's my first review in a while,  as this has been the first
time I've had a chance to breath and come up for air.

Been going through some very hard times these last few months,
primarily because I thought that it would be possible to sell Web
sites for small businesses.   But business has been so bad that I
haven't had any work in over 45 days.    Then,  in first week of may,
one client I did Mac programming for,  had to leave to Taiwan on an
emergency and didn't pay me before he left.   So,   my landlord
evicted me for being only 3 days late in paying rent.  What a greedy
fuck head.

To make matters worse,  last Tuesday it started to rain and I had no
way to clear out my place,  then injured my lower back...  Ruptured a
disc in my lower back,  trying to move some heavy boxes.   Yukk!!
and double Yukk!!   I really had my heart set on running B to B,
because last year I was in Australia and missed it.   I was even
training for it,  by running the Dipsea trail to Stinson Beach.

Thanx to John (A super great fellow SFRaver) for helping steer me
into good positive thinking and paying my way into Madness and
this weeks Space Teddy,   I was able to rave and be with wonderful
REAL PEOPLE.

Anyway,   back to the review...   Space Teddy was incredible!!   Mars
was spinning some of the sickest hard trance I heard since I left the
land of Oz....   His set was brilliant...   Fast!!   Probably topped the 150
BPM range...   Oh!  how I love the fast beats....

When Keoki finally went on (I was looking forward for his set,  by
the way),   he slowed the BPMs way down (Much too slow for my
taste)...   He smoothly worked into a more housy sound,   but frankly
I wasn't that impressed.   He did spin a lot of variety though,   but
after Mar's set,   which was a tough act to follow,   it seemed to
reduce the energy level.

Of course,  due to lower back problems,  I wasn't my usual hi-nrg
self,  so sorta waddled around the dance floor and couldn't dance that
much,  but I did manage to run into Austin (Tinsau).

After Keoki's set,  Mystr-E took the controls,  but his set got off to a
slow start,  with a few interruptions to the beats,  which I used to
take the opportunity to go off and hide to deal with my lower back
and do some yoga and stretching for a while.    Then,   after his set
started to get more consistent,   he played "Paraglider" and I literally
WENT OFF!!   Such a GREAT track....

I think Jon Santos went on after that,  but I chilled for quite a while,
trying to find some water....  I had no money and couldn't afford to
buy any water,   but eventually,  I was able to sneak my water bottle
past the water-nazi and re-fill it,  after I pulled a distraction
technique and waited for the right moment to sneak in and fill it.

I also got a chance to talk to the Spundae promoter for the first
time... Really nice guy,  he even bought me some water....  Thanx
man!

After chilling,   I went back to hear David Michael's set...  Not bad,
really consistent,  kinda housey...   then just after 6 am,  the music
faded,  I found Tinsau who was kind enough to give me a ride to the
Haight...   After wondering around,  looking for any restaurant that
was open,   failing to find one,   I caught bus to the Castro to eat at
Orphan Annies...   Then back to the GG park pan handle to catch the
first Bay to Breakers runners and watched the race from there,  and
walking to the finish line.    I certainly could NOT do any running,
and even if I could,  I had no place to stash my stuff....   I eventually
made it to the finish line,  looking for any SFRavers running in.
Didn't see anyone,  so headed to the polo fields to the "R" section,
and ran into Tinsau.    The FootStock festivities were GREAT,  I sorta
wandered around,  listening to Greg Allmond concert...   Somehow
Tinsau ditched me after I asked him to wait while I took a pee,   but
when I got back,  he left.    I got stuck in SF with no money for bus
back,  and eventually hooked up with a fellow Raver who loaned me
the bus fare to return home.    I never made it back home until 6 PM,
only to find all my possessions removed from the room (I was
supposed to hook up with a friend at 3 PM to help me move,  but
wasn't lucky enough to make connections.

So,  if anyone out there has any storage space for about 5 apple fruit
boxes,   PLEASE contact me.    Right now,  all my stuff is outside
getting soaking wet in the rain,  and I have no place to sleep.   Last
night,  I had to sleep under someone's porch.   I'm still trying to get
into a homeless shelter,  but as luck would have it,   they closed them
down a few weeks ago.   Now there's a 5 week waiting list...   If only
it would stop raining...

I'm still able to get on the net,  but only if I can find some kind soul
who is willing to let me use their phone to make local calls to my ISP
so I can check my Mail.

Right now,  I'm spending most of my time on coffee shops in Mill
Valley and sometimes if the right person is working,  they let me
plug in to upload and download my Email.    I've managed to keep
my laptop dry,  but have no safe place to stash it,  so it remains as a
piece of my body.

Crunchman
