From: NOMADS <tahsina@ix.netcom.com>
Organization: Nomad Interactive Productions
X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.01 (Win16; I)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Nomad Interactive response to ethan!!!!!!-long
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

First and foremost, we do not believe that the SFR list belongs to ethan
miller, it belongs to a group of different people from different 
backgrounds who share a sense of community which we feel part of.

Secondly, we do expect a public apology from ethan miller for the 
profanity and personal slander he administered against us!

The following is a summary of the events which took place last week 
before the ORIGIN party. We initially planned our event around another 
space but several factors, namely the fact that construction of a 
partition was not completed in the space, did not allow us to use that 
space. Consequently, we were left without a space and many commitments.

We were introduced to the owner of the space that madness used by a 
friend who told the owner that we also put together these types of 
events. The owner was very interested but also indicated that he had six 
other promoters approach him for the space. He said he was being 
selective and felt very excited about working with us. We do have 
excellent references from other people we have worked with.

After the owner gave the commitment to us, we recieved a call from ethan 
miller telling us it was disrespectful to use that space. He never 
bothered to ask why we needed that space. We know he cares alot about 
what he is doing and we respect that. Yet, several months back when F&F
needed a space, we took ethan and several members of the planning 
comittee to see a beautiful space with three musical areas that was well 
within F&F's budget. He loved the space and yet when it came down to it, 
he refused the space and even scared the manager into thinking that this 
was going to be some out of control party. We even asked ethan if we 
could donate one musical area to include sound, dj's, decorations, but he  
refused the space from the start and did not want anything to do with us.

We feel that we should all help each other if we can and we have never 
kept a space for ourselves. We found three new spaces in the last four 
months and they have been shared by many people. You cannot control a 
space unless you own it or lease it long term. Regarding the use of the 
map point that joe rice says we stole from madness: the people at that 
location are good people. The city has not allowed them to hold any 
events there for the past year and a half. They welcome the use of their 
location as a map point and would like others to use it as well.
The place has become a financial burden to them and if we and others can
help them supplement their financial obligations by using their location 
as a map point so be it. We have not stepped on anybody's toes or tried 
to take anything away from the madness people. as a matter of fact, we've 
made several map points available for people when we were asked for help.

Here are the facts regarding what happened last week:

Tuesday we spoke to the owner of the space who said yes lets do the 
party. 
Wednesday, we recieved a call from ethan miller saying it was 
disrespectful to use that space, even though his name is not on the lease 
for that space. He did not even ask why we needed the space. An hour 
later we recieved a call from the owner of the space saying he recieved a 
call from the police telling him "We understand you are having a rave 
party this Saturday. You can't do it and don't let us come down there".
The owner said that the caller never left his name. The owner told us he 
believed this to be a prank call from the madness people. He said lets 
still go ahead with the party. He did not want these people to bully him.

In the meantime there is a guy named billy who lives at this location 
free of charge. According to the owner billy introduced the madness 
people to him. The next morning, the owner called us and said that he 
recieved three calls from the madness people yelling at him not to do the 
party. He said the callers were alex, jon santos, and a third "person".
They told him don't do this party, these people are "this" and "that",
etc, etc. The owner also said that billy told him that the madness people 
had a meeting the night before and decided to cause problems for the 
party. If anyone wants to verify these facts they can ask the owner 
directly.

At this point the owner became hesitant and nervous about everything. He 
decided to call off the party. He also felt blackmaled by the madness 
people. A few hours later we met with him and he decided to honor his 
word and go through with the party. We addressed all the concerns of the 
owner to include sound levels, capacity issues, and adequate security.

Two hours after our meeting with the owner, ethan miller posted his 
malicious remarks on the internet.

During the party, around midnight, noise complaints started pouring in 
from far away locations. HOW STRANGE!!!

The sound levels were maintained so the party went on.

Overall, people were happy to have us in the neighborhood because we 
respected everything around us and that comes from doing events in that 
area for a while now and for keeping good relationships with the people 
we have worked with. 

On a final note, we do not feel that the SFR mailing list should be a 
forum to slander people. We have been victims of some very malicious 
rumors and we would not post these facts unless we know them to be 
correct. We have been very nice so far. We are good people. We have not 
caused harm to anyone and have nothing to hide. But we will never allow 
anyone again to use us as escapegoats. So please be warned and be 
careful about what you say. The power of the pen can destroy people.

The reason you do not see us posting alot is because there is so much 
negativity, slander, and critisism that frankly it does not make it fun 
to participate. We are very open minded about alot of the different 
events that take place in this community and we respect each of them for 
what they are. It is a shame that some people do not share the same view
point!

Tom & Stacey

Today has quite possible been the most fucked-up day of my life.  First of
all, I couldn't sleep all last night because I was stressed out about
finals.  So I got up and went to the store to get some food for breakfast.
And locked myself out of the house.  Not only could I not get inside, but
everything I needed for my finals was in there.  Along with my car keys.  So
I had to walk to school.  And just when I thought things couldn't get any
worse, it started to rain.  Luckily I got ahold of my roommate, who had a
spare set of keys, so I got my stuff, but that only left me about thirty
minutes before my final.  And then, on top of everything else, the final
that I thought I had today was not, in fact, the final I had today.  The one
that I actually had (and because I didn't know about it hadn't studied for
yet) is for my hardest class this semester.  So I'm sure I did terrible on
it (no, this isn't a value judgement, I really did).  Which puts me in
danger of losing a $10,000 a year scholarship.

Life Sucks.

You, are dreaming.

Your insinuation that someone from madness called the cops is a laughable.
The inverse is more likely true.

The rest of your post is you saying, "the owner said...." I have no way of
knowing what the owner told you. None of which matters to me. I'm not
talking about the owner, your deal with him, or his willingness to break
previous agreements in favor of your cash.

Everyone gives in to cash.

You seem to feel that buying your way into that space was ethical behaviour
and I disagree.  You seem to feel that putting 1000 people in that space is
responsible behaviour and I disagree. You think that noise complaints came
from berkeley instead of around the corner and I disagree. You call a space
used a week ago a virgin warehouse and I disagree. You suggest that
lathering the neighbohood with cash, just "helps the neighborhood" and I
disagree.

You have permanently changed the climate for that space and that
neighborhood. Now the owner expects fat wads of cash and the cops think fat
wads of cash are being made. To mention just a few of the changes you have
effected.

We didn't leave the space in that condition, you did. And I think it's jsut
as fucked now as I did on friday.

ethan

To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

Message-ID: <960522010453_71165.755_GHL109-4@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Stacey and Tom,

Thank you for posting such a calm, detailed and straightforward account of your
version of the events of last week.

I, for one, have let out a long sigh, releasing some of the tension of the past
days, feeling caught in the middle of something I never would have chosen to be
part of, and relieved that both sides have now spoken.  SFR is a forum for  us
to communicate, good and bad.  Using Ethan's tribal campfire metaphor, the
talking stick was passed to you and you used it eloquently.

It pains me to think that some of the actions you have outlined (such as either
reporting competitive promoters to authorities based on personal grudges, or
impersonating police) could even be implied to have been done by people who are
active in our community.

Again, the only side I take is of those who want to keep raving as an important
part of their life, and who depend on the party planners and organizers to
create the environment for us to come together.

May each and every person involved in this entire scenario deal personally with
whatever actions they took that created or contributed to the problems... as
well as whatever action they did *not* take that could have averted these
problems....  

We are each responsible for ourselves, and responsible for the consequences of
our actions .... even if nobody knows what we have done, what counts is who you
see when you look in the mirror.

I hope to see EVERYONE out partying in the future.

Love, peace and honesty.             Leslie  (yep, the raver mom)

On Tue, 21 May 1996, NOMADS wrote:

> First and foremost, we do not believe that the SFR list belongs to ethan
> miller, it belongs to a group of different people from different 
> backgrounds who share a sense of community which we feel part of.

Well, he never claimed it did. As I remember he always presented his 
views as his own.


> 
> Secondly, we do expect a public apology from ethan miller for the 
> profanity and personal slander he administered against us!
> 

???????

> The following is a summary of the events which took place last week 
> before the ORIGIN party. We initially planned our event around another 
> space but several factors, namely the fact that construction of a 
> partition was not completed in the space, did not allow us to use that 
> space. Consequently, we were left without a space and many commitments.
> 
> We were introduced to the owner of the space that madness used by a 
> friend who told the owner that we also put together these types of 
> events. The owner was very interested but also indicated that he had six 
> other promoters approach him for the space. He said he was being 
> selective and felt very excited about working with us. We do have 
> excellent references from other people we have worked with.
> 
> After the owner gave the commitment to us, we recieved a call from ethan 
> miller telling us it was disrespectful to use that space. He never 
> bothered to ask why we needed that space. We know he cares alot about 
> what he is doing and we respect that. Yet, several months back when F&F
> needed a space, we took ethan and several members of the planning 
> comittee to see a beautiful space with three musical areas that was well 
> within F&F's budget. He loved the space and yet when it came down to it, 
> he refused the space and even scared the manager into thinking that this 
> was going to be some out of control party. We even asked ethan if we 
> could donate one musical area to include sound, dj's, decorations, but he  
> refused the space from the start and did not want anything to do with us.

So this is your perspective which I'm sure others have different views 
on. I tend to wonder why ethan did not want to work with you.


> 
> We feel that we should all help each other if we can and we have never 
> kept a space for ourselves. We found three new spaces in the last four 
> months and they have been shared by many people. You cannot control a 
> space unless you own it or lease it long term. Regarding the use of the 
> map point that joe rice says we stole from madness: the people at that 
> location are good people. The city has not allowed them to hold any 
> events there for the past year and a half. They welcome the use of their 
> location as a map point and would like others to use it as well.
> The place has become a financial burden to them and if we and others can
> help them supplement their financial obligations by using their location 
> as a map point so be it. We have not stepped on anybody's toes or tried 
> to take anything away from the madness people. as a matter of fact, we've 
> made several map points available for people when we were asked for help.
> 

Yet what about the advertisments saying "Virgin Space"? That issue is not 
addressed in this post directly.



> Here are the facts regarding what happened last week:
> 

You claim.

> Tuesday we spoke to the owner of the space who said yes lets do the 
> party. 
> Wednesday, we recieved a call from ethan miller saying it was 
> disrespectful to use that space, even though his name is not on the lease 
> for that space. He did not even ask why we needed the space. An hour 
> later we recieved a call from the owner of the space saying he recieved a 
> call from the police telling him "We understand you are having a rave 
> party this Saturday. You can't do it and don't let us come down there".
> The owner said that the caller never left his name. The owner told us he 
> believed this to be a prank call from the madness people. He said lets 
> still go ahead with the party. He did not want these people to bully him.
> 
> In the meantime there is a guy named billy who lives at this location 
> free of charge. According to the owner billy introduced the madness 
> people to him. The next morning, the owner called us and said that he 
> recieved three calls from the madness people yelling at him not to do the 
> party. He said the callers were alex, jon santos, and a third "person".
> They told him don't do this party, these people are "this" and "that",
> etc, etc. The owner also said that billy told him that the madness people 
> had a meeting the night before and decided to cause problems for the 
> party. If anyone wants to verify these facts they can ask the owner 
> directly.
> 

This sounds a little suspicious to me. If billy is introducing the 
madness crew to the owner why would billy squeal on madness? Verification 
from the owner mearly would present his perspective which may or may not 
be fact.


> At this point the owner became hesitant and nervous about everything. He 
> decided to call off the party. He also felt blackmaled by the madness 
> people. A few hours later we met with him and he decided to honor his 
> word and go through with the party. We addressed all the concerns of the 
> owner to include sound levels, capacity issues, and adequate security.
> 
> Two hours after our meeting with the owner, ethan miller posted his 
> malicious remarks on the internet.
> 
> During the party, around midnight, noise complaints started pouring in 
> from far away locations. HOW STRANGE!!!
> 

Not necessarily. Shoreline amphitheatre used to get noise complaints from 
the east side of the bay. As a sound engineer I know that atmospheric 
accoustics can play strange tricks with the propagation of sound. I have 
had noise complaints come from a half mile away yet neighbors 50 to 100 
yards away never heard a thing ( or so it seemed ).


> The sound levels were maintained so the party went on.
> 
> Overall, people were happy to have us in the neighborhood because we 
> respected everything around us and that comes from doing events in that 
> area for a while now and for keeping good relationships with the people 
> we have worked with. 
> 

Cool! Keep that up.


> On a final note, we do not feel that the SFR mailing list should be a 
> forum to slander people.

I agree.

> We have been victims of some very malicious 
> rumors and we would not post these facts unless we know them to be 
> correct.

The only 'rumors' I believe I heard were those from ethan (please correct 
me if I'm wrong!).


> We have been very nice so far. We are good people. We have not 
> caused harm to anyone and have nothing to hide. But we will never allow 
> anyone again to use us as escapegoats. So please be warned and be 
> careful about what you say. The power of the pen can destroy people.
> 

And that sword cuts both ways.


> The reason you do not see us posting alot is because there is so much 
> negativity, slander, and critisism that frankly it does not make it fun 
> to participate.


Yet you want to use this forum to further your aims. hmmm


> We are very open minded about alot of the different 
> events that take place in this community and we respect each of them for 
> what they are. It is a shame that some people do not share the same view
> point!
> 
> Tom & Stacey
> 

Okay here is my 2 cents.
 
 I'm a very neutral observer in this situation. I do not know any of the 
people involved, yet I feel a right to respond as this is a public forum. 
 
 On the surface, ethan's original post is very harsh and (from my 
experience) much more violent than 99.99999% of the posts made here. 
However his anger MAY have been justified. I don't think I'll ever know 
the answer to that. However I have seen an immense outpouring of support 
and love for him here.

 I feel that Tom and Stacey have shown much respect by waiting until 
ethan was back online before posting their response. Whether this was 
deliberate or not? However their viewpoints above sound just as one-sided 
as ethans, despite how reasonable everything sounds. And as I have 
learned, reasonableness is not neccesarily fact.

 I also feel that perhaps ethan went overboard in his use of profanity 
and imflammitory (sp?) writing style. This in and of itself makes me 
suspicious of his motivations.

 While I feel that spot checking each other on shortcomings is good, 
stirring up feelings of anger and hatred is not good nor respected (by me).

Peace all

Ran


     ( if ravers can not get along, how can we expect the world to )
                                /
                          -=*=-/
                            ~

Subject: Rave Film Treatment - 96
Message-Id: <Pine.SUN.3.91.960521210542.10882C-100000@dfw.dfw.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


        'Hard Copy's recent piece regarding the dangers of  rave culture
is yet another rehash of the sensationalist tactics used by the media to
demonise those operating outside established legal/social constraints.  By
presenting the rave scene in a derogatory light public opinion grants the
power to shut down gatherings and arrest whomever they wish with no public
outcry or intervention.

        The draconian English Criminal Justice Bill  (which outlaws any
gathering of over ten people without a permit, as well as the right to
silence) is a prime example of direct action taken by government to stop
young people from gathering, expressing ideas, and having a good time.
The English government told the public that the 'Suss' laws were designed
to stop ravers from gathering in England, yet they are much further reaching.
Could this happen in the US - well the Exxon Bill passed didn't it?

        Raves provide a safe environment for young and old people to dance,
enjoy, express and explore themselves. The Rave Culture stands for Peace,
Love, Unity and Respect. Many lives have been touched and changed by this
movement.

        We propose a documentary project to show the positive facets of Rave
Culture.  We want to turn this project into a group endeavor, collaboration
is essential.  Since we will be operating on a 'no budget' we plan to 
film for
the most part in California and will be compiling footage over the summer.
If you would like to participate in the project and you are outside of
California you can send a video (high-8, super 8, vhs, etc.) to us.  We plan
to edit the material at the end of the summer.

        We will not film at any rave without the permission of the promoters
and participants.  We do not want to be confused with another "Hard Copy"
undercover agent.  Any assistance from promoters would be very welcome.  If
you are throwing a rave and would like to participate in the project, please
let us know.

	To subscribe to the online discussion mailing list send an email
message to majordomo@underground.org with a body of:

		subscribe rave-film

        If you wish to contribute footage please mail it to:

                Annaliza Savage
                1803 Mission St.
                Santa Cruz, CA 95060 USA

        Peace, and spread the word.

                Aleph One
                Sir Dystic
                Annaliza Savage

To: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
From: Vince <Vince@vmar.com>
Subject: Re: SFR Logo/T-shirts
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>let's make this a general logo contest.  Or not: Perhaps this will simply be a
>collection of logos from which people can choose what logo they prefer, copy
>it, and use it to create their own t-shirt/laminate/bumper sticker/ etc....

YEAH, NO CONTEST !

 I've butted heads with different galleries and art events over the issue
of art as a competition. I think is SUCKS, art is way to subjective to have
in a competitive situation. When I want to compete, I race. You get to the
finish line first, you WIN, period. So I think that everyone should use
whatever they want to identify themselves as an SFRaver.

Onward and upward Senor Dream, I like what you are doing.

Art is not a contest, it is an expression. It is all beautiful and comes
from inside the artist, they are giving us a piece of their heart and soul.

vince

PS: I have actually had some success in art competitions, BUT the work I
built for them was not built from my gut, it was built to impress the
judges. If you know that it is a contest, you are constantly thinking about
winning, instead of just expressing yourself, and letting it flow.

nuf said

Uh.... which people were *happy* to have you in the neighborhood?

I live in the neighborhood - on the other side of the park - and I wasn't
happy. I was home sick and unable to sleep because my windows and roof were
rattling from all the 140bpm bass. Not to mention the influx of gang-types
that always appear at over-commercialized raves.

And I know a lot of my neighbors weren't happy either, but we tolerated it.

Mixed industrial/residential neighborhoods are not good places to have huge
events.

It would have been different if there wasn't a party there the week before-
but there was.

-Rusty

From:  John Draper[SMTP:crunch@well.com]
Sent:  Tuesday, May 21, 1996 4:38 PM
To:  sfraves
Subject:  Space Teddy Review / Bay to Breakers

...
Been going through some very hard times these last few months,
primarily because I thought that it would be possible to sell Web
sites for small businesses.   But business has been so bad that I
haven't had any work in over 45 days.    Then,  in first week of may,
one client I did Mac programming for,  had to leave to Taiwan on an
emergency and didn't pay me before he left.   So,   my landlord
evicted me for being only 3 days late in paying rent.  What a greedy
fuck head.

To make matters worse,  last Tuesday it started to rain and I had no
way to clear out my place,  then injured my lower back...  Ruptured a
disc in my lower back,  trying to move some heavy boxes.   Yukk!!
and double Yukk!!   I really had my heart set on running B to B,
because last year I was in Australia and missed it.   I was even
training for it,  by running the Dipsea trail to Stinson Beach.
...
I got stuck in SF with no money for bus
back,  and eventually hooked up with a fellow Raver who loaned me
the bus fare to return home.    I never made it back home until 6 PM,
only to find all my possessions removed from the room (I was
supposed to hook up with a friend at 3 PM to help me move,  but
wasn't lucky enough to make connections.

So,  if anyone out there has any storage space for about 5 apple fruit
boxes,   PLEASE contact me.    Right now,  all my stuff is outside
getting soaking wet in the rain,  and I have no place to sleep.   Last
night,  I had to sleep under someone's porch.   I'm still trying to get
into a homeless shelter,  but as luck would have it,   they closed them
down a few weeks ago.   Now there's a 5 week waiting list...   If only
it would stop raining
...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue May 21 22:20:17 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id WAA06470; Tue, 21 May 1996 22:20:17 -0700

Date: Tue, 21 May 1996 22:20:07 -0700 (PDT)
From: Cami Edwards <cami@netcom.com>
Subject: Late Review of 111 Minna
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9605212154.A19029-0100000@netcom20>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Well, we did not get out much this weekend (music-wise), but we did make 
it to 111 Minna.  Friday nites never find me with too much energy, after 
a long week of work, but I like to dance off some steam for a bit.

When we arrived(10:30) at the gallery (very beautiful space, I might add), 
there were only about ten or so peeps there, but nice ones.  A couple of 
people dancing, music was sort of mellow (think it was a tape).  Then 
Markie came on.  He is amazing.  His mixing is so flawless and his music 
is so diverse (comparable only to M. Farina in both respects, IMHO).  
Very nice and funky house music.  It was a great way to unwind from the 
stress of the week.  Had a good time dancing with very few people.  One 
person in particular was just a barrel of energy, kept trying to get the 
wallflowers to dance, with a little success, but he was determined! Fun 
to watch, too. After Markie was Simon, also spinning good funky shit.  Tracy 
was set to go on next, but after nearly 2 hours of straight dancing I was 
pooped (must've been to miss Tracy:)  

I really hope more people showed later (we left around one), because 
the people throwing the party seemed really cool, and it was only $5.  
Bargain Friday nite.  Definitely check this space out sometime, 
though.  I have always heard of it, but never been.        

See you on the floor.

Cheers***
Cami


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue May 21 22:48:36 1996

From: Karen Hardie <eidrah@vanbc.wimsey.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: hi kids :)
Message-ID: <Pine.SCO.3.91.960521224030.13967B@vanbc.wimsey.com>

i just wanted to share with you all down SF way what an AMAZING party we 
had up here in darn rainy Vancouver :)

It was called XL.  12 djs, 3 rooms.  The headliner was John Aquaviva, 
with plenty of home-grown talent thrown in.  Kind of a piddly laser 
system than was promised, but nice anyways.  It was in an old Armoury in 
the middle of town.  The main room had 40 or 50 foot ceilings, so it 
stayed nice and cool.  

the VISUALS were astonishingly well done ... for a while a huge YOU ARE 
HERE was projected over the Army crest on the wall :) lovely fractal 
animations too.  And also, there was a professional acting/dance troupe 
of FIRE BREATHERS! there :) one of them was this guy on stilts wearing a 
gas mask, strobe light breasts, a jockstrap and garters while juggling 
flaming torches.

The second room was the house room which sadly was way too echoey ... 

The third room was the ambient room ... to reach it you went up four 
flights of stairs .... but when you got there it was like stepping into 
heaven.  It was also a strictly non-smoking environment, which was 
appreciated :)

it went pumping and bouncing until four-thirty until KABOOM!  they shut 
it down, the bastids!  oh well.  it was worth it, every minute!!!

k

From: "Bryce Ryan" <brycer@ultima.org>
In-Reply-To: <31A256DF.738C@ix.netcom.com> from "NOMADS" at May 21, 96 04:50:55 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]

Content-Length: 3405
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

My mailer says that NOMADS said:
> 
> Yet, several months back when F&F
> needed a space, we took ethan and several members of the planning 
> comittee to see a beautiful space with three musical areas that was well 
> within F&F's budget. He loved the space and yet when it came down to it, 
> he refused the space and even scared the manager into thinking that this 
> was going to be some out of control party. 
> 

just a point of fact about the space in question here, and what 
members from the collective  brought to the attention of the manager:
that the party was going to be all night and that it was going to be loud.
the all night, loud part was news to the manager.  my sense, and his
conversation, indicated that this was new news to him, and got him to 
thinking on his own.

we also became aware, on inspecting the space and talking with the manager,
that there was a rest home 100 feet from the space, as well as residences
just across the street.  the residences we may have been able to deal with
by a door to door canvas;  the rest home, with many older and infirm
people, couldn't be  dealt with in any sensible manner except to recommend
against doing events there. going into a neighborhood and disturbing
all the neighbors, especially folks who aren't well and can't get away
from the disturbance, was the only responsible action under those 
circumstances, IMO.  i'm sure the manager's thoughts also turned in
that direction, since the space is maintained in the public interest
(i seem to recall that the building is owned by the city or county),
and he has to consider the impact on the community he serves.  we may
be there for one night...he has to live with the aftermath for the
remainder of his term of care, AND answer to the city or county.

i suspect, but don't know for sure, that the manager of the space also
took into consideration the fact that he was not informed until a very
late date, of just what that party would entail.  i recall him being
very surprised that we expect to go beyond 1 or 2 AM.  For a legal
event in a legal space, popping surprises like that on the management
is not a good thing. 

if there was anyone scaring anybody, it was responsible people considering
the long term consequences of their actions.

as it was, F&F had a fine event outdoors that disturbed no one and
was well attended, instead of a chancy event indoors that could have
resulted in noise complaints, an early shutdown, and unhappiness on all
sides.  Given that the event was an anniversary party, and F&F's previous
anniversary party got shut down very early because of a variety of
problems, ethan, i, and other members of the collective recommended against
doing an event in a space that was even modestly chancy.  Knowing the
potential draw of an F&F in a legal space, good promotion, and all
that, we decided NOT to risk another debacle of large proportions.  We
saw no reason to risk the happiness of our attendees with a potential
bust, nor risk the happiness, well-being and good will of the neighbors.

ethan did not, on his own, refuse the space.  he consulted with the planners
group and made a recommendation on our behalf. 
-- 
=== Bryce Ryan ===== AMBIANCE ========= e-dress: brycer@ultima.org =========
=== Internet services, education, and Toaster Net construction :-) =========
===  Web Weather report at http://priscilla.ultima.org/stats.html  =========

Hi everybody . Tickets are moving fast for our campout , so I'll 
repeat 'get them early' once they are gone ,that's it. We should have 
tickets through the weekend but I expect it to sell out before the 
party. Our store will be closed ,we'll be at the mountain.
   So bring a sleeping bag or maybe a tent,some food to share,a 
telescope for the stars,something for the alter, something for your 
head,be creative.
   Friday night: settle in with early campers, slower beats with Corbin, 
Everett and others,warm up the hot tubs, Rather chill but every ones 
welcome.
   Saturday: inaugurate the mud baths, add on the rest of the sound(4 
corners, 8x by JK), Large spagetti feast for as many as we can(BRING 
STUFF TO ADD), then prepare to freak out all night with Spun(just 
confirmed!) Tony, Tracy, Carlos, Galen, Solar, Alex etc. 
   Sunday: relax and enjoy blue berry pancakes with Pollywog, Allen, 
Andrew and more,  but don't split yet because the full moon will soon 
rise in time for sunday night sets from Garth, Markie Mark, and John 
Howard.(and maybe an encore set from Tracy!)
   Monday: Sleep in, clean up, adios !!!
  So bring the whole family,(kids are welcome,dogs are not.)Please 
carpool to the limit of your vehicle( we have space for lots of 
people,not lots of cars. There's bus service to Willits(Greyhound or 
Green Tortoise} get yourself there and we'll shuttle you up to the 
party. Directions to the map point in Willits will be posted on the VM 
263-3915 where you will show your ticket and recieve final instructions.
Please try to arrive during the daylight hours on Fri, Sat, or Sunday, 
this will greatly help you in camping and locating the site which can be 
tricky at night. 
  
       Thanks everyone  ,  See ya there  , Mark Ameba

 p.s. The vision of a festival called Tribal Future popped into my head 
while visiting my daughter in New Zealand in October 1993. The first 
party by that name was on the Russian River in late summer '94 . The 
next Tribal Future was near Willits in October '95 and was subtitled 
"Mendocino Mountain Jam". 
 "Big Mountain Boogie" is the third in the Tribal Future series, but 
it's the fifth campout we've done up north since '92.                   
  Inspired by an impromptu after-party after "CREATION" we did on the 
river by Hacienda bridge near Guerneville we put together the "Russian 
River RE-UNION" on June 27-8 1992 followed by our collaboration with 
Preston known as "ACME ACRES" on August 15-16 '92 . This was the party 
that landed us in Sonoma County Court the day before the event , slapped 
with a restraining order from a local supervisor hysterical about "the 
rave" We won, first amendment in hand, to throw the party, shaken, but 
not stopped.
  We've got more events planned for this year, look for our workshop on 
Techno-Primitive Awareness at Harbin Hot Springs July 26-28, possibly a 
LARGE Tribal campout in Aug. or Sep. and another Tribal Future In 
Mendocino on October 19-20.      
  
-- 
salutations,  Mark Ameba

FROM: Robert Brown

SUBJECT: Car Break-ins & Theft (mostly NRR)


 I had sent an email about this yesterday morning but it never showed up
 on SFR that I could see, so I'll resend it...

 After seeing a few posts about car break ins at raves I felt I just HAD
 to chime in on it given what happened to me over the weekend.

 On Saturday night/Sunday morning my car was stolen while I was in SF
 dancing.  Not an expenisive car, but not a heap either.  Coming out
 at 3:30am to discover your car is no more is not a pleasant experience,
 especially when you're alone, stranded 45 miles from home!

 According to the police (who was reasonably nice, btw) Hondas seem to
 be the current favorite flavor of car thieves in SF.  I had a "locktronics"
 ignition lock, but obviously it didn't prevent the car from being stolen.
 Seemed to be a pro job.  Also, again according to the police, auto theives
 do cruise around various party/club spots in SF looking for cars - so
 be careful as well as you can.  I think they were definitely after the car
 itself because I hid everything out of site so there'd be no obvious
 motivation for breaking into the car.  To no avail...

 Ironically I was looking at car alarms just a couple of weeks ago, but
 couldn't afford to get one at the time.  Argh!  :(

 Aside from the car my uninsured, personal, and expensive cellular phone
 was taken, and my planner/address book.  So, if any of you have given
 my your addy/phone # I no longer have them and would like them again,
 if possible.

 If anyone sees a black Honda Prelude with CA license plate EZP 233, please
 call the police!  Though I'm sure it's been hacked to bits and the
 parts sent all over the place by now.  :(

 And just to make things completely miserable, my s.o. decided to break up
 with me last night.  Paradise lost...(that phrase just came to mind)
 Life seems a swirl of negativity currently...

 Sorry, but had to spill to whomever was listening.

Ok, there's been a fair amount of insterest so I'll post it:

(btw I've also verified that at last one noise complaint came from 1 block
away from the party by personal contact with the person who made the call)

---

Insinuation will get us nowhere. I'm just going to respond directly to
items that I can shed some light on.

At 5:50 PM  -0600 5/21/96, NOMADS wrote:


>Tuesday we spoke to the owner of the space who said yes lets do the
>party.
>Wednesday, we recieved a call from ethan miller saying it was
>disrespectful to use that space, even though his name is not on the lease
>for that space. He did not even ask why we needed the space. An hour
>later we recieved a call from the owner of the space saying he recieved a
>call from the police telling him "We understand you are having a rave
>party this Saturday. You can't do it and don't let us come down there".
>The owner said that the caller never left his name. The owner told us he
>believed this to be a prank call from the madness people. He said lets
>still go ahead with the party. He did not want these people to bully him.
>

The respect issue isn't about being on the lease for the space. It's about
nurturing a location for longterm use. The owner today told me he barely
scraped by on Saturday and wants to take a long time off before another
event. I find the police call story very odd as the owner has a good
relationship with his local station and knows enough of them to check that
kind of threat out. It should also be obvious that we (madness) are
straight up about our feelings and wouldn't resort to underhanded tactics
to stop a party. The owner has the utmost respect for us and I've had
several discussions with him both before and after your party and he's in
no way led me to believe he has any doubts about us nor did he mention any
phone calls or any police contact until he approached them on Saturday
before the party.

>In the meantime there is a guy named billy who lives at this location
>free of charge. According to the owner billy introduced the madness
>people to him. The next morning, the owner called us and said that he
>recieved three calls from the madness people yelling at him not to do the
>party. He said the callers were alex, jon santos, and a third "person".
>They told him don't do this party, these people are "this" and "that",
>etc, etc. The owner also said that billy told him that the madness people
>had a meeting the night before and decided to cause problems for the
>party. If anyone wants to verify these facts they can ask the owner
>directly.
>

I'm not sure what day your refering to. The only time we had a meeting last
week was on Monday night when we took down lights at the space and did a
post party analysis. We never at any time had any discussions about causing
problems for your party. I did ask the owner to be extra sensitive to sound
levels based on the two complaints we generated, but that's about it.

>At this point the owner became hesitant and nervous about everything. He
>decided to call off the party. He also felt blackmaled by the madness
>people. A few hours later we met with him and he decided to honor his
>word and go through with the party. We addressed all the concerns of the
>owner to include sound levels, capacity issues, and adequate security.

Blackmailed? We have nothing to blackmail him with. I for one only
expressed my concern for the continued usability of his space and the
avoidance of problems with his neighbors. That's what I'm concerned about.
It wouldn't have mattered who did the party.

>
>Two hours after our meeting with the owner, ethan miller posted his
>malicious remarks on the internet.
>
>During the party, around midnight, noise complaints started pouring in
>from far away locations. HOW STRANGE!!!
>

If you're insinuating we were calling trying to get your party busted I
find that completely disgusting. We had two complaints from neighbors at
our party, I don't find it  unreasonable at all to think that the same
people complained again. You may not have been aware that there's a
convalescent home right on the other side of 280.

>The sound levels were maintained so the party went on.
>
>Overall, people were happy to have us in the neighborhood because we
>respected everything around us and that comes from doing events in that
>area for a while now and for keeping good relationships with the people
>we have worked with.

So you spoke to neighbors before and after the party?

Look, I don't want to slander you, and as I've said on SFR I don't have
anything against you personally and I don't care about the rumors floating
around. Unless someone does something to me personally I'm not going judge
them. I feel you had little respect for the work we'd done getting that
space and made a selfish snap decision because your "virgin" space didn't
work out. And hearing you refer to the location on your voicemail as virgin
merely added insult to injury. I don't think you have as much respect for
the location as we do. Life goes on.

Joe

My friend also had his rental car broken into and all his traveling stuff 
(as well as my friends' jacket and sweater) stolen during Gaia.  When we 
drove to the party we had no idea that the neighborhood was as bad.

In the morning there were other people who had their cars broken into 
waiting for the cop to finish talking to us :(.  

Maybe one way to try to prevent it (or cut down on it) is to have 
promoters say something about the area on VM.  If there has been a 
history of car break-ins to let people know that the area is not the best 
and maybe offer other alternatives (BART, safe near by area + cab....).
Also to send the cops who come to visit the party to drive around and 
check the cars every once in a while.

Sometimes cops are nice enough to do it - I live in OK part of SF (border-line
of Pacific heights and Western Addition) and whenever I have 
problem with the bums (when they get agressive and try to follow us to 
the house or threaten to beat us up for some money - happened to me once 
during the party we had and I was brave/stupid/drunk enough to talk back 
to this lady who was twice my size) police comes and scares them away.  
Or just checks the neighborhood is safe.

Just a thought...

Hugz,
Branka

P.S.  Funky Tekno Tribe - I will be there - look for me - glow sticks, 
gray/purple back-pack, glow in the dark koosh balls etc.

>From the HP Starlink Messaging Pager:

=======================================================
--TOP STORY --
Comgress announced this morning that it will be taking up
legislation to try to stop firms from marketing herbal drugs as
legal alternatives to illegal street drugs such as "ecstacy"
and "speed."  Sen. Alfonse D'Amato (R-NY) was joined by Sens.
Christopher Dodd (D-CT) and Bill Frist (R-TN) in New York City
today to unviel the bill. At least 15 people have died in the
US from use of the herb-based drugs.
=======================================================

First off, I am sorry to learn of your loss.  My 'cherry' 1984 Toyota SR5 
was stolen last July 28, two weeks before a one week off road vision 
quest, and of course I had to take a piece of shit rental car to my 
second Burning Man...  After completely giving my truck away in my heart, 
it came back to me two days after returning from Burning Man...Sept. 5.
it was missing the camper shell, a brand new battery, the power antennae, 
and many valuable belongings (as I was going out that night), etc.

Knowing what I know now, I would have paid $1000 for an alarm!  The theft 
cost me dearly, like yours.  Like you I had thought about getting an 
alarm for years... You would think that the insurance companies would 
tell us which are the hottest vehicles stolen, well my truck and all 
Toyota trucks, 4 runners, etc. are the number one stolen vehicle in 
California, especially in Southern Ca. and yours is very popular...
These are actual statistics...  So my advice is if you get your baby 
back, put an alarm in it and a club (why make it easy for them) even if 
you have to go in debt to do it.  If you have to purchase a new vehicle, 
put an alarm in that as well.... You can also have a mechanic put in an 
additional kill switch...    Good luck...  --Maureen

P.S.  If you had insurance, don't let them screw you by quoting blue 
book...insist on replacement value, do some research in auto trader 
magazines....

>  especially when you're alone, stranded 45 miles from home!

>  couldn't afford to get one at the time.  Argh!  :(

Another thought would be for the promoters to have security folks 
patrolling the area...  The Funky Techno guys have done this when their 
parti4es are at Caesar's ...in the past...  The other thing is to listen 
to you gut feelings...when you park your auto and something doesn't feel 
right, you are probably being watches... listen to your instincts....Your 
instincts are not paranoia....they are ancient and quite real....  your 
inner wolf...  

At this point I simply refuse to party in bad, really bad neighborhoods...
for not only do we risk losing our vehicles or belongings, but the odds 
increase for being personally assaulted...So I either go with friends or 
not at all... and I usually arrive hideously early to insure a close 
space near the door....  --Maureen

I wish promoters would remember that many SOMA areas once considered 
abandoned warehouse areas, now house people in live in artist spaces...not 
all of them are ravers...the base does carry, we know this..  Promoters 
need to check out local buildings thoroughly before renting new spaces...
I have mentioned this before...  It was probably the reason the F8 party 
was made to shut the music off  on New Years..or was it March 
1..anyway...remember..  

And also, the only way this entire matter will be settled is for each 
party to meet mano to mano and have a discussion/healing 
session...I suggest they use a talking stick, and in the tradition I 
learned, you can only speak from the heart while holding this stick and 
no one can interrupt you...

Way too much human 
information is lost arguing back and forth on the net...   --Maureen

On Wed, 22 May 1996, Jon Zimmerman wrote:

> Before you buy an alarm, try the $35 alternative, "The Club". I've had one
> in every car I've ever owned, and use it often particularly in bad
> neighborhoods.
> 
> Jon
> 
All these suggestions are great if the theives are amateurs. If they are 
pro's the Club is a minor inconvience. However, it does do one important 
thing, slow them down. You are not going to stop a determined theif, but 
you can slow them down to the point that your vehicle becomes 
unattractive. Alarms also help in this, especially if you have a 
secondary battery located somewhere besides the engine compartment.

                                     Black Adder

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed May 22 14:44:49 1996

Cc: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Car Break-ins & Theft (mostly NRR)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.960522134343.18603B-100000@value.net>
Message-Id: <Pine.SUN.3.91.960522142432.25977C-100000@crl.crl.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


 Like any other device, The Club can be defeated, but for $39 you really 
can't do better. Most theives will put their feet on the steering wheel, 
while pulling on the club in an effort to 'flex' the wheel enough to get 
it off. It helps to attach the Club's 'hooks' near the spokes on your 
steering wheel where it is a bit more rigid.
 Also, you can add an ignition kill switch for the price of a simple SPST 
toggle switch from Radio Shack (~$1.50), and some wire. Just intercept 
the hot wire, and mount the switch somewhere that isn't obvious.

peace,
Dan

On May 20, 10:57am, Eric P. Peterson wrote:
> Subject: Car break-ins
> Hey, y'all!  RLunatic's story got me to thinkin': car vandals may be hip to
> some of the events at which we gather, finding ripe fields of cars waiting
> for them to reap a bountiful harvest.  There may be no way to prevent this
> from happening, but we may be able to decrease the chances of a car being
> broken into.  I suggest driving a vehicle that doesn't look to spiffy,
> sporty, shiny, or otherwise suggests the owner's affluence; if you have a
> "nice" car, get a ride with someone whose wheels don't look as nice.  Also,
> when you park, HIDE Y'ALL'S GOODIES!  If someone can't see anything
> attractive inside da ride, he/she may be less likely to have in.  Any other
> ideas?  We need to help each other, if we care about each other :)
>
> Peace,
>
> - E
>
>-- End of excerpt from Eric P. Peterson

On May 21,  4:50pm, NOMADS wrote:
> Subject: Nomad Interactive response to ethan!!!!!!-long
> First and foremost, we do not believe that the SFR list belongs to ethan
> miller, it belongs to a group of different people from different
> backgrounds who share a sense of community which we feel part of.
>
> Secondly, we do expect a public apology from ethan miller for the
> profanity and personal slander he administered against us!
>
> The following is a summary of the events which took place last week
> before the ORIGIN party. We initially planned our event around another
> space but several factors, namely the fact that construction of a
> partition was not completed in the space, did not allow us to use that
> space. Consequently, we were left without a space and many commitments.
>
> We were introduced to the owner of the space that madness used by a
> friend who told the owner that we also put together these types of
> events. The owner was very interested but also indicated that he had six
> other promoters approach him for the space. He said he was being
> selective and felt very excited about working with us. We do have
> excellent references from other people we have worked with.
>
> After the owner gave the commitment to us, we recieved a call from ethan
> miller telling us it was disrespectful to use that space. He never
> bothered to ask why we needed that space. We know he cares alot about
> what he is doing and we respect that. Yet, several months back when F&F
> needed a space, we took ethan and several members of the planning
> comittee to see a beautiful space with three musical areas that was well
> within F&F's budget. He loved the space and yet when it came down to it,
> he refused the space and even scared the manager into thinking that this
> was going to be some out of control party. We even asked ethan if we
> could donate one musical area to include sound, dj's, decorations, but he
> refused the space from the start and did not want anything to do with us.
>
> We feel that we should all help each other if we can and we have never
> kept a space for ourselves. We found three new spaces in the last four
> months and they have been shared by many people. You cannot control a
> space unless you own it or lease it long term. Regarding the use of the
> map point that joe rice says we stole from madness: the people at that
> location are good people. The city has not allowed them to hold any
> events there for the past year and a half. They welcome the use of their
> location as a map point and would like others to use it as well.
> The place has become a financial burden to them and if we and others can
> help them supplement their financial obligations by using their location
> as a map point so be it. We have not stepped on anybody's toes or tried
> to take anything away from the madness people. as a matter of fact, we've
> made several map points available for people when we were asked for help.
>
> Here are the facts regarding what happened last week:
>
> Tuesday we spoke to the owner of the space who said yes lets do the
> party.
> Wednesday, we recieved a call from ethan miller saying it was
> disrespectful to use that space, even though his name is not on the lease
> for that space. He did not even ask why we needed the space. An hour
> later we recieved a call from the owner of the space saying he recieved a
> call from the police telling him "We understand you are having a rave
> party this Saturday. You can't do it and don't let us come down there".
> The owner said that the caller never left his name. The owner told us he
> believed this to be a prank call from the madness people. He said lets
> still go ahead with the party. He did not want these people to bully him.
>
> In the meantime there is a guy named billy who lives at this location
> free of charge. According to the owner billy introduced the madness
> people to him. The next morning, the owner called us and said that he
> recieved three calls from the madness people yelling at him not to do the
> party. He said the callers were alex, jon santos, and a third "person".
> They told him don't do this party, these people are "this" and "that",
> etc, etc. The owner also said that billy told him that the madness people
> had a meeting the night before and decided to cause problems for the
> party. If anyone wants to verify these facts they can ask the owner
> directly.
>
> At this point the owner became hesitant and nervous about everything. He
> decided to call off the party. He also felt blackmaled by the madness
> people. A few hours later we met with him and he decided to honor his
> word and go through with the party. We addressed all the concerns of the
> owner to include sound levels, capacity issues, and adequate security.
>
> Two hours after our meeting with the owner, ethan miller posted his
> malicious remarks on the internet.
>
> During the party, around midnight, noise complaints started pouring in
> from far away locations. HOW STRANGE!!!
>
> The sound levels were maintained so the party went on.
>
> Overall, people were happy to have us in the neighborhood because we
> respected everything around us and that comes from doing events in that
> area for a while now and for keeping good relationships with the people
> we have worked with.
>
> On a final note, we do not feel that the SFR mailing list should be a
> forum to slander people. We have been victims of some very malicious
> rumors and we would not post these facts unless we know them to be
> correct. We have been very nice so far. We are good people. We have not
> caused harm to anyone and have nothing to hide. But we will never allow
> anyone again to use us as escapegoats. So please be warned and be
> careful about what you say. The power of the pen can destroy people.
>
> The reason you do not see us posting alot is because there is so much
> negativity, slander, and critisism that frankly it does not make it fun
> to participate. We are very open minded about alot of the different
> events that take place in this community and we respect each of them for
> what they are. It is a shame that some people do not share the same view
> point!
>
> Tom & Stacey
>
>-- End of excerpt from NOMADS

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: SFaRt & Design "Contest"?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

If I understand correctly the design "contest" is off?  This is kind of a
bummer.  It's not so much the competition I would enjoy as it would be the
chance to see the variety of input, and seeing the best, no matter whose it
is.  I can't say that I would agree with an art contest, but this is where
design differs.  Design in the sense we're using it has a specific purpose, a
mission, before it is even created.  Art is free to be whatever it wants to
whoever wants it.  (<This was top of the head rhetoric and if it goes up for
debate, I reserve the right to contradict myself)
  Besides, I believe that the best design for either T-Shirts or Laminates,
is going to be several designs, all with some unifying theme.  Kinda like us!
: )  
Love, Art & Design,
Steveo

If I spent half the time designing as I did emailing, I'd probably be famous.

Precedence: bulk

About the car thefts:

In college I was a security guard at a large apartment complex in San Jose.  
13 buildings, 250 units, something like that.  Lot's of good stories came 
out of that job, but the pertinent one was the time I almost caught some 
guys trying to steal a truck.  He ran just a tad quicker than I did, and his 
buddy had their getaway vehicle already rolling with the door open.

Anyway, the way they got in was to pop the back on the camper and bust the 
latch on the window between the bed and the cab.  A tire iron will get them 
in with little or no noise and no obvious sign of entry once they're in.  
With that kind of entry, they have more time to work on getting the car 
started with little damage.  Once in the cab, the guy was busy popping the 
case on the steering column to get to the ignition wires.  Another couple of 
minutes and he'd have been long gone.

Point is, an alarm would have had me over there in a heartbeat and they 
probably never would have even gotten in the cab, or better for the owner, 
they would have picked a different vehicle.

S

I am tired of people telling others (or the whole) list what can and 
can't be posted.  I understand what it's like to have 100's of messages, 
but there is this magic little delete key which can alleviate your 
problems.  I know there is much difference of opinion about rave 
relevance on this list, but there is also the fact that we are a 
community, and sometimes off-topic posts help with a little bit of 
community bonding.  If you don't like something, don't read it.  I do 
that all of the time.  I just don't feel it is right that everyone seems 
to think they can tell everyone else what is right and wrong.

I apologize for adding any negativity to a list that is having enough 
intense things going on, but I just couldn't sit idly by anymore.  I am 
perfectly ready to be flamed, if that's what is going to happen.  I just 
got tired of everyone telling everyone else what to do.  Diversity comes in 
many forms, and part of diversity is a diversity of opinions.  

Dismounting,
--kaySEE

KaySEE,

KaySEE wrote:
> Where can you receive it?  What is the channel?

> On Tue, 21 May 1996, wilton paul risenhoover wrote:
> 
> > Greetings,
> >
> > For those of you who are interested, x-radio is back online after a long
> > series of troubles.  We hope to keep it up.  Thanks to those of you who
> > sent letters of encouragement.

It's a RealAudio web site.  Go to http://www.realaudio.com and download the 
RealAudio player (version 2), then go to http://www.x-radio.com/x-radio/.  
There are about a disks online that you can listen to across the 'net.  The 
catch: you need a 28.8 modem.

Meaning: you can receive it ANYWHERE!

Enjoy,
pauly

Well, since enough people seem to be interested in the order form, just
print this puppy up!

Love,
Shawna


>Ok, for those of you who wish to register and don't have the form, just 
>print this out (or write it the part that follows the:


>*************************************************
>
>BURNING MAN 1996 ADVANCE REGISTRATION/ORDER FORM
><Copy and distribute freely>
>
>on a piece of paper and send it to the address specified...  so here it is:
>
>Whats follows is another advance release from the Spring 96 "Building Burning
>Man" newsletter. '96 Registration form included at end'o'file; get a $10
>discount if you send it in before June 1st!
>
>*************************************************
>
>SURVIVAL
>
>Visitors to the playa should not come as spectators to a show. Instead, they
>will encounter an interactive experience; a spontaneous outpouring of energy
>that is created by our community itself. Burning Man is a phenomenon which
>springs from your immediate involvement. We are not funded by grants or
>product endorsements. We depend upon direct contributions. Hundreds of people
>are now engaged in creating this year's event. Here is how you can help:
>
>CONTRIBUTE
>Send in your registration fee today!  By purchasing your ticket now for $25
>you can save $10. Beginning in June tickets to the event will cost $35. 
>Buy a
>t-shirt or a video. If you can, make an extra contribution (see the check box
>on order form). Many new projects- Mudhenge, the Inferno, a new public
>transit project, and an elaborated Man-are being readied for 1996. None of
>this will happen without your early support. If you are among those people
>who already know they are coming to Burning Man, help us now. 
>
>VOLUNTEER
>There is only one way to become a member of the Project.  You must do
>something. Burning Man is a society of activists. Later this year we will
>solicit volunteers to help us run the infrastructure of our camp. We are now
>recruiting experienced builders, people to do data entry and distribute
>flyers, help with clerical tasks, and individuals who can assist with
>transport of materials to Nevada throughout the year. If you have any skill
>or resource which you think might help us in our preparations, please call
>our Hotline.        
>
>ARTISTS
>In addition to the "Inferno," Burning Man is planning many new art
>initiatives in 1996.  Our burning pageant in the desert on Sunday, September
>1, will feature large-scale portable effigies that can be raised overhead.
> Puppeteers, model makers, stilt walkers, fire performers, etc.-please
>contact us.  We also need folks to assist us in casting a large number of
>plaster brains (yes, brains ) that will be featured at our premier show on
>March 23 at the Minna Street Gallery in San Francisco.      
>
>MUDHENGE
>In 1995 our camp was inundated by a rainstorm and mudpeople sprang from the
>playa (you know who you are). In 1996 we will construct a temple and public
>shower in which to house these rites. We invite all persons of mud to
>worship, wallow, and bathe between the legs of "Water Woman" (Showers are
>restricted to initiates. You must first get down in the mud). If you would
>like to help construct and tend the temple, or wish to organize and schedule
>an event here (i.e. mud wrestling, a mud procession, etc.) please contact our
>Hotline.
>
>PUBLIC TRANSIT
>The playa of the Black Rock Desert is a fundamentally safe environment.
> Apart from the very real, dire, and life-threatening hazard of becoming lost
>[please read the Survival Guide that is mailed to all registered
>participants] the playa is as flat and as forgiving as the mattress of a
>playpen. The greatest hazard that we face is self-created. Nearly every one
>of the few serious accidents and injuries that we have witnessed during
>Burning Man has involved automobiles. This year we encourage everyone to
>bring bicycles. They are perfectly adapted to the hard-packed surface of the
>playa.  We plan also to organize a pool of specially marked bicycles for
>public use. If you can help us with this effort please call our Hotline.
>
>FILM FEST
>We are now accepting entries for the 2nd Annual Burning Man Film and Video
>Festival. The deadline for submissions is July 4th. Please contact Coffee
>Achievers at 415.826-3277. Ask for Hernan. 
>
>SETTLEMENT
>This year, the city of Black Rock will sport a newly renovated downtown area
>and a number of exurban hubs, or "meta-theme camps." If you want to create
>your own city within a city, call the Hotline. 
> 
>*************************************************
>
>1996 REGISTRATION/ORDER FORM
>
>Burning Man Festival
>Wednesday, August 28 through Monday, September 2, 1996
>
>The annual celebration of BURNING MAN will take place over Labor Day weekend
>in the Black Rock Desert of Northern Nevada. All attendees need to register
>for the event, and must bring their own shelter, food and water. 
>
>This form can be used to register and/or order Burning Man merchandise. Feel
>free to make copies. If you are purchasing tickets you will receive your
>registration packet (including 1996 map, survival guide, and schedule of
>events) approximately one month before the festival.
>
>Tickets: Purchase advance tickets now for Burning Man, August 28 - September
>2, 1996.  We will mail you a ticket, your survival guide, map, and a detailed
>schedule of events approximately one month before the event. Order now and
>save! After June 1st, the price goes up to $35 per person.
>
>Burning Man Video: Only the finest photons, hand-selected and lovingly

For those of us coming into the City from the south,  Caltrain can be an option
The terminal is at 4th & Townsend, right in the middle of SOMA.
the last 2 trains arrive at about 9:30 and 11:30,
and the first train out in the morning is at 5 on weekdays, 7 Satuday, and 8
Sunday.
Not so good for clubs that close at 2, but if you're really sure it will go
all night...

meeting at one of the grill pits at a park were an upcoming Sunset is
going to be? Music for those who want it , or just chilling , or tastes
of both as the whim moves ya ... We could even show up early to get our
little SFR thingy going and some pre-music chatting & grilling.

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

Dear Friends & Family,

My computer tells me that on Mon, 20 May 1996, Eric shared:

> Hey, y'all!  RLunatic's story got me to thinkin': car vandals may be hip to
> some of the events at which we gather, finding ripe fields of cars waiting
> for them to reap a bountiful harvest.  There may be no way to prevent this
> from happening, but we may be able to decrease the chances of a car being
> broken into.  I suggest driving a vehicle that doesn't look to spiffy,
> sporty, shiny, or otherwise suggests the owner's affluence; if you have a
> "nice" car, get a ride with someone whose wheels don't look as nice.  Also,
> when you park, HIDE Y'ALL'S GOODIES!  If someone can't see anything
> attractive inside da ride, he/she may be less likely to have in.  Any other
> ideas?  We need to help each other, if we care about each other :)

	This may not be practical at every parking site, and it might 
damage some cars, but with a little work and a good heavy crane, we 
could do something that would probably astound these pesky thieves so 
much they would kiss our hubcaps in appreciation and awe.
	I'm thinking that what we do is arrange our cars in groups of 
three, specifically two cars stood vertically on end, with one car across 
them on top.  (We would need to have some way of matching up vehicles by 
length to really make this work).
	Then, we make concentric circles of these groups of three, 
radiating outward.  Can you imagine a would-be vandal arriving at a 
quiet, moonlit lot near a party and being confronted with this vision of 
Stonehenge?  I'll bet car stereos would be the last thing on his mind.
	Tell me, do I have great ideas or what?   ;)  Do we have any 
other problems that need solving?

Invoking the vibe,

				<<< Starchild >>>
