From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu May 23 06:34:53 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id GAA05815; Thu, 23 May 1996 06:34:53 -0700
Received: from netcom12.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id GAA05809; Thu, 23 May 1996 06:34:51 -0700
Received: from DialupEudora (jsl@localhost.netcom.com [127.0.0.1]) by netcom12.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id GAA23879; Thu, 23 May 1996 06:34:44 -0700
Date: Thu, 23 May 1996 06:34:44 -0700
X-Sender: jsl@localhost
Message-Id: <v02130500adc9b65fc54f@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: This VS That - VERY LONG!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I really didn't want to say anything about the two promoters going verbal
fisticuffs at each other, but since both seem to have a need to air their
laundry in public, I now feel a need to respond in kind.

This discussion is no longer fun.

Promoter VS Promoter
-----------------------
I really only have one question, what is the VALUE of having this
tit-for-tat on-line?  Ethan had a problem with some promoters.  He then, in
a very public way, called them to task.  What is the point, other than
venting, of doing it?  The way in which Ethan did it, was at best unethical
for one reason;  He said a big FU without ANY explanation.  Sorry, this is
just straight poor judgment.  If you're going call someone out, at least
give the background in it's totality (i.e. the whole story from your point
of view), otherwise it is just venting for the sake of venting, and that
does nobody any good.  Ethan did give background, after several posts from
people asking him why he went off the way he did.  However, the damage had
already been done; the hornets nest had been disturbed.

I understand his beef, but I also understand Tom & Stacy's perspective.
Despite what people want to believe, there ARE two sides to this story, and
depending on YOUR perspective you will find the truth that fits your
reality.  From a non-participatory view, they both have agendas, and both
will be right in their respective views.

What aggravates me is the airing of dirty promoter BS laundry in public.
This stuff is best left behind closed doors where the participants (the
direct participants) can hash it out.  If it doesn't work out, fine, agree
to disagree and move on.  What is the point of all of this "he said, she
said", when in fact it's all a done deal?  Will it change the result or
expected outcome?  I doubt it.  Will it stop whatever from happening again?
I doubt it.  So really what is the point?  To let everyone know what
really happened?  Who cares?  As far as I am concerned, there is an FnF
planners list, THAT is the place this discussion belongs.  There, the party
promoters, planners, whatever, can go round and round with this thing ad
infinitum.  It would have more value to the people DIRECTLY involved with
the throwing of parties, than the general partying public.  But here for
all to see?, what value is any of this.

Not everyone is equal, nor has access to the same information.  My days as
Mr. Party Man started changing, when I was brought in to do parties with
various people.  It changed more when I got to know the lowdown on each and
every party, it changed more when I found out about the personalities
behind the parties, and it changed more as I got to know more and more
about some of the ugly underbelly of parties.  And yes, it does exists.
This discussion, if I may stretch to call the present arguments that, is
just that.  Part of the ugliness that is part of this scene.  Of course
that is my perspective, but what else would you call the present round of,
er discussion?  Constructive dialog?  People working stuff out?  Is that
what is going on?  No, it is two camps at odds, trying to explain how right
each view is.  And to WHOSE benefit?  Does it benefit the list or people
going to parties? , or does it illuminate that which would be better left
unsaid?( i.e. "Is EVERYTHING an issue open for discussion?") Was there a
need for a big loud "fuck you"?  Did this benefit the community?  Was there
a need for a reply?  And what need?  Do you REALLY want to know all the
dirty deeds some people might do to run parties at times?  Do you really
want to know who has been fucked over in this scene, whether justified or
not?  Do you want to know all of the dirt on everyone and everything in our
dance community?  Is this really all THAT?  Or do you want to hear good
music, in a good place, with people you enjoy being with?  Which and what
is more important to you?

I'll always remember Harry Who telling me, during a bad time between me and
another person doing parties: "Hey!, You guys are friends.  Shit happens.
Make-up."  after a blip in the radar.  That's what this is supposed to be
about.  Being friends & catchin' a groove.

Maybe I'm strange, I've always liked the music and the people, not how
something was put together.

When it comes to parties I don't know everything.  But then I've decided I
don't want to know everything.  Ignorance can be a good thing, when
executed properly, it can result in sheer bliss.  The LA scene was so cool
at one time.  Then the promoters started taking themselves very seriously.
The result is evident.  That house is STILL being reconstructed.  The same
thing IS happening here.

All of this talk about his space, my space...c'mon, sounds like some
pre-school argument over whose tree house it is.  The scale has changed,
the conversation is very much the same.

The harsh reality of parties:

-If you find a space, do not become attached to it in the slightest.  The
second you open the doors to said space, there will have already been
several promoters who will have talked to the person in charge of the
space.  You just lucked out, this time.
-You own no space, other than the one you have FOR THAT NIGHT.
-There will ALWAYS be a someone with more money and guile.  You do not
operate in a vacuum.
-The most hardcore care little about what you think.  It's what you do that
counts.
-If another promoter  beats you to the punch, outbids you, steals your
DJ's, remember it's just a party.  Hash it out with all people involved,
take it on the chin, learn from it, and move on.
-You're really hardcore if you let the person who fucked you over, into
your gig for free.
-The ideal is to have no expectations of anyone external to your group.
Expect and plan for the worse, you'll never be disappointed.  Having this
psyche makes even the slightest good thing be a grand bonus point.
-You got a problem with a someone?  Take it to them.  If you must, you
might want to talk to friends.  But be sure, most people could really care
less.  They are looking for the next party, or the next place to spin, or
the next place to be spun.  Your problems are for the moment, and there is
a weekend coming up...
-Got fucked over?, get over.  It's for the moment, you live and learn.  You
build a book of trust and a book of people to watch out for.  You get to
know who'll need a contract, and who's word is as good as gold.

There are more, but I follow these general rules, and have not been
surprised at the results.  I am happier, and have had great interactions
with people in dance culture.

I just think the bulk of this could've been handled off-line between the
respective parties.  Maybe the end result could've been the movement of MAD
or the other party.  Maybe the end result would've been the same minus the
back-and-forth.  I think that any other result, short of breaking out the
guns, is probably more desirable than what we have witnessed here over the
past few days.

Cool off & settle it between yourselves please.  A nice long weekend approaches.

Gang of many
--------------
Then comes the troops.  I have always found mob mentality interesting.
Especially when it develops around , so-called, peaceful movements.  People
create allegiances for all sorts of reasons.  I found it amusing how easy
it was for many to quickly forgive Ethan his minor trespass.  These same
individuals however would've roasted anyone else for doing the same thing.
Maybe it's a matter of familiarity with the person that determines the
level of forgiveness one will receive. I dunno.  I *DO* know that most of
the people, either agreeing or disagreeing with what was going on had
NOTHING TO DO WITH THE INTERACTION BETWEEN ETHAN & TOM&STACY.  With that in
mind, why chime in at all?  There are probably only a few who really know
what's going on depending on who was where when.  I know Ethan knows, Tom &
Stacy, & the club owner.  So, there will be three stories, three views.
Which is right?  Probably all of them.  Which is wrong?  Same answer, all
of them.  We are seeing the collision of expectations.  When they cannot be
reconciled we witness anger, on all sides.

Many of you jumped on Ethan's shit...I can only wonder how many of these
folks ever read the SFRaves archive?  Many of you chimed in agreement...I
can only wonder how many of you were there for the series of events leading
up to Ethan's frustration.  I know Ethan and respect him, I also was not
there for the interaction between he, tom & stacy.  My stance is neutral.
I empathize with Ethan because similar has happened to me and my friends
over the years.  I understand Tom & Stacy's view, sometimes the party MUST
go on.

There are two views.  And that is the only conclusion I can draw from the
information given.

What do *I* have to do with this?  Very, very little.  I am involved
because this has been made public.  Other than that, I am more than happy
to sit on the sidelines and watch these people duke it out, much like I
used to watch kids fight growing up.  Laugh at the loser, cheer the winner.
But the thing I have learned is that there are very few definitive winners
and losers when it comes to this party dance scene.  Either you'll stick it
out, or bow out, or bow out and come back (the choice of champions ;)).
really though, if one party goes away, there will be others to take it's
place.  My allegiance is to the music and my friends, not an entity called
a club or scene or particular party.  Where there is good music to my ears,
I'll be there, period.

Lessons
--------
What is going on now is weak bubble gum compared to what has gone on in
this city in the past IMO.  Feel very fortunate, those of you doing the do,
that there are many less snakes in the grass these days.  What happened to
Ethan & crew, used to happen ALL THE TIME.  What is worse is when you have
reserved a space, printed flyers, then have the space sold from under you.
Yikes!  Even worse is when you get outbid in one way or another....Yikes!
How about having a space, then the person who owns it blows it out before
your party, the venue busted by the cops, then expects you still have your
party there the next night, even though the space is red fucking hot!
YIKES!!!!  These things used to happen ALL THE TIME.  Some have happened to
me, some to others.  I feel fortunate though, because I can still catch a
groove and haven't let any of the bad things outweigh the enormous good
I've enjoyed.  As a matter of fact, I will work with some of the very
people who got on my nerves in the past.  Why?  Why not?  I'd rather
forgive, and try to forge a truce, than to waste energy maintaining
hostilities.  If others can do likewise, then we have a basis to work with
each other.  I'd rather move forward and test the waters with new projects,
using history to guide my present.  Besides, there are other more important
things to worry about...like, where's the next party?

The Power of The Phone
-------------------------
There  was a brief moment in dance culture history when promoters called
each other to determine when they could throw a party and not have it
defeat another person's gig.  It was brief, but it was good.  You actually
talked to the person throwing the gig, and created a cooperative model.
Alas, it was fragile; people became disconnected.

And then there were none
------------------------
"Peace, live in it or rest in it!  Come together!" - DJ Pierre;  This man
is the fucking mac.  I am so saddened at his departure from house music.
There is no other like Pierre, and there is no equal to his magic.  I hope
homey comes back to the fold one day.  My man feels house music hasn't been
as good to him as he's been to it.  No matter what, that man is by far, one
of the greats of our dance culture.  He IS one of the originators.  His
music will be missed.  He's the fucking mind bomb!  Everyone else is just
visiting!

Props to Jeno for working the DJ Pierre "Generate Power" @ Toon Town back
in the day (man, he would have motherfuckers grabbing @ straws - Jeno can
WORK this track!).  Extra special thanks to Wicked posse for bringing DJ
Pierre to SF to rock some fucking heads!!!  Now THAT was wicked!!!  (I am
talking in particular about an event held in the "front" of Townsend.  This
was one for the record books.  If you weren't there, you missed out on what
can truly be called a stellar event.  Even Markie & Jeno got affected!)

I'm done now,
John

Peace.

This started out as a message to Tom & Stacey - but I'm posting it to
everyone who might have an interest in the "T&S affair" and more importantly
an interest in raving... With out getting into the who's and why's of
detailed actions AND I guarentee that  UNFAIR & devious actions HAVE been
taken against Tom & Stacey including BUT not limited to an unfair narc
rumor... but then T&S have either knowingly or PERHAPS unknowingly done
things to upset certain people in the underground (UG) Particularly the
low cost UG... so actions have been taken by BOTH sides ... so perhaps
thinking about what is going on is in order... I know my mind has been 
buzzing the past week...  As a suggestion: The next time you deal with a
commercial or $20 party whether as a promoter charging it OR as a "guest"
or consumer ask yourself WHY?  If you don't think about it you might not
even care as long as the music and dancing is good.... if you think about
what is going on more deeply you might find as I have that you do care
after all......

Tom & Stacey,

  Basically good response - but after really thinking about it which I admit
I had NOT really done before this I don't think this addresses the root
cause of the problem......

  The real problem after some thought seems to be your desire to be 
COMMERCIAL more than a part of the UG.... to as one person said " tap the
house MARKET " - you know: make money at it and market the music & vibe...
While it's fine to be commercial - it does NOT mix well with the low cost
UG as we have just found out....


At one point, I thought jee if I sell my visuals for say $500-600 per show
and do 2 shows per month I can pull in $15-20K per year ( tax free if cash 
only ) Wow that would push my income up into 6 figures of tax equivalent
income and for about 2 hours that was attractive.... then I thought about
the alternative of working with the low cost high vibe UG and making $500
every 6 months and I chose that route.... I'll get to that later...
 
 By my figuring if you had a good turn out last weekend you guys pulled in
$4000 for yourselves.... but how many friends ( that you didn't already know)
did you meet at your party ? Are the people who come to your $20 house music
party people you really want to hang out with ?  At the end of the day when
all is said and done are you counting new friends made or money ? Which is
more important in your life ?  These I think are the fundemental questions
you have to answer for yourself.... about what you are doing.... but what
are you doing and what makes it different ?

  At first I thought like you do : Why can't we all SHARE spaces? I wouldn't
have introduced you to Dru if I hadn't thought this way.... I'm so used to
being open and sharing everything I have in the UG that I just naively wanted
to share the space with you and everyone else... so what's wrong with that ?
The way you use a space DOES ruin it for the UG and here's why :

  1) You hire thugs to be your guards ( actually off duty police but BIG 
     ones - sorry Pat ) to buy off
     busts.... At Jerrald I "bought" your explaination that the OWNER made
     you do it - but he's a $$$$ grubbing BASTARD.... so it made sense to 
     me.. then I hear at Dru's space you did the same and the guards removed
     water bottles during their searches.... SEARCHES WHAT SEARCHES ? Did
     you notice at MADDNESS NOBODY was searched at all ! NOBODY !  Try that
     at one of your parties - with the crowd you invite is it safe ? OK so
     now there's another space that when the police come by they EXPECT to
     see other police working the security - if not likely bust... Can you
     understand that creating the policy of "greasing the police" this way
     is something the UG does NOT want to do....

  2) The people you invite will ruin the space. If the people you invite or
     attract NEED to be searched then are they the type of crowd you really
     want to hang with or do you just want their $20?  I noticed at the
     Jerrald deli Tom spent most of his time hanging with the employees
     behind the counter or at the door... this is what I'm talking about
     when I talk about VIBE... Anyone can fill a room full of drug taking
     dancing, even shouting people but what is this thing called "vibe". To
     me it's NOT about how many people are shouting on the floor - hell it's
     easy to make people shout - just let them have their drugs and a good
     DJ... But when I go to a F&F I meet ( in a way that is significant )
     20-30 new people EVERY time in addition to 50-150 people I already
     know.... Talking with people is difficult because there are so many
     people to meet and talk with... at your parties I meet 3-5 MAX... How
     many new people do you meet each time ? And when I say meet I mean
     people that you would "hang with" at other times & places... Are these
     the people you search at the door ?  If so why ?

       So the VIBE I talk about is one of COMMUNITY... that is a dynamic
     community of friends... that TALK to each other... That share with each
     other... that do NOT need to be searched... that are all worthy of being
     friends - that are NOT charged top dollar for the party . Parties like 
     that are AMAZING... NO amount of $$$ could make
     me want to give that up... that's what I'm in the scene to nurture.
     AND btw I seldom go to Martin's commercial parties or wicked because
     from my definition they are vibeless... little groups of people who
     know their small group of friends and it STAYS that way.... the only
     community that is built is one of small but independent groups of
     friends taking drugs and dancing together... BUT there is NOT really
     an overall merging of the group... The outcome when I go to a wicked
     I meet 3-5 people just like at your parties.... community - WHAT
     COMMUNITY ?  Just a bunce of people paying top dollar to dance together.


  3) The 3rd reason you ruin a space is you pay top dollar for it... Instead
     of nurturing low cost spaces and passing the savings on - you pay $4000
     and pass that on in the form of $20 entry... anyone can do that but the
     UG chooses NOT to because these are our FRIENDS or people who will be...
     If we filled a space full of people we didn't care about and weren't
     meeting as friends then we could say :  $20 bucks is cheap for a whole
     night  BUT is $20 cheap for your FRIENDS ?.... See Stacey there's the
     difference... FRIENDS  vs CUSTOMERS and don't minimize that difference
     it's a BIG one...

      When I met you and Tom and you told me about being from Cypress I 
     thought - How nice! I bet you know about freinds and family drinking
     and dancing together in Greek bars and resturants... late into the
     night... now there's a culture that knows how to party AND more 
     importantly celebrate with friends... I really thought THAT was the
     experience you wanted to nuture here.... but that means taking another
     route than making money on the scene.... this can be a business or it
     can be about bring friends together.... you have to decide which you
     really want MOST... 

     Paying more and more for spaces and then passing the high cost on goes
     against the UG movement of giving more for less to the community... 
     helping to build a community... as you pay more for spaces you make it
     impossible for the LOW cost UG to use them... Will Dru after getting
     $4000 for his space go back to letting people rent it for $800-$1000 ?

 
  4) UNEQUAL treatment of the people who work for you... another problem
     with commercial intent - everyone has a price and gets it... but there
     is an UNEQUAL distribution of funds... the more I think about it the
     more it troubles me... When I got into doing visuals I bought a $1000
     mixer and a second $3K projector as a donation to the scene... I go
     out with about $12K- $15K of equipment... and all I ask is a donation
     if possible so I'm definitely NOT going to get my money back much less
     make money at it... ( As I admitted before one day I daydreamed about
     making $20K per year doing it but immediately gave it up ) I do free
     parties like Wayne's house party or when you didn't make budget I didn't
     get paid by you... and that's ok by me... I NEVER turn down any party
     because of money or lack thereof... it's about time and my friends!
     So where does the UNEQUAL treatment come in ?  When I did your NYE show
     and I got paid $100 + another $60 later I felt good about it UNTIL I
     found out all the DJ's were getting $1000... Another show I did not many
     people showed... everyone else made money and I took nothing... I felt
     ok with that because this is NOT about money for me... BUT then I 
     thought about it... ok if this is about FRIENDSHIP and you guys are my
     friends: How come you guys feel comfortable about paying everyone but
     me $1000 ? Is this the way you treat a good friend ?  What I do is 
     special I think - I work ALL NIGHT long and I put loving energy into 
     it.. Admittedly I didn't ASK for higher pay so I didn't get it ... 
     but I naively thought everyone was sharing equally... That happens in
     F&F and because of DONATIONS the "guests" pay $5 or less... but when
     things get commercial things change... everyone gets what they charge..
     If I naively say I work for a donation then that's what I get - EXACTLY
     a small donation and nothing more... but if a DJ who works 1/5 the time
     I do asks for $500 that's what they get... and it's passed on to the
     CONSUMER at the door - NOT the friends coming ... If you take in $20K
     at the door it's NOT divided with any equity among friends... everyone
     gets what the "market will bear".... and anyone like myself who assumes
     if profits are made they will be gladly "profit shared EQUALLY" among
     those who contributed is NOT facing the fact of what profit motivated
     party throwing is all about.... prices will be bargined out and talent
     and work will be "bought and sold"....

     As a final comment, I'm not saying this is totally wrong... Hey it's 
     the American way... NO as I write this I AM SAYING that buying and
     selling at a negotiated price leads to a fucked up system EXACTLY like
     the US... where some people play the system and get rich while others
     who don't play (drop outs) , can't play ( mentally ill ), or are
     forbidden to play ( minorities )  - are left out in the cold with very
     little of the wealth expressly because wealth is NOT distributed equally
     for equal contributions.... 


 So these are the problems I have with trying to mix commercial raving with
the UG rave scene... The more I think about it the more I want to stay in
the LOW cost UG - where things are about community and sharing... I see
nothing totally wrong about being commercial ( although I have some problems
with it see above ) BUT NOT mixing commercial with UG... I've noticed that
Martin & wicked do NOT mix with the UG... They seldom sho up at UG parties
and they don't use the same spaces....

  So my suggestion to anyone such as yourself who wants to commercialize the
scene is to stay clear of low cost UG spaces and do like wicked and go into
clubs... Of course, you don't HAVE to but it would keep things MUCH 
friendlier....  Especially since you have said to me numerous times that you
want to support the UG and you like the UG... Then why would you be willing
to do the things outlined above ?  Why are you willing to search your 
friends ?  Why are you willing to charge them $20 ?  Why are you willing to
pay friends who work with you UNEQUALLY ?  Could it be that this isn't about
friends ? It's about making $$$, perhaps ? THAT difference IMHO is the
REAL reason we have just had the problems that have come up... 

  I hadn't REALLY thought this all out before - so I want to thank you and
Tom for being the catalyst that brought this all into focus for me... you
have been my teachers... You have once again reminded me - why I rave -
why I donate my visuals to the scene... You've shown me that years from
now long after any $$$ made from the scene is spent and forgotten, What I
will have is the memories of Milton and the E-bee, Ethan running around
in boxer shorts, Gateway zooming the crowd with lasers, Claire and New
Moon putting up loving alters, DJ's from all over NOT getting paid and
still loving it, dancing on Fort ORd with the Cloud Factory,people 
passing my table and telling me "great visuals"... and so many other people
all sharing a wealth of experiences with me... commercialize this?  my
answer is NO WAY !!!!! I might suggest that you and Tom really think about
what you want from the scene... Do you want to SELL music events to the
house "market" ?  OR  Do you want to create community and events that will
form friendships that you will remember for the rest of your life? .....


  Once you've decided that answer.... your actions will become clear....
I know mine have been....

Saying all of this as someone who wants to befriend all fairminded people,

Mike


 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & ecstatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

 What makes all the difference in the effectiveness of The Club is the 
constructions of the car's steering wheel. A lot of newer cars have 
wheels made mostly of hard rubber, to protect the driver in a crash, and 
these are the ones that flex enough to get The Club off. If you have a 
sturdy, rigid wheel, it can work quite well.

Dan

<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< THE DETAILS >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

FEATURES:
* FOUR sound systems surrounded by beautiful trees
   and rock formations.
* 360o of the event surrounded by Hi-Tech effects: 
   lasers, intelligent lighting, computer projections,
   and beyond...
* Wide variety of food, beverage, and merchandise vendors
* Orbotrons, Spaceballs, and other cool rides
* Multiple Beer+Wine stands available for
   those over 21 with I.D.
* Friendly and Helpful Security Staff
* First Aid Stations
* Daytime (pre-event, 8am-4pm) Activities: Horseback
   riding and mountain biking around the mountain and event
   site.  You must call 1 week in advance to make a reservation
   because space is limited.  Please call 800-680-SNOW.
* Secured parking
* Information about accomodations will be given at time of
   ticket purchase or on voice mail.
* Maps and information guidelines will be provided at
   ticketmaster at time of purchase.

LOCATED at Snow Valley Resort in *YOUR* San Bernardino
  National Forest.  (This is your forest, come check it out,
  utilize it, have fun in it and respect it.)
  In the town of Running Springs, CA (twenty-five minutes
  before Big Bear).

*** Highly Recommended things to do: ***
* Bring layers of warm clothing, blankets(if desired),
   durable shoes, and smiles.
* Please CARPOOL--save gas, have a designated drive
   and help cleaner air.
* Please drive safe--be aware of mountain roads.  Roads
   are curvy and dark.
* Please travel during Daylight hours--Come early, and
   Stay late!
*** Cautions: ***
* Please No cans, bottles, liquids, food, weapons, etc.
* Please No Fires anywhere
* Please No roadside parking or camping
* Please No on-site camping
* Please Be aware of fire hazards--this event is in the
   forest on dry clearings--be   cautious.
* No Ins and Outs--please be sure you have everything
   you need before entering.
* No tailgating or loitering in the parking areas.

*** Hours: ***
Saturday, June 22, 1996
Show/Bands from 7pm till 6am.
Site open from 4pm till 8am. 
First band on stage at 7pm sharp.  Again Come Early.

Tickets on sale June 1 at 10am at all aTicketmaster locations.
To charge by phone call
213.480.3232.   714.740.2000    805.583.8700.   619.220.TIXS. 
For Tickets with NO SERVICE CHARGE go to
the Ticketmaster outlets at 6243 Hollywood Blvd.
Mon-Sat 10am-5pm.

>...>_>_..._..._..._...>>>  ORGANIC '96  <<<._..._..._..._<_<...<
        Confirmation is complete (and a reality)
     A musical voyage that you will never forget.
           Come in peace or do not come at all.
                          Seeeeee ya there!

From: epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson)
Subject: Promoters: cooperation/competition
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

(Chiming in like it's my business)  This may have been mentioned before,
but my unqualified opinion is that it is in promoters' best interest to
cooperate in securing and nurturing business relationships with those from
whom spaces are rented/leased for parties, since a good relationship will
encourage not only repeat business for one promotion crew, but also
business from other crews.  We share the SF Bay Area, we share the City and
the East Bay, etc., so why not work in the spirit of sharing locations?
Owners/lessors of the locations might even put in a good word on behalf of
promoters with other owners/lessors who are considering letting their space
be used for parties.  Does this make any sense at all?  What would be the
point of childish, undermining stunts against any one promotion crew, other
than to discredit them and cause them problems.  I hope all promoters will
strive to keep the business end of the scene from turning into a model of
corporate America, where cut-throat tactics are sometimes employed to help
one company get ahead at the expense of others.  It ain't healthy, it ain't
appreciated, and it ain't respectful.

OK, enough change from me.  Peace out,

- E

  How to learn to give a "sucker" an even break - be a prof ;-)

  Just finsihed my first spreadsheet - Intro to Comp Sci class....

  Let's see class avarage 77 %
  Let's look for curve breakpoints or seperation between adjacent students


  break between 89% - 87% of 17pts A cutoff goes there.....
  break between 81% - 77% of 30pts B cutoff goes there....
  break between 72% - 66% of 48pts C ..... maybe not

  here comes the even break.....

  IF I go down to 61% with the C's there's another separation point
  of 50 pts between the 61% student and a 55%....

  OK now which one to use ?  I'm feeling generous... so I'm going with
the lower one..... C's down to 61%...

  And who says teacher's aren't inflating grades ;-)

  Mike OUT

OB RAVE :  Next time you're judging someone in the rave scene - lower your
           cutoff point....

Regarding what people think does and does not belong on this list...

Sharif Torpis said...  

...here's another thought: if u have sense enough to mark your message w/
"non-rave" in the subject line then perhaps it doesn't belong in a rave
mailing list?...maybe, just maybe?

--------------------------
(Sorry, Sharif, I don't know how long you've been on SFR, so this may be
redundant to you, but ...)

This group has had many conversations about this, and one of them is that we'd
try to put some clue in the header so people could skip a message they didn't
want to read ... and NRR is your clue -- feel free to skip it ... or to skip
followup messages on topics that don't interest you....  We do pretty well on
this, I think...

but this is one big ongoing conversation with a group of people that has a
common connection, and it's an open forum... 

I personally (as many people know) think the main things that don't belong on
here are out-of-control personal attacks on other people ... intelligent
articulate disagreements are fine, it's personal nastiness that pushes my
buttons... pretty much anything else I can deal with (especially short messages
telling funny stories, jokes, etc., I love that stuff! It usually arrives when I
most need it!)

and frankly, earthquakes are WAY BIGGER than this little newsgroup, and are
pretty worth talkin' about no matter what ...

I mean, if the *mother ship* was hovering over San Francisco, would you think we
shouldn't talk about it here because it was NRR??  Please.

(actually, next time people see me, ask me about my theory about aliens
influencing our rave culture genetically) 

To me, diversity comes in the form of the many different people on SFR, and I
don't want to subscribe to "many different mailing lists" to talk about the
important things that affect our lives. We on SFR are a community, and we don't
have a review panel censoring people's posts ... "oh, I'm sorry, that's only 72%
rave-related, doesn't meet the standards, try again!"

When I subscribed to SFRaves, I expected to get messages, thoughts, ideas and
interchanges from the lives and perspectives of ravers, both about raving and
the more important bigger picture, and that's just what I got.  Except now, it's
not just from other ravers, it's from friends.  Thanks everyone!  

Leslie  : )

>Can't say i agree with all of your perspective (you'd have to throw me in
>with the 'Ethan troops'), but this is _far and away_ the most constructive
>thing posted on this subject thus far.

one of the things that i read out of john's post was a reminder to all that
no matter who's camp you are in, you are basing your alligence/views on
subjective truths. remember that the 'other side' believes in their truths
as well. try and persuade them of your POV if neccessary, but more important
is to respect their views and find a workaround that fits into both your
agendas.
PLUR


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu May 23 12:16:33 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA08047; Thu, 23 May 1996 12:16:33 -0700
Received: from hornet.ns.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA08041; Thu, 23 May 1996 12:16:30 -0700
Received: (from dwarzau@localhost) by hornet.ns.net (8.6.10/8.6.10) id MAA25514; Thu, 23 May 1996 12:16:23 -0700
Date: Thu, 23 May 1996 12:16:22 -0700 (PDT)
From: John Deatherage <dwarzau@ns.net>
To: "John S. Lee" <jsl@netcom.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: This VS That - VERY LONG!
In-Reply-To: <v02130500adc9b65fc54f@DialupEudora>
Message-ID: <Pine.HPP.3.91.960523120736.24510H-100000@hornet.ns.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Really all I can say is that Ethan was just REALLY PISSED, and I think 
any one in his situation would have done the same thing.  There have been 
a ton of times where I've done the same thing and regretted it later.

As far as having this discussion online, it NEEDS to be here.  This is 
called a SCENE for a reason.  In any community, matters that affect 
everyone need to be discussed in a public forum.



> I really only have one question, what is the VALUE of having this
> tit-for-tat on-line?  Ethan had a problem with some promoters.  He then, in
> a very public way, called them to task.  What is the point, other than
> venting, of doing it?  The way in which Ethan did it, was at best unethical
> for one reason;  He said a big FU without ANY explanation.  Sorry, this is
> just straight poor judgment.  If you're going call someone out, at least
> give the background in it's totality (i.e. the whole story from your point
> of view), otherwise it is just venting for the sake of venting, and that
> does nobody any good.  Ethan did give background, after several posts from
> people asking him why he went off the way he did.  However, the damage had
> already been done; the hornets nest had been disturbed.
> 
> I understand his beef, but I also understand Tom & Stacy's perspective.
> Despite what people want to believe, there ARE two sides to this story, and
> depending on YOUR perspective you will find the truth that fits your
> reality.  From a non-participatory view, they both have agendas, and both
> will be right in their respective views.
> 
> What aggravates me is the airing of dirty promoter BS laundry in public.
> This stuff is best left behind closed doors where the participants (the
> direct participants) can hash it out.  If it doesn't work out, fine, agree
> to disagree and move on.  What is the point of all of this "he said, she
> said", when in fact it's all a done deal?  Will it change the result or
> expected outcome?  I doubt it.  Will it stop whatever from happening again?
> I doubt it.  So really what is the point?  To let everyone know what
> really happened?  Who cares?  As far as I am concerned, there is an FnF
> planners list, THAT is the place this discussion belongs.  There, the party
> promoters, planners, whatever, can go round and round with this thing ad
> infinitum.  It would have more value to the people DIRECTLY involved with
> the throwing of parties, than the general partying public.  But here for
> all to see?, what value is any of this.
> 
> Not everyone is equal, nor has access to the same information.  My days as
> Mr. Party Man started changing, when I was brought in to do parties with
> various people.  It changed more when I got to know the lowdown on each and
> every party, it changed more when I found out about the personalities
> behind the parties, and it changed more as I got to know more and more
> about some of the ugly underbelly of parties.  And yes, it does exists.
> This discussion, if I may stretch to call the present arguments that, is
> just that.  Part of the ugliness that is part of this scene.  Of course
> that is my perspective, but what else would you call the present round of,
> er discussion?  Constructive dialog?  People working stuff out?  Is that
> what is going on?  No, it is two camps at odds, trying to explain how right
> each view is.  And to WHOSE benefit?  Does it benefit the list or people
> going to parties? , or does it illuminate that which would be better left
> unsaid?( i.e. "Is EVERYTHING an issue open for discussion?") Was there a
> need for a big loud "fuck you"?  Did this benefit the community?  Was there
> a need for a reply?  And what need?  Do you REALLY want to know all the
> dirty deeds some people might do to run parties at times?  Do you really
> want to know who has been fucked over in this scene, whether justified or
> not?  Do you want to know all of the dirt on everyone and everything in our
> dance community?  Is this really all THAT?  Or do you want to hear good
> music, in a good place, with people you enjoy being with?  Which and what
> is more important to you?
> 
> I'll always remember Harry Who telling me, during a bad time between me and
> another person doing parties: "Hey!, You guys are friends.  Shit happens.
> Make-up."  after a blip in the radar.  That's what this is supposed to be
> about.  Being friends & catchin' a groove.
> 
> Maybe I'm strange, I've always liked the music and the people, not how
> something was put together.
> 
> When it comes to parties I don't know everything.  But then I've decided I
> don't want to know everything.  Ignorance can be a good thing, when
> executed properly, it can result in sheer bliss.  The LA scene was so cool
> at one time.  Then the promoters started taking themselves very seriously.
> The result is evident.  That house is STILL being reconstructed.  The same
> thing IS happening here.
> 
> All of this talk about his space, my space...c'mon, sounds like some
> pre-school argument over whose tree house it is.  The scale has changed,
> the conversation is very much the same.
> 
> The harsh reality of parties:
> 
> -If you find a space, do not become attached to it in the slightest.  The
> second you open the doors to said space, there will have already been
> several promoters who will have talked to the person in charge of the
> space.  You just lucked out, this time.
> -You own no space, other than the one you have FOR THAT NIGHT.
> -There will ALWAYS be a someone with more money and guile.  You do not
> operate in a vacuum.
> -The most hardcore care little about what you think.  It's what you do that
> counts.
> -If another promoter  beats you to the punch, outbids you, steals your
> DJ's, remember it's just a party.  Hash it out with all people involved,
> take it on the chin, learn from it, and move on.
> -You're really hardcore if you let the person who fucked you over, into
> your gig for free.
> -The ideal is to have no expectations of anyone external to your group.
> Expect and plan for the worse, you'll never be disappointed.  Having this
> psyche makes even the slightest good thing be a grand bonus point.
> -You got a problem with a someone?  Take it to them.  If you must, you
> might want to talk to friends.  But be sure, most people could really care
> less.  They are looking for the next party, or the next place to spin, or
> the next place to be spun.  Your problems are for the moment, and there is
> a weekend coming up...
> -Got fucked over?, get over.  It's for the moment, you live and learn.  You
> build a book of trust and a book of people to watch out for.  You get to
> know who'll need a contract, and who's word is as good as gold.
> 
> There are more, but I follow these general rules, and have not been
> surprised at the results.  I am happier, and have had great interactions
> with people in dance culture.
> 
> I just think the bulk of this could've been handled off-line between the
> respective parties.  Maybe the end result could've been the movement of MAD
> or the other party.  Maybe the end result would've been the same minus the
> back-and-forth.  I think that any other result, short of breaking out the
> guns, is probably more desirable than what we have witnessed here over the
> past few days.
> 
> Cool off & settle it between yourselves please.  A nice long weekend approaches.
> 
> Gang of many
> --------------
> Then comes the troops.  I have always found mob mentality interesting.
> Especially when it develops around , so-called, peaceful movements.  People
> create allegiances for all sorts of reasons.  I found it amusing how easy
> it was for many to quickly forgive Ethan his minor trespass.  These same
> individuals however would've roasted anyone else for doing the same thing.
> Maybe it's a matter of familiarity with the person that determines the
> level of forgiveness one will receive. I dunno.  I *DO* know that most of
> the people, either agreeing or disagreeing with what was going on had
> NOTHING TO DO WITH THE INTERACTION BETWEEN ETHAN & TOM&STACY.  With that in
> mind, why chime in at all?  There are probably only a few who really know
> what's going on depending on who was where when.  I know Ethan knows, Tom &
> Stacy, & the club owner.  So, there will be three stories, three views.
> Which is right?  Probably all of them.  Which is wrong?  Same answer, all
> of them.  We are seeing the collision of expectations.  When they cannot be
> reconciled we witness anger, on all sides.
> 
> Many of you jumped on Ethan's shit...I can only wonder how many of these
> folks ever read the SFRaves archive?  Many of you chimed in agreement...I
> can only wonder how many of you were there for the series of events leading
> up to Ethan's frustration.  I know Ethan and respect him, I also was not
> there for the interaction between he, tom & stacy.  My stance is neutral.
> I empathize with Ethan because similar has happened to me and my friends
> over the years.  I understand Tom & Stacy's view, sometimes the party MUST
> go on.
> 
> There are two views.  And that is the only conclusion I can draw from the
> information given.
> 
> What do *I* have to do with this?  Very, very little.  I am involved
> because this has been made public.  Other than that, I am more than happy
> to sit on the sidelines and watch these people duke it out, much like I
> used to watch kids fight growing up.  Laugh at the loser, cheer the winner.
> But the thing I have learned is that there are very few definitive winners
> and losers when it comes to this party dance scene.  Either you'll stick it
> out, or bow out, or bow out and come back (the choice of champions ;)).
> really though, if one party goes away, there will be others to take it's
> place.  My allegiance is to the music and my friends, not an entity called
> a club or scene or particular party.  Where there is good music to my ears,
> I'll be there, period.
> 
> Lessons
> --------
> What is going on now is weak bubble gum compared to what has gone on in
> this city in the past IMO.  Feel very fortunate, those of you doing the do,
> that there are many less snakes in the grass these days.  What happened to
> Ethan & crew, used to happen ALL THE TIME.  What is worse is when you have
> reserved a space, printed flyers, then have the space sold from under you.
> Yikes!  Even worse is when you get outbid in one way or another....Yikes!
> How about having a space, then the person who owns it blows it out before
> your party, the venue busted by the cops, then expects you still have your
> party there the next night, even though the space is red fucking hot!
> YIKES!!!!  These things used to happen ALL THE TIME.  Some have happened to
> me, some to others.  I feel fortunate though, because I can still catch a
> groove and haven't let any of the bad things outweigh the enormous good
> I've enjoyed.  As a matter of fact, I will work with some of the very
> people who got on my nerves in the past.  Why?  Why not?  I'd rather
> forgive, and try to forge a truce, than to waste energy maintaining
> hostilities.  If others can do likewise, then we have a basis to work with
> each other.  I'd rather move forward and test the waters with new projects,
> using history to guide my present.  Besides, there are other more important
> things to worry about...like, where's the next party?
> 
> The Power of The Phone
> -------------------------
> There  was a brief moment in dance culture history when promoters called
> each other to determine when they could throw a party and not have it
> defeat another person's gig.  It was brief, but it was good.  You actually
> talked to the person throwing the gig, and created a cooperative model.
> Alas, it was fragile; people became disconnected.
> 
> And then there were none
> ------------------------
> "Peace, live in it or rest in it!  Come together!" - DJ Pierre;  This man
> is the fucking mac.  I am so saddened at his departure from house music.
> There is no other like Pierre, and there is no equal to his magic.  I hope
> homey comes back to the fold one day.  My man feels house music hasn't been
> as good to him as he's been to it.  No matter what, that man is by far, one
> of the greats of our dance culture.  He IS one of the originators.  His
> music will be missed.  He's the fucking mind bomb!  Everyone else is just
> visiting!
> 
> Props to Jeno for working the DJ Pierre "Generate Power" @ Toon Town back
> in the day (man, he would have motherfuckers grabbing @ straws - Jeno can
> WORK this track!).  Extra special thanks to Wicked posse for bringing DJ
> Pierre to SF to rock some fucking heads!!!  Now THAT was wicked!!!  (I am
> talking in particular about an event held in the "front" of Townsend.  This
> was one for the record books.  If you weren't there, you missed out on what
> can truly be called a stellar event.  Even Markie & Jeno got affected!)
> 
> I'm done now,
> John
> 
> Peace.
> 
> 
>

From: John Deatherage <dwarzau@ns.net>

cc: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: $20 parties
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9605230612.A26222-0100000@netcom14>
Message-ID: <Pine.HPP.3.91.960523121918.24510I-100000@hornet.ns.net>

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I'm going to change the subject here a little...

There are really too many $20 parties in Northern California.  Some are 
worth the money, but 90% of them are the same exact 5 all-SF DJ lineup.
If a promoter is going to charge $20, some out of town DJs, killer 
visuals, and a decent location.  Am I the only person sick of hearing the 
same pool of about 20 DJs OVER AND OVER AGAIN?  Most SF DJs are notorious 
for having a small playlist, and it all gets old really fast.  Even the 
out of town DJs people bring in are usually the same ones (ie Donald 
Glaude, Barry Weaver, DJ Trance, etc).  If I was threw another party I 
would bring in *TERRY MULLAN*.... He's been around a few times in the 
past 6 months, but he's INCREDIBLE!  I guess the main reason why is these 
out of town guys cost so much money to bring in, but don't draw enough to 
justify the money they cost to fly out.  One party to check out is Open 
Space this Friday - A-1 from Dallas will be there, and I know that Space 
Children and In-Touch will put a lot of work into that party..


> thinking about what is going on is in order... I know my mind has been 
> buzzing the past week...  As a suggestion: The next time you deal with a
> commercial or $20 party whether as a promoter charging it OR as a "guest"
> or consumer ask yourself WHY?  If you don't think about it you might not
> even care as long as the music and dancing is good.... if you think about
> what is going on more deeply you might find as I have that you do care
> after all......

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu May 23 12:54:33 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA10836; Thu, 23 May 1996 12:54:33 -0700

	id MAA11435; Thu, 23 May 1996 12:54:32 -0700

In-Reply-To: <Pine.HPP.3.91.960523120736.24510H-100000@hornet.ns.net> from "John Deatherage" at May 23, 96 12:16:22 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]

> 
> 
> 
> Really all I can say is that Ethan was just REALLY PISSED, and I think 
> any one in his situation would have done the same thing.  There have been 
> a ton of times where I've done the same thing and regretted it later.
> 

I have been in Ethan's situation on more than several occasions.  You 
will not find any post anywhere of my gripes with any promoters, period.  
I take it to them, hash it out, throw my party, then move on.

Like I said, I am strange.


> As far as having this discussion online, it NEEDS to be here.  This is 
> called a SCENE for a reason.  In any community, matters that affect 
> everyone need to be discussed in a public forum.
> 


I have to disagree, let you have the last word after this.  I do not care 
if president clinton wipes his ass.  In the same vein, I really don't 
care what it takes to have a party.  Either you're going to do it or 
not.  As a promoter and now partygoer/promoter-redux, all I am concerned 
about is catching a groove.  If Wicked or Preston has problems with the 
venue, I feel for them, becuase I was there.  But then the final question 
is always "Well, what are you gonna do about your party?"  Looking at it 
in this manner, you have taken your head out of what caused the problem, 
into a mode fo resolving to do something about it.  Sometimes talking 
FACE-TO-FACE helps, sometimes not.  Those who have been doing this for a 
while have learned not to dwell on the same issues for any more than a 
second.  The same could be a reason why the ranks have thinned, people 
concentrating on everything else but the dance/party.

I know the personal sacrifice it takes to find a space, get plyers done, 
etc.  I also know that not all of my travails are open for public 
scrutiny or discourse.  I would rather resolve problems between all 
parties, do my gig, make sure the people attending are having a good 
time.  Do the people entering the venue or space need to know I had to 
kiss so and so's ass, that I had to push one DJ out of a slot for 
previous obligations to another, that I had a flat tire on the way to 
distributing flyers, that I sacrificed my personal time to make sure they 
had a good time?  Do people come to parties to hear all of this?  I 
seriously doubt it.

For those who are curious fine.  Maybe there should (there once was), a 
place where everyone could dish their dirt, trials, and travails.  But 
for the general public, that which makes up the bulk of our dance 
community, they really could care less.  Most of them don't even know 
Jeno from Ethan anyway, and that is my point.  People come ot hear the 
music, people are a part of this because of the music, not becuase of 
politics or internal fighting.

I thought it was of great foresight to ask people interested in this 
debacle to get private e-mail correspondence.  As far as I am concerned, 
that is great.  As for everyone else who doesn't want to make the effort 
to be cc'ed on this, please do not assume that they are not certain of 
thier intentions.  Kepp that argument, debate, tit-for-tat promoter vs 
promoter stuff private.  I for one do not care to know.

I know others feel the same (well at least one other).  Anyway I hope 
things work out for all parties involved.  SInce I know Ethan, I *DO* 
hope he gets what he wants and hope he does well in all his future 
endeavors.  We need not overanalyze and be informed of the obvious.

As for everyone in the community being involved, they already are, 
whether they like it or not.  So much for choice.  ANyway I do think it 
holds intrigue for those who are not familiar with how parties are done, 
the mechanics and logistics of the party, etc.  So while I am all for 
such opportunities for learning (It ain't black magic), I am not down 
with the other aspects.  The pettiness, the bickering, the "my 
space"/"Your space" (a DJ once told me a certain venue was his, I laughed 
in his face...get real), the nonsense, the back-stabbing.  Hell, it's 
better to write a book:

"The Benefits and Risks of Being a Rave Promoter"

This book is a tell all!  Get it now!  In it you'll learn...

-How to outbid a promoter who has the DJ you want for your gig.
-How to make more money by busting a competitiors party.
-How to put off paying DJ's so that you alone can reap the benfit of your 
hard work.
-How to get work done for free.
-Throwing benefits for profit.
-Selling the concept of a virgin space.
-Safe circledancing.
-How to make money via the roving party scam.
-Lining up your troops, how to create a loyal posse that would do 
ANYTHING to ensure your party's survival.
-Waxing cops asses, or how to have an unbustable party.
-How to fuck someone over who did you a bad 5 years ago.
-Guerilla party tactics.
-The art of party subtrefuge.
-How to promise, but never deliver.

And this is just the tip of the iceberg.

Yeah, everyone really wants to know all these things, and for $19.95 you can!

Peace, live in it, or rest in it,
John

P.S.  I would rather go to a party where the people throwing it are people 
I trust.  The rest is icing or bollocks.  But then again, I am a very 
strange person.

Out & Peace.

Subject: The Community was Re: Earth's a shakin
In-Reply-To: <199605230541.AA16181@crl.crl.com>

I'm not replying to this in order to make a "I'm right, you're wrong" kind 
of statement.  I respect where you are coming from, Sharif, but I kindly 
disagree.  

To me raving is about community.  I've been able to learn more about 
human beings and myself through raving.  This list (to me) is more than 
just a place to discuss the dance/music/party aspect of raving.  It is a 
community, one in which people care for each other.  Reaching out to 
someone comes in many forms, and if it takes topics which aren't 
"rave-related", whatever that means, so be it.  I think the interactions 
between people, like when we are commenting about earthquakes, are 
infectious and for the most part enjoyed.  It is all a part of good-will.

I understand that I am but one person with one voice, and I do not hope 
or try to impose my view on you.  Rather, I'd like to share with you how I 
see this list.  (which I think I've done)

Another thing that I find odd when ppl complain about "such-and-such" 
topic, is that in order to complain, they *had* to have read the posts in 
question.  If it angers someone so much, why do they read the posts in 
the first place?  I think it's because everyone is so afraid they are 
going to miss something.  Well, if this is true, maybe one should ask 
themselves why they feel this way.  Maybe because it is fun to be here, 
and to relate to people, which is my whole point!!

Finally, if you are not seeing topics that you would like to see, why 
don't you begin to post about them?  This is another thing that I don't 
get.  If there is something you'd like to talk about, then why don't 
you?  I do agree that I have seen little about music recently, and , 
unfortunately, I don't know enough to start talking about it, but maybe 
you do?  There are so many people on this list, that someone will most 
likely reply to any request that you make.

I hope you don't take this as a personal affront, because I am addressing 
my thoughts to everyone.

Sincerely, 

KaySEE

this weekend. I'm going to make my first real mix tape this weekend. I've
made some just to listen to find out what the heck I was doing wrong and to
help improve myself, but this weekend I'm going to get serious and make a
tape. This may not seem like a big deal to some people and other DJ's, but I
just get off when I'm mixing a record and everything is flowing so good. I
feel enough happiness and energy and have such a great time doing it I can
live forever and pass that energy to others. I love the music and love the
people I've met in this great scene of ours. So if you don't see me out this
weekend, I'll be in SF, but I'll be in front of some turntables having a
blast. I'm going to make 1 House and 1 Trance tape. So if everything goes
good, I'm going to make a bunch of copies and just give them out for
everyone to check out and give me feed back on how or what to do to improve.

day weekend!!!!!

     Although I'm still basically just a chippy in this scene, I would 
     suggest that no argument between event organizers could possibly be as 
     persuasive as an evaluation of the parties they promote (on a purely 
     subjective basis, of course) --it says a lot about people and their 
     integrity.
     
     After attending Madness --which was splendid-- I was prepared to check 
     out the Nomad party the following weekend (unaware that they were 
     planning to use the same space).  I didn't get very far.
     
     Perhaps I'm overly sensitive where selling is concerned, but as soon 
     as I rang their number I knew Nomad wasn't getting a dime out of me.
     Furthermore, it came as little surprise to learn how they conduct 
     their business, nor how their event came off.  I'm only sorry that my 
     gut reaction *wasn't* wrong.
     
     
     Corey
     
     ps - If anyone is wondering what I mean about the voicemail, just call 
          them at 415-675-5605.  I haven't heard the message lately, but    
          I'll wager the recording says "beautiful", "great", or "really    
          exciting", about 15 times.  Why not "More Absorbent!", "Longer    
          Lasting!" or "Phat Free!"  Business must be good.

> 
> 
> I don't like the fact that they said VIRGIN WAREHOUSE the night of the 
> party on the voicemail.  That's NOT cool...
> 
> > So, howzabout some smiles, laughs, friendships, and healing after all
> > that's happened of late?  I, for one, am sending out light, love, positive
> > energy, and a hope for reconciliation to Ethan, Stacy, Tom, and all their
> > posses.  Let love rule, y'all!
> 

Virgin Warehouse?  In San Francisco?  You're kidding, right? 

I just want to lend a bit of perspective...there has not been a virgin 
warehouse in SF since the last huge quake of 1912.

People, this is the friggin barbary coast.  A place of gambling, brothels 
(yeah!), home of the shang-hai (soory to all my Asian bro's & sistahs), 
gold rush, sardine canneries, etc.

There has been undergrounds and secret societies and subcultures since we 
first started walking upright.

There is NO SUCH THING as a VIRGIN WAREHOUSE in SF.  If someone used it 
for anything, it is no longer virgin, by strict definition.  Please 
remember, this place has long been the focal point for gay culture & 
people.  The UG gay scene here, with it's dance parties and sex clubs 
were world renown, second only to maybe New York.  You can best believe 
that if there was an empty space, that at some time within the past 85 
years, it was used for something other than what is was designed for.

People have been partying in this city forever.  We are not the first, 
nor will we be the last.

To some Virgin Space menas one that has never been used for anything, 
never been used for a party, never been used for a massive.  It all 
depends on your view.  If you have a very strict sense of things, so be 
it.  You'll find plenty of people who are wrong, with such rigid standards.

I have always referred to spaces as new, where appropriate.  Now this can 
mean that my party 
had never used it before, or it could mean that, to my knowledge, it 
hadn't been used before by any other party.

Everyone's knowledge starts somewhere.  Those who are new to doing 
parties here in the city may just mistake a place THEY have never used 
before as being virgin.  It's common, especially with promoters from 
outside the area.  It happens all the time.

Also remeber, there are alot of people who are still first timers.  First 
timers are usually attracted to the larger events, so to alot of people, 
who might be used to going to Townsend, this space might seem new.  To the 
uninitiated it could be BRAND new.  I just try to remeber that 
some things are relative.

I do think that if *I* were to throw a party at this particular space, I 
would see no problem in calling it new or a newer space.  It hadn't been 
used that much, and since it can still be worked (unlike Townsend), I 
think the term new would be appropriate.

Virgin?  I dunno, it all depends.  Now I think it is a far cry from 
calling Townsend a new or virgin space.  That place is more reamed out 
than a soap-on-a-rope convict.  Oh well...

Ok now...let's all take a deep breath.  relax.  While taking your next 
deep breath, tighten your buttocks, as you exhale, relax them. 
Mmmmmm...doesn't that feel better.

Anyway, we can find 1000 ways to be pissed at someone or something.  I am 
not defending the actions of unscrupulous promoters who use the term 
"Virgin Warehouse" as a selling point to pack in heads. But sometimes it 
CAN be a matter of perspective.  

Maybe we all might do better if we broaden ours.

Peace, livin' it,
John

P.S.  This weekend will be the mac daddy bomb.  Why?  Becuase I am going 
out drinking then partying my ass off with some friends.  It is DJ 
Loren's bday on Sunday.  I was told he will be playing @ Sunset, so Im 
going to catch some grooves with the guy who got me into playing records.  Right 
on!  On Saturday?  Hangin' wit' da homeys!  Gonna drink, cook some food, and of 
course, partay!  Fukin-el!  Just a primer for Sunday.  Will I 
crackerjack?  My friends are jackin', but I probably will not.  That 
doesn't mean I won't have a good time.  Crackerjackin' was all good at 
one time, nowadays, I can catch a groove with my mind and hills of green.

This will be a good weekend.  Not for amatuers, not for the weak @ 
heart.  If you're not going to tribal "crackerjack" Future (which I also 
hear will be the mega bomb), I guess I'll see you @ Sunset.  Otherwise, 
have a good one.

That party on Tuesday @ 111 Minna is called Light N' Up Lounge.

I'm out!

My dad mailed me this and I thought that it might help you all out....


______________________________ Forward Header __________________________________
Subject: New Virus
Author:  Walt Campbell at FWENJ2
Date:    5/23/96 1:58 PM
     
     
     There is a computer virus that is being sent across the Internet. If 
     you receive an email message with the subject line "Good  Times", DO 
     NOT read the message, DELETE it immediately.  Please read the messages 
     below. Some miscreant is sending  email under the title "Good Times" 
     nationwide, if you get anything like this, DON'T DOWN LOAD THE FILE! 
     >It has a virus that rewrites your hard drive, obliterating anything 
     on it.
     Please be careful and forward this mail to anyone you care about.
     
     WARNING!!!!!!!  INTERNET VIRUS
     
     
     The FCC released a warning last Wednesday concerning a matter of major 
     importance to any regular user  of the Internet. Apparently a new 
     computer virus has been engineered by a user of AMERICA ON LINE that  
     is unparalleled in its destructive capability. Other more well-known 
     viruses such as "Stoned", "Airwolf" and "Michaelangelo" pale in 
     comparison to the prospects of this newest creation by a warped 
     mentality. What makes this virus so terrifying, said the FCC, is the 
     fact that no program needs to be exchanged for a new computer to be 
     infected. It can be spread through the existing email systems of the 
     Internet.
     
     Once a Computer is infected, one of  several things can  happen. If 
     the computer contains a hard drive, that will most likely be 
     destroyed.  If the  program is not stopped, the computer's processor 
     will be placed in an nth-complexity infinite binary loop -which can 
     severely damage the processor if left running that way too long.
     
     Unfortunately, most novice computer users will not realize what is 
     happening until it is far too late. Luckily, there is one sure means of 
     detecting what is now known as the "Good Times" virus. It always travels 
     to new computers the same way in a text email message with the subject 
     line reading "Good Times". Avoiding infection is easy once the file has 
     been received simply by NOT READING IT! The act of loading the file into 
     the mail server's ASCII buffer causes the "Good Times" mainline program 
     to initialize and execute. The program is highly intelligent- it will  
     send copies of itself to everyone whose email address is contained in a 
     receive-mail file or a sent-mail file, if it can find one. It will then 
     proceed to trash the computer it is running on.
     
     The bottom line is:  - if you receive a file with the subject line "Good 
     Times", delete it  immediately! Do not read it"  Rest assured that 
     whoever's name was on the  "From" line was surely struck by the virus. 
     Warn your friends and  local system users of this newest threat to the 
     Internet! It could save them a lot of time and money.
     
     
     DO NOT DOWNLOAD ANY FILE NAMED PKZIP300 REGARDLESS OF THE 
     EXTENSION!!
     
     A NEW Trojan Horse Virus has emerged on the internet with the name 
     PKZIP300.ZIP, so named as to give the impression that this file is a 
     new version of the PKZIP software used to "ZIP" (compress) files.
     
     DO NOT DOWNLOAD this file under any circumstances!!! If you install or 
     expand this file, the virus WILL wipe your hard disk clean and affect 
     modems at 14.4 and higher. This is an extremely destructive virus and 
     there is NOT yet a way of cleaning up this one.
     
     REPEAT: DO NOT DOWNLOAD ANY FILE NAMED PKZIP300 REGARDLESS OF 
     THE  EXTENSION.
     
     
     
     
     
     

-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Matthew S. Wietzke                                            U.C. Davis

Amidst all the recent talk of "posses", "ethan's troops", etc., I really
need to make sure that the following is absolutely clear:

Everything I've said is my personal view and mine alone.

Nothing I have said IN ANY WAY reflects or represents the views of
Friends and Family the group, or any of its members.

This is also true in regard to madness. It was very difficlut to try and
describe the history of the ruccus without using some pronoun. I chose "we"
as it seemed more accurate than "I" in representing that history. But, as
noted, the emotions are mine not "ours", whoever that might be.

So please don't hold my views against anyone other than myself...  8)

wellll.... you can get hit with an ansi-bomb, but since email programs don't
seem to use ansi colours, you'd have to export it and view it with another
program.. but you can get burned by an ansi-bomb without running it. if you
view it, it can remap keys on your keyboard to do different things (see:
reformat your harddrive), but you'd have to have an old ansi driver in order
for it to let that happen. nothing to worry about, anyway.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu May 23 16:47:34 1996

Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA01125; Thu, 23 May 1996 16:47:32 -0700
Received: from [128.32.160.58] (hmfmac20.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.160.58]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.5/8.6.12) with SMTP id QAA30107 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 23 May 1996 16:47:36 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <v02130501adcaaa7886ae@[128.32.160.58]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 23 May 1996 16:45:56 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Capitalist Mentality and the Death of Alternative Community
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Folks, it's all about spaces.   Property for sale to the highest bidder,
and what that tells us about our society.    This is not "Ethan vs. Tom &
Stacy", but what this argument represents -- the vitality of underground
parties vs. the dominance of commercial raves.  Some of us love the coming
together of friends in an UG; some of us love the world-class dj's and
production of a CR.   Babies or massives, it's all good!!  But
unfortunately, the fact is that commercialism has the nasty effect of
crushing the underground. Since no UG promoters own a fabulous space, they
must locate one from a third party, who's most interested in PROFIT.  When
a higher-end promoter comes along and offers a king's ransom for a space,
that space is forever priced out of UG range.  Another space lost.

Commercial parties are fine, but not when their method of business
eliminates the possibility of any OTHER kind of party.  Why did Chrysalis
fall through for this weekend - leaving us with only FTT?  Why hasn't there
been a Friends & Family in almost a year? Why are there so few
undergrounds, but a plethora of massives on any given week-end?? Spaces,
SPACES - it's all about the AFFORDABILITY of spaces.  So when a space is
finally located and much energy and time is devoted to it, only to have it
also disintegrate because of folks who claim to support the underground, a
reaction such as Ethan's is understandable, IMO.

This is, however, the mechanics of capitalism.  Charging what the market
will bear, pricing everyone's services - as Mike pointed out, "consumers"
not friends.  The ideal values of the UG -- donation of time and effort,
respect and trust of friends, collectives working together selflessly to
create something better for the whole -- cannot survive in an environment
dominated by an economic mentality.   The only way an alternative community
such as this CAN flourish is if it has its own protected space, apart from
the dominant values of the mainstream.   In a society where greatest price
wins, the value of community will always lose, at least as far as the owner
of a potential space is concerned.   Since UG's are forced to compete with
richer contenders for spaces -- the fundamental necessity for even HAVING a
party -- well, we can see the result.  Which value will prevail in a
society BASED on economic values?  Just count the number of undergrounds
compared to the money-making raves.

So our experiment of creating community apart from capitalist values may be
doomed.  I guess the UG has to move even further out of commercialized
arenas, back to beaches (Sunsets) and the forest (Tribal Future) and the
Desert (Dune) - though even there we are still within reach of permit
hassles, police, and vagaries of the weather.  Just think about it, people
-- the dominance of economic rationality (evaluating everything by its
monetary value) is SO pervasive that it is almost impossible for us to
create a community that celebrates something different.  Something more
human, life-affirming.  More loving.  The mainstream capitalist society
forces us to play by their rules, and either become like them (commercial
raves), or lose.

I think raves are three things - the music, the people, and the feeling.
That incredible feeling springs, for me, from the emancipation of finding a
public place NOT based on an economic mentality.  How amazing that is for
us all!  How unusual!  But the music and the physical exterior of the rave
were marketable - so, naturally (following capitalist logic) these were
elevated to become the characteristics of  commercial "raves."  The
unmarketable aspects are what were left behind in the UG.  You can't sell
it, but precisely because it is not sellable means its extinction.  Under
mainstream economic rationality, those things without a price are useless.
If it can't be traded for money, what good is it?  Because money is the
ultimate value.

The loss of this particular space is merely a symptom of a much-larger
socio-political phenomenon, bigger than Ethan or T/S.  I fully support and
love the concept behind the undergrounds.   It's just that with every lost
space, I grow increasingly pessimistic of its possibility.
Capitalism/Modernity/Industrialization has been an unbelievably powerful
force, trampling over other cultures and ideas all over the globe.  Today
we see a global hierarchy with the West firmly on top, and most of the
world suffering - cultures which were thriving before the imperialism of
the West.  Can alternative values grow right here in the heart of
Capitalist Mentality?  When even to question our national dogma is to be
labeled a commie, or backward, or a hippie (or a raver? :) ?  Or will the
might of economic rationality crush our experiment?

No Chrysalis this week-end - hmm, you decide.

Love, Nancy

P.S.  I'm unsubbing tomorrow <SOB!>, so I probably won't get to your
responses, if any.  But I do think it's something for us as a society to
consider, whether manifested as a "rave promoter squabble" or as global
politics.  Because they do share the same, fundamental basis.

Today,  I'm a lot more optimistic than I was last week.   I went to a killer

candidate...  but they plan to interview just one more person this coming
Tuesday...   Because of the unexpected rains,  My belongings needed at
least two more days to dry out in the sun.   So I told off Rico (Landlord)
today,   saying that his "move out" time was unreasonable and unfair,  and
got him to back off and bought till the end of the month before I have
to vacate.

Thanx so very much to all those generious people who came forward to help
me find a temporary place for my boxes.   I might still need to store then
there,  until I can find my own place,  and have privately arranged that
already.

So,  I ask all of you great people to please send me all the positive vibes
and energy my way....  :-)

to fly me out to Raliegh, NC next week for an interview and (brain picking)
session,  and will send me home with some $ and possibly an offer if this
Sausalito job doesn't work out....

>> called a SCENE for a reason.  In any community, matters that affect 
>> everyone need to be discussed in a public forum.

>if president clinton wipes his ass.  In the same vein, I really don't 
>care what it takes to have a party.

If President Clinton's ass-wiping had an impact on his public policy, you 
might care to know more about it.  Similarly, promoter behavior that has 
a public impact on the raving community (e.g. affects space availibility, 
relations with police, etc.) may deserve public attention.  Whether this 
particular recent issue qualifies on these grounds is, of course, a 
matter of opinion.
