This exact same thing happened to me last year on May 31st.  I still
remember the worrible day.  I too have a Honda; a civic though.  Well it
used to have nice rims and and a great sterio but now it's pretty much
stock.  It was stollen in front of Club X on Harrison.  It had a Clifford
alarm too but these pros got by that.  I had to take a taxi to sf state to
stay with friends untill the next day when I could get picked up.  Good
news though- I got it back 3 days later when the police called and found it
on blocks behind a house in OAKLAND.  Only positve thing=3D the theives
filled my gas tank up and didn't break any windows or dent any fenders.
Let me tell you the feeling sucks when you come out of a club of have a
great time and it is all shatters by the theft of something presious.  Lock
you valuables up!, park in lit areas, get a great alarm and just hope the
theives will pass your car up.

That night a cop told me.. If a theif wants your car bad enough there is
almost nothing you can do to stop him...

Peace
Austin

PS.  FINALS ARE OVER!!!!!!!!!!!! YEAH TIME TO DANCE AND PARTY

>FROM: Robert Brown
>
>SUBJECT: Car Break-ins & Theft (mostly NRR)
>
>
> I had sent an email about this yesterday morning but it never showed up
> on SFR that I could see, so I'll resend it...
>
> After seeing a few posts about car break ins at raves I felt I just HAD
> to chime in on it given what happened to me over the weekend.
>
> On Saturday night/Sunday morning my car was stolen while I was in SF
> dancing.  Not an expenisive car, but not a heap either.  Coming out
> at 3:30am to discover your car is no more is not a pleasant experience,
> especially when you're alone, stranded 45 miles from home!
>
> According to the police (who was reasonably nice, btw) Hondas seem to
> be the current favorite flavor of car thieves in SF.  I had a "locktronics=
"
> ignition lock, but obviously it didn't prevent the car from being stolen.
> Seemed to be a pro job.  Also, again according to the police, auto theives
> do cruise around various party/club spots in SF looking for cars - so
> be careful as well as you can.  I think they were definitely after the car
> itself because I hid everything out of site so there'd be no obvious
> motivation for breaking into the car.  To no avail...
>
> Ironically I was looking at car alarms just a couple of weeks ago, but
> couldn't afford to get one at the time.  Argh!  :(
>
> Aside from the car my uninsured, personal, and expensive cellular phone
> was taken, and my planner/address book.  So, if any of you have given
> my your addy/phone # I no longer have them and would like them again,
> if possible.
>
> If anyone sees a black Honda Prelude with CA license plate EZP 233, please
> call the police!  Though I'm sure it's been hacked to bits and the
> parts sent all over the place by now.  :(
>
> And just to make things completely miserable, my s.o. decided to break up
> with me last night.  Paradise lost...(that phrase just came to mind)
> Life seems a swirl of negativity currently...
>
> Sorry, but had to spill to whomever was listening.

From:  Matt Wietzke/DJ Xpress[SMTP:mswietzke@ucdavis.edu]
Sent:  Thursday, May 23, 1996 3:53 PM
To:  sfraves
Subject:  New virus (NRR)

My dad mailed me this and I thought that it might help you all out....


______________________________ Forward Header
__________________________________
Subject: New Virus
Author:  Walt Campbell at FWENJ2
Date:    5/23/96 1:58 PM
       

       

     There is a computer virus that is being sent across the Internet. If   

     you receive an email message with the subject line "Good  Times", DO   

     NOT read the message, DELETE it immediately.  Please read the   
messages
     below. Some miscreant is sending  email under the title "Good Times"   

     nationwide, if you get anything like this, DON'T DOWN LOAD THE FILE!   

     >It has a virus that rewrites your hard drive, obliterating anything   

     on it.
     Please be careful and forward this mail to anyone you care about.
       

     WARNING!!!!!!!  INTERNET VIRUS
       

       

     The FCC released a warning last Wednesday concerning a matter of   
major
     importance to any regular user  of the Internet. Apparently a new
     computer virus has been engineered by a user of AMERICA ON LINE that   
   

     is unparalleled in its destructive capability. Other more well-known   

     viruses such as "Stoned", "Airwolf" and "Michaelangelo" pale in
     comparison to the prospects of this newest creation by a warped
     mentality. What makes this virus so terrifying, said the FCC, is the   

     fact that no program needs to be exchanged for a new computer to be
     infected. It can be spread through the existing email systems of the   

     Internet.
       

     Once a Computer is infected, one of  several things can  happen. If
     the computer contains a hard drive, that will most likely be
     destroyed.  If the  program is not stopped, the computer's processor   

     will be placed in an nth-complexity infinite binary loop -which can
     severely damage the processor if left running that way too long.
       

     Unfortunately, most novice computer users will not realize what is
     happening until it is far too late. Luckily, there is one sure means   
of
     detecting what is now known as the "Good Times" virus. It always   
travels
     to new computers the same way in a text email message with the   
subject
     line reading "Good Times". Avoiding infection is easy once the file   
has
     been received simply by NOT READING IT! The act of loading the file   
into
     the mail server's ASCII buffer causes the "Good Times" mainline   
program
     to initialize and execute. The program is highly intelligent- it   
will
     send copies of itself to everyone whose email address is contained   
in a
     receive-mail file or a sent-mail file, if it can find one. It will   
then
     proceed to trash the computer it is running on.
       

     The bottom line is:  - if you receive a file with the subject line   
"Good
     Times", delete it  immediately! Do not read it"  Rest assured that
     whoever's name was on the  "From" line was surely struck by the   
virus.
     Warn your friends and  local system users of this newest threat to   
the
     Internet! It could save them a lot of time and money.
       

       

     DO NOT DOWNLOAD ANY FILE NAMED PKZIP300 REGARDLESS OF THE
     EXTENSION!!
       

     A NEW Trojan Horse Virus has emerged on the internet with the name
     PKZIP300.ZIP, so named as to give the impression that this file is a   

     new version of the PKZIP software used to "ZIP" (compress) files.
       

     DO NOT DOWNLOAD this file under any circumstances!!! If you install   
or
     expand this file, the virus WILL wipe your hard disk clean and   
affect
     modems at 14.4 and higher. This is an extremely destructive virus   
and
     there is NOT yet a way of cleaning up this one.
       

     REPEAT: DO NOT DOWNLOAD ANY FILE NAMED PKZIP300 REGARDLESS OF
     THE  EXTENSION.
       

       

       

       

       

       


 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
Matthew S. Wietzke                                            U.C. Davis

       This is not Greg, this is his roommate Matt. All words in this 
post are not Greg's, they are mine and mine alone. I do not understand 
why people complain about spending $20 on a party and then go and spend 
$20-$60 on EEEEE!!! If someone is so concerned about the cost of the 
party, then don't go. If you go and then spend more money on EEE and 
then complain about the expensive evening, then you need a lesson in 
money management. I go knowing how much my evening is going to cost me 
and if the party doesn't seem worth the entrance fee, then I won't go. 
It's just as simple as that.

not directed at you, but at those individuals who are constantly 
complaining.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "hey, where am I?" <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: Yes, my 6 month anniversary! :)  (long!)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>  Hey all you kiddies! As many of you know Chrysalis is this weekend. 
>As many of you don't know,  this weekend will also be the 6 month 
>anniversary for Shawna who, you guessed it, had been raving for 6 months. 
>Unfortunately, I'll be out of town and won't be able to celebrate with her.
>So, I want everyone to give her an anniversary hug for me;):):):).



Ok, now that Reagan has sufficiently embarrassed me in front of the whole
class, might as well make a 
speech! ;)

*warning! possible spiritual subject matter ahead! Read at your own risk!*
(seriously, if you are bothered by this kind of thing, then stop here! :)


This weekend it will be, as Reagan said, my six month raving anniversary.  I
know that's not very long, I know some of you Crusty Grumpy Old Ravers out
there have been doin it since the Famed Toon Towns & before, but when I look
at the absolutely amazing changes my life has gone thru since having begun
raving, I really can't believe I've been doing it for as short a time as I
have! :)  I've met up with the most wonderful people, made the most
wonderful friends, and have had some mind-blowing experiences that I
wouldn't change for the world (yes, sober too! ;)  This, more than anything,
has really taught me something about so-called "life (my own anyway),
liberty & the pursuit of happiness".  I've experienced more of those three
in the last three months I think, than in the rest of my life put together
just about.  

Life:  never in my life have I been so excited to just merely exist!  I was
realizing that the other day.  I suddenly became aware that I was all hyper
& excited, and I began to wonder why, because there wasn't anything in
particular going on.  Then I realized, I was just happy & excited because I
was alive, and also realized how much I was looking forward to seeing what
happens in my life next!  Kinda like a book where you can't wait to turn the
page?  This really surprised me.  Once upon a time, I dreaded what would
happen in my life, I despaired of ever being able to change the situation I
was stuck in, and thought "god. is that what the rest of my life is going to
be like?"  This was only last September, folks!  And then last Saturday
(before Madness), I find myself lying there with my best friend listening to
a beautiful song, and I realize (alert, corny moment ahead) that I am about
as happy as I've ever been and to top it off I also realize I'm crying! :)
This totally blew me away needless to say.  And there wasn't anything
fabulous going on, I hadn't won the lottery, I hadn't found an incredible
new love or anything, I was just happy to exist.  And that was what *really*
blew me away. Not only was I happy enough to be crying out of the blue, but
there wasn't any greater reason than simple existence that was making me
feel that way.  This was probably one of the most intense experiences I've
ever had in my life, and yes it was stone sober for those enquiring minds
that want to know!  Y'alls can now understand why I feel such affection for
the rave scene & everything it entails!  

Liberty:  Woo-wee! :)  I have experienced the most amazing sense of freedom
since having joined up with my raving clan, in a number of ways.  One rather
obvious way is thru the breakup with my boyfriend.  This occurred right
before I began raving, and boy was it the best thing I've ever done in my
life just about!  Jealous, drunk & abusive, no way in hell I could have done
any raving at all with him still in the picture.  This was a situation I
thought I was stuck in, hence my above statement about wondering how the
hell I was going to get myself out of this, wondering if this was how my
life was going to be for the rest of my life.  We'd go to a party, & if I
took too long in the bathroom he'd come pounding on the door demanding to
know why I was there so long & who was in there with me.  I remember having
to steel myself ahead of time when I knew I was going to have to deal with
him drunk again.  So!  You can imagine the amazing sense of lightness &
freedom I experienced attending beautiful experiences like my first
Chrysalis after having broken up with him! :):)  And it's just been going on
like that since.  Total night & day.  I've savored every bit of freedom I
could experience in these past few months, and you guys really wouldn't
believe how like a completely different person I feel now! Anyway, that
freedom is pretty obvious when you look at the before-and-after picture.
Another freedom I've experienced I think I described in my review of Basics
a couple of months ago.  This was a freedom from all that bizarre crap that
parents & society instill in you at a young age & onwards.  I definitely
still feel that we were all born a certain way, in awe & wonder about the
world around us, full of unconditional love.  And I believe that along the
way, society decides for us what proper behavior is, proper ways of thinking
are, proper ways to feel are, and teaches us to fear the very way we were
born feeling & behaving.  I described in that review how at that party I
somehow felt like I had completely come full circle back to how I was when I
was born, and it seemed that everyone around me was feeling the same way.
You can imagine how beautiful that group experience was!  Everybody acting &
feeling & thinking the way it seemed we were meant to do from the start.  No
negative reinforcement to be found.  It was a very simple & clear way to
exist.  I will always remember that party (and also the amazing group of
people I was with) for making me feel that way (again!).  Not every party
does that, and it taught me yet another valuable lesson.  So yes, in many
respects, I really feel like I now know what it is to be free.

The Pursuit of Happiness:   It is also important for me to point out that
while I directly attribute much of my recent changes of being to the rave
scene, it has very much taught me to look internally for this happiness I
described above.  Much like how Jesus taught Peter (it was peter, right?)
how to fish for himself, rather than simply handing him with the fish.
Raving has been this incredible force in my life that while providing me all
these amazing things & experiences, still managed to teach me how to seek
these things out & find them for/within myself.  I don't know about all of
you, but this has actually been one of the most important things I've been
learning lately, and this change of perspective on my part has literally
changed my life in a very short amount of time.  The pursuit of happiness
has led me to myself, all the while finding a thousand ravers holding my
hand! :)


I just wanted to write this & let you all know how much the rave scene, &
thus all of you who make up the scene, has done for me.  You are all
important to me, dj/promoter/party-goer/etc, you all make up what feels like
a close community for me.  Without one of those components, it just wouldn't
be the same, in fact it wouldn't even exist.  You have all played a part
somehow in those things I described above, you have all helped teach me the
real meaning of Life, Liberty, & the Pursuit of Happiness (The Inalienable
Rights of Raving!)  And you have all helped teach me to find these things in
myself as well.  

And to top it all off, I just had the best mango I've ever had in my life!
Life just doesn't get any better than this! :)


Well, since I *was* gonna celebrate my anniversary at Chrysalis, looks like
I'll hafta put it off for one week and do it at Tribal Future instead.  I
hope to see everybody who's made a difference to me there, to help me "ring
in" the next six months! :):)


Thanks for your patience if you've read this far! :)

Love,
Shawna

1996 has been a great year so far!


"For what shall it profit a man to gain the world but lose his lunch..."

To: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy), sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Andrew Nourse" <andy@pythagoras.org>
Subject: Re: Capitalist Mentality and the Death of Alternative Community
Message-ID: <19960524071247.AAA28642@pythagoras.pythagoras.org>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 04:45 PM 5/23/96 -0800, Nancy wrote:
>Folks, it's all about spaces....
> Since no UG promoters own a fabulous space

I think we COULD!

>The only way an alternative community such as this CAN flourish is if it has
>its own protected space, apart from the dominant values of the mainstream.

When people are exposed to the real thing, they lose patience with the hyped-up
imitations.  We need no protection from the system.  The system feels the need
to be protected from us.

>In a society where greatest price wins, the value of community will always
lose,
>at least as far as the owner of a potential space is concerned.

If the current owners all act like automata, as you suggest, then the
solution to
the problem is obvious---   We become the owners...

>Just count the number of undergrounds compared to the money-making raves.

That is hard to do.  The money-making ones advertise, and the undergrounds
are, well, underground, so most of us don't always hear about them.

>I guess the UG has to move even further out of commercialized
>arenas, back to beaches (Sunsets) and the forest (Tribal Future) and the
>Desert (Dune)

I have always preferred places like this anyway.  Often the best places are
ones that are protected from the ravages you speak of by the sheer difficulty
of building anything there.  It is often possible to purchase land in such
places for surprising little money.

>I think raves are three things - the music, the people, and the feeling.
>That incredible feeling springs, for me, from the emancipation of finding a
>public place NOT based on an economic mentality. ...  The
>unmarketable aspects are what were left behind in the UG. ...

> precisely because it is not sellable means its extinction.

No, it just means that capitalists will not attempt to sell it.  They  can
attempt to stamp it out, but since they don't really understand what it is,
eliminating it will always be very difficult for them to do.

>If it can't be traded for money, what good is it?  Because money is the
>ultimate value.

And raves are one of the places that people learn that this isn't true.
(which, no doubt, is a source of great concern to some people).

Lots of stuff this Memorial Day weekend, all around the bay area and
Northern CA - in SF, in Santa Cruz, in the East Bay, in Stockton, and even
on the Bay!  Funky Tekno Tribe and Spundae will probably be the biggest,
and there are also free afternoon parties on Saturday and maybe Sunday.


                           THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning 3am-6am - "Aural Fixation"
       experimental sounds of ambient and trip hop with a splash of hi
       nrg, from trance to jungle. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

In my experiance they concentrated on the music and, hence, attracted
people who understand the vibe music can make.  The more expensive 
massives - while good-attract a different vibe IMO because they are
inherently spectacles and maybe inherently alienating because of their
size. That doesn't mean they are bad but maybe massives then become
something different than a rave or maybe they to become a series of
small raves with people moving into cliques to find that bonding and
shared experiance that I have always enjoyed at smaller raves.  

Cassandra

P.S. Is anyone going to anything else other than FTT?:)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 24 01:22:15 1996

In-Reply-To: <1.5.4.16.19960523041504.388f73d4@popd.ix.netcom.com>

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I didn't include Shawna's original message becuase it is very long;
however, I think everyone should skim it becuse I think there is an
important lesson in Shawna's lovely post.  I, also, consider myself a
*new* raver though I was aware of a lot of the things like Toon Town and
Mr. Floppy's when they were going on. Other friends of mine, however, did
including my current boyfriend who at one time helped throw a rave called
Peace (by the way, did anyone ever go to it? I am just curious to see what
people's were of it ;).  He and these other friends of mind do not rave
anymor but consider that period in their lives to have been crucial in
their growth.  They are also among a group of people who give the current
scene a lot of crap for being too commercial, too plastic, etc.  And to a
certain extent those criticisms are vaild.  Those problems do exist in the
scene.  But that does not mean the scene does not have something to offer
or can not offer the same experiance to us now who will never know what it
eas like in the olden days.  I do want to venture that maybe what people
lik me and Shawna will experiance at our peaks in the scene won't be rave,

Maybe the
scene needs to change and look into different directions but the lessons
and values at the foundation are the same.  I have known many ravers from
the Bay Area scene and no matter what generation they have been from the
vast majority have been looking for the same things (whether thay knew it
or not) - Peace, Love, Unity,
Respect- many things may have changed over the years but not that cliche
(which should not be considered overused)!     
We need to remember that and respect that each of us has our own path and
our own time to experiment and find what we need.

Cassandra :)

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 23 May 1996 13:16:23 +0200 (MESZ)

************
this post apparently got lost on its way, so i'm sending it again.
************


 
> children is something like number 4 of the charts in germany and is played
> c o n s t a n t l y  all over the place... not that i mind...
> the video is neat, too.

after i sent this i figured that you guys over there would maybe 
appreciate some additional information on the subject 
(**don't you**???!), so here it comes.
techno or better some special branch of easily consumable techno is big in 
the german charts since about one year. 
especially something that is known as kindergarten techno never fails to 
make it at least into the top 10. it has either little underage girls 
with squeaky voices repeating some entirely stupid sentences, or  
features the voices of characters of wellknown children tv shows (to make 
it more complicated, mostly former east german ones that are 
cancelled now), like a freaky fox, a magpie and a female duck, uttering 
something that is meant all innocently but might be understood in an obscene 
way. 
yes. kindergarten techno. strange enough. this is an all german 
phenomenon, i believe.
i don't know who's responsible for the chart success of that stuff. kids 
probably.
apart from that, much pretty trancey (sp?) stuff, mostly german originated,
is around and successful. i can't say much about the music to help your 
imagination up because i'm not so first-class-beknowned in music styles, 
i mainly care wether the music is right to jump around to if i go out... 
it mostly has vocals that are drug related in some way or generally like: 
ravers of the nation, see your hands in the air, give me your hand, let's 
go to wonderful land, bla bla bla.  my impression is, that, especially 
if it comes to the aesthetics of the videos, the reality escaping aspect of 
techno and techno drugs (which is kinda strong in germany i believe) is 
particularly emphasized, not critical, but often apparently with some 
consciousness of its ambivalent quality.

so, you see, techno is quite mainstream over here. of course, our 
very own and beloved ** s c e n e ** always attempts to dissolve 
itself from the mainstream,which is pathetic on the one hand, but the source 
of innovation and development on the other. 
but, generally and alltogether, everybody is quite at ease with that fact.
however it wouldn't help much to complain.
ok. i hope, you don't find this too perverted and your world view feels 
broadened now.
i understand that the experience of techno becoming bigtime mainstream is 
new and maybe somewhat scary for you, but yuck and yikes don't help much. 
you gotta arrange with it.
have a nice day everybody. 
ulrike
 


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 24 08:06:39 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id IAA22164; Fri, 24 May 1996 08:06:39 -0700
Received: from precipice.v-site.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id IAA22151; Fri, 24 May 1996 08:06:35 -0700
Received: from ecotopia by precipice.v-site.net (8.6.10/SM-8.6.4)
	id IAA25539; Fri, 24 May 1996 08:06:10 -0700
Date: Fri, 24 May 1996 08:06:10 -0700
Message-Id: <199605241506.IAA25539@precipice.v-site.net>
X-Sender: geoffw2@v-site.net
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 2.0.3
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
From: geoffw@cybertribe.com (Geoff White)
Subject: Re: Capitalist Mentality and the Death of Alternative Community
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Folks, it's all about spaces.   Property for sale to the highest bidder,
>and what that tells us about our society.    This is not "Ethan vs. Tom &
>Stacy", but what this argument represents -- the vitality of underground
>parties vs. the dominance of commercial raves.  

Once again I don't see this as a US vs. Them but a question of personal
preference and human nature.  MOST of what you would call commercial
raves started as undergrounds, Wicked, Funky Techno, The Gathering, etc.
The promoters of these well known parties used various devices in the
past to obtain venues. The DRIVING factor in all of these parties is that
all of these groups are doing this as a primary means of revenue for the
individuals involved, i.e. they are not students, don't have compuer industry
jobs, or trust funds.  Many of them have been doing this for 4 or 5 years,
after a while, guess what? Life is pretty different at 25 then it was at 20!
(even more different at 30 then it is at 25!).  Where as before if your party
got busted, you might not make the rent on your flat and have to move in with
your mate, now if your party gets busted, your 3 year-old's play-school may
not get paid, people who were just partiers or Djs or promoters before are
parents now, they are starting families (or have some in full bloom :) Many of
them are not willing to take the risk when it comes to the little-ones future.
Remember, many of these parties are still going on because there is a market
for what is being offered and the promoters more or less deliver consistantly.
For this type of rock solid consistancy you need a reliable venue(s).


>Some of us love the coming
>together of friends in an UG; some of us love the world-class dj's and
>production of a CR.   Babies or massives, it's all good!!  But
>unfortunately, the fact is that commercialism has the nasty effect of
>crushing the underground. Since no UG promoters own a fabulous space, they
>must locate one from a third party, who's most interested in PROFIT.  When
>a higher-end promoter comes along and offers a king's ransom for a space,
>that space is forever priced out of UG range.  Another space lost.

I have to disagree here, 5 years ago when ALL raves were pretty much
underground,
a space was as good as the unbusted party that was just held there.  Most
promoters considered it a success if the party went unbusted and they were
able to get their equipment out and at least break even.  Props were given
to the promoter for being the "first" (see jsl's definition of first)
to use the space, part of the thrill (that is totally absent now) is knowing
that
a party was about to happen and not knowing where it was going to be, not
knowing _anything_ but a mappoint when you call the voice-mail, packing you
backpack and being ready to party _anyplace_ from an abandonded warehouse,
to a beach, to a deserted ice cream factory, the rush was more like "shit
this is a
deserted Nike missle base! This is an absolutely _sick_ venue!".  What has 
happened is not commercialism but the UG's loss of daring.  Not to many people
(or party goers willing to risk getting arrested just to catch a groove anymore)


>
>Commercial parties are fine, but not when their method of business
>eliminates the possibility of any OTHER kind of party.  Why did Chrysalis
>fall through for this weekend - leaving us with only FTT?  Why hasn't there
>been a Friends & Family in almost a year? Why are there so few
>undergrounds, but a plethora of massives on any given week-end?? Spaces,
>SPACES - it's all about the AFFORDABILITY of spaces. 

No, It'a all about the avialbility of Space and how much your willing to
risk in using one that you found. If you have a set of bolt-cutters, you'll
be amazed at how much space is available :) But consider, all venues have
their price, the promoter has to ask him/her-self, is s/he willing to pay?
If you have a break in and your party goes unmolested (some of you may remember
the ledgendary Equinox parties) then you get the venue for free, if you get
busted, well you may have to pay for bail, lawyers and a new sound system :)

Just how dedicated to the UG are you? :)


>This is, however, the mechanics of capitalism.  Charging what the market
>will bear, pricing everyone's services - as Mike pointed out, "consumers"
>not friends.  The ideal values of the UG -- donation of time and effort,
>respect and trust of friends, collectives working together selflessly to
>create something better for the whole -- cannot survive in an environment
>dominated by an economic mentality.   The only way an alternative community
>such as this CAN flourish is if it has its own protected space, apart from
>the dominant values of the mainstream.


As Hakim Bey has pointed out in TAZ, protected space is more or less impossible.
You may have a utopia for a period of time but sooner or later "external or
internal forces" will form to implode on it. One strategy is to realize this
and to plan for ultimate demise, i.e. constantly look for new venues, spaces,
area where your ideals can florish, this takes time, agility and commitment.

  
> In a society where greatest price
>wins, the value of community will always lose, at least as far as the owner
>of a potential space is concerned.   Since UG's are forced to compete with
>richer contenders for spaces -- the fundamental necessity for even HAVING a
>party -- well, we can see the result.  Which value will prevail in a
>society BASED on economic values?  Just count the number of undergrounds
>compared to the money-making raves.

As far as i know ther are at least two Underground parties scheduled for this
weekend (I'm sure there are other that i don't know about yet).  Rest assured
that id indeed the party is underground, it will most-likely not be listed
on SFRAVEs (wich is pretty much above ground these days )

>
>So our experiment of creating community apart from capitalist values may be
>doomed.  I guess the UG has to move even further out of commercialized
>arenas, back to beaches (Sunsets) and the forest (Tribal Future) and the
>Desert (Dune) - though even there we are still within reach of permit
>hassles, police, and vagaries of the weather.  Just think about it, people
>-- the dominance of economic rationality (evaluating everything by its
>monetary value) is SO pervasive that it is almost impossible for us to
>create a community that celebrates something different.  Something more
>human, life-affirming.  More loving.  The mainstream capitalist society
>forces us to play by their rules, and either become like them (commercial
>raves), or lose.

There is a third alternative but it take courage, you can make them irrelevant.
Throwing a successful underground party is about rising ABOVE all of these
things, that's what makes them, the people who throw them and the people who
go to them special.  You dance differently when the cops are putting on riot
gear and bringing out Dogs. You spin differently when your in an abandon
warehouse and the crowd is "going off" and the police are at the door and your
an illegal alien.  Maybe these times are gone for good, maybe it's a good thing
that they are, I don't know, but I do know that when you share events like these
with people over the years, it bonds you in a very different way then a hit
of e, or liking the same type of music, or even the same DJ's. In order to
have these kinds of parties it takes trust, the crowd has to trust the promoter
that they are dedicated to delivering the Music NO MATTER WHAT! The promoter
has to trust that the party goers will stick by them and not desert at the
first flash of a blue light (ther is safety and power in numbers :). How much is
charged at the door is totally irrelevant when you have this level of trust.
The party goers trust that the promoter will use the money wisely to throw
more killer parties and not to just pocket it and live fat), the promoter
trust the party goers to attend, police themselves and the general area and
not to bring about problems or have the maturity t realize that the goal is
to not draw any unnecessary attention.


>
>I think raves are three things - the music, the people, and the feeling.
>That incredible feeling springs, for me, from the emancipation of finding a
>public place NOT based on an economic mentality.  How amazing that is for
>us all!  How unusual!  But the music and the physical exterior of the rave
>were marketable - so, naturally (following capitalist logic) these were
>elevated to become the characteristics of  commercial "raves."  The
>unmarketable aspects are what were left behind in the UG.  You can't sell
>it, but precisely because it is not sellable means its extinction.  Under
>mainstream economic rationality, those things without a price are useless.
>If it can't be traded for money, what good is it?  Because money is the
>ultimate value.

No they are not useless, and in-fact they still exist ( but the Underground
today is smaller and deeper and less accessible then 4 years ago).  You may
have to look deeper than the parties that you know about (i.e. mentioned)

>
>The loss of this particular space is merely a symptom of a much-larger
>socio-political phenomenon, bigger than Ethan or T/S.  I fully support and
>love the concept behind the undergrounds.   It's just that with every lost
>space, I grow increasingly pessimistic of its possibility.
>Capitalism/Modernity/Industrialization has been an unbelievably powerful
>force, trampling over other cultures and ideas all over the globe.  Today
>we see a global hierarchy with the West firmly on top, and most of the
>world suffering - cultures which were thriving before the imperialism of
>the West.  Can alternative values grow right here in the heart of
>Capitalist Mentality?  When even to question our national dogma is to be
>labeled a commie, or backward, or a hippie (or a raver? :) ?  Or will the
>might of economic rationality crush our experiment?

Or will our experiment just be incorporated into the machinery (more likely)

> Ok, now that Reagan has sufficiently embarrassed me in front of the whole
> class, might as well make a 
> speech! ;)
> 
> *warning! possible spiritual subject matter ahead! Read at your own risk!*
> (seriously, if you are bothered by this kind of thing, then stop here! :)

Wow.  What can I add to that?  As many of us do, I read my e-mail
first thing upon coming to work, and I can't tell you how amazing
a difference it makes to begin a day by reading something like
that!

I think this really clarifies to me what I, personally, get out
of this SFR community of ours.

First of all, there's the reason I signed up: to get info on parties, when
they are, what's good, etc.

But increasingly, the reason why I stay subscribed to this
monstrous beast of an e-mail generator is the existence of
posts like this one, which give me much needed boosts of inspiration
randomly interspersed throughout the week.  Despite all of the
complaints of negativity that have popped up recently, I personally
still feel that the positivity and love that exists on this list
is overwhelming!

So promoter flamewars, earthquake reports, I love it all, but if we
ever ban posts like this I'm LEAVIN!  :)

Props to Shawna, BEAUTIFUL!  My only complaint is that it came on
a Friday instead of a Monday ;)


                Smiles,
                        Chin

P.S. Happy 6-month anniversary, it's my 6-month too!

hello all-

i'm in a moral dillema.  i work at st. ignatius church as a musician.  i'm
good friends with the music director and with the assistant music director,
as both of them have educated me in the ways of music and liturgy.  the
assistant director, though, is more of a personal friend.

the music director has decided to fire the assistant music director and has
asked me to replace him.  i can't decide if i should take the job and try to
work out things between be and my friend (the assistant music director) or
refuse the jub on moral grounds.

i'm caught in the middle of 2 factors: a good friend, and a job as choir
director that i have wanted for years.

HELP!!!!!  I NEED INPUT!  I'M LOST!!!!!

peace, love, and thanks-

matt l

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 24 10:50:23 1996

Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id KAA08867; Fri, 24 May 1996 10:50:21 -0700
Received: from uclink2.berkeley.edu (uclink2.berkeley.edu [128.32.136.72]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.5/8.6.12) with ESMTP id KAA02905 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 24 May 1996 10:50:20 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from krok@localhost) by uclink2.berkeley.edu (8.7.5/8.6.12) id KAA19664; Fri, 24 May 1996 10:48:12 -0700
Date: Fri, 24 May 1996 10:48:12 -0700 (PDT)
From: Kyung Rok <krok@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Some CD Reviews (NRR)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9605241050.A12057-0100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


V/A, "WALL OF PUSSY," (Wall of Sound/Pussyfoot):  9/10
_Quality_ downtempo grooves.  Lush, funky, and occasionally 
quite beautiful.  Twelve artists featured on this 70+ 
minute cd.  Import, twenty dollars.    

JEDI KNIGHTS (aka Global Communications) "New School Science" 
(Evolution):  7/10.  Star Wars meets Breakdancin'.  A little 
inconsistent.  Import, 70+ minutes, $18.  

V/A, "EARTHRISE 2" (Ninja Tune):  7/10
Another vehicle for promoting the entire Ninja stable and their 
mother.  2-CD's, $15.    

V/A, "FLEXISTENTIALISM -- The Joy of Dex" (Ninja Tune):  7/10
Read previous.  10 of the tracks on this double-cd overlap with those 
found on Earthrise 2.  No need to get both.  Get Earthrise if you'd like 
a few more spacey experimental tracks, Flexistentialism if you'd like a 
little jungle thrown in.  $15+.    

I think I may need a break from Ninja Tune.  Keep your eye 
out for releases on Wall of Sound -- they got it goin' on.     

Share Music.  Rok.     


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 24 11:18:35 1996

From: Begroovy@aol.com
Received: by emout16.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id OAA29953 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Fri, 24 May 1996 14:18:03 -0400
Date: Fri, 24 May 1996 14:18:03 -0400
Message-ID: <960524141801_120353202@emout16.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Respect, capitalism, and where are we going?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I am going to relay my own personal views and explanations to the events and
discussions of the past week or so? The first thing is respect. We try to
worship it, but we get carried away and loose grasp of it. There are alot of
people in this world out to make a buck. These people are also idolized in
the western culture, that we happen to be stuck in the middle of. Bill Gates,
Magic Johnson, Mick Jagger, Donald Trump......There are also alot of people
in our world that are not out to make a buck.These people are also idiolized
in western culture. Martin Luther King, Ghandi, Yogananda, Christ,
Mohammed.......(If someone could explain to me why I chose live examples of
one and dead examples for the other ???) Now the point I am trying to get at
is that PLUR does not just pertain to like minded individuals (ravers,
nazi's, christians, deadheads, hindi's.........). We have to understand that
we are spinning on this not so round ball through the universe. On this ball
are billions of not like minded individuals. We have two choices: a) fight
everyone; b) respect everyone's individuality.Maybe three all of the above?
Now the point at hand is repect. And the question at hand is support. Now if
Nomad's individual choice is to make lots o' cash and you personally don't
believe in this type of endeaver, then your peaceful choice is to  respect
there goal and support someone who's endeavers are less monitarilly inclined.
Fighting them is not going to change there economic goals, it is more likely
to cause them to retaliate and try to put down SFR. Now as far as Ethan goes,
I think his energy would be better used to start work on the next F&F, MAD...
and put down the arms. Ethan will gain more support from me as a party
organizer and DJ than a warrior. But that is his choice and what I can do is
respect that choice. Now to elaborate on Geoff's point about the status of
the underground. The rave situation has definately evolved out of the
underground. Look at the party listed yesterday "Organic '96" (I see trouble
brewing just in the name for starters). The performance lineup is incredible,
and a high price to fly all of these cats out here is justifiable. Now the
promoter has pulled a major boner in my opinion by stating: a) no liquids!!!,
b) no ins and outs, c) bring every thing you'll need for 12+ hours of
partying at once?? This is a very contradictory thing to me. In 12 hours
especially outside in the sun, I assume I will need approximately a gallon of
water?? I can't bring it in? Then I will have to purchase it there at $$$$
per half liter?? What is this promoters motive? He is concerned about high
quality performers but the question of high quality comforts for party goers
is up in the air? Back to Geoff and the Wicked thang. Wicked definately
started in the underground. The biggest vibe of concern I feel from Wicked is
the music. These cats want to rip it up with that mind blowing sound system.
They are also top ass DJ's they know the tunes and they know how to melt you
down with the music. All support for the wicked crew (soundcrew, DJ's etc.).
Now as far as venues go. I respect King Street's right to run there club and
treat there patrons and choose who they want in their club, any way they
want. But I do not support that venue in any way shape or form. I actually
recently went back to King Street out of respect for a great friend. He had
personally expressed a great interest in supporting an old friend that was
playing that particular Wicked. I went and repected King Street's dress code,
drug code and other various technicalities that are a part of their trip. Now
as far as Wicked and others, economic stability and state of the underground.
Economic stability and the state of status quo tends to not support change. I
came into this scene because I had outgrown the status quo in the dead scene
that was a great part of my life prior to this. It had become crusty and old
and was rehashing the past. The dead have a much larger family than wicked
and they were touring and playing to keep their economic ship of fools
afloat. The economic stability issue started to show in their performance and
choices of venues. In my opinion and from qoutes from the band, it became
apparent that they were not playing for the love of music but for the need of
economic support. This is what brought me into this scene. The love of music,
dance, and last but not least unbridled hedonism. I hope Wicked doesn't fall
into this need for economic support, but from Geoff's opinion which I respect
because he is close to the source this same thing seems to be happening. I am
curious where it'll all go from here?? Have a great day, PEACE! Cid

From: epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson)
> Survey time, kidz!  Who likes what kind(s) of candy the best at parties?
> Also, I'd like to know if there is a certain time during a party when
> people are more receptive to offers of candy.  All sugar-coated responses
> are welcome :)  - E

Apple Jolly Ranchers -- exquisite mix of citric acid and sugar.
Altoids -- "curiously strong"
Chocolate peppermints -- I especially like that the coat checker at
	the King Street Garage sells them, so you don't get that
	melted glop in your bag.
Gum of various sorts -- I brought some Stimerol (minty and licorice
	flavored) to a rave once, and it created quite a sensation.
	I also love clove gum as well, but it's hard to find!

As far as times are concerned, I'd say around 2-4am is the time I'm
most into having something in my mouth whilest I rave. It does depend
on my time of arrival, of course.

-G-

P.S. Spundae it is! I'll be wearing a laminate, and a multicolored
maroon, gold, and blue shirt that has a batik look to it. See you
there!

promoting but only because this party isn't about money. Jeff, who does
Nexus/second Chakra is throwing a free outdoor party tommorow in Peoples Park
in Berkeley. Dj's Carlos, Tony, Donald Glaude and Dreamer. I just got off the
phone with Jeff and all he kept saying was, he is tired of this,People paying
all their cash to get into some party at the same location with $2.00 water,
no bringing in your own water bottles and all that other BS. I wish everyone
could talk to him( Tommorow you can) he puts so much energy and love into his
parties, and he isn't doing it for the money. Alright, I can be talking
bullshit and everyone is going to flame me, or you can go to the party

Chin responded to Shawna's wonderful post with ....

.... increasingly, the reason why I stay subscribed to this
monstrous beast of an e-mail generator is the existence of
posts like this one, which give me much needed boosts of inspiration
randomly interspersed throughout the week.  Despite all of the
complaints of negativity that have popped up recently, I personally
still feel that the positivity and love that exists on this list
is overwhelming!.....

======================

I totally agree -- I often save the most inspirational of messages, like when
Tim (knucklehead) had a transformational experience at Madness, or Jess was on
the ceiling after Beaufiful People... and sometimes I print them out to share
with my friends who aren't on SFR ... so they can understand why I get so much
out of it....

Share that happiness! It changes people's lives ... 

yep, I know cuz I used to be a psychopathic bitch!  hehe  ; )  ...

Much love to everyone on this beautiful weekend and   :::hugs::::  (and wishes
that we get to experience Chin's fuzzy white glove again soon!)


Leslie   : )

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA26958; Fri, 24 May 1996 14:03:47 -0700
Received: from wired.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA26951; Fri, 24 May 1996 14:03:44 -0700
From: jen@hotwired.com
Received: from [204.62.132.173] (jaws.wired.com [204.62.132.173]) by wired.com (8.7.4/8.7.3) with SMTP id OAA14460; Fri, 24 May 1996 14:03:43 -0700 (PDT)
X-Sender: jen@wired.com
Message-Id: <v02140b03adcbe1624216@[204.62.132.173]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 24 May 1996 14:08:31 -0800
To: Begroovy@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Respect, capitalism, and where are we going?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The performance lineup is incredible,
>and a high price to fly all of these cats out here is justifiable. Now the
>promoter has pulled a major boner in my opinion by stating: a) no liquids!!!,
>b) no ins and outs, c) bring every thing you'll need for 12+ hours of
>partying at once?? This is a very contradictory thing to me. In 12 hours
>especially outside in the sun, I assume I will need approximately a gallon of
>water?? I can't bring it in? Then I will have to purchase it there at $$$$
>per half liter?? What is this promoters motive? He is concerned about high
>quality performers but the question of high quality comforts for party goers
>is up in the air?

Well now, it's not completely fair to blame the promoter for this.  It
could very well be that the owner/keeper of the space is insisting on no
liquids brought to the event.  This could be for a variety of reasons but
the most common ones I have encountered are 1. they want to run their own
water concession (read: money) (they can even make this a requirement to
renting the space, he who has the space makes the rules), 2. for security
reasons (read: drugs in bottles) and 3. garbage - if they provide the
drinks they can ensure no broken glass is going to end up lying on the
ground for someone to step on.  When you go to a movie or concert usually
bringing your own food and drink is not allowed.  An event this size is no
underground party so the rules will be different but placing the blame
solely on the promoter is wrong.  Yes, I'm sure there is more that can be
done to fix this common problem and I'd rather see free water everywhere
but until the rest of the world catches up we have to make do.  One thing I
would commend this promoter for is making the situation known in advance
rather than surprising us the day of.

thrivin' lika weed...... jen

I'm pleased and proud that Pacific is making an effort to suppress the
presence of nitrous at parties.  

It's that kind of crap that the woefully misinformed media can
easily use to discredit our scene (and that the police can use to bust
otherwise decent parties). 

Respect and discretion are two very important components for the continued
health of this scene, and nitrous (IMO) does not jive with either of them.

Just a reminder:

Robert Rich live on KUCI 88.9 FM in Irvine  11 PM PDT to 8 AM PDT TONITE!

If you aren't in the broadcast area.  There will be RealAudio
and CUSeeMe connections.  For more info on that, check out:

http://www.kuci.uci.edu/

Dan Bremmer said:
> 
> Here is some more specific information regarding The upcoming Robert Rich 
> Sleep Concert this friday, May 24th from 11pm until Saturday, May 25th at 
> 8am on kuci 88.9fm.
> 
> Kuci is a student and 
> volunteer run non-profit public radio station broadcasting at 200 watts 
> out of the University of California, Irvine. We reach the greater Orange 
> County area.
> 
> We should have a RealAudio broadcast as well. Check out KUCI's web site 
> at HTTP://www.kuci.uci.edu later in the week for details. We suggest you 
> set everything up previous to the broadcast at HTTP://www.RealAudio.com.
> 
> If you have any questions Email me at 9-5Superspy@kuci.org.
> 
> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
> 
> The idea behind a sleep concert is to immerse yourself into the world of
> pure sound, a continually shifting slow-motion acoustic environment, to
> remove the perceptual walls of a room and transport you into a deep
> surreal landscape. 
> 
> Robert Rich's original sleep concerts took place with a live audience, so
> the acoustics of the room could be carefully controlled. Since Robert will
> perform this concert on the radio, each listener will  control his or her
> own sound environment.  To best experience the sleep concert, you should
> pay attention to the setup of your radio. First, make sure your tuner is
> picking up the station in stereo. If you have four speakers, try putting
> one in each corner of the room, with your head in the middle. Set the
> volume lower than usual, so the sound blends in with the background.
> Headphones might work for you as well, but it may be harder to sleep with
> them, and they may fall off during the night.
> 
> The first hour or two will be slightly more active than the rest, but soon
> the music will drop away into slow foggy textures and strange ambient
> sounds. At low volumes, these textures can blend into your acoustic
> environment, creating a sort of sonic dislocation, a re-focusing of your
> perceptions. 
> 
> You can use the sound texture as a way to focus your attention onto images
> that arise out of your half-sleeping mind. In the transitions between
> sleep and wake, hypnogogic images may become intensified and more vivid.
> You may also become more aware of dreams, and you can observe the
> different layers of perception as you teeter on the edge of consciousness.
> 
> The sleep concert will last from 11:00 PM Friday night until 8:00 AM
> Saturday morning, then we will resume our normal broadcast schedule.
> 


 ,
dana

     and on for a while but have never actually posted anyting. The reason 
     I have decided to speak up is because last friday I had my car 
     vandalized and burglarized while I was at Smarties. This location has 
     been used frequently in the past two months and I have never had any 
     problems with anybody there. But last friday when I went out to my car 
     it was fucking thrashed! My car was the only car that I saw that had 
     been broken in to. Has anybody else had any problems at this location? 
     
        I would hope that this was just a random break-in but if someone 
     was looking to steal stereos I would think that other cars would have 
     been burglarized as well. Not only did they take about $1000. worth of 
     stereo equipment, they destroyed my back seats and trunk, which they 
     didn't have to do to get to the stereo and speakers.

     wondering if anybody else has had similar problems. I am beginning to 
     think that maybe someone was plotting on me in particular. I would 
     like to be able to go out and not have to worry about being robbed. I 
     can go to City Night or DV8's for that. Thanks for your time and\or

Precedence: bulk

cassandra,

I totally agree.

In my (limited) experience wityh massives, they just seem like big
techno-concerts. Plus they bug because the huge sound systems don't let ya
talk... maybe a BLOCKED OFF chill area would make it better? hmmm...

Small parties seem to attract a better crowd because no one expects a
little tiny party to be a "rave," so they just look out for the big flyers
with the fractals and E references on them because they fit better into
peoples' preconception of what a "rave" should be. probably fed by years of
media portrayal of bad raves... grumble grumble... fuckin' media... black
helicopters... grumble grumble... =)

-m.

>In my experiance they concentrated on the music and, hence, attracted
>people who understand the vibe music can make.  The more expensive
>massives - while good-attract a different vibe IMO because they are
>inherently spectacles and maybe inherently alienating because of their
>size. That doesn't mean they are bad but maybe massives then become
>something different than a rave or maybe they to become a series of
>small raves with people moving into cliques to find that bonding and
>shared experiance that I have always enjoyed at smaller raves.
>
>Cassandra
>
>P.S. Is anyone going to anything else other than FTT?:)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri May 24 17:36:24 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA15212; Fri, 24 May 1996 17:36:24 -0700
Received: from xinet.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id RAA15204; Fri, 24 May 1996 17:36:21 -0700
Received: from DialupEudora by xinet.COM via ESMTP (940816.SGI.8.6.9/931108.SGI.ANONFTP)
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com> id RAA12435; Fri, 24 May 1996 17:36:13 -0700
Message-Id: <v0300660badcc0d8374ca@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 24 May 1996 17:36:08 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Tony Rotundo <tony@xinet.COM>
Subject: SFR Haiku Contest -- JBRR
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

(JBRR = Just Barely Rave Related  :^)

It's that magic time.  Five o'clock, Friday, long weekend ahead.  Hard not
to be giddy.  Nice company supplied Liberty Ale in one hand, key board in
the other.  Why not devise a contest?  Hell, I got the prizes today.
(Can't tell ya what they are yet, maybe soon...:^)

Thus is born...

THE FIRST ANNUAL SFR HAIKU CONTEST!

You see, I love haiku.  So wonderfully compact and delicate, yet sturdy and
stable.  A cross between a poem and a limrick?  You all remember them
right?  Grade school english class.  Five-seven-five.  Here's an example:

"There once was a man from Nantucket..."

Oh shit!  Wait, *that's* a limrick.  ;^)

Here's a haiku:

House music is dope.
But then, so is acid trance?
Guess I love it all!

Get the idea?

Well, here's the assignment:  Please send me your top three haikus,
relating to raving, rave music, the rave scene, rave experiences, etc...
*I* will pick the winner ('Cause I got the prize ;^) and will announce the
results at our first SFR awards banquet!  Or sometime real soon.

Have a great (belated) weekend folks and be careful out there!!

Love ya!

Tone

P.S.  I have a funny yet macabre list of haikus relating to the Una bomber
(I didn't generate it).  Email if you'd like to see them.

Received: from tgrigsby (tgrigsby.us.dhl.com [199.41.137.104]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id SAA20880 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 24 May 1996 18:27:58 -0700
Date: Fri, 24 May 1996 18:27:58 -0700

Mime-Version: 1.0

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Re: SFR Haiku Contest -- JBRR
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>THE FIRST ANNUAL SFR HAIKU CONTEST!

An empty warehouse
Silent but for the murmurs
of happy ravers.

I turn to the crowd
place the needle on the wax
and crank up the bass.

Explosion of sound
Lasers ripping the chill night;
the Dance has begun.

Circle dancers spin.
Glo-sticks flash sick green lightening;
music warping minds.

Music pounds their souls,
ripping frenzied screams from them,
releasing, freeing.

I slow the fever
I pull the music down now
to touch their faces

Fade in faster beats
Machine gun fire snare drum
Bursting with a BOOM

Pounding again now,
the people freak to my beats...
the trance rewards them.

Your skin is prickling
I'm prying open your mind
scooping up your thoughts

Machines without souls,
the turntables play the souls
cut into vinyl.

Years of poetry
become a single moment
of hedonism.

People come to me
Hugs, sweet acceptance and joy,
Smiles, stickers, candy.

I pour it all back,
weaving tunes for my family,
my beloved friends.

Time blows soft away
Sweat, water, wet vibrations
Blasting ocean beats...

The music flows on
A stream carrying the sun
Light flowing upward

The light returning
Ravers, like stars, disappear
Just a few remain.

Finally, no more
the music fades to grey dust
Clapping my payment

An empty warehouse
Silent but for the murmurs
of happy ravers.

Precedence: bulk

Yo! Here it is - now everyone could be a star :)
the review comes from the new issue of future mag

A couple of years ago, our very own Dave Robinson asked the head of Roland
a certain Mr Kakehashi - why the hell Roland wasn't reproducing the classic=
=20
TR-808, TR-909 and TB-303 machines that were (and still are) fetching such
extortionate prices on the secondhand market. "There's surely money to be=
=20
made there," is something he tried to say before being ejected from the
building by large Japanese security guards for his impertinence.

The answer has always been that Roland would never do it due to
manufacturing costs and the lack of the original circuitry. But Dave,
bless him,must have made some kind of impression because here's the=20
Roland MC-303 Groovebox - seemingly a TB-303, TR-808 and TR-909 in a
box,with loads of other features for less than 600 quid. A Roland
climb down? The end of high prices. The answer to techno musicians'dream?

An about-face? Roland has not backed down completely. The MC-303
may have rather stunning retro looksand sounds, but it is very much a 90s'
machine with digital technology at its core and features to match, such as
an 8-track sequencer and a wealth of patterns. Analogue purists will
doubtless kick it into touch without even auditioning it. Ah, the fools -
they will miss out on one of the most creative performance tools yet
released...

The Groovebox is essentially a pattern-based instrument: press Play
and 8-part complete arrangements will kick into action. If your only
experience of patterns is the kind of Bossonova stuff found on keyboards
with speakers, you may need to unscrew your brain and flip it over because
these are patterns you will not have heard before - except down at your=20
local nose-bleed techno house.=20

There is everything from house to jungle, acid jazz to hip-hop:
120 patterns in all and 300 variations on each. Using them could not
be simpler: Press Play and use the eight buttons above the screen to
mute parts for those classic drop-outs or ecstasy-inducing builds. And,
if you so wish, you can use the black-and-white keys below to play
melodies over the top.

It is, of course, easy to drop in variations of the patterns or swap
to completely different patterns during real-time performances, but this
is using the MC-303 at its very simplest level. The really neat stuff
starts when you select parts of the accompaniments for some real-time
manipulation. For example, you all know those piercing, resonating
basslines found in so much techno music. Well, on the MC-303, it's=20
simply a matter of selecting the bass part and twirling the resonance
control. Press Record and all that twiddling of knobs will be recorded=20
to a user pattern. And it's not just the bass parts that you can apply
it to: chucking the rhythms or leads through the resonance and cutoff=20
will achieve some bizarre effects. Great results - it can be tempting to
apply this to everything and end up with all sorts of fighting squeals.
Use care: sometimes less is more.

So what of these patterns? They are all genuine reproductions of what=20
is moving and shaking the floors of clubland in many areas of techno
music (although leaning heavily to the house end of the spectrum) with
only one or two acid jazz exceptions. It's not surprising that they are
so good, though, as many of the leading DJs from around the world were
called in for their input. And you needn't worry too much about dance=20
fashions because as they change you can emulate them yourself by
creating new patterns from scratch: rhythms, leads, basslines,=20
everything in fact...

Recording the patterns together is easy, but if you want to switch
between them in real time, go to PTN Set and assign the ones you want
to each of the 16 keys. This saves you from having to dial through all
the patterns to find the ones you want next by giving you instant access
to them across the black-and-white keys.

Kickin' The MC-303 is not just an accompaniment module or sound module.
You can link it up to a sequencer in a 'normal' sound module situation,=20
but the real benefits lie in its performance capabilities. As well as
the knob-twiddling stuff described above, the black-and-white keys can=20
be used for complete 'on the fly' performances. If you enter the RPS mode
you can assign each of these 16 keys to rhythms, fills, drop ins,
effects, basslines and leads. Press one button for the rhythm, add the
bass, build those fills and stab in some effects for instant tracks.=20

The obvious use is for the DJ mixing between tracks or composing on the
move while judging crowd reaction, although with 16 sets of these sounds=20
(all user definable), careful timing and variation between patterns, it
would probably be possible to play a whole set with just the MC-303 and=20
without a single record. Another great feature is that these riffs are
also programmable, so your own compositions can be broken down and
played in real time.

The sounds that make up the patterns are excellent dance classics.
Alongside the faithful reproductions of the 909, 303 and 808, the other
sounds that make up the 448 on-board tones consist of various pads and
variations on the basslines. There are other Roland favourites like
Junos and Jupiter, as well as noises and hits. All the sounds can be
fattened up with the on-board effects processors - a surprising but
welcome feature. Most of what you get is high in quality and there is
plenty to inspire you to create your own accompaniments -an essential=20
future operation since you'll be hearing these preset on-board patterns
everywhere!

Let's get one thing straight before the inevitable concluding remarks:=20
the MC-303 is not really intended to be a straight TR-808, TR-909 and
TB-303. The controls on those machines have not all been reproduced,=20
and analogue listeners will be able to detect some differences -
digital can be too perfect, after all. Having said that, 99% of us=20
wouldn't be able to notice much of a difference if it was put up=20
against the originals in a comparison test.=20

For anyone who is fed up with sampling and wants more control but
doesn't want to pay over the odds, the MC-303 is essential. At the=20
very least you could use it as a high-quality vintage tone module,
but you'd be missing most of the point, because the MC-303 is really
an instant techno machine, and the key word is performance. One button
press will turn you into a DJ monster from resonance hell. Producing
original dance classics is also a doddle - almost too easy.=20

Rest assured, the next time Dave Robinson runs into Mr Kakehashi he has
been primed to ask about completely reworking the Jupiter 8, the SH-101,
the Juno 60...=20

Number of tones 448=20
     Drums12 sets=20
     Multitimbrality 16 parts (8 main, 8 RPS)=20
     Polyphony 28 voices=20
     Effects Reverb, delay, chorus and flange=20
     Sequencer 8 tracks, 10 songs=20
     Patterns 120 standard, 200 RPS, 50 user
     (14,000 notes), 300 variations=20
     RPS sets 30=20
     Pattern sets 20

     Cost =A3565=20
     From Roland UK, Atlantic Close,
     Swansea Enterprise Park, Swansea,=20
     West Glamorgan SA7 9FJ.=20
     Tel: 01792 702701=20

Features 100%
      Ease of Use / Setting up 90%
      Quality of results 90%
      Value for money 90%=20

      Overall rating 93%

                                       VERDICT:
                                       A dance essential.
                                       That's it!=20



     =A31,499 from Roland UK, Atlantic Close,=20
     Swansea Enterprise Park,
     Swansea,=20
     West Glamorgan SA7 9FJ. Tel: 01792 702701

     =20

        Analogue Heaven <analogue@hyperreal.com>, AMEBA <ameba@netcom.com>
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9605242204.A26744-0100000@bw>

>=20
> The obvious use is for the DJ mixing between tracks or composing on the
> move while judging crowd reaction, although with 16 sets of these sounds=
=20
> (all user definable), careful timing and variation between patterns, it
> would probably be possible to play a whole set with just the MC-303 and=
=20
> without a single record. Another great feature is that these riffs are
> also programmable, so your own compositions can be broken down and
> played in real time.
>=20
> The sounds that make up the patterns are excellent dance classics.
> Alongside the faithful reproductions of the 909, 303 and 808, the other
> sounds that make up the 448 on-board tones consist of various pads and
> variations on the basslines. There are other Roland favourites like
> Junos and Jupiter, as well as noises and hits. All the sounds can be
> fattened up with the on-board effects processors - a surprising but
> welcome feature. Most of what you get is high in quality and there is
> plenty to inspire you to create your own accompaniments -an essential=20
> future operation since you'll be hearing these preset on-board patterns
> everywhere!
>=20
> Let's get one thing straight before the inevitable concluding remarks:=20
> the MC-303 is not really intended to be a straight TR-808, TR-909 and
> TB-303. The controls on those machines have not all been reproduced,=20
> and analogue listeners will be able to detect some differences -
> digital can be too perfect, after all. Having said that, 99% of us=20
> wouldn't be able to notice much of a difference if it was put up=20
> against the originals in a comparison test.=20
>=20
> For anyone who is fed up with sampling and wants more control but
> doesn't want to pay over the odds, the MC-303 is essential. At the=20
> very least you could use it as a high-quality vintage tone module,
> but you'd be missing most of the point, because the MC-303 is really
> an instant techno machine, and the key word is performance. One button
> press will turn you into a DJ monster from resonance hell. Producing
> original dance classics is also a doddle - almost too easy.=20
>=20
> Rest assured, the next time Dave Robinson runs into Mr Kakehashi he has
> been primed to ask about completely reworking the Jupiter 8, the SH-101,
> the Juno 60...=20
>=20
> Number of tones 448=20
>      Drums12 sets=20
>      Multitimbrality 16 parts (8 main, 8 RPS)=20
>      Polyphony 28 voices=20
>      Effects Reverb, delay, chorus and flange=20
>      Sequencer 8 tracks, 10 songs=20
>      Patterns 120 standard, 200 RPS, 50 user
>      (14,000 notes), 300 variations=20
>      RPS sets 30=20
>      Pattern sets 20
>=20
>      Cost =A3565=20
>      From Roland UK, Atlantic Close,
>      Swansea Enterprise Park, Swansea,=20
>      West Glamorgan SA7 9FJ.=20
>      Tel: 01792 702701=20
>=20
> Features 100%
>       Ease of Use / Setting up 90%
>       Quality of results 90%
>       Value for money 90%=20
>=20
>       Overall rating 93%
>=20
>                                        VERDICT:
>                                        A dance essential.
>                                        That's it!=20
>=20
>=20
>=20
>      =A31,499 from Roland UK, Atlantic Close,=20
>      Swansea Enterprise Park,
>      Swansea,=20

Finally!  CRASH WORSHIP have set their dates.  Below are those of likely
interest to sfraves subscribers:

June 15 World Beat Center San Diego, CA

June 20 TBA Hollywood, CA
June 25 The Trocadero San Fransisco, CA 415-995-4600 #2356
June 27 John Henry's Eugene, OR 541-342-3358

I'll be at the SF show for sure and possibly LA as well.  I don't know
what's up with these weeknight dates...more may be added.  Just in case
this rings no bells, I'll reprise my remarks from the last time the topic
arose here:

>...leaving all this, and indeed *everything*,
>behind--beyond rave, rock, rap, the Dead, Burning Man, sex, drugs,
>bungee-jumping naked from collapsing bridges, or whatever other paltry
>thrills you may turn to for your occasional tot of ecstasy, that little
>electric taste of The Edge--there is CRASH WORSHIP.  You want to talk about
>temporary autonomous zones?  A Crash Worship show is, without exception or
>reservation, the farthest remove from everyday reality, from normality,
>from life itself as we know it, I've ever found.  A Crash Worship show is
>not a place, not an event--it's an entity, a single seething fusion of
>audience and performers that can grow to be invested with an awesome, even
>terrifying, elemental force.  I've felt myself dissolved, become a single
>swarming cell within the greater being, catalyzed by the power and
>intensity of the performance.  Really, there are no words.  It's just WAY
>OUT.

Yeah...so if you want to get crazy, come on down.  Disposable clothing a must.

anarch@scruznet.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat May 25 04:07:50 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id EAA03000; Sat, 25 May 1996 04:07:50 -0700
Received: from orion.sfsu.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id EAA02991; Sat, 25 May 1996 04:07:47 -0700
