Date: Sat, 25 May 1996 04:07:42 -0700 (PDT)
From: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
X-Sender: star@orion
To: Nancy <nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Capitalist Mentality and the Death of Alternative Community
In-Reply-To: <v02130501adcaaa7886ae@[128.32.160.58]>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960525030333.26011G-100000@orion>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Dear Friends & Family,

	While I share Nancy's concern expressed in the post below that 
commercial bookings may price some spaces out of the range of promoters of 
underground events, let us never forget that in reality there is *no shortage 
of spaces*, in San Francisco or anywhere else, suitable for a party.
	On any given night, most of the locations at which parties have 
been thrown in this town at one time or another will be empty!
	It strains credibility to suggest that all the owners of 
those empty spaces are holding out for the big fees of the commercial 
promoters rather than booking the smaller parties when they face a choice 
between a small fee or nothing. 
	May I suggest that the real cause of the lack of available spaces 
lies elsewhere?
	One, many owners don't want raves happening on their property, not 
because they dislike ravers, but because they are worried about 
liability.  The fact that they have this worry is because we have a legal 
system which allows people to avoid responsibility for their own actions.
	If someone suffers an overdose at a space, or a problem similarly 
outside the control of the owner arises, our wonderful laws allow the 
victim or the victom's relatives to sue the owner for lack of oversight!  No 
wonder people with a lot to lose would rather err on the side of caution and 
just not allow events to happen in the first place.	
	The other main reason spaces are scarce is of course the 
police.  It isn't only outdoor parties that get hassled about permits, as 
we all well know.  How many spaces are virtually bust-free?  Not many, from 
what I can tell.  Since we give promoters flack when their parties are 
busted -- rather than directing our anger where IMHO it rightfully ought to 
go -- naturally many of them seek to use only secure spaces. 
	Promoters may compete with each other for these spaces, but what 
they're fighting over is the 10% left over after the law has made the other 90% 
risky propositions at best.  What we see at work here is not the mechanics 
of capitalism, but an artificial scarcity caused by a restriction of 
supply.  
	Anyone who feels cramped for space should first and foremost be 
pissed about the unavailability of that 90%.  

Rave on,
				<<< Starchild >>>


My computer tells me that on Thu, 23 May 1996, Nancy shared:

> Folks, it's all about spaces.   Property for sale to the highest bidder,
> and what that tells us about our society.    This is not "Ethan vs. Tom &
> Stacy", but what this argument represents -- the vitality of underground
> parties vs. the dominance of commercial raves.  Some of us love the coming
> together of friends in an UG; some of us love the world-class dj's and
> production of a CR.   Babies or massives, it's all good!!  But
> unfortunately, the fact is that commercialism has the nasty effect of
> crushing the underground. Since no UG promoters own a fabulous space, they
> must locate one from a third party, who's most interested in PROFIT.  When
> a higher-end promoter comes along and offers a king's ransom for a space,
> that space is forever priced out of UG range.  Another space lost.
> 
> Commercial parties are fine, but not when their method of business
> eliminates the possibility of any OTHER kind of party.  Why did Chrysalis
> fall through for this weekend - leaving us with only FTT?  Why hasn't there
> been a Friends & Family in almost a year? Why are there so few
> undergrounds, but a plethora of massives on any given week-end?? Spaces,
> SPACES - it's all about the AFFORDABILITY of spaces.  So when a space is
> finally located and much energy and time is devoted to it, only to have it
> also disintegrate because of folks who claim to support the underground, a
> reaction such as Ethan's is understandable, IMO.
> 
> This is, however, the mechanics of capitalism.  Charging what the market
> will bear, pricing everyone's services - as Mike pointed out, "consumers"
> not friends.  The ideal values of the UG -- donation of time and effort,
> respect and trust of friends, collectives working together selflessly to
> create something better for the whole -- cannot survive in an environment
> dominated by an economic mentality.   The only way an alternative community
> such as this CAN flourish is if it has its own protected space, apart from
> the dominant values of the mainstream.   In a society where greatest price
> wins, the value of community will always lose, at least as far as the owner
> of a potential space is concerned.   Since UG's are forced to compete with
> richer contenders for spaces -- the fundamental necessity for even HAVING a
> party -- well, we can see the result.  Which value will prevail in a
> society BASED on economic values?  Just count the number of undergrounds
> compared to the money-making raves.
> 
> So our experiment of creating community apart from capitalist values may be
> doomed.  I guess the UG has to move even further out of commercialized
> arenas, back to beaches (Sunsets) and the forest (Tribal Future) and the
> Desert (Dune) - though even there we are still within reach of permit
> hassles, police, and vagaries of the weather.  Just think about it, people
> -- the dominance of economic rationality (evaluating everything by its
> monetary value) is SO pervasive that it is almost impossible for us to
> create a community that celebrates something different.  Something more
> human, life-affirming.  More loving.  The mainstream capitalist society
> forces us to play by their rules, and either become like them (commercial
> raves), or lose.
> 
> I think raves are three things - the music, the people, and the feeling.
> That incredible feeling springs, for me, from the emancipation of finding a
> public place NOT based on an economic mentality.  How amazing that is for
> us all!  How unusual!  But the music and the physical exterior of the rave
> were marketable - so, naturally (following capitalist logic) these were
> elevated to become the characteristics of  commercial "raves."  The
> unmarketable aspects are what were left behind in the UG.  You can't sell
> it, but precisely because it is not sellable means its extinction.  Under
> mainstream economic rationality, those things without a price are useless.
> If it can't be traded for money, what good is it?  Because money is the
> ultimate value.
> 
> The loss of this particular space is merely a symptom of a much-larger
> socio-political phenomenon, bigger than Ethan or T/S.  I fully support and
> love the concept behind the undergrounds.   It's just that with every lost
> space, I grow increasingly pessimistic of its possibility.
> Capitalism/Modernity/Industrialization has been an unbelievably powerful
> force, trampling over other cultures and ideas all over the globe.  Today
> we see a global hierarchy with the West firmly on top, and most of the
> world suffering - cultures which were thriving before the imperialism of
> the West.  Can alternative values grow right here in the heart of
> Capitalist Mentality?  When even to question our national dogma is to be
> labeled a commie, or backward, or a hippie (or a raver? :) ?  Or will the
> might of economic rationality crush our experiment?
> 
> No Chrysalis this week-end - hmm, you decide.
> 
> Love, Nancy
> 
> P.S.  I'm unsubbing tomorrow <SOB!>, so I probably won't get to your
> responses, if any.  But I do think it's something for us as a society to
> consider, whether manifested as a "rave promoter squabble" or as global
> politics.  Because they do share the same, fundamental basis.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
>

listening to this was incredible. I tuned in via realaudio at 11 and =
they were a running a little bit behind, so I got to hear Rob Rich and =
the station DJ talk for a while about his music. I was listening with my =
window open, and the sounds of the crickets and frogs outside seemed to =
enter the room and become a part of the sound environment, while it =
seemed that other sounds from the program were located far beyond the =
walls of my room... closing my eyes, the walls fell away...

unfortunately, I have to march in a marching band in a parade this =
morning, so I had to get up at 7:30 and turn this off, but the Sleep =
Concert was GREAT! this was the first time I had ever used realaudio to =
listen to a live broadcast stream, and it worked extremely well. it was =
great to be able to listen to Irvine's college radio station from up =
here in northern california.

>> Ok, who works at SUN MICRO SYSTEMS?
>> 
>> The shippers at SUN are inserting flyers for this party with the pallets of
>> "Sun Sparc Stations" I've received today 5/23/96.  I must say it was a
>> surprise to see the flyer.  I guess that is one way to get people to go to
>> your party.

>Actually, the filers for the really cool parties are tucked in with the 
>Ultras.  Something about a daytime party called "Solaris?"

Yeah, I went to  this party. THey said there will be no waiting lines
getting in because they were multithreaded (i guess this means people
wearing cool clothes). But then all the sudden, reality just freezes,
and all the bag/ticket checkers and packet filters just stop dead in
their tracks and the line backs up for miles. Then this gang of paunchy
hirsute wizards and monks  suddenly appeared chanting "the network is
the computer, the computer is down" while smacking themselves over the
head with a Sparc IPX .... finally they managed to find the circuit
breakers to reboot the party. 

The voicemail said it was a huge abandoned wherehouse with lots of room
to grow -- but when we got in, the space, even though it only contained
a few users, was completely packed. We went to the concession counter
and they said you need to buy our herbal perfomance enhancing RAM -- at
least 32Megabytes more -- because we have lots of important features
that you the customer need and want! After all, Solaris is the result
of years and years of trying to be 100%-buzzword compatible, and that
kind of PLUR doesn't come cheap. But at $1600.00 for their herbal
boost, we found that a bit steep so we just huddled in the corner
eating our "vi" pops and "rogue" candybars while this huge pulsating
kernel bloated in the center of wherehouse sucking up all the free
resources.

I also heard they had cappucino machines all around that said "come get
your java -- it's free, it's secure, it's safe, and everybody's doin'
it". People seemed awestruck by the little dancing bitmap figurines and
the fact that the letters on the flyers would change fonts and bounce
around illegibly, even though that's considered mundane
kindergarten-level computer graphics and has also been proven to be
useless in promoting a good vibe at a party.

Afterwards, I heard that the people that drank Java got very sick from
a stomach virus, and that it wasn't even very good coffee. It's all in
the beans you see -- and you just can't make good coffee from C++
beans, no matter what James Gosling says.

I had much more fun at this underground party called "Linux" and I only
had to bring food donations, instead of wasting $20.00 on some
overhyped piece of commercial crap...

-- NPM.

> children is something like number 4 of the charts in germany and is played
> c o n s t a n t l y  all over the place... not that i mind...
> the video is neat, too.

after i sent this i figured that you guys over there would maybe 
appreciate some additional information on the subject 
(**don't you**???!), so here it comes.
techno or better some special branch of easily consumable techno is big in 
the german charts since about one year. 
especially something that is known as kindergarten techno never fails to 
make it at least into the top 10. it has either little underage girls 
with squeaky voices repeating some entirely stupid sentences, or  
features the voices of characters of wellknown children tv shows (to make 
it more complicated, mostly former east german ones that are 
cancelled now), like a freaky fox, a magpie and a female duck, uttering 
something that is meant all innocently but might be understood in an obscene 
way. 
yes. kindergarten techno. this is an all german phenomenon, i believe.
i don't know who's responsible for the chart success of that stuff. kids 
probably.
apart from that, much pretty trancey (sp?) stuff, mostly german originated,
is around and successful. i can't say much about the music to help your 
imagination up because i'm not so first-class-beknowned in music styles, 
i mainly care wether the music is right to jump around to if i go out... 
it mostly has vocals that are drug related in some way or generally like: 
ravers of the nation, see your hands in the air, give me your hand, let's 
go to wonderful land, bla bla bla.  my impression is, that, especially 
if it comes to the aesthetics of the videos, the reality escaping aspect of 
techno and techno drugs (which is kinda strong in germany i believe) is 
particularly emphasized, not critical, but often apparently with some 
consciousness of its ambivalent quality.

so, you see, techno is quite mainstream over here. of course, our 
very own and beloved ** s c e n e ** always attempts to dissolve 
itself from the mainstream,which is pathetic on the one hand, but the source 
of innovation and development on the other. 
but, generally and alltogether, everybody is quite at ease with that fact.
however it wouldn't help much to complain.
ok. i hope, you don't find this too perverted and your world view feels 
broadened now.
have a nice day everybody.
ulrike

> same band that had an album out a few years ago called "Change The 
> Weather", with the singles "Underneath The Radar" and "Stand Up"?

Yes.

> 	If they are, when did they change their sound and become the 
> darlings of the dance world?

About three (?) years ago they released a track called "Skyscraper, I Love
You", a very dubby, bass-heavy song with vocals tha some people didn't
like but I did.  After that came the album Dubnobasswithmyheadman, which
was extremely good, and critics and DJ's liked it a lot.  I think they had
some personnel changes between their older sound and this newer sound -
I'm not sure if their lead guy Darren Emerson was a part of the band back
then or not.  But yes, they are the same band, in lineage at least.

After I got off work last night at 11:30pm, I popped a techno tape in 
and headed home toward the bay bridge to SF. In a short while I was 
dancing in my car while I was driving by bopping my head and moving my 
arms.

When I got to the toll booth I forgot to lower my music which is 
something I usually do, so I don't blast the toll booth worker.  
Another car must have either heard my music or seen me dancing because 
a little ways up the bridge I see this car filled with people with one 
guy hanging out the window with his fist in the air waving at me and 
shouting WOOOHOOO!

This brought a bigger smile than I already had, as I felt that 
increased special rave connection as I watched the car most likely 
filled with ravers heading off to a rave with the beautiful SF skyline 
all lit up in the backround.
By any chance was that anybody on this list?
If so thanks.

See you all at tribal future,
:)
peter

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat May 25 13:11:39 1996

Received: from well (mh2o@well.com [206.15.64.10]) by mh1.well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id NAA07712 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sat, 25 May 1996 13:11:34 -0700
Date: Sat, 25 May 1996 13:11:32 -0700 (PDT)
From: Maureen Garrett <mh2o@well.com>
Subject: Pac-a-bowl Review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <86@spinback.demon.co.uk>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9605251209.A12512-0100000@well>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Last Thursday night some friends and I finally had to check out this party..
I had heard so many 'interesting' things about it over the past several 
months..

Walking in the front door, my friends in their mid to late twenties 
commented what a young crowd... Avg. age 15-19.. This leads to a moment 
from a conv. in the woman's john.. a 17 year old asked,"I don't mean to 
be rude or anything, I have been coming here since the beginning and I 
have never seen you before, and you seem old for this."  I responded, 
with a big smile, "What do you invision yourself doing at my age?"  We 
had an 'interesting' conversation...She liked my taste in 
lipstick...called Lust..lilac and shinny..  ;-)...

We tried to bowl...but the lane where we chose to hang was 
malfunctioning...!no doubt!..Later on we went back to the same spot since 
there was room to sit, and watched the bowlers...we laughed and laughed as
two people assaulted the pins together in the same lane, as one young man 
threw the ball with such velocity that I was certain something would break,
as pins somehow found themselves six feet in front of the reset 
mechanism, as ravers were using many balls to knock other balls back into the
end of the wall thing ( I really don't know what the hell you call bowling
devices  ;-) )  it was just pure madness...  I mean, I guess the owner 
must 'know' his place is being pretty trashed...The balls were in bad 
shape, etc....  my guess is that it won't be long before it is closed 
down and becomes something else...And as many have pointed out, the 
sounds of bowling didn't interfere with the music...

Next, we also tried to play pool but after entering the pool room for 
one minute and smoking 2 packs of cigarettes, I just had to leave... 
Los Angeles smog on a bad day...

The alley has a nice bar, beautiful ambient music (didnt' recognize the 
DJ)..free water..

**Music....excellent!!!!!!!!!!!  Tracy was great and when Carlos came 
on...I realized how much I had missed him for I have not heard him spin 
for over 1.5 years...just don't seem to frequent the parties where he 
spins...  ghod I love what he does....his energy, his always present smile...


At the time we were leaving the cops were arriving...  

I also noticed lots of heavy security throughout the night...would I 
return to this party in the Haight...  nope, glad I went...yup..regrets, 
that I didn't have a video camera for the bowling.....   --Mau

yet, I'm sending out this message is from the three of us:

On Friday night, as most of you may know, the Pier location for Open 
Space got busted.  In Touch's last party got busted and if you remember, 
the DELI was where the party was moved to.  Because of lame rave rumors, 
Tom and Stacey were suspected to have been the people that busted the 
first one that time.  Now we KNOW it was the people at the DELI *BOTH 
TIMES*, since they're on some kind of trip and want to make as much as 
possible off the rave scene.  If you don't throw your party there, they 
will bust it if they can...  Our apologies go out to Tom and Stacey for 
this...

but if for any reason any of them are still around to run the place in 
the next couple of weeks, I suggest BOYCOTTING it (like I had to tell you 
that).  I don't think they'll be able to have parties much longer, 
because they've just pissed the WRONG people off.  If you have any 
questions for me, Mikey, or Karl, please send them to this email and I'll

emails soon, so they'll be on here in a while...

Hello, everyone, the children are out playing again without mom present.
Please read carefully!!!!!!!



>WARNING!!!!!!!  INTERNET VIRUS  The FCC released a warning last Wednesday 
>concerning a matter of major importance to any regular user of the Internet.  
>Apparently a new computer virus has been engineered by a user of AMERICA ON 
>LINE that is unparalleled in its destructive capability.  Other more 
>well-known viruses such as "Stoned", "Airwolf" and "Michaelangelo" are pale in 
>comparison to the prospectus of this newest creation by a warped mentality.  
>What makes this virus so terrifying, said the FCC, is the fact that no program 
>needs to be exchanged for a new computer to be infected. It can be spread 
>through the existing e-mail systems of the Internet. Once a Computer is 
>infected, one of several things can happen.  If the computer contains a hard 
>drive, it will most likely be destroyed.  If the program is not stopped, the 
>computer's processor will be placed in an nth-complexity infinite binary loop 
>- which can severly damage the processor if left running that way too long.  
>Unfortunately, most novice computer users will not realize what is happening 
>until it is far too late.  Luckily, there is one sure means of detecting what 
>is now known as the "Good Times": virus.  It always travels to new computers 
>the same way in a text e-mail message with the subject line reading "Good 
>Times". Avoiding infection is easy once the file has been received simply by 
>NOT READING IT!  The act of loading the file into the mail server's ASCII 
>buffer causes the "Good Times" mainline program to initialize and execute.  
>The program is higly intelligent -- it will send copies of itself to everyone 
>whose e-mail address is contained in a receive-mail file or a sent-mail file, 
>if it can find one.  It will then proceed to trash the computer it is running 
>on.  The bottom line there is:  if you receive a file with the subject line 
>"Good Times", delete it immediately!  Do not read it"  Rest assured that 
>whoever's name was on the "Form" line was surely struck by the virus.  Warn 
>your friends and local system users of this newest threat to the Internet!  It 
>could save a lot of time and money.  Could you pass this along to your global 
>mailing list as well?
>
>George H. Bowers
>Vice President for information Systems
>University of Maryland Medical System
>410-328-2579  (fax) 410-328-0572
>gbowers@umms_itg.ab.umd.edu
>

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Well hey!  There's one more day of weekend!

So I just wanted to share my first brush with the awesome energy in this 
bay area scene since moving here two weeks ago--

I had heard great things about the Chrysalis party, so I was bummed when 
it was cancelled, and I would not get to meet Shawna this weekend 
afterall!   =)  Plus, my crazy Friday kept me from meeting up with the 
South Bay sfravers Friday night (oops)!!

So it was with great pleasure that several friends and I spent the 
afternoon yesterday basking in some really nice vibes at the party on 
Panther Beach near Santa Cruz, and churned out some energy of our own as 
we dug little dance patterns into the sand at our feet.  There were some 
wonderful house beats, a very diverse and down-to-earth crowd (geez- it 
felt like a Dead show!), and most of all the ocean which added such a 
rich, wonderful undertone-- harmonious mother nature padding out the 
crisp sounds of the music!   Now I know what's missing from those 
beautiful Rocky Mountain parties I just left!   So, there was this sweet 
spot where the sound was caught by the overhanging rock that makes that 
cool natural arch, and the hyper little birds that live in holes in the 
rock were groovin' in sets of four to the speakers!   If the promoters 
are on this list, THANK YOU for a wonderful chillspace yesterday!

In fact, we had so much fun, we ended up being shamefully late getting 
back north, and thus didn't use our tickets to Wigstock!  The money 
went to AIDS charities, so not using the tix was no biggie except for 
missing all the fun dancing with the drag queens!  If anybody went, 
please tell us how it was!

Anyway, time to send out happybeams to everyone on this list--
PLUR
John

hey randy.
your email _is_ the virus. A mimetic one. Like chain letters, and pyramid
scheme letters, _you_ are the host, and are convinced to reproduce the
virus (the warning) and send it out.
It is cool of you to try and let people know that there might be a problem,
but in this case you have actually spread it :)
a cathcy phrase or a pop tune is also a mimetic virus. you whisle it, and
it sinks into someone elses brain.
I used to have a better URL for info about it, but its someplace to start...
http://www.lucifer.com/virus/alt.memetics/what.is.html

"Memetics is to media as genetics is to biology."  -FringeWare Review

As a student of memetic engineering, I've assembled a collection of usefull 
links regarding memes and memetics, from tutorials to examples, etc.

Point Netscape (2.0 if ya got it) to:  http://myhouse.com/pronoia/
and choose the "ways and memes" button.  The word "memes" is hot, and 
takes you to the resources I'm ranting about!   Have fun..

I'm logging in from my mom's house in Washington, DC, where I grew up.
Rather than the usual heat'n'humid smogfest of early summer, the weather
is unexplainably Oregon-like.  Cold and drizzly today, very nice and sunny
yesterday.

I went to Buzz on Friday night for a while, Scott Henry was playing
old-skool
hahdcoah techno a la 1992, a guy named Ed Bailey was doing housier stuff
in the smaller room.  Buzz is two or three garages stitched together into
a fairly large but, I am afraid, vibeless club with tons of bored-looking
kids milling around.  I didn't think it was bad or good, more or less the
same as the big parties in Portland actually.

It's down by the Navy Yard Metro stop, where I had never been before despite
living in DC for years and years.  There are several other clubs in a two
or three block area, and they divide neatly into straight and gay, white
and non-white.  Very weird to see such self-segregation in such a small
area.  It was all pretty relaxed and lots of booming bass as I walked
around the neighborhood checking the scene :)

Yesterday I went record shopping and spent a good long while at 12" Dance
Records off Dupont Circle -- they have definitely improved their buying
for house (still no jungle though) and I found quite a few good tracks.

Last night, Wicked played in a tent behind Tracks, one of the other clubs
near the Capital Ballroom.  I actually had a pretty good time and stayed
until about 5:30.  I caught just the end of a local DJ's set (didn't hear
his name), then the order was Jeno-Garth-Markie and I think Thomas was
being rounded up to go on after I left, with Scott Henry and Lieven 
following into the morning inside the club.

A pretty good crowd, not too packed, but the dancefloor never really got
going and there was a more or less constant set of circles happening
through most of the proceedings.  Jeno had one of the better sets I've
heard him play recently, a nice jazzy overtone but still straight down
the chute.  Garth pulled the short straw, unfortunately, after starting
a very nice jazzy-housey set the sound crapped out on one side and it
took the techs more than an hour to get it working properly.  Markie
did his usual eclectic walk through things, and then it was time for me
to go.  Hadn't been to a Wicked since the Doc one in January at King St
in SF (I dropped in very briefly last month but didn't stay), so this turned
out rather nicely and the guys seemed very relaxed.  They played St. Louis
Friday night and the (S)Limelight in NYC tonight.

I'm off to New York City early Tuesday morning.  Have a couple of meetings
and I'll also be doing some record shopping.  

I ran into Dan the Love Man at Wicked last night, but not too many others.

see y'all!

phred

I know all you hardcore underground ravers might cringe, but I have to say
that last night's Spundaes was an awesome party.  Even at 1015 Folsom!

I did not see any laminates :-(  Where were you all hiding?  I had extra
tickets that I wanted to share with some of y'all, but noone answered my
calls, "Anyone here from the SFRaves listserv?"  Damn near made a fool of
myself.

Thought the set by John Aquaviva was really good.  Danced hard to whoever
was in the basement.

Was leary about the crowd b4 coming, because of all the general circulation
ads, but the crowd was 98% smiles & hugs.  Thanks to my knowing compatriots
on this very list, I was having an absolute ball giving away spearmint gum
and apple Jolly Ranchers.  They didn't sell Charms Blow-Pops at Safeway.

So, if you are one of the girlfriends who let me hug your boyfriend, if
your one of the boyfriends that didn't mind I gave your girlfriend a
backrub, if your one of the MANY people who threw me a humungous smile
back, thanks for making it an awesome night out for me.

area.  The thing is, Troy overheard them talking to the party organizers 
and they said there wasn't anything they could see wrong with what we 
were doing, but we should stop it anyways.  No complaints, it wasn't 
bothering anyone, we should just stop.  So it stopped for an hour, 
then they were gone and the music started again.:)

>ROOM this weekend & i don't know by who .... man, i HATE the human race

That really sucks!  I'm sorry that happened.  Were these "friends" of
strangers that were in your room?  You cannot deny that some people can be
or are assholes.  So sometimes it's necessary to take precausions such as
putting away your cd's when you have many people at your place or making
sure there is nothing visible in your car when you park in the city or even
locking your car doors. 
 
Doesn't it suck that we have to do these things?  Why can't people respect
others and what they own?  If someone is not satisfied with what they own,
maybe they should do something about it such as get a better job or
sacrifice other things to attain what they want.  Or better yet, make an
effort to change their values to center less around materialistic things. 
 
I'm sure glad nobody can steal my Love from me!  If everything I own is
taken from me... 
             it will always remain. 
 
--erik

spotted at a Harmony Party a few months back.  First sighted at Burning Man
95.  Apparently moved out to SF earlier this year and currently living
somewhere therein with significant other.  If you have seen or heard from
this individual (short/dark hair, short-med height, med build, socio major,
age 24 or so) please advise.
Over,
Steveo

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon May 27 16:48:58 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA07974; Mon, 27 May 1996 16:48:58 -0700
Received: from ix10.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA07968; Mon, 27 May 1996 16:48:55 -0700
Received: from wck-ca4-09.ix.netcom.com by ix10.ix.netcom.com (8.6.13/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id QAA03581; Mon, 27 May 1996 16:46:26 -0700
Date: Mon, 27 May 1996 16:46:26 -0700
Message-Id: <1.5.4.16.19960526222034.38df392a@popd.ix.netcom.com>
X-Sender: shawna-@popd.ix.netcom.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.4 (16)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "hey, where am I?" <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: Funky Tekno Review (long) (yeah yeah I know!)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey all!

Well it's been a very interesting weekend.  Went to Funky Tekno Tribe on
Saturday, being one of the Chrysalis ousted. :(  This party definitely had
some real up points and some *real* down points.  

We all met up ahead of time to go there together, so at least we had a group
of mostly sfravers to go with.  So we all drive over to the warehouse, and
when we get there, we see this enormous line of people stretching down the
block.  Very daunting, pretty usual with massives I guess, cuz they searched
each person (not very well I might add!)  So we wait there in line for an
hour, entertaining ourselves, to get in.  There are lots of youngsters &
gangster types along for the ride, lots of people swishing down bottles of
Jack Daniels as fast as they can and them throwing them to the side onto the
ground.  One particularly charming gentleman kinda stumbled around in
between the line of people & the building itself, and naturally eventually
fell face & hands forward into one of the glass windows of the warehouse.
He seemed fine, but of course now there's this enormous broken window and
glass all over the place.  One of the policemen occupying one of 5-6 cop
cars sitting there outside the event hauls him away.  Boy I tell you folks,
at this point, I realize I really am experiencing pangs of homesickness for
you guys, all the friendly folk that woulda showed to the Chrysalis party!
(which was one saving grace for this party, many ousted Chrysalis folk made
it to this one instead, thereby raising the vibe-factor by quite a bit!)
And I'm also thinking that if I had come by myself in my own car, I would
have left then & there.  But I came with other people in someone else's car
so oh well.  And then, after the aforementioned hour, we *finally* make it
up to the front of the line, and I am *completely* dismayed to see that
while the pre-sale tickets were $20, the at-the-door tickets were jacked up
to $25!!  There of course was no mention of this on the recording, or
mention at the stores where the tickets were being pre-sold. You didn't
learn this until after waiting a whole hour in line, so that by the time you
get in, you feel you *have* to go to this party just to justify having
waited that long.  My friends are going in, I have no way home on my own, so
I say "shit. fine. here's my money, now leave me alone" and go on in.  

The warehouse setup is kind of weird.  It's huge and long, so that one side
is completely lit, while the other side is darkened like a normal rave.
There's a big alcove also that is decorated only with a blacklight on the
ceiling and a white parachute hanging from the ceiling directly under it.  I
liked the way that looked, but if possible I would have at least covered the
ceiling in these blacklight parachutes so you'd have this entire eerily
glowing fluffy ceiling above, that woulda looked cool!  The only real effort
in decor that ws made was the dj setup and the lasers.  The laser show was
pretty damn cool, saw some nifty effects.  There was a scaffold platform in
the middle of the floor, in between the laser (which was set up on one side
of the dance area) and the dj setup (on the other side of the dance area).
People often climbed up on this and danced, and looking at the people
dancing against the laser design background looked pretty darned cool too,
especially since a number of these were totally decked out in these enormous
glow-sticks that were a little longer than the length of one's forearm.
These people had one glow-stick tied to each leg & one tied to each arm, and
against the laser show that in & of itself made a pretty cool show!  But of
course, still not worth $25.  The warehouse was nice because you could go
outside, they had a whole outdoor area you could go sit and cool off at,
which was very nice.  The warehouse was also *very* large, so in spite of
the large numbers of people there was always lots of open space (with the
possible exception of in the thick of the dance area of course). 

Upon first getting into the party, I was needless to say in a rather surly &
bitter mood.  And then I promptly lost most of the people I had come with.
So I do my usual thing and wander around scoping out the set-up seeing where
everything sits.  As I wander thru the dance area, I am completely surprised
when somebody looks at me and offers me candy with a big smile!  This was so
completely not what I was expecting at a party like this, anybody who would
actually run around with candy offering it to random people.  This actually
did a considerable amount towards raising my spirits quite a bit.  Like I
said, there were probably a lot of people there who originally had intended
to go to Chrysalis, so it probably isn't as much of a surprise as it
normally would have been.  But still, even tho my spirits had lifted quite a
bit, a lot of the people were composed of what I had already seen outside in
line.  However, the music rocked! :)  I've learned that when I go to a party
like this, and the music does rock, I pretty much have to put away my "soft
& fluffy" expectations (like expecting people & vibe from parties like
Chrysalis), and kind of get a little more hardcore about it, and just really
enjoy the great music & dance my ass off the whole time.  I love the soft &
fluffy stuff, it's a large part of what I seek out, but at a party like
this, putting that away is really the best way I can assure that I will have
the best time possible, and for $25 I definitely want to have the best time
possible!  This also meant not indulging, cuz (for me) that would be a total
distraction from just dancing all night & would make me want to find heaps
of happy people to hang out with, & that just wasn't to be found here.  So I
had an immensely good time dancing!  It's that same type of energy that I
experienced in Montreal, just the energy of a huge number of people all
really enjoying dancing their asses off with excellent music.  And I also
discovered something new, which is that I now contend (for me) that if I am
gonna *just* dig on the groovy music & dance real hard all night, a massive
is the way to go!  The music just sounds so much fuller with a good system
in a huge area, WHOOM WHOOM WHOOM WHOOM, jeez!  That alone just keeps ya
going (I like lotsa bass, ya definitely get that effect in a large space!).
Not quite sure why yet, but I keep hearing the music I really enjoy more at
larger parties, rather than the smaller ones (with the exception of a couple
of dj's at the last Beautiful People).  Or maybe the large space is just
providing for better effects.  Anyway, this music I really enjoyed, and I
regret not having made note of which dj was spinning when with the exception
of Dj Dan. Oh yeah, the infamous fire dancers came out for an appearance or
two, which i saw a bit of.  And the most notable item I must make mention of
here is Our Own SDream!  Yes folks, SDream like you've never seen him
before!  I'm dancing out in the middle of the floor, and I look up to
realize that there, upon the small scaffold built up right next to the dj
setup, is the Good Ol' Boy from Tallahassee wearing one of his cat-in the
hat style hats (this one red with white polka dots), his pants, & nothing
else!  Dancing around up there, along with several other people, one of
which had a big hat like his.  I couldn't believe it!  And the best part?
We got PICTURES! :):)  Good blackmail material if I ever saw! ;)  & if not
that, a good source of merciless teasing!  So all in all, having danced the
whole time, I had a really great time.  My bare minimum requirement for
having fun is great music, and that was taken care of.  As long as i didn't
expect much chill-room fun, I was set, so at the end of the party I still
found myself feeling great.  I do need to just do simple dancing at parties
more often I think, I don't feel that particular type of energy as much as
I'd like to.  

And then for the fabulous ending.  We leave the building the following
morning, and walk the couple of blocks to our car.  We see that the car is
still in the lot and Paul says "oh cool!  my car wasn't broken into!"  And
for some reason, I just say "let's just wait & see if my purse is still
there or not before we say that!"  And sure enough, we pop the trunk, & the
purse is gone.  The car didn't look vandalized because they hadn't broken
any windows or anything, they simply jimmied the lock.  Strange thieves too,
they took my purse and ripped out the little change box in his car that
contained 45 cents or so, but left my tape collection *and* Paul's portable
cd player!  Go figure.  So we look around the parking lot to make sure that
maybe the thieves hadn't simply dumped my purse into a dumpster or something
after taking what they want.  Nothing of mine was found, altho we did find
someone else's purse that had been dumped along with her wallet, which we
took & called her to let her know we'd found her stuff.  But nothing of
mine.  So I had to go thru the usual rigamarole of calling the credit card
people & such, turns out these thieves had made charges to my card already,
they had gone to a gas station and made three $1 charges on it!  Hmm.  But
luckily I got it blocked before any more charges were made.  Anyway, for
some reason I was not overly disturbed by this.  I did realize that it could
have been much worse, the car & the rest of the contents were still there,
the biggest pain I had to go thru was having poor Paul drive me all the way
from Oakland to Pleasant Hill so I could get my spare house & car keys (my
originals were in my purse, so there was no way for me to get my car which I
had left in SF), and make those phone calls to the credit card folk.  Yeah
it sucks that people would do that in the first place, but I just know it
could have been way worse.  & it still didn't ruin the rest of my day which
was real nice & laid back.  And ya know what?  I get a call at Paul's house
later that afternoon from my roommate.  My roommate says that a lady called
the house to let me know she'd found my purse, and that it was almost
entirely still intact! :)  I figure I musta had some good karma stored up or
something, cuz I consider that real lucky to have happened.  She leaves it
hidden at her house for me, I pick it up, and she's right, it is almost
entirely intact.  A few papers were missing, but my wallet was there, my
passport was there, and my drivers license was there.  Even my checkbook was
still there!  (altho the fuckers went & stole my stamps!)  Only the couple
of credit cards I had already had blocked were really missing from my
checkbook.  That was really nice to make that recovery, the credit cards
were really something that would be easier to replace than a lot of personal
things I had in that purse, in addition to having to spend more money to get
a another one of similar quality to the first.  

Oh yeah, a big public embarrassing thank you to Paul Abramson who really
helped out a lot with this situation. Like I said, he drove me all the way
to Pleasant Hill from Oakland, and then back to San Francisco again, and
lent me money to be able to eat, which I really needed to do but hadn't yet
(& coffee, which I *really* needed to get!), and was just generally a great
& helpful friend! :)  The next time you see him at a party, he'll probably
have brilliant tangerine colored hair, so go up & say hi to him!


Ok, I'm done now!

Love,
Shawna


  *smurp*

>I Just borrowed a Kawai KI-ii  from a friend for the summer, but there
>isnt a manual...do any of you know where I could look to find sa manual as
>to how to progrqm this thing? Thanks :)
>
>* * ** *** ***** ******** ************* ******************
>Paul Anthony Rose
>UC Berkeley Computer Science/ Mathematics
>http://violet.berkeley.edu/~trose
>TRANCE_HARDER--DEEPER--FASTER
>****************** ************* ******** ***** *** ** * *

I dont have a manual, but there is a place in Emeryville, shit, I cant
remember the name, but they usually have an ad in keyboard magazine, anyway
they sell manuals for virtually every synth. And they do mail order. (I'll
CC this message to SFraves, someone should know what the store's name is)

As far as the Kawai K-series, they are really easy to program. I have a K4
and I have played around on a Kawai K1 and they seem to be virtually the
same. Do you have any experience with synth programming? If you do, you
should have no problem. Let me know. If you don't I'll give you a primer.
All synths, no matter how fancy they are, have the same format as far as
fundamentals. It's just a matter of finding where the parameters are, and I
believe the layout of the K1 and the K4 are the same.

Hope this helps,
Courtney

		A D R E N A L I N      R E C O R D S 

	Is looking for new material to sign. We are interested in
development of techno artist is the USA. We are looking for Hard House,
Progressive House, Trance, Acid Trance, Funky Breaks, Trip-Hop, Ambient,
and Hardcore Gabber and Techno track to sign to Adrenalin Records.

If you have a demo and would like to submit it to us for review for
signing to the label then send it to the following address. In the near
future we have many 12" vinyl releases coming out by Cotten Club from the
UK who is now signed to us, Stryke, The Tweakers and many more.....

38@send Demos to:

Heliotrope Review - A SoCal adventure..

Well,   surprisingly things have actually turned out as planned.    I
finally got my boxes of stuff together in time before Greg arrives to
pick me up.   We head over to Justin's place to store my stuff,  then
with Jeremy, Greg, and myself,  head south towards LA and got
underway.

We wasted no time getting down to LA and arrived about noon,
where I was to meet an old friend I haven't seen in 45 years.   Yes,
that's 45 years.   I tracked him down via the Internet,  amazingly
enough.    After that,  we head to Venice Beach to hang out and take
in the SoCal scene.

Late in the afternoon,  I tried many times to find a place to plug in
my laptop to post something to SoCal raves,  but none of the Kinko's
places we checked allowed us to plug in to check my mail,   but I was
able to find Kevin who had included his phone numbers in his mail
sig.   I cannot believe how BACKWARDS this country is in it's
telecommunications infra-structure.   Just about any other place in
the world,  they provide data jacks on the pay phones,  but NOT
HERE...

We hooked up with Kevin at the Santa Monica pier and made our
way to Heliotropic.    The info number said it was in Downtown LA at
some art studio.

The venue had NO free water,  but $2 a bottle,  with no running
water to refill the bottles.   I was constantly going around,  begging
for money so I can get some water.   As usual,  the place was stuffy
and very hot,  but the music more than made up for it.

Things started off with some jungle,   then moved into full goa
trance.    Excellent performance by Code IV performing live.   Our
very own Alien Life force tore the place to shreds,  playing some
amazing hard trance (The really fast kind).   WOW!!   Incredible.

I wish I could say I went ballistic,  but due to recent back injury,
my dancing was no way what I would call "up to par" but I did spend
a lot of time dancing this time..

Following Alien Life force was LA's Eric Daveport,  who played a little
slower stuff.    I managed to run into a few SoCal ravers,  and thanks
to Eric who bought me some water and saved me from certain
dehydration.

The rave ended at 6 am,  so we head out somewhere to get some
sleep before driving back.    We left in late afternoon and got back at
10 am.

Anyway...  Mike,  the promoter got us on his guest list,  Thanx Mike...
but next time,  please don't use that venue...  the owner is far too
greedy and has no concern for people's health...  not allowing access
to running water and charging $2 for it,  really SUX...   Is it THIS way
for all LA venues....   I'm so sorry that you SoCal ravers have to put
up with such greed.   So,  why not fight back and force those greedy
venue owners to provide at least some running water.    I've got
some ideas,   Email me....

Hello to all you SoCal ravers I met....   I really had a great time down
there,   but I sure wish that we had good trance parties up here,
instead of having them be so secret and underground,  and closed to
only those special people.

Crunchman

It was at the beach near Belano State Park (or something like that), about
25mi north of Santa Cruz.  Don't know which crew it was.  "Formally" met
Wonka (I've seen him before, last year), and helped carry some gear down to
the beach.  Carried a speaker with the legendary John Carel, though we
didn't officially meet (Hi, John!).  Saw my bud Joey (of the Harmony Crew)
there, and helped gather some firewood.
The wind was fierce and bone-chilling, and blew lots of sand around.  All I
had on was a tee-shirt and an overshirt (yes, pants too :)), and couldn't
take the cold, so I bailed.  Hope the party went off BIG; I left just as
others were arriving.
Questions: what was this party called?  Which crew was it?

Howdy ho all!

Hope the weekend was good to ya'll as for me....

Friday nite I was chillin @ the F-8 mappoint socalising with Mars'n'Mystr-E.
(Mars new tape has a gobs and gobs of uplifting trance.. Worth a
Checkout...).  Ending up at a lil underground saturday morning...

Saturday was reserved for the Panther beach partie(s)-  Nice to have a scene
kind enuff to house two soundsystems on the same beach without any
disputes... Too bad the sheriffs dropped by to shut them down @ round'
6ish...

Saturday nite was reserved for a few friends , no dancing here. Contuing with
Sunday at a B-day partie and onto "Something Free".  Got there @ midnite. The
setup wasn't up... Stayed till 2 in the cold ( Cold, COLD) wind.  Still no
Music, so time to jet....

Monday was the traditional Labor day BBQ and stuff... 

Smile O Meter ratings....

Friday nite:  8 smiles (nice to be with friends...)

Saturday @ Panther Beach:  8 smiles  (Ditto Friday nite, big plus on the 1hr.
stall time before the sheriffs shut the system down).

Well that's it for now... 
Spaz get together up in Seattle this weekend from what I hear, as well as A
F-8 event Saturday night.  Decisions, decisions.....


"Dance with me.."

-Adam

Greetings,

Some of you may remember the interactive DJ turntable application I put up
on the web
for download last year - that was Macintosh-only.  The Windows 95 version
is finally
done for your PC's - it requires both QuickTime and DirectX, so it'll take
a while to download
if you don't already have those installed.

The Zip file is downloadable from http://www.tactilepix.com/demos.html;
please read the
instructions carefully, since having the right system extensions is
critical.  It's only been
up there a short time, so let me know if there are any problems.  In
particular, you may
have problems with the FTP server timing out because the file is so large.

There's a little info about the Tactile1200 in this month's i-D Magazine
and Mixmaster Morris mentioned
it in last month's Mixmag :-).

-Derek

Subject: My Dinner with Andre (long excerpt)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Here's an excerpt from the video "My Dinner with Andre". The setting is
a restaurant and a famous playwrite, Andre Gregory, is having dinner 
with his friend Wallace Shawn. Their conversation is about Andre's
experiences at Finhorn (SP?) where people are able to grow plants in
soil that has no nutrients in it all among other scientifically
unexplainable phenomena and also about his experience at leading an
improvisational play with beatiful music in a Polish forrest with people
who could not speak any of his own languages. His interpretation of his
experiences seems to closely parallel our "underground"?

Peace and Love,
John

----

Andre:

"Finhorn people see it a little differently, they're feeling that there
will be these pockets of light springing up in different parts of the
world and that these will be in a way invisible planets on this planet,
and it as we or the world grow colder we can take invisible space
journeys to these different planets, refuel for what it is what we need
to do on the planet itself and come back. It's their feeling that there
have to be centers now where people can come and re-construct a new
future for the world and when I was talking to Gustav Bjornstron, he was
saying that actually these centers were growing up everwhere now and
what they're trying to do, which is what Finhorn was trying to do, and
in a way which was what I was trying to do...I mean these things can't
be given names but in a way these are all attempts at creating a new
kind of school or a new kind of monastery and Bjornstron talks about the
concept of reserves - islands of safety where history can be remembered
and the human being can continue to function in order to maintain the
species thru a dark age. In otherwords we're talking about an
underground, which did exist in a different way during the dark ages
among the mystical orders of the church ... and the purpose of this
underground is find out how to preserve the LIGHT ... LIFE! The culture!
How to keep things living! You see, I keep thinking that what we need is
a new language ... a language of the HEART, a language as in the Polish
forrests where language wasn't needed, some kind of language between
people that is a new kind of poetry, thats the poetry of the dancing bee
that tells us where the HONEY is! And I think that in order to create
that language you're going to have to learn how you can go thru a
looking glass into another kind of perception where you have that sense
of being UNITED to all things ... and suddenly ... you understand
everything!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue May 28 13:41:15 1996

Date: Tue, 28 May 1996 13:41:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: Jonathan Mark Logan <gonzo@leland.Stanford.EDU>
To: Tony Rotundo <tony@xinet.COM>

In-Reply-To: <v03006609add11294be2a@DialupEudora>

As far as media portrayal of the rave scene goes, I thought this was
fairly positive and well-written. 

Do check it out, decide for yourselves.

Remember, all mass-media depictions of the scene are going to
suffer from a sort of pervasive ignorance despite any bad or good
intentions.  Media love to generalize on a subject, in order to cater to
the lowest common denominator.  Hence, some rather blatantly dumb
statements... :P

Regardless, it's nice to see the media focusing on the *cultural* aspect 
of raves for once!  


		jon

Subject: New York Times article

Precedence: bulk

There is an article in todays New York Times about Raves. It is on the front
of B1, the Living Arts section. It focuses on weekend outdoor parties and
has the expected "Teenage Wasteland" NYT angle. It is perceptive on some
fronts, saying "the rave scene has grown and evolved on its own energy,
becoming an entrenched subculture that exists in a near-vacuum, similar
not only to the cults that gather around punk-rock or Gothic-rock music
but also to the Deadheads that followed the Grateful Dead." It carries
the Deadhead angle a bit far, describing in detail how the Dead and Rave
scenes are alike and claiming that many Deadheads are becoming ravers.
Does Neil Strauss (the writer of the article) read this list?

It ends with a discussion of the possibility that raves will become the
youth subculture of the baby boomlet generation. Anybody got a better
name for that cohort?

Peace,
Jim

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue May 28 16:01:08 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA23778; Tue, 28 May 1996 16:01:08 -0700
Received: from dub-img-6.compuserve.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA23762; Tue, 28 May 1996 16:01:01 -0700
Received: by dub-img-6.compuserve.com (8.6.10/5.950515)
	id TAA14603; Tue, 28 May 1996 19:00:22 -0400
Date: 28 May 96 18:58:33 EDT
From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@CompuServe.COM>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: SPUNDAE Review!  Whew!
Message-ID: <960528225833_71165.755_GHL94-1@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

For all of those of you hardcore ravers who looked at me as if I were totally
out of my mind to be planning to go to Spundae after Sunset on Sunday....

WOOOOO HAAA!  IT ROCKED!!

I think this was the best club experience I've ever had out -- the energy at 11
pm was incredible already, and the place was only half open at that point ....
and it stayed high all night long!

There were four totally awesome dance areas -- we started in the smaller front
room (the main room was already too packed), danced some, went up to the roof,
hung out, went back downstairs to the big room which was ON FIRE -- THUMPING AND
POUNDING! then upstairs to the trip-hop rooms, with new comfy leather couches
(and the great company of Tom and Stacey and friends) .... then back all the way
down to the basement where Carlos and DJ Dan were so hot, I swear the
temperature was 100 degrees (oh, yeah, I think it WAS 100 degrees, way too hot,
but the music was too god to leave it)... back upstairs to chill and dance to
trip hop, back to the roof... back to the basement to dance more ... ending the
night in the front room on comfy couches after the music stopped, the best of
chill spaces....

All night long, every single space was totally perfect in its own way... I was
thankful that I got there early at 11, which meant I got a full 8-1/2 hours in
by the time I left at 7:30 .... every minute was great!

The crowd?  Lots of real ravers (met a new SFRaver who has a sheepdog and is
actually going to learn how to herd sheep -- what's your name again? I'm sorry,
I forgot!), plus lots of high-energy club people of all sorts from all kinds of
places -- these people were ALL having a great time, and the mix was totally
amazing.  I saw people from all over, even friends from Seattle who'd come down
for the weekend!

Weirdest moment? on the roof when all the security guys came running through,
climbing on the roof frame and edges looking for someone who must have snuck in
over the wall 3 floors up!  Like Lethal Weapon III!

So, now that I'm switching to a 3-day schedule at my job soon, I think you'll
see me at Spundae again, seeing if it's that fun on normal nights!

Here's to diversity in parties!  Leslie  : )

different guises and names....
Be it beatnik gatherings,love fests of the 60's, speakeasies,underground
discos, Illegal ghetto parties (Remember Beat Street?) or any other
collection of persons for sub/counterculture activities  (If you also count
dancing as subcultureish...). 
 
Times change but the vibe is the same...

We are the future..

From: Uncle Noah <napodaca@ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: ez031733@elroy.ucdavis.edu
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: media representations of rave culture
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960528171219.21784A-100000@elroy.ucdavis.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


all these comments have made me think about how the media views us and 
our music.  I started noticing recently the big trend with stand-up 
comics to rip on techno music.  Anyone else notice this?  I went to see 
three commedians the toehr night and every one of them did a bit on how 
terrible techno music is.  Then, last night I happened to watch 
Politically Incorrect with Bill Mahr (sp?) and Bill and the panel (which 
included the top dude from Spin magazine) were discussing Tim Leary.  The 
discussion got to drugs (how did that happen?) and a comment went out 
that as soon as the government realizes that people have fun with a 
particular drug, the make it illegal, even if there aren't bad aeffects 
from the drug; as was the case with marijuana, 
LSD, ecstacy... and at that point, one of the comics on the panel said, 
"Yeah, but ecstacy makes you listen to really bad music!" and the crowd 
erupted into laughter.  
I don't know, maybe I'm just hyper-sensitized, but there is a lot of 
resistance out there.  And I just don't see why!  They don't make jokes 
about how rotten Nirvana is or how bad punk rock is or how sad it is that 
Aerosmith came back from the dead to milk a few more bucks out of the 
industry.  But if people enjoy a form of music that is too alternative, 
the American mainstream slams down upon them.  
I didn't mean to sound too bummed out and I hope I'm not sending out a 
bad vibe, it's just amazing to me.

Peace! :)

--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+---
                 "Uncle" Noah Apodaca - napodaca@ucdavis.edu
                    Student, Disc Jockey, Resident Advisor
  		      Listen to the Uncle Noah TV Show 
  		    The best in Techno and House music
   	        Saturdays, 3-5am only on KDVS 90.3fm in Davis

something like "butt-ah."  Also, I just got off the phone with my dad

elsewhere.  Thus, I'm looking for a cheap room in Buffalo, and fortunately,
there's nothing but.  I'm not bitter, really, but I am rather pissed at you
all for showing my sister such a good time her brain collapsed and she got

better get in with the Republican's because they own the banks.  Ahhh,

WWW stuff (among other things) is what I do for a living, and You don't
want to use one of those web generating programs like pagemill. While they
are really easy to use, you'll find that they really won't do what you want
them to do. My advice is to go out to a bookstore, and pick up a book on
html. It's really easy to learn, and you'll be much happier that you only
spent $20 instead of $200.
Good Luck
Tim

Precedence: bulk

I will examine the article closely -- it is important for coverage to be
concise - if they do cover the "teenage wasteland" angle and nothing else,
they are being slack journalists. Sure, there is negativity that desrves
fair coverage, as does the positive . . . .

also - I gotta step up and say that I'm a deadhead (and hardly "former"!)
who has discovered the rave scene has a similarly enormous "good mojo"
about it, just as the dead's traveling road show did. I miss them so much,
you can't comprehend. but there's no end to the gladness I feel when
witnessing and participating in what the rave scene has to offer. the
scenes are cut from the same cloth. aside from the asthetic details of the
music, the rave scene and the dead scene spring from the same
dance-of-life. yes. the scraggly-ass drummers, for example, are common
elements between the dead and the rave thang. we are of one family.  From a
historical perspective, the rave scene is a direct descendent on Ken
Kesey's Acid Tests. But I'm sure that is old news to you-all.

>it for a little while."
>
>Yeah, escape *this* pal, we're just trying to get away from crap journalism
>and bad music.
>
>Anyway, enjoy....
>
>
>>http://www.nytimes.com/yr/mo/day/news/arts/rave-festival-650.html
>>
>>front page of today's Living Arts Section.
>
>Peace!
>
>Tone
>
>P.S.  Please pass it on to SoCal and NW

I read it this morning.  Some truth, some fiction, some new words, some old
reporter, whatever.  It won't be the first or last time someone tries to
pigeonhole something.

"Deadbeats"?  I dunno.  Here in the city of trust funds, and people
pretending to be poor, who the fuck knows. (BTW, I lived in LA for a while.
SF IS quite different.  Where else do you find people NOT grabbing for
BMW's, but bumming it by choice or worse, hiding the fact that they have
much $$$'s for the sake of fitting in...strange place indeed!)

Seriously though, some important issues were brought up.  Like really, what
HAS been the influence of rave OUTSIDE the rave sphere?  Please spare the
"techno in commercials". I am talking impact, not pablum.

Rave has been very autonomous from the onset, existing outside most other
common frameworks, save capitalism (which works well within our little
subculture).

As for deadheads, I see it a bit more these days.  The scene has changed
from my view, and now it definitely has the feel of a more hippie-crunchy
kinda flavor at times(it was more soulful when I started going out).  Just
my view.

The rest of that article was just that, another just-say-no to drugs
article very late on the fact that this scene as it may be, has taken a
life of its own, and operates outside of most common constructs.  People
really hate it when you do or think for yourslef.  That is all that article
said to me.

As I have always said, the media exists for one reason...its own existence.

Peace,
John

P.S.  You can blame many promoters for making things worse.  Many are all
too willing to talk to the press, about thier gig.  I remember I was
approached by a media type to talk about, er, stuff.  I told her I had
little to say, and that maybe she might want to go to a few events, instead
of dropping in and taking notes.  She then asked me when the next
underground is, I then asked , "When isn't there one?"  and walked away.

You want UG, don't talk to the press.  Live with snakes, die by them.

Shit used to be way more silent than now.  Soemtimes I long for the old
days, when the TELEPHONE and a VOICE on the other end was the ONLY WAY you
knew where a party was.  No call, no party.  Now *THAT'S* UG!

Out & Peace.



Side of mouth shit:

"Ruthless gangstah definition villian, keep your shit unlocked and I'm
stealin'!" - Eazy-E

Speaking of LA, when I used to rave/party there, I ALWAYS used to listen to
the most hardcore ass thumpin' rap before catchin some rave/dance/love
tunes @ a party.  That shit would have me pumped up to dance, keep me bold
enough to brave some of the roughest LA neighborhoods, and have me hyped
for anything, good or bad.  I love hardcore ganstah roughneck shit before I
bust love grooves.  Straight jackin' baby!

"I got a bone to pick cuz' I'm sick, of you muthafucka's talkin' shit, you
pick us up, you put us down, now I'm mad, time to talk about your dog
ass!..." - Geto Boys

"Word to your mother." - Vanilla Ice <- THE hardcore rapper bar nun! ;)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed May 29 00:42:04 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id AAA12976; Wed, 29 May 1996 00:42:04 -0700
Received: from dfw-ix10.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id AAA12970; Wed, 29 May 1996 00:42:01 -0700
Received: from  (peterbf@sfo-ca14-09.ix.netcom.com [205.184.16.73]) by dfw-ix10.ix.netcom.com (8.6.13/8.6.12) with SMTP id AAA13277 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 29 May 1996 00:41:23 -0700
Date: Wed, 29 May 1996 00:41:23 -0700
Message-Id: <199605290741.AAA13277@dfw-ix10.ix.netcom.com>
From: peterbf@ix.netcom.com (peter fogel)
Subject: adolescent rave perspective
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I've been working mostly on the adolescent unit at the hospitol where I 
work.  Today I overheard one kid telling the other about how she missed 
out on going to a rave this past weekend.  I decided to ask her more 
about her rave perspective.
I asked her if she likes techno, because I only hear her listening to 
rap music.  She says she likes techno, but added "you have to be on 
drugs to like that music". 
I asked her why she goes to raves.  "For fun" she says.  I told her "I 
hear alot of people who go to raves find it to be a spiritual 
experience."  Both of these 16 year olds just looked at me with a blank 
expression.
They asked me if I ever been to one, and if so what did i wear.  They 
said if I wore what i was wearing (green slightly baggy pants, nice 
button down shirt) I'd probably get jumped.  "You have to wear tye-dye 
type clothing"
I told them the rave I went to was more of an anything goes, all 
excepting type crowd.  When I told them it was on the beach they said  
"oh that's different, thats not what its like in the warehouse raves."

I asked them if they ever heard of plur which stands for peace love 
unity and respect and some ravers I hear use it as a set of ideals to 
live by.  Again blank expressions.

After talking with these two 16 year olds I felt kinda sad, thinking 
that there may be a major lack of spirituality to alot of the younger 
people going to raves.  

I am thankfull this isn't true for many, and as long as I can hear good 
music and can still enjoy dancing, I think there will always be some 
element of spirituality.

>Hey: I plan to be building my own web page real soon for my studio -
>primarily a house music studio - but I don't know where to begin. I would
>like to include sound bytes of new records as well as previous ones, which I
>plan to re-release. I have noticed a few software titles that let you
>"build" a web page, does anyone know if those are any good?
>        I have a PowerMac 7200/90 w/ 16 megs RAM, a fair amount of graphics
>software, lots of gear, not a lot of money.
>        Can anyone point me in the right direction?
>
>Thanks!
>
>Courtney
depends on what you are looking for. if its something really simple, and
you have a place to host it (i dont know how earthlink works) I could help
you througha lot of it. i personally think that most of the helping
software is bunk ('xcept BBedit, which is a nice editor). Really, it isnt
more than a few hours worth of work (i used to teach an intro compArt class
that icncluded web design) noone ever managed to _not_ make a page.)

http://www.ncsa.uiuc.edu/General/Internet/WWW/HTMLPrimer.html
Between this and looking at the source to otheres peoples pages should give
you a good start. Something that works really well when you are starting is
finding something you like, "view source", copy that source, and use it in
your page.

seriously though, feel free to drop me a line if you get stuck on
something. (yeah, yeah bored netSaint and all that)

hmmm.. will swap html for ride to TribalFuture this weekend :)

take care
kcroy

People are so funny.

I played house music to my mom and she said:  It sounds just like disco!

My mom is so right on.

My standard answer to the techno diss is to say:  Hey!  There's a zillion 
types of techno music, and each has its place and time to shine.  At four 
in the morning, you need something fast and weird to keep you going.  
At 8 in the morning, you need something smooth and funky to keep you 
happy.  And at midnight you need some house music to get you started off 
just right.

And then I start to rave on and on about trip hop and how it blows your 
mind.  That music is complex, man!  It's what our grandchildren will play 
on the way to the stars.

-Ann

>>There is an article in todays New York Times about Raves.

>>It carries
>>the Deadhead angle a bit far, describing in detail how the Dead and Rave

>The event in question was "Even Further." There was even a picture of the

>filled with Chicago attitude. Burning Man it was not, I'm sure.

>------------------------------------------------------
>|  Alexander M. Rosenberg   <mailto:alexr@bungie.com>|

Everyone probablly had a good time nonetheless. :)

Why do we have to go immediately to comparisons of who's was better?  Why
not just look at it as another type of celebration.  Which from the
article, it seemed it was.

As far as I am concerened, if there was no incident of violence, with all
that humanity (not to mention the Million Man March), it was ALL good!
Scott Hardkiss was there (at least one SFciscan representing), they said
nothing about violence or arrests, just a couple of freak-outs.  It
could've been written better.  But worse hack jobs have been done by our
local papers.

The author had some funny quips, but presented it as a brief look from the
outside of the culture.  We should be able to have others interpretation of
what they see, but they should get the whole picture, not just a late
edition snapshot.

It would be nice to know what the participants of the party/event, thought
about their event.

About this deadhead and rave connection, there is one, and there always has
been one.  In one way or the other.  There is little doubt though that
there is an active migration, heavier now than before.  Predictable.

Out,
John

As to the adolescent perspective - this is what we get when we thoughtlessly
dump 100's (1000's) of kids into large warehouses and mix in drugs
without any sort of initiation or connection with an experienced culture.
I'm very thankful I met raving through FnF where there are dozens of
connected people... makes for a whole different picture....

 Also, related are news stories about raving.... they can write things that
are TRUE and piss off people in the scene depending on who they inteview.
If they interview someone like you, Ethan or Bryce they get one story if
they were to interview those girls they would get another... so who's
telling the truth?  

  When you are blind about something you become a blind man grabbing the
elephant and truth becomes relative.... 

Mike

John S. Lee:
>Seriously though, some important issues were brought up.  Like really, what
>HAS been the influence of rave OUTSIDE the rave sphere?  Please spare the
>"techno in commercials". I am talking impact, not pablum.

Well, in the SF Bay Area, a pretty exciting network of creative and
technical professionals has evolved, partially fueled by their
(mostly former) involvement with the rave scene.  Geoff White gave
a good listing a while back that included many of these startups.
I myself was heavily recruited at the Sunset Boat party by the head
of a multimedia/internet company who preferred working with "a
similar mindset".  Raving has always (but not exclusively) attracted 
people who look to the future with an appreciation of sensory
stimulation, mind expansion and open communication.  Raving 
together *has* had an impact.  And the eventual impact that such
people will have on the evolution of the internet/web/multimedia
and our overall culture could be very large. 

>Shit used to be way more silent than now.  Soemtimes I long for the old
>days, when the TELEPHONE and a VOICE on the other end was the ONLY WAY you
>knew where a party was.  No call, no party.  Now *THAT'S* UG!

This still happens.  Perhaps there's an underground that even you
don't know about. :)  But let's face it, most people don't want to
go to parties that are so far underground that only the same exclusive
clique goes to them.   Such parties only go off (IMO) when
there aren't many other good choices.  Not that there's anything
wrong with a bunch of friends getting together,  but there's nothing
like the fresh energy exchange and unity that happens when it's with
people who *don't* know each other.

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk


> Seriously though, some important issues were brought up.  Like really, what
> HAS been the influence of rave OUTSIDE the rave sphere?  Please spare the
> "techno in commercials". I am talking impact, not pablum.

I think this is a moot point.   The whole idea of an underground rave scene
is that it is seperate from trying to impact the rest of society.  I think
if we look back to the sixties, where there was a huge push to have the
subculture clash directly with mainstream culture, mainstream culture always
won out.  I don't really expect the rave culture to change our existsing, sick
culture.  Instead, I see 2 different cultures... one rising up and one
fading away.  I mean, the only way rave spreads is from one person to another.
Try as we will, but a positive view of raves will never be seen in the mass
media.  All we can do is try our best to make sure they are not outright 
lying (as in the Hard Copy story), and present our views as articulately as
possible in other information channels not owned by transnational corperations.

> As I have always said, the media exists for one reason...its own existence.

Brainwashing the masses.  Defining a reality within narrow materialistic
parameters.  Supressing thought.  Distracting people from the true
reality.  ect, ect, ect.  

Rave mailing lists are one of the most valuable tools we have to spread the
rave culture.

-troy

On Wed, 29 May 1996, Lee Fogel wrote:

> Well, in the SF Bay Area, a pretty exciting network of creative and
> technical professionals has evolved, partially fueled by their
> (mostly former) involvement with the rave scene.  Geoff White gave
> a good listing a while back that included many of these startups.
> I myself was heavily recruited at the Sunset Boat party by the head
> of a multimedia/internet company who preferred working with "a
> similar mindset".  Raving has always (but not exclusively) attracted 
> people who look to the future with an appreciation of sensory
> stimulation, mind expansion and open communication.  Raving 
> together *has* had an impact.  And the eventual impact that such
> people will have on the evolution of the internet/web/multimedia
> and our overall culture could be very large. 

Yeah boyeeeeeeeeee!   THIS is how "rave values" will make it to the 
mainstream media without the filter of the old skool media 
conglomerates.  Memetic expression of PLUR is and will continue to 
subvert the "spectacle" of the mediasphere, IMHO.  

> don't know about. :) But let's face it, most people don't want to 
> go to parties that are so far underground that only the same 

I've personally tried to subvert the mainstream by confronting this 
alienation, and bringing the "rave vibe" to reporters by process of 
partying and (outright seduction) with them. (Some of you may remember 
the Zippy Pronoia spectacle from a few years back).   We had some very 
great success in getting the media to steer away from the anti-drug 
paranoia, and the villification-for-ratings phenomenon.   Lots of people 
read about "zippies" talking about raving and using technology for the 
first time, within a positive light.  Ironically, it was this exposure
which ultimately allowed the megalomania which many times accompanies an 
eruption of "underground" counterculture to the mainstream culture... and 
brought the whole "zippy vibe" crashing to the same floor Mondo 2000 and 
others currently sleep on.  IMHO, of course.   =)

This argument was very well defined and heated (even within this list) 
back then, and included many people from the international rave scenes.  
One of the recurring themes was that overground exposure brings dilution 
of "the vibe", and beer-soaked frat boys at raves when Hootie concerts 
sell out, etc.  The counter to that is this:  Nature Abhors A Vacuum.  In 
other words, new undergrounds will ALWAYS evolve from the disillusionment 
of the old.  Beatniks--> Hippsters --> Hippies --> Punks/Goths --> Ravers 
and on and on and on...

Just my two cents... have a groovy day!

-john

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed May 29 10:11:09 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id KAA06987; Wed, 29 May 1996 10:11:09 -0700
Received: from value.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id KAA06962; Wed, 29 May 1996 10:11:03 -0700
Received: (from scarab@localhost) by value.net (8.6.12/8.6.9) id KAA24757; Wed, 29 May 1996 10:10:58 -0700
Date: Wed, 29 May 1996 10:10:58 -0700 (PDT)
From: KaySEE <scarab@value.net>
To: peter fogel <peterbf@ix.netcom.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: adolescent rave perspective
In-Reply-To: <199605290741.AAA13277@dfw-ix10.ix.netcom.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.960529094556.22243F-100000@value.net>
