On Wed, 29 May 1996, peter fogel wrote:

> I've been working mostly on the adolescent unit at the hospitol where I 
> work.  Today I overheard one kid telling the other about how she missed 
> out on going to a rave this past weekend.  I decided to ask her more 
> about her rave perspective.
> I asked her if she likes techno, because I only hear her listening to 
> rap music.  She says she likes techno, but added "you have to be on 
> drugs to like that music". 
> I asked her why she goes to raves.  "For fun" she says.  I told her "I 
> hear alot of people who go to raves find it to be a spiritual 
> experience."  Both of these 16 year olds just looked at me with a blank 
> expression.
> They asked me if I ever been to one, and if so what did i wear.  They 
> said if I wore what i was wearing (green slightly baggy pants, nice 
> button down shirt) I'd probably get jumped.  "You have to wear tye-dye 
> type clothing"
> I told them the rave I went to was more of an anything goes, all 
> excepting type crowd.  When I told them it was on the beach they said  
> "oh that's different, thats not what its like in the warehouse raves."
> 
> I asked them if they ever heard of plur which stands for peace love 
> unity and respect and some ravers I hear use it as a set of ideals to 
> live by.  Again blank expressions.
> 
> After talking with these two 16 year olds I felt kinda sad, thinking 
> that there may be a major lack of spirituality to alot of the younger 
> people going to raves.  

Thanks for the perspective.  I've often wondered how some of the many 
adolescents I see feel about raving.  Unfortunately, my encounters have 
been similar to yours.  

Being a teenager is very difficult.  It is your 
first glimpse of being an independant human being, but at the same time 
you really are not.  Speaking from my experiences as a teenager, that 
time was a period of my life you couldn't pay me millions of dollars to 
re-live.  There is no tolerance for individuality; everyone tries their 
best to fit in, to be cool.  I actually refer to this phenomenon as the 
"cool-factor."

Being cool, unfortunately, means there is one standard way to do it, and 
all other ways are only worthy of disdain.  Hence, the occurance of a 
hierarchy of "cliques" and labeling such as "jocks", "nerds", and now 
"ravers"?  I can imagine what raving is to many teenagers.  It has become 
to a certain extent mainstream, and has now entered the "cool-factor."

Raving is the perfect activity to enter the cool-factor because in it are 
three things essential to establishing your place in the teenaged hierarchy: 
1) clothes 2)music 3) drugs.  I remember when I was a teenager, and 
partying (not raves-didn't have them) was cool.  HOnestly, to be a part 
of the IN-crowd you had to drink and do drugs and have the right clothes, 
and listen to the right music.  In that way, you could earn respect 
(however misdirected) from your peers.  When you are an adolescent and 
you desperately want to fit in, peer pressure almost always works it magic.

So, I can understand how the kids that Peter talked about replied the way 
they did.  It is probably not  a way of spirituality for many, but rather 
a way to fit in.  I want to qualify my comments by stating that they are 
wholely MY observations and MY experiences (especially my experiences as 
a pained teenager).  I am not that far from my teenaged years, and I 
sympathize greatly with many of the experiences.  And, not every teenager 
is the same.  Many people do different things with their lives, and many 
don't succumb to the pressures of being a teenager.  But, by all means, 
just like the rest of life, it is difficult and has pressures unique to it.

Hopefully many, just by being exposed to the spiritual side of raves, 
will eventually incorporate some of it into their lives.  I'm sure we 
have teenagers on this list that can elaborate and tell us what raving 
means to them. :)

Much respect,
KaySEE


              ****Shit, goddamn, get off your ass and jam****

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed May 29 10:34:15 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id KAA09458; Wed, 29 May 1996 10:34:15 -0700
Received: from cmac20.Colorado.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id KAA09442; Wed, 29 May 1996 10:34:08 -0700
Received: from [198.59.61.5] by cmac20.Colorado.EDU
 with SMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.1); Wed, 29 May 1996 11:37:46 -0600
Subject: Re: adolescent rave perspective
Date: Wed, 29 May 96 11:37:42 -0600
From: Andy Hawks <andy@cmac20.colorado.edu>
To: "Sanfrandisco Raves" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Message-ID: <1378752630-306661@cmac20.Colorado.EDU>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>After talking with these two 16 year olds I felt kinda sad, thinking 
>that there may be a major lack of spirituality to alot of the younger 
>people going to raves.  

I'm 22, I've been going to parties for about 4-5 years in Colorado, but I 
can honestly say I didn't see raves as anything "spiritual" until the 
last couple years.....I don't really know if I saw *anything* as truly 
spiritual until the last couple years....

A certain amount of that lack of spirituality comes from, simply and 
stereotypically, youth.  Most 16 year-olds don't know themselves well 
enough, don't know their world well enough, haven't really experienced 
enough to *gnow* a spiritual experience. Those that do are the exception 
rather than the rule by far, I'd say.  

Also, what you get out of rave culture, your opinions on what it's really 
all about, are largely shaped by your environment....If you come from a 
circle of friends that's young and not very spiritual-minded you're 
probably less likely to look at parties from that perspective....But if 
you're on SF-Raves or have read Hyperreal, read a lot of philosophy, do a 
fair amount of x or acid and little else, go to parties all the time, 
etc., etc., you're probably more likely to identify with the spiritual 
spect of rave culture.

All anyone can do in this regard is break down barriers that prevent 
people from seeing things in a different light.  So props for hinting at 
the spiritual possibility of rave culture for these kids.  Undoubtedly, 
the next time they go to a party, that's gonna cross their head.  And 
then it's up to them to do something with the seed you planted.

> 
> 
> > Seriously though, some important issues were brought up.  Like really, what
> > HAS been the influence of rave OUTSIDE the rave sphere?  Please spare the
> > "techno in commercials". I am talking impact, not pablum.
> 
> I think this is a moot point.   The whole idea of an underground rave scene
> is that it is seperate from trying to impact the rest of society.  I think
> if we look back to the sixties, where there was a huge push to have the
> subculture clash directly with mainstream culture, mainstream culture always
> won out.

On a macro scale, perhaps.  But you had alot of kids from different 
backgrounds, in the 60's, getting introduced to each other.  Music was 
part of the unification glue.  These people, from that point on unlike 
thier parents, met and even talked to, on a human-to-human basis with 
people far different than they.  This had an impact, no doubt.  The 60's 
weren't ALL wasteful.


> I don't really expect the rave culture to change our existsing, sick
> culture.  Instead, I see 2 different cultures... one rising up and one
> fading away.  I mean, the only way rave spreads is from one person to another.
> Try as we will, but a positive view of raves will never be seen in the mass
> media.  All we can do is try our best to make sure they are not outright 
> lying (as in the Hard Copy story), and present our views as articulately as
> possible in other information channels not owned by transnational corperations.
> 

Agreed.

> > As I have always said, the media exists for one reason...its own existence.
> 
> Brainwashing the masses.  Defining a reality within narrow materialistic
> parameters.  Supressing thought.  Distracting people from the true
> reality.  ect, ect, ect.  
> 

Agreed, etc. etc. :)

> Rave mailing lists are one of the most valuable tools we have to spread the
> rave culture.
> 
> -troy
> 

Whoaaa doctor!  I don't necessarily beleive this at all, and think this 
is more technology as lifestyle hype.  The people who have access to this 
have a computer.  This tends to be the minority of the people involved in 
dance culture.  This also tends to limit the exposure to the point where 
exclusivity is damn near unavoidable.  Yeah, people find out about things 
through others via the list, but you gotta know someone on the list. I 
think this is harder to access for most than a simple telephone call.

I think one of the most valuable tools we have to spread the rave culture 
is our voice, our hands in peace, and a good solid telephone connection, 
7 digits and a voice on the other end asking "So, where is it?"  and the 
reply is "A warehouse on xxxxxxx and yyyyyy.  Bring some friends, it 
oughta be good!".

My Numark 2060 has a cross fader for the headphones, which I find to be an
incredible advantage over the assignable left/right in the headphones kinda
thing, or the either on/off buttons that the Rane's have.  I find I can beat
mix much more precisely with the crossfader feature....but then again, I may
just need more practice.

> > I'm 22, I've been going to parties for about 4-5 years in Colorado, but I 
> > can honestly say I didn't see raves as anything "spiritual" until the 
> > last couple years.....I don't really know if I saw *anything* as truly 
> > spiritual until the last couple years....
> 
> It also may well be that the viewing of raves as "spiritual" events is 
> San Franciscocentric. I get the impression from talking to people from 
> areas other than the Bay Area, and from reading posts from people that 
> have gone to parties elsewhere that the "spiritual" aspect is not present(I 
> won't say lacking,) or least as not as much an issue. Does this make any 
> sense?
> 
>                                                       

It makes sense, but I don't think it is just a sfcentric thing.  Talk
to anyone who has been to a Moontribe in LA... serious spirituality there.
But even if people don't call it spiriutality per se, I think there can
still be good vibe.   Over the Christmas break I went to Seattle and checked
out a great little party.  People had lots of energy and were really into the
music and everyone was nice.  Dancing is generally a spiritual experience.
But you don't tend to label it as such if you are in a nightclub or a
warehouse.  Sometimes, it takes dancing to the sunrise in the middle of a 
vast desert with panoramic 200 mile views to make you label an experience
as "Spiritual"

-troy

John S. Lee sez: 
> I have never looked at UG as some unique clique.  I think SFR is more of 
> a clique than the overall culture.

Really?  Except for a few of us diehards, the personnel on this list
keeps changing.  Don't post for a couple of months and  hardly anyone
know who you are.  Perhaps the list is exclusive to those with
internet access, but it's hardly a clique.

> [...]  UG, IMO, is all about communication between people who trust one 
> another.  It certainly is not about making a general announcement on a 
> list of over 400+ people, I tend to think of them as more personal.

I think it's pretty cool when you can trust that a non-UG party will
have enough great music and enough of a vibe that people will come 
together with unity and respect.  With an underground, where fully
trusted people are carefully preselected, sure, you get good results,
but the accomplishment just doesn't seem as special.  You brought
together people who already are together.  Not much *new* trust is
created.  But everyone has a blast, and maybe that's the main goal.

> alot of spoiled brats complaining about what isn't at a party (there is 
> always a list opf what wasn't there).  Hell, if they would've gone to the 
> first equinox, held in a very sweaty e-filled warehouse in Hunters Point, 
> they would appreciate the bean bag and 1.25 water.  It's all a matter of 
> historical perspective.  To me, many of these "kids" (i.e. new skollers) 
> are soft.  But that's just me.

Well, count me as an old skooler who has gone soft.  I get more out
of (and can give more to) a party when I'm not hot, dehydrated and 
pressed up against someone's back.  I used to put up with
that kind of punishment when it was the only way to get near
the music I love.  I understand the bonding-through-shared-pain
thing, but I prefer to bond through shared pleasure.  YMMV.

> No, UG has it's place, and I think it keeps the scene very real.  It's 
> nice to go to a party that had no flyers, and is only avaialbe by vox 
> contact.  I guess it requires some networking, but to me, it is well 
> worth the effort.  

> > Such parties only go off (IMO) when
> > there aren't many other good choices. 
> 
> This is not so.  UG's are held even when there are other popular massives 
> or better known parties.  They still manage to go off.  Wassup?

Yes, true.  I retract my original statement.

> > Not that there's anything
> > wrong with a bunch of friends getting together,  but there's nothing
> > like the fresh energy exchange and unity that happens when it's with
> > people who *don't* know each other.
> 
> There is also nothing like being with people you trust.  People you can 
> hang out with, people who know how to handle their substances w/o use of 
> an ambulance, people who will take care of each other.  There is 
> something to say about both kinds fo energy, I just like it when there 
> are more expereienced folks to help direct such energies.

This does happen (sometimes) at parties that you would not consider to be
trictly undergound.  I guess it's all matter of degree.

>   I know plenty of old 
> skoolers who hang out at UG's and have a really good time.  No biitchin' 
> about water or a place to chill out.  People are talking chatting 
> laughing, and goofing on each other and the newbies.  New people get 
> introduced to some of the skoolers, and the tradition lives on.

Yeah, the whole *scene* thing can be fun.  And the scenes within the
scene; that sense of belonging, of being cool 'cause of who you know.
It can all be very superficial as well, the "I'm cool, you're cool"
mindset.  What ever happenned to getting down on the dance floor
and connecting to complete strangers through the music?

> It's all good.

Agreed!

> (Unity cannot happen without familiarity.  Introductions go alot farther 
> than a chance meeting at a party.)

Well, there's the Unity of the moment, which I've seen happen purely
through music and dance, and then there's the unity of the scene, which
I think you are focusing more on, and is needed to sustain a sense of
community.  Both are important.

> P.S.  And yes, I do go out alot more now that I'm spinning, and planning 
> on doing some events this year.  Time to get back and catch the groove.

Looking forward to seeing you!

Lee

>My Numark 2060 has a cross fader for the headphones, which I find to be an
>incredible advantage over the assignable left/right in the headphones kinda
>thing, or the either on/off buttons that the Rane's have.  I find I can beat
>mix much more precisely with the crossfader feature....but then again, I may
>just need more practice.
>
>Rick

Both Ranes (the MP-22 & MP-24) have cross-fading for the headphones,
although it's not a crossfader, it's a knob. I know with the 24 it's
possible to assign a turntable to each ear, and I think you can with the
22, too. The sound quality on either of them will blow away any Numark
(IMO).

-john

Received: from [136.152.95.73] (blather.HIP.Berkeley.EDU [136.152.95.73]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.5/8.6.12) with SMTP id MAA01429 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 29 May 1996 12:18:48 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Wed, 29 May 1996 12:18:48 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <v02130504add1d82a88c7@[136.152.95.73]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
X-mailer: Eudora Pro 2.1.3
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (michal migurski)
Subject: Re: media representations of rave culture
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>"Yeah, but ecstacy makes you listen to really bad music!" and the crowd
>erupted into laughter.
>I don't know, maybe I'm just hyper-sensitized, but there is a lot of
>resistance out there.  And I just don't see why!  They don't make jokes
>about how rotten Nirvana is or how bad punk rock is or how sad it is that
>Aerosmith came back from the dead to milk a few more bucks out of the

I think it's because techno is such a completely different *form* of music
than rock... for one thing no one respects it because it's "fake" (it is).
People who don't listen to techno are accustomed to the usual "musician ->
star" progression, and they get confused because making techno music
doesn't take much  practice, so how can anyone be a fan and how can anyone
be accorded respect for making such a simplistic form of music? However,
unlike rock music, the typical techno musician doesn't really expect any
kind of star-type recognition... for the most part, they remain pretty much
anonymous (with some exceptions like orbital or the prodigy). The musicians
are basically in the business to provide DJs with music... listening to a
typical trance single is pretty boring; it doesn't _really_ become music
until it's mixed with other songs playng at the same time... it's like the
DJ is the musician, and the records are just instruments. No one wants to
listen to a single tambourine being hit over and over, but when it's
"mixed" with a bunch of other instruments it becomes "music," just like a
boring trance single becomes music when a DJ takes control and actually
uses it to provide a changing mood.

Then there's gabber...

boomboomboomboomboomboomboomboomweeweeweeweeboomboomboomboom

Gabber just flat out confuses me.

I think my point escaped me somewhere in here...

-m.

At 9:17 AM -0600 5/29/96, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
>uhhh, doesn't all numark equipment suck??
>
>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
>==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Nope. New Numark equipment is mode by a different manufacturer than the
older mixers that everybody has (1750, 1800, 1950, etc.) The original
Numark went bankrupt awhile back and somone else bought the name. I don't
know much about the quality of newer mixers, but I haven't heard anything
bad. The older Numark stuff is fine, but certainly not in the same class as
Biamp, Urei, or Rane.

MTX supposedly is designed and/or made by some of the original Numark
engineers and has a decent reputation for mid-priced equipment.

Joe

Before we get into flame wasr about newbies, old-skool, new-skool etc.  
Let me preface by saying this was private e-mail.  It was not meant to be 
read by everyone.  I still stand by what I say though.

> 
> John S. Lee sez: 
> > I have never looked at UG as some unique clique.  I think SFR is more of 
> > a clique than the overall culture.
> 
> Really?  Except for a few of us diehards, the personnel on this list
> keeps changing.  Don't post for a couple of months and  hardly anyone
> know who you are.  Perhaps the list is exclusive to those with
> internet access, but it's hardly a clique.

I was applying your definition, from my view, of what a clique was.  The 
list is a cliquey as any arty that has any exclusivity.  The fact that 
you need internet access is enough of a limiting factor, IMO.


> 
> > [...]  UG, IMO, is all about communication between people who trust one 
> > another.  It certainly is not about making a general announcement on a 
> > list of over 400+ people, I tend to think of them as more personal.
> 
> I think it's pretty cool when you can trust that a non-UG party will
> have enough great music and enough of a vibe that people will come 
> together with unity and respect.  With an underground, where fully
> trusted people are carefully preselected, sure, you get good results,
> but the accomplishment just doesn't seem as special.  You brought
> together people who already are together.  Not much *new* trust is
> created.  But everyone has a blast, and maybe that's the main goal.
> 

Did you read the post Lee (or should I say private e-mail).  I said that 
new people are brought in.  It's not all that.  New people are what has 
kept this thing going as long as it has.  I do argue about how things are 
done.  But there is no argument that new people are the fuel of dance 
culture.  And it is that aspect, new people, trusted new people, getting 
involved, then going off and doing their own thing.  It's all about 
netoworking, gaining trust & respect, and sharing it with others.  NOT 
holding it to one's self.

As for new trust?  It is created all the time in UG.  Trust that.
It wouldn't be happening if it weren't for new people gettin' involved.

> > alot of spoiled brats complaining about what isn't at a party (there is 
> > always a list opf what wasn't there).  Hell, if they would've gone to the 
> > first equinox, held in a very sweaty e-filled warehouse in Hunters Point, 
> > they would appreciate the bean bag and 1.25 water.  It's all a matter of 
> > historical perspective.  To me, many of these "kids" (i.e. new skollers) 
> > are soft.  But that's just me.
> 
> Well, count me as an old skooler who has gone soft.  I get more out
> of (and can give more to) a party when I'm not hot, dehydrated and 
> pressed up against someone's back.  I used to put up with
> that kind of punishment when it was the only way to get near
> the music I love.  I understand the bonding-through-shared-pain
> thing, but I prefer to bond through shared pleasure.  YMMV.
> 

To each his own.

> > No, UG has it's place, and I think it keeps the scene very real.  It's 
> > nice to go to a party that had no flyers, and is only avaialbe by vox 
> > contact.  I guess it requires some networking, but to me, it is well 
> > worth the effort.  
> 
> > > Such parties only go off (IMO) when
> > > there aren't many other good choices. 
> > 
> > This is not so.  UG's are held even when there are other popular massives 
> > or better known parties.  They still manage to go off.  Wassup?
> 
> Yes, true.  I retract my original statement.
> 
> > > Not that there's anything
> > > wrong with a bunch of friends getting together,  but there's nothing
> > > like the fresh energy exchange and unity that happens when it's with
> > > people who *don't* know each other.
> > 
> > There is also nothing like being with people you trust.  People you can 
> > hang out with, people who know how to handle their substances w/o use of 
> > an ambulance, people who will take care of each other.  There is 
> > something to say about both kinds fo energy, I just like it when there 
> > are more expereienced folks to help direct such energies.
> 
> This does happen (sometimes) at parties that you would not consider to be
> trictly undergound.  I guess it's all matter of degree.
> 

All depends on if I and others trust the person who is doing the show.  
But I agree, it's all a matter of degree.


> >   I know plenty of old 
> > skoolers who hang out at UG's and have a really good time.  No biitchin' 
> > about water or a place to chill out.  People are talking chatting 
> > laughing, and goofing on each other and the newbies.  New people get 
> > introduced to some of the skoolers, and the tradition lives on.
> 
> Yeah, the whole *scene* thing can be fun  And the scenes within the
> scene; that sense of belonging, of being cool 'cause of who you know.
> It can all be very superficial as well, the "I'm cool, you're cool"
> mindset.  What ever happenned to getting down on the dance floor
> and connecting to complete strangers through the music?
> 

I ask myself this everythgime I hear someone complain about a chill space 
(a relatively new invention).  As for connections, from what I see and 
hear, they are still being made.

I do not think this is all about being cool or whatever characterization 
you continue to allude to.  I think it is a matter of direct 
communication, building trust, nad hanging out with friends you've 
connected with or been introduced to.  If there is any "cool" part, it is 
the direct communication and trsut that is built.  The rest of that "seen 
and be seen" ain't what I'm talking about.

As far as I am concerned, everyone is in a scene.  Admitted or not.  As 
you gravitate from one place to another, you get to know the parties 
people associate themselves with.  As a result you start to see the same 
faces you've seen at the last event.  If familairity is a scene, then 
we're all in scene's one way or another.  

When I use scene, I mean dance culture.

> > It's all good.
> 
> Agreed!
> 
> > (Unity cannot happen without familiarity.  Introductions go alot farther 
> > than a chance meeting at a party.)
> 
> Well, there's the Unity of the moment, which I've seen happen purely
> through music and dance, and then there's the unity of the scene, which
> I think you are focusing more on, and is needed to sustain a sense of
> community.  Both are important.
> 

I have seen both.  My focus?  Is on dance culture, and how it can be 
nurtured for further growth.

Unity of the scene?  I have never said that, I have talked about unity of 
people, communication, trust, hangin' out with those you trust, etc.  
Goals, I think are common to all of us in one way or another.  I think 
you mistook some of what I said, but it happens.

And the ouside world looks onto us as a scene so....it's all a matter of 
perspective.

Unity of the moment?  It happens!  Although I find it a rare commodity 
these days.

> > P.S.  And yes, I do go out alot more now that I'm spinning, and planning 
> > on doing some events this year.  Time to get back and catch the groove.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed May 29 12:59:53 1996

Date: Wed, 29 May 1996 12:59:40 -0700 (PDT)
From: jess <jfogler@itsa.ucsf.EDU>
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: SFcentric - LONG
Message-ID: <Pine.A32.3.93.960529123454.163282O-100000@itsa.ucsf.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


It _is_ true that california in general and SF in particular are some of
the new-age capitals of the world and as such, discussions of spirituality
are much more commonplace and acceptable here than many other places.

However, having spent last summer in the UK, where I grew up, I must say
that I was surprised at the number of discussions relating to PLUR and
spiritual things - topics which are often scorned and laughed at outside
of the rave scene.

Young people in England are pretty harsh with each other - "bitch" is your
favorite word for your best friend and groups of young adults will spend a
lot of time "slagging each other off" (teasing each other in a sort of
pointed and painful way) - you have to really toughen up to be able to
take it.  I used to get my feelings hurt a lot.

Also, young people in England and most other European countries have
pretty negative feelings about the US and turn their noses up at things
that smack of americanism - such as discussions of PLUR and spirituality
at raves for example - which they consider to be frank proof of how
shallow and superficial americans are - all touchy feely with no
substance, no honestly and no sense of reality 

HOWEVER, I almost fell over backwards at a rave in England last year when
some bloke told me that the scene in SF was reported to be "really
beautiful with lots of people loving each other".  And, if you read
UK-dance (which I highly recommend if you want to get out of your american
imperialist, self-centered attitude that thinks that this country is the
center of the universe), you will find references to PLUR and things
spiritual....so it isn't just SF afterall.

I personally think that the English have a lot to thank for raves and for
E because it's softened a rather harsh social scene.  So, this
spirituality that we talk of _is_ the reason other people in other parts
of the world are so hooked on raving - even if they don't talk about it in
those terms or as often.

But I also think we have something to learn from those people who aren't
so committed to the spiritual side of things as well as people who
criticize this aspect as being phoney and shallow.  I think we often use
PLUR as a way to avoid conflict and sometimes as a way to avoid the
realities of our relationships with each other - there are beautiful
things at raves, and there are some very ugly things.  Life isn't about
just looking at the beautiful things, it's about seeing reality, in all
its forms and about coming to some inner peace about that reality - it
_must_ be ok the way it is just because it _is_ that way - that doesn't
mean
that it has to be all nice and fuzzy and palatable all the time.  The
English prefer a harsh look at reality and, I would suggest, tend to err
on
the side of emphasizing the negative - we USers, especially in SF tend to
try and focus only on the positive things (peace man) - I think some
merger of the two is where the real power lies.  You wanna get really
high?  then let go of the PLUR crap and really LOOK at what life is all
about - then you will find beauty even in the ugliness and that's when
you'll be set free


	ranting and raving,
		jess

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed May 29 13:46:37 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA02407; Wed, 29 May 1996 13:46:37 -0700
Received: from cmac20.Colorado.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA02400; Wed, 29 May 1996 13:46:32 -0700
Received: from [198.59.61.5] by cmac20.Colorado.EDU
 with SMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.1); Wed, 29 May 1996 14:50:21 -0600
Subject: keeping plur in check (Re: SFcentric - LONG)
Date: Wed, 29 May 96 14:50:20 -0600
From: Andy Hawks <andy@cmac20.colorado.edu>
To: "Sanfrandisco Raves" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Message-ID: <1378741075-151516@cmac20.Colorado.EDU>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>But I also think we have something to learn from those people who aren't
>so committed to the spiritual side of things as well as people who
>criticize this aspect as being phoney and shallow.  I think we often use
>PLUR as a way to avoid conflict and sometimes as a way to avoid the
>realities of our relationships with each other 

i agree wholeheartedly...

there's no question in my mind that the hedonistic positive atmosphere 
created at parties -- comprised of a plur ethic that fades havily when 
the party's over, use of x and other drugs, indulgent ritualistic dance, 
and the very nature of walking around the space sharing smiles/candy/toys 
with strangers and people you abrely know -- has so much potential to 
create within a person an almost lobotomized bliss, and if that outlook 
becomes your dominant approach to the world, then you're in 
trouble...that's when plur becomes shallow, phony, and an escape....

a lot of "party people" live in this state of mind...i think it's vital 
to get beyond that, and, as you say later, look at all of life -- don't 
be blinded by plur, that's not a Good Thing.  when you find yourself 
surrounded by numerous acquaintances and shallow friendships and lacking 
in a comfortable amount of long-term and substantive connections, when 
you find yourself reading flyers instead of the New York Times, when 
everyone close to you is someone you'll see at the next FMR, if you're 
all plur on the outside and all wrecked up on the inside, those are all 
signs that it's time to re-broaden your perspective of the world.

the plur attitude, like any other mindset comprised of powerful feelings 
and a desire to affect other people with it, can be dangerous if not kept 
in check...people don't think that there can be anything negative about 
peace, love, unity, and respect, but there definitely can, especially in 
a culture as innately self-indulgent as rave.  i mean, every war is 
fought in the name of furthering peace.  

when a community is in the building process there's always that stage 
where things are "fake" and on the surface for the purpose of creating 
ties that bind tht allow the community to be built further and extended.  
i think global rave culture on the whole is still pretty much in that 
stage, even after 10 years.  after that -- and after the falling out and 
the hard times that always follow -- there's the opportunity for real 
community to be established.  that means that there is potential within 
rave culture for true peace, true love, true unity, true respect.  but we 
should never lose site of the fact that just because we talk about it and 
practice it in small ways doesn't mean we've truly achieved it -- it just 
means we're on the path. i think it's a journey worth taking.

> Life isn't about
>just looking at the beautiful things, it's about seeing reality, in all
>its forms and about coming to some inner peace about that reality - it
>_must_ be ok the way it is just because it _is_ that way - that doesn't
>mean that it has to be all nice and fuzzy and palatable all the time. 

props.

> You wanna get really
>high?  then let go of the PLUR crap and really LOOK at what life is all
>about - then you will find beauty even in the ugliness and that's when
>you'll be set free

it's just all about acceptance of things as they are -- letting go of 
desires to change things in your own vision, letting go of fear of things 
you don't understand or don't gnow about....the more you're able to 
accept yourself and your world, the more it instills within you a sense 
of true well-being and, yeah, freedom. ugly things lose their ugliness, 
power/greed/selfishness fade to nothingness, fear is replaced by love.  

but i think it's wrong to say "let go of the plur crap"....  the plur 
ethic is a tool and as long as it's kept in check like i said above i 
think it's a very valuable tool that for some is a guide along parts of 
the path to freedom. there's no one path to personal freedom -- it's an 
infinite sky.

>About this deadhead and rave connection, there is one, and there always has
>been one.  In one way or the other.  There is little doubt though that
>there is an active migration, heavier now than before.  Predictable.
>
>Out,
>John

Predictable, and a natural shift-of-medium/style, like learning to paint
impressionist after having spent time painting abstractionist (note: these
were chosen at random).  The collective known as ravers is composed of many
different kinds of people, all very individual and with varied beliefs and
tastes, but we're unified through music/dance, and some of us are unified
through spirituality.  Know what?  That's exactly what many of the
Deadheads were/are all about, too!  It doesn't take a label, a clothing
style, a drug, or a particular taste in music to make me the kind of person
that I am, but people like us are drawn together in different ways, by
similar forces, and it's very natural that we join together at times.  It's
an intersection of circles, which hopefully will expand to become a union,
IMHO.  Where else would we be?  What else could draw us together?  We're
family!

You all rule, and you know it :)  - E

At 12:59 PM 5/29/96 -0700, you wrote:

>Young people in England are pretty harsh with each other - "bitch" is your
>favorite word for your best friend and groups of young adults will spend a
>lot of time "slagging each other off" (teasing each other in a sort of
>pointed and painful way) - you have to really toughen up to be able to
>take it.  I used to get my feelings hurt a lot.

I was in the UK for about 2 years and noticed (IMO, and personal observation)
that the young people are alot more harsh because there is alot more
drinking there as well as other things. Mostly by males. I remember a few
friends and I had to pull off a guy hitting his girlfriend because she went
and hugged some other guy. This wasn't at a "RAVE" but a place were they had
Techno music playing, so it was a similar environment as maybe 1015 Folsom,
kinda clubby but not real clubby. If drinking wasn't has heavy out there, I
think the scene out there could be alot like it is out here. For what I have
seen there, most of the males act to macho because the are drinking and in
turn that's were all the harshness comes from. Remember this is just what
I've notice when I was there.

>Also, young people in England and most other European countries have
>pretty negative feelings about the US and turn their noses up at things
>that smack of americanism - such as discussions of PLUR and spirituality
>at raves for example - which they consider to be frank proof of how
>shallow and superficial americans are - all touchy feely with no
>substance, no honestly and no sense of reality 
>
>HOWEVER, I almost fell over backwards at a rave in England last year when
>some bloke told me that the scene in SF was reported to be "really
>beautiful with lots of people loving each other".  And, if you read
>UK-dance (which I highly recommend if you want to get out of your american
>imperialist, self-centered attitude that thinks that this country is the
>center of the universe), you will find references to PLUR and things
>spiritual....so it isn't just SF afterall.
>
>I personally think that the English have a lot to thank for raves and for
>E because it's softened a rather harsh social scene.  So, this
>spirituality that we talk of _is_ the reason other people in other parts
>of the world are so hooked on raving - even if they don't talk about it in
>those terms or as often.

I would agree here. Drinking played a roll it this too. There has actually
been a little decline on the drinking by the people in the age group that
usually attend "Raves". So "I" think this also softened up some of that
harshness in the scene over there.
>

>>pretty negative feelings about the US and turn their noses up at things

for years, and have plenty of British friends here in the US. This 
"slagging off" isn't a regional issue. Weak people anywhere will treat you 
badly if you allow it.

Wow,  you're a perceptive motherf***er aren't you :)
You're right on many points about my anger and my shitty attitude but I
think I also have a pretty strong experience on which to base some of my
opinions..

>  Exactly who are you accusing of having this "imperialist, self-centered 
> attitude"? I hope it's not me (or anyone else on this list you don't know 
> intimately). You are in no position to make such a judgement en masse.

Yes I am since I have seen in almost every American I meet here and
abroad, whether or not they see it in themselves - ask any out of towner.

When I first moved to this country, at the age of 17, I couldn't believe
how ignorant USers were about the rest of the world.  At first I thought
people were just lazy but now I realize how brainwashed we all are by the
crappy mainstream media over here that thinks a kitten getting stuck in a
cardboard box is headline new and spends no more than 4.5 minutes of an
hour on international news.  

Not all USers are so ignorant but you gotta
be pretty damn industrious and committed to keep alert to the important
goings on in other parts of the world.  If you are one of those people,
then more power to you, but I'm not and I find myself becoming more and
more unaware, the more I live here.  So I don't blame us as individuals,
but I do think we have a certain tendancy to be obsessed with
our own culture whether we realize it or not.  If you have ever travelled
you will quickly realize how
much more every one in the world knows about our culture than we know
about theirs.  Not our fault, but true, and worth rectifying if we ever
intend to do something about the US cultural domination that is sweeping
the planet and destroying many indigenous and beautiful cultures. 

> 
>  Interesting how you capitalize "England" and "European" but repeatedly 
> fail to capitalize any word having "america" as it's prefix.
>  Who's really got the problem here, Jess?

You're right - I'm mad about it.
> 

> >>lot of time "slagging each other off" (teasing each other in a sort of
> >>pointed and painful way) - you have to really toughen up to be able to
> >>take it.  I used to get my feelings hurt a lot.
> 
>  No you don't. You just need to make some new friends who aren't so insecure.
> I work for a UK-based company, have delt with British and European people 
> for years, and have plenty of British friends here in the US. This 
> "slagging off" isn't a regional issue. Weak people anywhere will treat you 
> badly if you allow it.

I disagree.  UK adults are pretty polite and friendly on the whole, but if
you are a teenager or young adult - IN ENGLAND - I think you'll find it
pretty different.  Also, if you meet English people here in the States,
outside of their home base, don't you think you'll be experiencing a
unique interaction with them?  They, then are the minority, trying to make
their way in a social scene dictated by us. 

If you want to get a taste of how young English people are with each other
then watch "Eastenders" - it's a UK soap about a working class group of
neighbours (spelling intended :) ) and it's on KTEH (channel 54 or cable)
and
you'll see how harsh they are with each other - OK, its drama but it's
really not so different - the aesthetic is correct even if the level of
harshness is upped for TV pleasure (?)

 > It isn't my intention
to just slam you for sport, but what are you > _really_ angry about?

Jfogler wrote:  >> we often use PLUR as a way to avoid conflict and sometimes
as a way to avoid the realities of our relationsh<< tiny part(read the whole

Excellent post Jess, very fresh!  Although this may be a hard perspective to
jive with at first, I feel everyone should read that post with open heart and
mind.
We should also remember though, that positivity is the road that took us to
where we stand.  And from where I'm standing that's something to be proud and
appreciative of.  It has taken a concious act to evolve ourselves from into
living more positive lives.  One thing we have all learned is our ability to
make a positive change in our surroundings or our situation merely by
changing our view and attitude towards it.  So yes, we should be leary of
using plur as a sort visor to evil, but also beware of keeping it hidden in
it's case, exposing your soul face first to all the harsh truths and evil
realities of  existence is not the simple solution either.   Perhaps we
should also be cautious using "plur" as a multi-purpose "that covers it"
phrase as well.  We seem to have bundled up quite a surplus of meaning in one
little word.  Perhaps sometimes spelling it out we may be less likely to find
fault in it. Certainly I cant find apathy, ignorance or denial in: PEACE,
 LOVE,  UNITY  AND REPSECT.
PLUR,
Steveo

From: Roy Feague <rfeague@starfishsoftware.com>
Subject: ECommunication Pitfalls, NRR, kinda long
To: "Daniel J. MacMillan" <djm@crl.com>
Cc: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
X-Mailer: Worldtalk (NetConnex V4.00a)/MIME
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hi Dan,
(Hi all,)
 Wow!   It's pretty clear that Jess got your hackles up.  That's   
certainly understandable, since no one likes to be on the receiving end   
of a generalization.  But your response inspired me to want to point out   
how careful we need to be about messages that smack of personal attack.   
 There are some shining examples in the past month of where this applies.
 As far as Jess' message, most people would probably agree that there are   
plenty of people in this country who really don't know anything about the   
rest of the world, and who think America is Number 1, not by rational   
thought and comparison, but by fiat.  So if the shoe fits, wear it.  If   
it doesn't, and it sounds like it doesn't in your case, Dan, don't.  I'm   
pretty sure there was no malicious intention to suggest that EVERYONE   
fits this bill.
 In your response, you publicly suggest "attitude", and then going on to   
suggest a hidden issue or agenda.  It seems like personal attack, and is   
going to arouse animosity and hurt feelings (correct me if I'm wrong   
here).  So what do ya do, pretend you're not angry?  Perhaps such things   
are best suited to a PERSONAL email, keeping the public response very   
consciously free of attack-tone.
 So why is THIS message a public post?  Because I want to suggest   
publicly that people take angry responses directly to the person in   
question, so there isn't the public attack element to exacerbate the   
situation (Isn't exacerbate a great word?), and keep the public responses   
as personal-attack-sound-free as possible.  I have had a couple of people   
contact me that way, and I think it works out much better, and keeps a   
friendlier community tone.  I'm not saying people should be falsely   
friendly, I'm saying taking grievance to the source FIRST will much more   
likely result in an amicable solution.  As far as the need for public   
rebuttal, that can be tone in a fairly neutral tone.
 Has anybody else noticed how pitfall-frought electronic communication   
is?  Without the aural and visual cues of observing the speaker, it's   
really easy to hear malice where there's none, or to have situations   
escalate beyond the intentions of either party, or to take half-serious   
and overly-general statements more seriously than they were intended.   
 That's why the use of smileys like :) in email isn't just cute, it's   
really essential to fill the missing element of intended tone!!  I have   
had SO many bad situations where I emailed something that was intended   
jokingly to a friend, and got back an ANGRY message because the intention   
wasn't clear.  I'm sure someone else has had similar experiences?

My $0.02, free to you guys during my special month-end pontification   
sale.
;)
 -Roy


 ----------

attitude"? I hope it's not me (or anyone else on this list you don't know   

intimately). You are in no position to make such a judgement en masse.

>>Also, young people in England and most other European countries have
>>pretty negative feelings about the US and turn their noses up at things
>>that smack of americanism - such as discussions of PLUR and   
spirituality
>>at raves for example - which they consider to be frank proof of how
>>shallow and superficial americans are - all touchy feely with no
>>substance, no honestly and no sense of reality

fail to capitalize any word having "america" as it's prefix.
 Who's really got the problem here, Jess?

>>lot of time "slagging each other off" (teasing each other in a sort of
>>pointed and painful way) - you have to really toughen up to be able to
>>take it.  I used to get my feelings hurt a lot.

 No you don't. You just need to make some new friends who aren't so   
insecure.
I work for a UK-based company, have delt with British and European people   

for years, and have plenty of British friends here in the US. This
"slagging off" isn't a regional issue. Weak people anywhere will treat   
you
badly if you allow it.
   

 It isn't my intention to just slam you for sport, but what are you
_really_ angry about?



Dan

Wow!!

Roy, you ended up summing up (and adding more) of what I felt about this 
entire issue.  

My feelings on this - when you read e-mail please don't take everything 
personally and give people some slack.  Sometimes all of us say/write 
things that are not 100% thought through.  I do it a lot (more in RL 
conversations, but in e-mail as well).

I think Dan, you were a little bit too harsh on Jess, because she did 
bring up some interesting points. 

Maybe one day all of us will learn how to communicate better, because 
that's usually the souce of many problems.

Hugz,
Branka

P.S.  Hope to meet people I haven't met at TF and hope to see many ppl I 
already know.  

On Wed, 29 May 1996, Roy Feague wrote:

> 
> Hi Dan,
> (Hi all,)
>  Wow!   It's pretty clear that Jess got your hackles up.  That's   
> certainly understandable, since no one likes to be on the receiving end   
> of a generalization.  But your response inspired me to want to point out   
> how careful we need to be about messages that smack of personal attack.   
>  There are some shining examples in the past month of where this applies.
>  As far as Jess' message, most people would probably agree that there are   
> plenty of people in this country who really don't know anything about the   
> rest of the world, and who think America is Number 1, not by rational   
> thought and comparison, but by fiat.  So if the shoe fits, wear it.  If   
> it doesn't, and it sounds like it doesn't in your case, Dan, don't.  I'm   
> pretty sure there was no malicious intention to suggest that EVERYONE   
> fits this bill.
>  In your response, you publicly suggest "attitude", and then going on to   
> suggest a hidden issue or agenda.  It seems like personal attack, and is   
> going to arouse animosity and hurt feelings (correct me if I'm wrong   
> here).  So what do ya do, pretend you're not angry?  Perhaps such things   
> are best suited to a PERSONAL email, keeping the public response very   
> consciously free of attack-tone.
>  So why is THIS message a public post?  Because I want to suggest   
> publicly that people take angry responses directly to the person in   
> question, so there isn't the public attack element to exacerbate the   
> situation (Isn't exacerbate a great word?), and keep the public responses   
> as personal-attack-sound-free as possible.  I have had a couple of people   
> contact me that way, and I think it works out much better, and keeps a   
> friendlier community tone.  I'm not saying people should be falsely   
> friendly, I'm saying taking grievance to the source FIRST will much more   
> likely result in an amicable solution.  As far as the need for public   
> rebuttal, that can be tone in a fairly neutral tone.
>  Has anybody else noticed how pitfall-frought electronic communication   
> is?  Without the aural and visual cues of observing the speaker, it's   
> really easy to hear malice where there's none, or to have situations   
> escalate beyond the intentions of either party, or to take half-serious   
> and overly-general statements more seriously than they were intended.   
>  That's why the use of smileys like :) in email isn't just cute, it's   
> really essential to fill the missing element of intended tone!!  I have   
> had SO many bad situations where I emailed something that was intended   
> jokingly to a friend, and got back an ANGRY message because the intention   
> wasn't clear.  I'm sure someone else has had similar experiences?
> 
> My $0.02, free to you guys during my special month-end pontification   
> sale.
> ;)
>  -Roy
> 
> 
>  ----------

Hey everyone quick notes on parties attended the past weekend:

Sat : Nexus in People's Park

  Beautiful day and fun music for most of the time there. i actually 
danced to carlos when he got deep for a bit ;)  it really helped my
suntan tho

Sun:  Sunset

  Arrived around 6 and heard DJ named michael from Seattle spin.  he
was good, and i really liked Lauren (sp?) who spun next. funky but 
hard set that really got me moving.  this was only my second sunset of 
this year and i was suprised by how many new faces i didnt recognize
but some old skoolers came towards the end.  I actually met a SFRaver
also (hey Sarah!) =)

Sun Night : Spundae's

  This was a lot of fun.  At the end of the night i was worn out cause i
had been taken on a house excursion by Tom Aquaviva (thats his name right?)
and when he played this one song i bought two years ago but never heard
out before, I was running around in ecstatic circles and jumping up
and down in front of the dj booth.  =)

well thats it for now.  peace and see ya around

doug ) ( dougie@sfsu.edu

Subject: MONEY = HAPPINESS (non rave)

Precedence: bulk

I would like to sharewith SFRaves a letter I wrote back to my friend: 
 
On Tue, May 28, 1996 5:12:22 PM, 
 
  A FRIEND OF MINE wrote: 
 
 >Actually, one of the things keeping me here is the possibility of mucho
money...  = 
>I'm trying to be a millionaire by 28 yrs old.  I know I will do it.  But= 
>I am beginning to wonder if its worth the agony and not enjoying life in =

>the mean time. 
 
So you admitted that you're not enjoying life before you're a millionaire
(that is... right this minute and for the next 4 years until you're 28). 
Are you so sure that you will enjoy life when you are a millionare?  You're
saying that money will make you happy?  R U sure?  I hope so.  Because you
will have spent your precious youth getting to a place you believe is the
answer to happiness.  There's no turning back the clock. 
 
 >How did you do it...  How did you work and play at the same time... did
you just not >take work seriously?  
 
Well... my philosophy is that my youth is precious.  I have about 60 years
left if all goes well.  And if all doesn't go well and life ends
tomarrow... I will have lived a happy life up until the end.  I could die
right now and not regret much-- and I mean that.  I've been following my
heart for the past few years and that's what's most important.  If during
the next sixty years I believe that money is the answer, then I will go for
it.  It won't take but a few years to educate or train myself to the level
where I could start earning 100 K.  And I definately don't need a
helicopter to make me happy. 
 
But for right now... I'm trying to figure out exactly what it is that will
allow me to be happy so I don't go through life down the wrong path.  I
want to figure it out now so I don't wast time.  That's more important than
wasting money.  I've figured out the latter already.  It's as simple as
looking at my Mother and my Father: 
 
My Father has the Cadillac, large house and lawn edger...  
My mother has an old, small house, second-hand clothes and a Ford Tempo. 
 
But I know my Mother's happier.  Who would you rather be? 
 
Believe it or not,  right now I'm happy being poor.  I love living in the
precious present. 
 
Love, 
 
--erik 
 
PS.  I'm glad to hear that your quitting smoking.  I've decided not to
smoke even on ocasion, like I had been doing lately.  And like you and
Jenny, I've become mostly a vegetarian, too.  But I will have a big mac
from time to time.... like today! 
 
PSS  I took a motorcycle ride around the San Francisco Penninsula
Yesterday.  I stopped at the Golden Gate bridge and at several of the Parks
and beaches along the way.  It's so fucking gorgeous here!  I was about the
only one on the beach while I watched the waves crash on shore and the
Golden Gate bridge was off on the horizon and South of me the waves were
crashing along the cliffs and a cool breeze blew through my hair... 
 
I miss you Greg.  Please at least stop to smell the roses. 
 
**IMPORTANT!  READ DISCLAIMER** 
These words were NOT written by moonpup 
He's in London until late August 
 
...and I'm ERIK.  I'll be using his address until then 
Please address all comments, rebuttals, love or hate letters to me, ERIK 
or drop me a line... 415-337-6666

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed May 29 19:50:32 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id TAA05958; Wed, 29 May 1996 19:50:32 -0700
Received: from ix10.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id TAA05942; Wed, 29 May 1996 19:50:25 -0700
Received: from wck-ca8-08.ix.netcom.com by ix10.ix.netcom.com (8.6.13/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id TAA27384; Wed, 29 May 1996 19:47:27 -0700
Date: Wed, 29 May 1996 19:47:27 -0700
Message-Id: <1.5.4.16.19960529012119.358f699a@popd.ix.netcom.com>
X-Sender: shawna-@popd.ix.netcom.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.4 (16)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "hey, where am I?" <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: Re: media representations of rave culture
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>>"Yeah, but ecstacy makes you listen to really bad music!" and the crowd
>>erupted into laughter.
>>I don't know, maybe I'm just hyper-sensitized, but there is a lot of
>>resistance out there.  And I just don't see why!  They don't make jokes
>>about how rotten Nirvana is or how bad punk rock is or how sad it is that
>>Aerosmith came back from the dead to milk a few more bucks out of the

>I think it's because techno is such a completely different *form* of music
>than rock... for one thing no one respects it because it's "fake" (it is).
>People who don't listen to techno are accustomed to the usual "musician ->
>star" progression, and they get confused because making techno music
>doesn't take much  practice, so how can anyone be a fan and how can anyone
>be accorded respect for making such a simplistic form of music? 


There may also be a couple of other factors, at least from what I've
experienced.  One is, as noted by that comedian, drug use (for me anyway,
I'm almost embarrased to admit).  I know that once a upon a time I totally
hated that music, and had no clue why people listened to it.  Then one day I
indulged for the first time, heard some of it, and said "Ooohhhh! *Now* I
get it!"  So I can see where that guy maybe got his opinion of how e makes
you like bad music, but for me it really was a simple adjustment of
perception on my part.  A lot of the time I listen to music, it is simply
background noise for me to do my work by, or surf the net by, etc.  I don't
usually take the time to really listen to what's going on musically.  This
is why I often like to listen to music stoned, it totally changes my
perspective and i really sit and listen to *everything* that is going on in
the song that's playing.  I have been totally blown away by music listened
to in this state that I had not previously taken note of.  This was also the
case the first time I did e, I really approached the music with a very
different perspective, and understood what there was to like about it.  Now
having experienced that different perspective, I now know it's there, and of
course don't require drugs to appreciate it, and now I listen to that kind
of music more than most other kinds.  But I hafta admit, drugs did work as a
catalyst in my situation.  
Another thing I've noticed is that probably a lot of people who make joke
about our "bad music" have probably not really heard some good quality
techno.  All I have to do is to to any "hip" store at the mall, or even the
steakhouse down the street, and bizarre cheezy housey kinda stuff (no i'm
not saying house is cheezy, just the stuff emanating from these mall
stores!) is playing, and imho sounds like shit!  If this is what people hear
on a regular basis, it's no wonder they think it sounds like shit.  It's
like hearing A-ha music (whoa 80's flashback!) and thinking that rock music
in general sucks.  They're not really hearing what's being made by people
who really love the music and put all their energy into it, imo.  
And really, I don't consider this music "fake" any more than any other kind
of music.  What makes music fake, to me, is when you get a band together
that uses only synthesizers to try and attempt to sound like live drums, a
guitarist, a bassist etc.  They are only attempting to imitate real
instruments.  With techno, I do not hear this.  Synthesizers are real
instruments in their own right, to me, and come up with some of the craziest
sounding noises! :)  They are not attempting to sound like anything but
themselves.  I've found an amazing amount of depth in this music that goes
way deeper than lots of "live" music created by "real" instruments I've heard.

Well enough rambling!

Love,
Shawna


  *smurp*

On Wed, 29 May 1996, Roy Feague wrote:

>  In your response, you publicly suggest "attitude", and then going on to   
> suggest a hidden issue or agenda.  It seems like personal attack, and is   
> going to arouse animosity and hurt feelings (correct me if I'm wrong   
> here).  So what do ya do, pretend you're not angry?  Perhaps such things   
> are best suited to a PERSONAL email, keeping the public response very   
> consciously free of attack-tone.

Oh, I get it, we should all be duplicitous when we are upset by something 
someone says in public mail? We should be polite in public, and reserve 
our negative views to private mail? What a bunch of unnatural, lying,
hypocritical *CRAP*. The wonderful thing about this list is that anyone 
can post their views publicly. If someone makes a public statement, 
someone can make a public reply. When you start telling people that they 
should reserve their negative remarks, it strikes me as very *wrong*. Not 
wrong from the "you shouldn't do that" standpoint, but wrong because you 
are attempting to deny the negative. You can't have yin without yang.

                                             Black Adder 



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed May 29 21:14:38 1996

Hi Black Adder -
(Hi All) -

Wow, I feel like I just got my ass bitten off.  But I doubt our points of   
view are really _so_ far apart on this; I think you just misunderstand   
me.  I'm trying to make two points:
1.  It's important to be tactful and sensitive in public responses to   
posts, because someone's feelings are on the receiving end.
2.  If you are so steamed that #1 is impossible, it's probably a good   
idea to give the person a chance to respond to a private mail to clarify   
before you bake their ass in a public forum.

>Oh, I get it, we should all be duplicitous when we are upset by   
something
>someone says in public mail? We should be polite in public, and reserve
>our negative views to private mail?
Hmm.  Well, no, I think you DON'T get it.  I'm not suggesting you   
suppress your honest opinion.  I'm just saying that a little TACT and   
SENSITIVITY goes a long way, and I'm trying to point out that with this   
medium, it's particularly important.  Don't keep your negative views   
private.  Just express them in a fashion that doesn't attack and insult   
_unnecessarily_.  Not only is it more respectful, but it almost always   
elicits a more constructive response.

If you're sufficiently riled up that tact is impossible, wait ten minutes   
and try again.  If it's still impossible and you're going to get   
personal, then maybe the decent thing to do is take it direct first.   
 Otherwise it becomes public insult.  Insult is rough enough; public   
insult in a forum of nearly 1000 should really be reserved for the   
extreme case.  What if there is a misunderstanding?  You can't undo the   
damage of a public attack if it turns out you went off half-cocked or   
just read more into something than was intended.

>What a bunch of unnatural, lying,
>hypocritical *CRAP*.
Well, this really illustrates my point.  You could easily have disagreed   
with me without such inflamatory words as "lying, hypocritical CRAP",   
don't you think?  Feelings get hurt unnecessarily, and your words are   
needlessly harsh and extreme.

This exchange is a perfect example.  I got your message, and I was   
initially hurt and riled up.  It's taken me several minutes to chill to   
the point where I can reply in a civil fashion, but I think it's worth   
making the effort.  Posting one's thoughts publicly puts one in a   
somewhat vulenerable position.  So when someone else discards opinions as   
lying, hypocritical CRAP, that's just bound to hurt feelings.  Maybe   
you'd call that weak.  I think it's just human.  I don't think it's   
necessary to be coarse or rude to be genuine and true to one's self.

>The wonderful thing about this list is that anyone
>can post their views publicly. If someone makes a public statement,
>someone can make a public reply. When you start telling people that they   

>should reserve their negative remarks, it strikes me as very *wrong*.   
Not
>wrong from the "you shouldn't do that" standpoint, but wrong because you   

>are attempting to deny the negative. You can't have yin without yang. 
You're right, it's wonderful to see the honest exchanges that go on here.   
 Again, I'm definitely NOT advocating squelching your dissenting   
opinions.  You can speak your truth with humility, respect, sensitivity,   
and tact, and still speak your truth effectively and honestly.  Yin and   
Yang only coexist peacefully in a sphere of mutual acceptance.

I'm guessing that what was offensive to you in my original post was the   
suggestion that the public a private ought to be different.  Well, yeah,   
maybe that's a bit half-baked... you shouldn't post a nicey-nicey public   
response and a bite-your-ass private mail.  That WOULD suck for all the   
reasons you point out.  What I'm saying is, if you can't possibly be   
tactful in your response, respond privately first to allow for the   
possibility that you misunderstood.

And always remember that on the other end of your dissenting sword is a   
human being whose feelings and opinions should be treated with respect,   
even if you disagree.

 -Roy

P.S.  "Duplicitous" is an even better word than "exacerbate".
;)

My roommate woke me at 3:00 am in San Rafael as I requested and we 
proceeded to head out to China Beach...I was completely blown away by 
this beautiful sight...it was higher on the Zenith then was originally  
planned..  pretty much directly overhead as it arched from the west to 
the east...Bright magenta white with yellow glowing object with a   
beautiful plasma trail...blending into a dimly visibly 
milky way...  once it passed it took about 4 minutes for the sonic boom 
to be heard...  it took my breath away...  (Note.. I experienced the 
first Shuttle landing at Edwards AFB a long time ago  :)  )  My prayer 
for the evening is that humans get back into space, the spin-off 
technology alone (remember Apollo) is worth the price to get there...

So I think it would be cool for those of us who are interested in such 
wondrous events to gather for the next one..?    --Maureen

On Wed, May 29, 1996 9:14:24 PM  at Jessica Robin Berkson wrote:

>I hate to admit it too, but it did take e for me to enjoy techno- I had a

Yes, it does seem that drugs may act as a "catalyst" to rave culture or
spirituality/ awareness for some people.  Terence McKenna is an advocate of
this belief.  I cannot deny that drugs have offered me an alternate
perception of things.  And at times this alternate perception has
enlightened me on certain issues concerning the "real world"...maybe even
helped clarify issues that I had been seemingly uable to resolve in an
unaltered state.  But I really can't confirm this (I was fucked up at the
time, right?) 
 
Terence McKenna seems to believe that drugs, particularly psychedelics, if
used in a responsible manner, are the catalysts or gateways to spirituality
and awareness.  Where if we pass through these gateways and educate
oursleves in this space, we can apply this knowledge to the "real world".  
 
The obstacle that I run into with this approach is that we're playing with
fire.  There is no question in my mind that drugs are to be feared.  I have
had some terribly BAD experiences on drugs, marijuana for example.  Why not
use meditation to reach an altered state?  It may be harder and will take
more discipline.  But it's a hell of a lot healthier, safer, less addictive
and cheaper! 
 
And as for enjoying Techno music...  I listened to it and loved it long
before I even heard of E or X (as it used to be called). 
 
But if E appears the only way to boost one's self into the spiritual
realm...  better than not at all! 
 
Just watch your ass for what comes next.   
 
--erik

Roy -

I have to agree with the thoughts behind Black Adder's message. However, it 
obviously wasn't a delivery that was going to work for you, and I respect 
your right to question it. 
I can't think of any reason why my reply to Jess should have been sent 
through private email. When someone posts to a public forum, they are 
initiating conversation, and that's all that has happened here. My 
response wasn't designed to hurt her, and given the context of her reply, I
don't think it did. In my experience, this is how you get to know people 
through email ... After just a few messages, I already know so much more 
about Jess than I did yesterday, and that's the best part. For me, the 
net is a quick glimpse into the lives of people that I may have never 
had contact w/ otherwise, and may never, ever meet in person (although on 
this list it's quite likely!) ... Debate / conversation / whatever; it's all 
good.

I can't think of a better use for all this bandwidth.

Dan

dancing, It must have been around 3 am because people WERE GOING OFF!!

For those of you who attended Burning Man last summer, you must remember
those crazily costumed performance artists dancing
around the Lingham as it burned phallically into the night... Collapsing
Silence!  They're performing this Friday at Stanford University.
 (no, we're not entirely stuffy and conservative... not yet, at least)

CS is performing at the dedication ceremony of Stanford's Papua New
Guinea sculpture garden; a wonderful little glade
with *extremely* cool authenically carved totems and stone sculptures...
As a bonus, the sculptors are going to be at the event!

So, if you're looking for something to kick off the weekend, I suggest
checking this out.  It should be a smallish affair (the sculpture garden
is pretty tiny), but worth it.  

Um, I don't have any phone #s on hand, sorry.  You could try the calling
Stanford Information.  I'm certain the event is on Friday.


		jon

From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@CompuServe.COM>

Precedence: bulk

Roy said (snip)

Has anybody else noticed how pitfall-frought electronic communication   
is?  Without the aural and visual cues of observing the speaker, it's   
really easy to hear malice where there's none, or to have situations   
escalate beyond the intentions of either party, or to take half-serious   
and overly-general statements more seriously than they were intended.   
 That's why the use of smileys like :) in email isn't just cute, it's   
really essential to fill the missing element of intended tone!!

_________________________________

Right on Roy, that is so true, and important to remember -- ESPECIALLY when
we're talking to someone we haven't met personally, which means when we read
their words, we are only imagining the tone and attitude behind them...

Example .... I used to read John S.(famous for his strong personal expression on
SFR, right John?)  Lee's posts and imagine him in one way .. then I had the
great pleasure of meeting him and realizing immediately, when I saw the big open
smile on his face, that I had misread/misunderstood some of his written
thoughts.

So, remember we're only seeing a partial vision of someone's ideas when we read
them on email, much of the spirit and soul is not translatable in this medium
.... so let's be careful out there!

Much love (can't misunderstand that, and I REALLY mean it!) it all, and I hope
to see all your smiling faces at Tribal Future!!

Leslie  : )

I am originally from New York City and the emphasis in my experiance
there was not on spirituality but intellectualism.. This difference in
emphasis hass led to a scene characterized by a lot of creative and
vibrant people mentally but also a lot of competition and snobbery
("where have you shown? what play did you work on? what is the concept
behind your clothes?) between people compelled to build very elaborate
personas. can lead to an empty and cold vibe sometimes but I am a New
Yorker so actually do miss "shade" sometimes

Cassandra

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu May 30 09:47:22 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA19849; Thu, 30 May 1996 09:47:22 -0700

From: KaySEE <scarab@value.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Random Raver Experience
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.960530093126.20626J-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Last night I went to this cool little bar on the Albany/El Cerrito border 
called Club Mallard.  It was the first time I had gone, and not usually 
liking any bar scene, I actually enjoyed this place.  I went with the 
intention of hanging out with a group of friends, some of which I hadn't 
seen in awhile.

So, my good raver friend shows up and has brought with her the map to 
Tribal Future (which is VERY cool btw).  She and I and my SO (the three 
of us are going!!) are commenting on how wonderful it will be, when this 
guy seated at the bar notices the flyer and that we are talking about 
dj's and starts talking to us.  Turns out he and his friend 
are long-time ravers.  We all started talking about TF, and, he, having 
gone before, described the place, and got us even more excited.  We were 
all filled with that "raver" excitement at having randomly met others of 
our kind.  Plus, we know some of the same people.  It was totally random, 
and totally sweet.  We all hung out for awhile, parting with the promise 
of hooking up in Mendocino.  

Now THAT  made my evening which turned out to be a barrel of fun!!

Connections,
KaySEE
