On Wed, 29 May 1996, Roy Feague wrote:

> 
> Hi Black Adder -
> (Hi All) -
> 
> Wow, I feel like I just got my ass bitten off.  But I doubt our points of   
> view are really _so_ far apart on this; I think you just misunderstand   
> me.  I'm trying to make two points:
> 1.  It's important to be tactful and sensitive in public responses to   
> posts, because someone's feelings are on the receiving end.
> 2.  If you are so steamed that #1 is impossible, it's probably a good   
> idea to give the person a chance to respond to a private mail to clarify   
> before you bake their ass in a public forum.

The problem is that this goes *both* ways. This list can be very cyclic 
at time: 

Person A says something inflammatory, whether personally or in the form 
of a generalization.

Person B(the person that felt offended) responds back with something 
inflammatory.

Persons C,D,E,F, etc. get on persons *B* case about the means in which 
they chose to respond.  

And the circle continues....

> 
> >Oh, I get it, we should all be duplicitous when we are upset by   
> something
> >someone says in public mail? We should be polite in public, and reserve
> >our negative views to private mail?
> Hmm.  Well, no, I think you DON'T get it.  I'm not suggesting you   
> suppress your honest opinion.  I'm just saying that a little TACT and   
> SENSITIVITY goes a long way, and I'm trying to point out that with this   
> medium, it's particularly important.  Don't keep your negative views   
> private.  Just express them in a fashion that doesn't attack and insult   
> _unnecessarily_.  Not only is it more respectful, but it almost always   
> elicits a more constructive response.

That is not what you were asking in your original message on the subject. 
An excerpt:
 
>  In your response, you publicly suggest "attitude", and then going on to   
> suggest a hidden issue or agenda.  It seems like personal attack, and is   
> going to arouse animosity and hurt feelings (correct me if I'm wrong   
> here).  So what do ya do, pretend you're not angry?  Perhaps such things   
> are best suited to a PERSONAL email, keeping the public response very   
> consciously free of attack-tone.

I do appreciate your clarification of your position, but it is indeed 
different from your original suggestion.

> If you're sufficiently riled up that tact is impossible, wait ten minutes   
> and try again.  If it's still impossible and you're going to get   
> personal, then maybe the decent thing to do is take it direct first.   
>  Otherwise it becomes public insult.  Insult is rough enough; public   
> insult in a forum of nearly 1000 should really be reserved for the   
> extreme case.  What if there is a misunderstanding?  You can't undo the   
> damage of a public attack if it turns out you went off half-cocked or   
> just read more into something than was intended.

Given the above senario of person A,B etc., and your feelings on TACT and 
SENSITIVITY, don't you think it might be more appropriate and useful in your 
to suggest to person A that they not make potentially inflammatory 
generalizations that would illicit such responses?    

Personally, I fully support the right for Jess to say that Americans are 
all imperialistic, self-centered, egotistical bastards, or whatever, if 
that is how she truly feels on the subject.

However, I disagree with her, and I also fully support anybodies right to 
return words that are as equally inflammatory in a public forum. 

> >What a bunch of unnatural, lying,
> >hypocritical *CRAP*.
> Well, this really illustrates my point.  You could easily have disagreed   
> with me without such inflamatory words as "lying, hypocritical CRAP",   
> don't you think?  Feelings get hurt unnecessarily, and your words are   
> needlessly harsh and extreme.

Given the level of distate I had for your original suggestion, I feel 
that my words were quite appropriate. 

> This exchange is a perfect example.  I got your message, and I was   
> initially hurt and riled up.  It's taken me several minutes to chill to   
> the point where I can reply in a civil fashion, but I think it's worth   
> making the effort.  Posting one's thoughts publicly puts one in a   
> somewhat vulenerable position.  So when someone else discards opinions as   
> lying, hypocritical CRAP, that's just bound to hurt feelings.  Maybe   
> you'd call that weak.  I think it's just human.  I don't think it's   
> necessary to be coarse or rude to be genuine and true to one's self.

Perhaps you know have an idea of how I felt at the suggestion that I or any 
other member of this list be confined to only "thinking good thought and 
saying good things"(twilight zone reference) in public, and reserve their 
real feelings for private exchanges. You are not in any means the first,  or am 
I sure the last, person to suggest this, and wrapping it a cloak of civility 
does not make the thought any more appealing. I do not say things without 
the willingness to back up those statements. If you would like to 
continue this discussion in private, I will be happy to go on ad nauseum 
about why I feel this concept has no merit, is hypocritical, lying, and 
crap. I am not saying you are stupid, kick puppies for fun, or anything 
else, just that this idea is a very poor one.   

> You're right, it's wonderful to see the honest exchanges that go on here.   
>  Again, I'm definitely NOT advocating squelching your dissenting   
> opinions.  You can speak your truth with humility, respect, sensitivity,   
> and tact, and still speak your truth effectively and honestly.  Yin and   
> Yang only coexist peacefully in a sphere of mutual acceptance.

So again I ask, why only post when you saw Dan's reply? Why didn't you 
post immediately when you saw the post from Jess? Do you really feel that 
saying (paraphrasing)"you Americans are a bunch of imperialistic 
egotists," is speaking your truth with humility, respect, or sensitivity?

Believe it or not, I am agreeing with what you are saying in this regard, 
but question its validity when that respect and sensitivity is not shown 
in the first place.

> I'm guessing that what was offensive to you in my original post was the   
> suggestion that the public a private ought to be different.  Well, yeah,   
> maybe that's a bit half-baked... you shouldn't post a nicey-nicey public   
> response and a bite-your-ass private mail.  That WOULD suck for all the   
> reasons you point out.  What I'm saying is, if you can't possibly be   
> tactful in your response, respond privately first to allow for the   
> possibility that you misunderstood.

Well then, I guess we can agree to disagree.

                                      
                                      Black Adder

On Wed, 29 May 1996, jess wrote:

> 
> 
> Not all USers are so ignorant but you gotta
> be pretty damn industrious and committed to keep alert to the important
> goings on in other parts of the world.  If you are one of those people,
> then more power to you, but I'm not and I find myself becoming more and
> more unaware, the more I live here.  So I don't blame us as individuals,
> but I do think we have a certain tendancy to be obsessed with
> our own culture whether we realize it or not.  If you have ever travelled
> you will quickly realize how
> much more every one in the world knows about our culture than we know
> about theirs.  Not our fault, but true, and worth rectifying if we ever
> intend to do something about the US cultural domination that is sweeping
> the planet and destroying many indigenous and beautiful cultures. 

I'd agree with Jess.  The average American knows very little about other 
cultures and current events outside of the States.  However, there are 
reasons for this.  After traveling and living in other countries (Latin 
America), I've come to some conclusions on why this is true.  First and 
foremost, is the basic fact that, YES, WE, the UNITED STATES OF AMERICA 
are the world's biggest military and political power.  Admittedly, I am 
not an expert on foreign policy or relations, but we are still the 
most powerful country in the world, especially since the Cold War has 
ended.  We are definitely one of the richest too, and with wealth comes 
power.  The United States has always been an imperialistic country.  And 
with imperialism comes a hierarchy in which we seem to have our foot 
firmly planted on top.

Sitting where we do in the world's hierarchy, of course the average 
American is going to think the same and reflect that view.  There is 
also a subtler view I attribute to our ignorance.  This being the sheer 
size of our country.  I am under the opinion that since we are not 
surrounded by many other countries like in Europe, we do not get as wide 
a view of other cultures.  It is a simple geographic problem.  In both 
Europe and Latin America, you are bordered by more countries, and 
geography allows you to have more interactions with other countries and 
therefore have a larger world view.  I think in the more ethnically 
diverse states like California, the people are forced to know more than  
they otherwise would.

Americans are under a lot of scrutiny because o their place in the world, 
which is a hard thing to deal with sometimes when you are an individual.  
I've found ignorance goes both ways, and many times people in other 
countries stereotype us, which to me is also ignorance.

So, I'd have to agree with all the points that Jess has made, but I'd like to 
buffer it by pointing out that one has to see the history behind the 
interaction in order to fully understand how it came to be.

--Bye--
KaySEE

On Wed, 29 May 1996 SteveOSac@aol.com wrote:
> changing our view and attitude towards it.  So yes, we should be leary of
> using plur as a sort visor to evil, but also beware of keeping it hidden in
> it's case, exposing your soul face first to all the harsh truths and evil
> realities of  existence is not the simple solution either.   Perhaps we
> should also be cautious using "plur" as a multi-purpose "that covers it"

I think we tend to overuse PLUR, inserting it where it doesn't need to 
go.  Sometimes it's painful but necessary for someone to tell us to shut 
the f__k up when we're mouthing off, or to tell us to just say so what 
when we see too people non-PLURing.  Example: this whole thing with 
apoligizing for our posts in advance (e.g. NRR, or LONG, as if you were 
afraid to violate our right to our 15 second attention span, or afraid 
that what you consider to be part of the rave culture isn't necessarily 
part of another's view of rave.  We're all on this newsgroup together: if 
you've got something to say, SAY IT TO ALL OF US!

Learn to deal (SIV- sarcasitic inflection of voice ;))
-alberT

> I'd agree with Jess.  The average American knows very little about other 
> cultures and current events outside of the States.  However, there are 
> reasons for this.  After traveling and living in other countries (Latin 
> America), I've come to some conclusions on why this is true.  First and 
> foremost, is the basic fact that, YES, WE, the UNITED STATES OF AMERICA 
> are the world's biggest military and political power.  Admittedly, I am 
> not an expert on foreign policy or relations, but we are still the 
> most powerful country in the world, especially since the Cold War has 
> ended.  We are definitely one of the richest too, and with wealth comes 
> power.  The United States has always been an imperialistic country.  And

> firmly planted on top.

So what.
Just because you are the biggest and strongest has nothing to do with why
the people in the US are ignorant (as in uneducated to  other parts of the
world). In fact...just imagine the attitude of some of the guys/girls who
work out a lot...weird analogy i know...when they have 'that'
attitude..what do we usually think of them?
Besides all the power and miltary in the world isnt going to do you guys a
bit of good...imagine all the breakaway republics in Europe right
now...starving for $$$$...well you know all those Nuclear missiles the
Russians had in all them little countries...guess where they are now?
And guess where they're still pointed. Theres no massive government with
the finger on the button either...one word...Khadafi. (sp?) 

> Sitting where we do in the world's hierarchy, of course the average 
> American is going to think the same and reflect that view.  There is 
> also a subtler view I attribute to our ignorance.  This being the sheer 
> size of our country.  I am under the opinion that since we are not 
> surrounded by many other countries like in Europe, we do not get as wide 
> a view of other cultures.  It is a simple geographic problem.  In both 
> Europe and Latin America, you are bordered by more countries, and 
> geography allows you to have more interactions with other countries and 
> therefore have a larger world view.  I think in the more ethnically 
> diverse states like California, the people are forced to know more than  
> they otherwise would.

Umm..hello?
No other cultures?
What do you call Canada? Mexico?
I wonder how many Americans still feel we'll be the 55th state one day ;|
If you think thats being sarcastic...
 
> Americans are under a lot of scrutiny because o their place in the world, 
> which is a hard thing to deal with sometimes when you are an individual.  
> I've found ignorance goes both ways, and many times people in other 
> countries stereotype us, which to me is also ignorance.

And so they should be...you _should_ be setting the example for EVERYone
else. No one is stereotyping anyone...but the facts you stated yourself.
Ignorance is absolutely no excuse.
The only reason anyone might stereotype americans is because it is soooo
easy to do.
 
> So, I'd have to agree with all the points that Jess has made, but I'd like to 
> buffer it by pointing out that one has to see the history behind the 
> interaction in order to fully understand how it came to be.

Dont get me wrong on this...I am not American bashing...
The US has done a lot of good things...and for the most part I loooove
coming down to the US even tho our dollar is only worth about .70 cents
down there. But thats the way it goes.
I especially love SF..I cant wait to come down :)

BUT the fact does remain...as you stated...that Americans are quite
ignorant to the ways of anything outside their country.
I am not trying to start any sort of arguement with this...but living in
Canada, trust me..many many people here...as well as many people in
Euro-Asian countries with which we have huge relationships with...unlike
what you stated for your country (meaning your geographic dis/advantage is
not an excuse either!) think or have at least heard of the taste we get in
our mouths when we think of the US.

Im not proud of it...but ive got more annoying stories about things Ive
heard from Americans mouths than I care ti bring up.
I mean Polar bears thru downtown? Come on.

Have a good day :)

[Apologies in advance for the slight divergence from the subject of
raves...]

Eric, guest-subbing for Moonpup, writes:

> Terence McKenna seems to believe that drugs, particularly psychedelics, if
> used in a responsible manner, are the catalysts or gateways to spirituality
> and awareness.  Where if we pass through these gateways and educate
> oursleves in this space, we can apply this knowledge to the "real world".  

I've always felt that there is a conspiracy on the part of politicians
advocating the war on drugs. The idea is that if people got in touch
with their spirituality through hallucinogenic drugs, then many of the
ideals on the Conservative Republican agenda would be in danger of
being attacked by their constituency (such as favoring industry over
ecology, large millitary budgets, tax laws favoring the rich, reduced
spending on social improvement programs, etc). So long as they have
that mind-numbing drug alcohol around, and make those other drugs
relatively inaccessible, they can control that dissenting voice.

> The obstacle that I run into with this approach is that we're playing with
> fire.  There is no question in my mind that drugs are to be feared.  I have
> had some terribly BAD experiences on drugs, marijuana for example.  Why not
> use meditation to reach an altered state?  It may be harder and will take
> more discipline.  But it's a hell of a lot healthier, safer, less addictive
> and cheaper! 

We're already playing with fire -- that which lights up tobacco. ;-) 

But seriously, the conspiracy has nothing to do about the dangers of
drug use -- it's just a bunch of hype. After all, many thousands of
innocent people die at the hands (well, cars, really) of those under
the influence of alcohol. And more people die from tobacco-related
diseases than from most, if not all, other causes. I have yet to hear
of a single case of someone who died from overdosing on marijuana, for
instance. And the number of deaths from psychedelics is comparively
very small.

> And as for enjoying Techno music...  I listened to it and loved it long
> before I even heard of E or X (as it used to be called). 

Same here.

> But if E appears the only way to boost one's self into the spiritual
> realm...  better than not at all! 

Amen to that! :-) The use of drugs as the gateway to the spiritual
realm has a long history. Native Americans still do it with peyote, of
course. Many Muslims smoke marijuana to "get closer to Allah". They
also shun the use of alcohol, calling it the "drug of the Devil". Very
interesting indeed...

-G-

Subject: All we really need to know...

(From a poster, given to me by my longest-known friend)
All I really need to know I learned in kindergarten.
All I really need to know about how to live and what to do and how to be I
learned in kindergarten.  Wisdom was not at the top of the graduate-school
mountain, but there in the sandpile at Sunday School.  These are the things
I learned: Share everything.  Play fair.  Don't hit people.  Put things
back where you found them.  Clean up your own mess.  Don't take things that
aren't yours.  Say you're sorry when you hurt somebody.  Wash your hands
before you eat.  Flush.  Warm cookies and cold milk are good for you.  Live
a balanced life--learn some and think some and draw and paint and sing and
dance and play and work every day some.
Take a nap every afternoon.
When you go out into the world, watch out for traffic, hold hands, and
stick together.
Be aware of wonder.  Remember the little seed in the Styrofoam cup: The
roots go down and the plant goes up and nobody really knows how or why, but
we are all like that.
Goldfish and hamsters and white mice and even the little seed in the
Styrofoam cup--they all die.  So do we.
And then remember the Dick-and-Jane books and the first work you
learned--the biggest word of all--LOOK.
Everything you need to know is in there somewhere.  The Golden Rule and
love and basic sanitation.  Ecology and politics and equality and sane
living.
Take any one of those items and extrapolate it into sophisticated adult
terms and apply it to your family life or your work or your government or
your world and it holds true and clear and firm.  Think what a better world
it would be if we all--the whole world--had cookies and milk about three
o'clock every afternoon and then lay down with our blankies for a nap.  Or
if all governments had as a basic policy to always put things back where
they found them and to clean up their own mess.
And it is still ture, no matter how old you are--when you go out into the
world, it is best to hold hands and stick together.

By Robert Fulghum.

Think about these things.  Live and love.  - E

Sure, Americans, generally speaking, are ignorant of the rest of the world.
But do you guys really think that any other country's citizens are not as 
equally focused on their home country?  I mean, how many Iranians or 
Welsh or any other nationality have any idea who Nathan Hale is?
I think it's multi-directional.
Pondering,
Timothy

I've been thinking about this a lot recently, about the idea that techno
music is sort of 'fake,' or unnatural, or whatever other problematic 
adjective you wish to use... I love techno and trance and all its related
forms, mind you, and I don't want to start a big flame war or anything 
silly like that, but the conclusion I keep arriving at is this one:
Dance music doesn't have any PERSONALITY!  Of course, ravers do, and DJ's 
do, and the parties do, but maybe all the personality that you see at a 
rave is to compensate for the music's lack thereof?  I think the music 
has a lot of things going for it: rhythm, funk, sensuality, power, emotional
persuasion, et al, but I keep having trouble when I look for the 
personality...then again, maybe that's the appeal.  Dunno... 
I'd love to see what other people have to say about this, though.  
high fives,
Timothy


On Wed, 29 May 1996, hey, where am I? wrote:

> >>"Yeah, but ecstacy makes you listen to really bad music!" and the crowd
> >>erupted into laughter.
> >>I don't know, maybe I'm just hyper-sensitized, but there is a lot of
> >>resistance out there.  And I just don't see why!  They don't make jokes
> >>about how rotten Nirvana is or how bad punk rock is or how sad it is that
> >>Aerosmith came back from the dead to milk a few more bucks out of the
> 
> >I think it's because techno is such a completely different *form* of music
> >than rock... for one thing no one respects it because it's "fake" (it is).
> >People who don't listen to techno are accustomed to the usual "musician ->
> >star" progression, and they get confused because making techno music
> >doesn't take much  practice, so how can anyone be a fan and how can anyone
> >be accorded respect for making such a simplistic form of music? 
> 
> 
> There may also be a couple of other factors, at least from what I've
> experienced.  One is, as noted by that comedian, drug use (for me anyway,
> I'm almost embarrased to admit).  I know that once a upon a time I totally
> hated that music, and had no clue why people listened to it.  Then one day I
> indulged for the first time, heard some of it, and said "Ooohhhh! *Now* I
> get it!"  So I can see where that guy maybe got his opinion of how e makes
> you like bad music, but for me it really was a simple adjustment of
> perception on my part.  A lot of the time I listen to music, it is simply
> background noise for me to do my work by, or surf the net by, etc.  I don't
> usually take the time to really listen to what's going on musically.  This
> is why I often like to listen to music stoned, it totally changes my
> perspective and i really sit and listen to *everything* that is going on in
> the song that's playing.  I have been totally blown away by music listened
> to in this state that I had not previously taken note of.  This was also the
> case the first time I did e, I really approached the music with a very
> different perspective, and understood what there was to like about it.  Now
> having experienced that different perspective, I now know it's there, and of
> course don't require drugs to appreciate it, and now I listen to that kind
> of music more than most other kinds.  But I hafta admit, drugs did work as a
> catalyst in my situation.  
> Another thing I've noticed is that probably a lot of people who make joke
> about our "bad music" have probably not really heard some good quality
> techno.  All I have to do is to to any "hip" store at the mall, or even the
> steakhouse down the street, and bizarre cheezy housey kinda stuff (no i'm
> not saying house is cheezy, just the stuff emanating from these mall
> stores!) is playing, and imho sounds like shit!  If this is what people hear
> on a regular basis, it's no wonder they think it sounds like shit.  It's
> like hearing A-ha music (whoa 80's flashback!) and thinking that rock music
> in general sucks.  They're not really hearing what's being made by people
> who really love the music and put all their energy into it, imo.  
> And really, I don't consider this music "fake" any more than any other kind
> of music.  What makes music fake, to me, is when you get a band together
> that uses only synthesizers to try and attempt to sound like live drums, a
> guitarist, a bassist etc.  They are only attempting to imitate real
> instruments.  With techno, I do not hear this.  Synthesizers are real
> instruments in their own right, to me, and come up with some of the craziest
> sounding noises! :)  They are not attempting to sound like anything but
> themselves.  I've found an amazing amount of depth in this music that goes
> way deeper than lots of "live" music created by "real" instruments I've heard.
> 
> Well enough rambling!
> 
> Love,
> Shawna
> 
> 
>   *smurp*

1)  Does anybody actually know if Galen did spin at Funky Tekno Tribe?  I
saw his name in the line up, but forgot to pay attention, and I know that
some of the dj's did not spin after all.  Just wonderin!

2)  Can somebody please explain this bizarre phenomenon:  I bought a mixed
music cd a while back, and then recorded it onto a tape for listening at
work.  The mixing of the songs on the cd is fine, but when I recorded it
onto the tape, the mixing disappeared!  When one song was about to end,
instead of it blending into the next one, it cuts short.  Then there's a few
seconds of silence like there would be on a normal non-mixed cd, and then
the next song abruptly starts.  The space where the two songs are combined
is cut out entirely.  And it has recorded this way onto my tape.  It sounds
real weird!  But I just can't figure out why the tape didn't recor exactly
what was playing on the cd, this doesn't make sense to me.  Any techy people
out there know the answer?


Love,
Shawna

We tried to do this last week, but had to cancel at the last minute...but
tonight for sure!!!!

RE: will be playing free live ambient/idm at Thursday Night Market in
Sacramento tonight.  TNM is on K Street Mall in Sacramento.  It's an annual
event that runs every thurs in downtown Sac all summer.  They have tons o
people, performers, vendors with various booths of stuff.  We will be
located in front of "Records" on K between 7th and 8th.  We will also have a
guest dj named Jonny who will be spinning ambient records and generally
helping us mix everything together.  Jonny is great.  You just have to hear
him sometime to understand.  He's pretty "out there"  

Hope to see some of you there.

Rick

Hi Shawna-

 Here's my take on your problem with the recording.  Depending on your stereo 
system, your CD player may automatically skip from the end of one track to the 
beginning of the next.  This may cause the mixing of track to no occur.
 Now I haven't had any direct experience with this, but I know of friends to 
which this same problem has happened.

-Todd








To: sfraves @ hyperreal.com @ SMTP
cc:  (bcc: Todd Manley/Santa Clara/HDS)

Subject: two things (kinda rave related)

2)  Can somebody please explain this bizarre phenomenon:  I bought a mixed
music cd a while back, and then recorded it onto a tape for listening at
work.  The mixing of the songs on the cd is fine, but when I recorded it
onto the tape, the mixing disappeared!  When one song was about to end,
instead of it blending into the next one, it cuts short.  Then there's a few
seconds of silence like there would be on a normal non-mixed cd, and then
the next song abruptly starts.  The space where the two songs are combined
is cut out entirely.  And it has recorded this way onto my tape.  It sounds
real weird!  But I just can't figure out why the tape didn't recor exactly
what was playing on the cd, this doesn't make sense to me.  Any techy people
out there know the answer?

Actually, I didn't think it was *that* cold.  The sun did peep out
for about 10 minutes to our cheers a couple of times.

I thought Dervish (guy with ponytail right after Solar?) and
Michael who followed him both were fine.  Nothing amazing, but
they kept us dancing, and warm.  

It may be my imagination, but the Sunset vibe always seems much
better at the Berkeley Marina compared to Pt. Molate in Richmond.
Less alchohol, less garbage, friendlier people.  Also less Nitrous
(Galen had threatened to shut the party down over it) was evident,
though I did see the telltale balloon litter down closer to the water.
I hope things remain manageable for the Pacific crew now that summer
is here with influx of folks off from school with nothing else to do.

Will see many of U at TF!

Lee

well, i don't know how to explain it in technical terms, and this is just
a guess at best anyway, but here goes :

when you set up the cd player to make the tape, you put it into program 
mode and selected it to play song 1, then song2, then song 3 etc...
now if you watch the little time display while your cd player is switching
from song 1 to song 2, you'll notice a little anomaly in there somewhere
where the display says -0:02 and counts backwards till 0:00, then it goes
up again... i suspect that if you set up the cd player in program mode,
it skips those little in-between negative-seconds and just starts at 0:00.

sooo, the way to fix the problem i gues would be to just play the cd normally
like you would if you were just listeening to it and record that way.

confused yet? :)

justin

Hi Shawna-

 Here's my take on your problem with the recording.  Depending on your stereo 
system, your CD player may automatically skip from the end of one track to the 
beginning of the next.  This may cause the mixing of track to no occur.
 Now I haven't had any direct experience with this, but I know of friends to 
which this same problem has happened.

-Todd

2)  Can somebody please explain this bizarre phenomenon:  I bought a mixed
music cd a while back, and then recorded it onto a tape for listening at
work.  The mixing of the songs on the cd is fine, but when I recorded it
onto the tape, the mixing disappeared!  When one song was about to end,
instead of it blending into the next one, it cuts short.  Then there's a few
seconds of silence like there would be on a normal non-mixed cd, and then
the next song abruptly starts.  The space where the two songs are combined
is cut out entirely.  And it has recorded this way onto my tape.  It sounds
real weird!  But I just can't figure out why the tape didn't recor exactly
what was playing on the cd, this doesn't make sense to me.  Any techy people
out there know the answer?

Hi Shawna... my JVC boombox does the same thing.  It automatically places
spaces in between the tracks.  Look in your manual if you have one, there
should be a way to turn off that option.  On mine I think I have to play
the disk and pause it, then turn the deck on to record.  Hope this helps.
smiles
Andrew

I went. It was the first time I ever made it to Sunset, and what a
time to initiate myself! The weather was cold, cloudy, and
windy. Despite that, it rocked! I especially got down with Lorin's
set. The vibe was a great change from those of massives and clubs,
which I'm used to. Highlights of the event: the sun made two rare
appearances: one around 4-5pm, for about 20 minutes or so, and another
just as it was setting: a blazing red display. Everyone cheered at
those two moments.

Looking forward to the next one,

From: George Feil <george@unrrts.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Shawna asks:

> 2)  Can somebody please explain this bizarre phenomenon:  I bought a mixed
> music cd a while back, and then recorded it onto a tape for listening at
> work.  The mixing of the songs on the cd is fine, but when I recorded it
> onto the tape, the mixing disappeared!  When one song was about to end,
> instead of it blending into the next one, it cuts short.  Then there's a few
> seconds of silence like there would be on a normal non-mixed cd, and then
> the next song abruptly starts.  The space where the two songs are combined
> is cut out entirely.  And it has recorded this way onto my tape.  It sounds
> real weird!  But I just can't figure out why the tape didn't recor exactly
> what was playing on the cd, this doesn't make sense to me.  Any techy people
> out there know the answer?

This phenomenon occurs for me on my Yamaha X-90 mini system when I
record CD to tape under certain programmed modes. When I play a CD in
programmed mode, it intentionally puts several seconds of blank space
between the tracks. This happens even when the tracks are programmed
in sequence. The logic on the CD unit isn't smart enough to handle the
situation, and let the previous track play continuously into the
next. However, a good feature of this is that you do a music search on
the tape, the tape deck will correctly find the track breaks. My unit
will even pause the tape after several seconds if the CD unit needs to
change disks, or scan over many tracks, so that the spacing between
the tracks on the tape is constant.

It's all rather annoying when recording a mixed CD, but I've found a
workaround: play the CD manually (unprogrammed), and start and stop
the tape deck on my own at the appropriate times.

Of course, I'm only guessing this is what's happening for you, since
you didn't mention what you were recording the CD on.

-G-

On Thu, May 30, 1996 10:24:52 AM  at KaySEE wrote: 
 
  There is  
>also a subtler view I attribute to our ignorance.  This being the sheer  
>size of our country.  I am under the opinion that since we are not  
>surrounded by many other countries like in Europe, we do not get as wide  
>a view of other cultures.  It is a simple geographic problem.

That's a good point that is often overlooked: 
 
If I had taken my 3,000 mile x-country trip in Europe instead of the United
States, I would have traveled through 13 Countries, not 13 states.  That's
a hell of a different experience all together!  It's obvious to me how much
easier it would be to educate myself interculturally in other less
"isolated" countries. 
 
--erik

BTW, what would you consider "gangster"? Is it the way people dress, attitude? 
Please explain. I am not at all involved with any gangs, yet when ever I come in
contact with police I am automatically classified as a gang member. I have also 
noticed at parties sometimes that people seem to be intimidated by my 
appearance. Little do they know, I am just as fun loving and open minded as the 
next guy\gal. I have been raving in SF for about 3 years now and have noticed 
that the number of "gangster type" people at parties has increased 
considerabely. Keep in mind that people cannot and should not be judged by their
appearance. Just because one dresses a certain way doesn't necessarily mean they
are affiliated with gangsters or a gangster attitude. That's just like me 
calling you a tweaker or a scrub because you wear Vans, cut-offs and ride a 
skateboard. Know what I'm sayin'? Just my two cents. Talk to y'all later.

updated.

(because of the ads I assume).

I used to run screaming from a room if I ever heard techno music.  It
seemed so grating and uninviting to me.

And yet, sometime last year I heard it again and I *got it* in a major way
- now I'm totally hooked.

Most of you already know that I haven't done any drugs for years so that
wasn't a factor in my initiation - however, I _used_ to be really into
psychedelics and I think those pathways are still open and available for
me to access.  I'm not sure if I'd never tranced out on drugs if I'd know
how to do it sober - On the other hand, cultures have been trancing out
for eons and not all of them had drugs so it must be an inate human
ability.

just my .02

	ranting and raving

		jess

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I have a couple of thoughts in response to Dan, Blackadder, Roy etc..about
personal attacks in public.

If there's one thing I've learned in my life it's that it is _extremely_
difficult to get someone to reconsider their position on something if you
direct your comments in the form of a personal attack.  Dan's initial
response to my post certainly stung for a few minutes but I can't say,
given the nature of this list, that I didn't expect an attack like that
from someone.  

I think that if you disagree with someone you have two paths you can take
	1. slam them - you'll feel better
	2. focus your response on the ideas while validating the person at 
	the same time - you might not feel better but you might actually
	get them to reconsider their position

I really believe that people rarely change their minds about things that
important to them unless they feel that you are on their side and
have their best interests at heart.  In other words that you are acting
as a friend rather than a foe. I mean, if you feel attacked then you get
defensive and that isn't very conducive to introspection and thoughtful
ruminations.

Dan's comments were largely directed at my person rather than my ideas and
as such constituted a personal attack. However, he wasn't completely wrong
either - Dan is obviously a very perceptive man and saw that my ideas were
colored by my emotions - he's right - but isn't that true for all
important issues.

I guess it would have affected me more if I didn't have such a
thick skin from hanging aroung those harsh UK young people (j/k).

I guess my point is that the private vs. public thing is not really the
issue here - the issue is whether you are interested in engaging someone
in a mutually respectful interchange where people feel safe enough to
actually risk changing their minds about long-held ideas, or whether you
are interested in starting a flame fest of the Ethan vs. Tom and Stacey
variety - I'm willing to bet that very few people really reconsidered
their positions on that one.

So I don't really think it matters whether it happens in full view of all
or behind closed doors - attacks are attacks - the advantage to public
airing of grievances is that you get support for both sides and so the
attackee may not feel so alone and that's a very good thing.

Last point - I don't think flame fests are such a bad thing really - I am
really glad that we are finally talking about the SFcentric issue and if I
hadn't written such a provocative post we never would have done it - like
I said in my original post, lets not get so blotto on PLUR that we forget
how to wrestle with each other - let's just do it respectfully -
challenging people on their ideas, not their personal atributes

	ranting and raving
	
		jess

From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@CompuServe.COM>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Techno Music and Who Loves It (LONG!)
Message-ID: <960531002136_71165.755_GHL83-1@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A very long message, but hey I had to share it!!  ... food for thought... 

I think a lot about music and why certain people are triggered by certain styles
of music .... Sometimes I'm out dancing and thinking "what is it about this
music that is so important to me?" or sometimes "what am I missing here that so
many people obviously love this music but I don't?"

What I've come to believe is that each person has their own "vibrational" rate
(this is perhaps different from the purely spiritual vibrational rate theory,
maybe not, but I am in no way implying any sort of spiritual development level
here) -- 

That vibrational rate means that when Person A hears a certain type of music, it
reaches deep into their heart and soul, and triggers in them an emotion (happy,
sad, hopeful, whatever) -- the music talks to them and moves them.  

Now, Person B may hear that same music and say ... "I don't get it" ... but THEY
get that emotional response to something totally different, let's say country
music.   We call this "having different tastes in music" but I really think it's
much more than that.

These differences can be subtle ...  but we each know when we're hearing
something that "belongs" to us, because of how we respond.  When I'm dancing
like mad, loving the funky sexy house beat, and look over to my friend Jess, who
is hardly moving because it's too slow for her .... and then the music speeds up
to trance and she's going wild, but my feet have stopped moving ... I know that
there are truly differences in our individual "beats."

(....sometimes I wonder if there are physiological similarities between people
who love house, or people who love jazz, or whatever -- do their hearts beat at
the same rate?  blood pressure?  other measureable things?  ...anyone?  anyone?
...)

Some people would like to put a value judgment on having different musical
tastes ... "oh, you're just not SOPHISTICATED enough to like this music" or "you
listen to TRASH" ....  but I don't think that's valid at all.  Because the love
of music, whatever it is, isn't about thinking, it's about feeling.

Is techno music impersonal or without "soul"?  Not to me, I think it's TOTALLY
personal, because it talks to me deeply, and makes me move, and helps me to be
the person I want to be!  It's TOTALLY personal, because when I hear it, it
becomes part of me, and it brings out MY soul.  

Would that be as possible without the electronic, synthesized nature of it?
Maybe not, because maybe if there was too much of a personal stamp on it from
someone else, I couldn't own it as much when I hear it.  I often listen to music
with a strong personal voice (such as blues vocals or rap/hip-hop music) but
that doesn't affect me in quite the same way -- that's more like a person
singing to me, more like a conversation with another person, there's a
separation there like being an observer/listener.  

One of my favorite things is electronic music with scrambled or muffled vocals
that you can't quite make out (Jeno is a master at this), because then you have
to allow the words to absorb into your mind first, then let the message appear
from within -- almost like talking to yourself.  No other (identifiable) person
to come between you and how the music affects you.  (Again, classical has
similarities but because it is not made to dance to, it is a totally different
experience.)

Is music better when high?  Hell yes -- I feel that sometimes being stoned, or
an EmpathogEnic state creates a clear path to the vibe of the music -- like
walking through a door that was there all the time, only you didn't see it
before.  To me, that altered state lets me let go of my "mental" self and become
my "physical and emotional" self, and that is the part of me that responds best
to music and dancing.

So as part of this long testimonial (sorry!), I'd like to say a BIG THANK YOU to
the people who create techno music, the creators of the amazing equipment that
makes/mixes the music, and MOST of all to the DJs who use these tools to take us
on journeys where we get to BE ourselves, get to SEE ourselves, and get to have
MORE FUN than many people feel they deserve in a lifetime!

Leslie  ("I got the music in me")

p.s.  Separate topic but related?  Let's not be too hard on the 14-year-olds who
don't see the spiritual side of raving yet -- "when the student is ready, the
teacher will appear" -- we all develop at different rates, and sometimes it
takes time for someone to be ready for a leap in their personal development --
let's just try to be there with them to light the path when they are ready.

In case anyone was wondering...

Due to crowding constraints and other reasons, some rave organizers don't
want their events listed in this calendar (since it goes to well over
a thousand recipients).  So sometimes I have to use discretion to decide
if an event should go in the calendar - if it sounds pretty underground
I might leave it out.  If the party is flyered on Haight and the clubs,
I'll assume it isn't underground and put it in.  Otherwise, if you're a
promoter and you definitely do or don't want your event in the calendar,
please send me mail at dhchung@hyperreal.com.  Occasionally I get behind
in my mail, or I'll get a lot at once and so I might miss something -
apologies if this occurs.


                             THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning 3am-6am - "Aural Fixation"
       experimental sounds of ambient and trip hop with a splash of hi
       nrg, from trance to jungle. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

A parking alternative has been researched and brought to my attention 
(thank you swoosh!) :


From: swoosh@ucscb.UCSC.EDU (John Elias Darrow)
> ...
> If you get to the campus before 8pm, you can drive right through the gate
> without being stopped, and then just walk around until 9.  There are some
> great views of the town and bay, and paths around there.
> You can park almost anywhere on campus after 5pm and all weekend without
> fear of getting ticketed.
> ...

 And to double check on his information, I called The Crown College parking
office ( 459-4373 ). The gal who answered the phone told me that , after
5PM , general public parking is OK in the "A" lots. Also , to avoid the
guard at the gate , I should enter campus before 7:30PM.

i'm being brave by responding to this post without reading anyone else's 
responses! :)

I didn't need e to appreciate techno .... as a matter of fact, i think
techno helped me appreciate e if anything.  my first rave was an accident. 
i didn't even know that such things existed and i had heard o ecstacy. but
only occasionally, as the group i hung with was more into acid at the time
... and since i was taking one of my "rests" from drugs at the time, my
earliest techno experiences were all DRUG FREE!!! and you know what?  I
LOVED IT ANYWAYS! :)

jess wrote:
>
> I used to run screaming from a room if I ever heard techno music.  It
> seemed so grating and uninviting to me.
>
> And yet, sometime last year I heard it again and I *got it* in a major way
> - now I'm totally hooked.
>
> Most of you already know that I haven't done any drugs for years so that
> wasn't a factor in my initiation - however, I _used_ to be really into
> psychedelics and I think those pathways are still open and available for
> me to access.  I'm not sure if I'd never tranced out on drugs if I'd know
> how to do it sober - On the other hand, cultures have been trancing out
> for eons and not all of them had drugs so it must be an inate human
> ability.
>
> just my .02
>
>         ranting and raving
>
>                 jess

     Jess, I know what you mean about the drugs. I have been in the
underground music scene for about seven years and the vibes are more
addictive than drugs. I love to make a tape and just jam out. I am in
treatment so I can't say I never done drugs I done them most of my life.
I knew that it wasn't the drugs that made me love the music I just love
the vibes I get from it. All I need is to do one more fix(mix) and then I
will get off of the shit(turntables). That's what they all say!!!
   JUST SAY YES TO A GOOD CLEAN MIX
      BIG"O"
          
      Some where in Jackson,Ms.  HELP!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

From: Bill or Brent Overstreet <billover@netdoor.com>
X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.01 (Win16; I)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
CC: billover@netdoor.com
Subject: RE: TECHNO MUSIC AND...
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> A very long message, but hey I had to share it!!  ... food for thought...
>
> I think a lot about music and why certain people are triggered by certain styles
> of music .... Sometimes I'm out dancing and thinking "what is it about this
> music that is so important to me?" or sometimes "what am I missing here that so
> many people obviously love this music but I don't?"
>
> What I've come to believe is that each person has their own "vibrational" rate
> (this is perhaps different from the purely spiritual vibrational rate theory,
> maybe not, but I am in no way implying any sort of spiritual development level
> here) --
>
> That vibrational rate means that when Person A hears a certain type of music, it
> reaches deep into their heart and soul, and triggers in them an emotion (happy,
> sad, hopeful, whatever) -- the music talks to them and moves them.
>
> Now, Person B may hear that same music and say ... "I don't get it" ... but THEY
> get that emotional response to something totally different, let's say country
> music.   We call this "having different tastes in music" but I really think it's
> much more than that.
>
> These differences can be subtle ...  but we each know when we're hearing
> something that "belongs" to us, because of how we respond.  When I'm dancing
> like mad, loving the funky sexy house beat, and look over to my friend Jess, who
> is hardly moving because it's too slow for her .... and then the music speeds up
> to trance and she's going wild, but my feet have stopped moving ... I know that
> there are truly differences in our individual "beats."
>
> (....sometimes I wonder if there are physiological similarities between people
> who love house, or people who love jazz, or whatever -- do their hearts beat at
> the same rate?  blood pressure?  other measureable things?  ...anyone?  anyone?
> ...)
>
> Some people would like to put a value judgment on having different musical
> tastes ... "oh, you're just not SOPHISTICATED enough to like this music" or "you
> listen to TRASH" ....  but I don't think that's valid at all.  Because the love
> of music, whatever it is, isn't about thinking, it's about feeling.
>
> Is techno music impersonal or without "soul"?  Not to me, I think it's TOTALLY
> personal, because it talks to me deeply, and makes me move, and helps me to be
> the person I want to be!  It's TOTALLY personal, because when I hear it, it
> becomes part of me, and it brings out MY soul.
>
> Would that be as possible without the electronic, synthesized nature of it?
> Maybe not, because maybe if there was too much of a personal stamp on it from
> someone else, I couldn't own it as much when I hear it.  I often listen to music
> with a strong personal voice (such as blues vocals or rap/hip-hop music) but
> that doesn't affect me in quite the same way -- that's more like a person
> singing to me, more like a conversation with another person, there's a
> separation there like being an observer/listener.
>
> One of my favorite things is electronic music with scrambled or muffled vocals
> that you can't quite make out (Jeno is a master at this), because then you have
> to allow the words to absorb into your mind first, then let the message appear
> from within -- almost like talking to yourself.  No other (identifiable) person
> to come between you and how the music affects you.  (Again, classical has
> similarities but because it is not made to dance to, it is a totally different
> experience.)
>
> Is music better when high?  Hell yes -- I feel that sometimes being stoned, or
> an EmpathogEnic state creates a clear path to the vibe of the music -- like
> walking through a door that was there all the time, only you didn't see it
> before.  To me, that altered state lets me let go of my "mental" self and become
> my "physical and emotional" self, and that is the part of me that responds best
> to music and dancing.
>
> So as part of this long testimonial (sorry!), I'd like to say a BIG THANK YOU to
> the people who create techno music, the creators of the amazing equipment that
> makes/mixes the music, and MOST of all to the DJs who use these tools to take us
> on journeys where we get to BE ourselves, get to SEE ourselves, and get to have
> MORE FUN than many people feel they deserve in a lifetime!
>
> Leslie  ("I got the music in me")
>
> p.s.  Separate topic but related?  Let's not be too hard on the 14-year-olds who
> don't see the spiritual side of raving yet -- "when the student is ready, the
> teacher will appear" -- we all develop at different rates, and sometimes it
> takes time for someone to be ready for a leap in their personal development --
> let's just try to be there with them to light the path when they are ready.

-- You shouldn't limit yourself on music expecially in this type of
music. I love jazzy house to hard jungle. It's all in your mood at the
time. I make a tape just for the mood I'm in at that time. It would be a
bore if you had a one track mind.
  KEEP THE GOOD VIBS FLOWING
        BIG"O"

  

-- 
  Bill or Brent Overstreet
    Clinton, Mississippi
      Visit "Aa-aah-hh-h, Now You're Cooking" at...  
        http://www2.netdoor.com/~billover/index.html

X-Sender: shawna-@popd.ix.netcom.com

Subject: Jack in the box
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well I guess last night was the first night of Jackin the box, so I decided
to go & check it out.  I did enjoy the music, but it really did make me miss
MAD! :(  When I first got there, we were the only ones in the entire place!
This was located at 375 1st street, and you had to go down a flight of
stairs from the street level entrance to get to it.  It felt very weird
somehow to be finally be literally underground rather than figuratively!  It
did feel strange being underground, tho.  And there wasn't a bit of
decoration in the space, there was just the bare wood floor, the dj's
turntables, the walls, and black plastic garbage bags taped to the windows
to keep out the light from other rooms.  For the longest time, there wasn't
anybody there except a couple of other people milling about the place.  Then
for about five minutes two circle dancers took turns watching each other, &
then they too sat down and did nothing.  It really took close to 1 1/2 hours
for anybody to really start dancing, & I don't think there were any more
than ten people at any given time dancing at once. That group energy you
experience when a whole group of people is just totally getting off on the
music & dancing their asses off was completely lacking here, it was just a
few individuals kinda dancing around.  I had fun, but it wasn't the
phenomenal dancing experience I've had at MAD.  But then again, this was
only this weekly's first night, so I will have to check it out further on
down the line & see if it's improved at all.  But the music was good!  Some
good trance & techno stuff.  It had an ambient bar too, which was kind of
nice, you could go somewhere quieter if you wanted a break & to talk to
people (assuming people do show!).  But it just wasn't the same.

Ethan & Joe R. & co, I hope you all find somewhere new soon for MAD, we miss
you! :)


Love,
Shawna


  *It's not easy being cheezy...*

[ to sfraves list ]

Getting to this Friday night's ORACLe on the bus -

 Sorry for my incomplete message asking about the #1 Santa Cruz Metro bus
to UCSC. Right at the end of my previous message , it occured to me to 
use my web browser to find the Santa Cruz Metro home page (if any). I was
trying to exit my mailer but accidentally sent the message anyway!

 Santa Cruz Metro does have a home page! It's a bit of a bother to get to a 
schedule ( unless I did it the hard way again ) - I had to download and
set up a special document reader to read on download their schedule.

 Anyway - from the downtown Metro Center there are buses leaving every
15 minutes that get to the Applied Sciences center about 18 minutes later.
That's until 10PM , then the buses leave every 1/2 hour. 

 The last buses from the Applied Sciences center leave at 11:48PM and 
12:28 AM. I suspect that the bus passes the ORACLe site before it gets
to this Applied Sciences building , so plan ahead if you're bus dependent.

 I may catch the bus just so I don't have to hustle early to the campus to
find parking. Also, after commuting from Santa Clara and driving around
to find a new/strange restaurant, I'll be in the mood to let some other
person drive me around!

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

 PS - No mention of fare on the schedule , but other folks have said $1.
 I assume that's $2 for a round trip.

>Sure, Americans, generally speaking, are ignorant of the rest of the world.
>But do you guys really think that any other country's citizens are not as
>equally focused on their home country?  I mean, how many Iranians or
>Welsh or any other nationality have any idea who Nathan Hale is?
>I think it's multi-directional.

Yeah, but we Americans are *particularly* ignorant... we live in this
little seperate area, while the rest of the world is across the ocean, so
why should Joe American give a damn about the rest of the world, unless it
has a direct impact on his life? People who live in Europe, Asia, etc., are
all right in the middle of a bunch of countries with long histories of
conflict and competition... in Europe, you'll be lucky to meet someone who
_isn't_ well informed about the state of world politics and who _doesn't_
know a foreign language or two.

Considering the state of this country, I don't think our economic/cultural
dominance of the world will last long.

-m.

On Thu, 30 May 1996, Larry Ching wrote:

> Getting to this Friday night's ORACLe on the bus -
> 
> 
>  Anyway - from the downtown Metro Center there are buses leaving every
> 15 minutes that get to the Applied Sciences center about 18 minutes later.
> That's until 10PM , then the buses leave every 1/2 hour. 
> 
>  The last buses from the Applied Sciences center leave at 11:48PM and 
> 12:28 AM. I suspect that the bus passes the ORACLe site before it gets
> to this Applied Sciences building , so plan ahead if you're bus dependent.

This it does. When arriving mearly ask the driver for Crown College stop. 
That college is uphill from the stop. You should be able to hear the 
beats :)


> 
>  I may catch the bus just so I don't have to hustle early to the campus to
> find parking. Also, after commuting from Santa Clara and driving around
> to find a new/strange restaurant, I'll be in the mood to let some other
> person drive me around!
 
At the base of campus there is a theatre called the Barn Theatre. It is 
the first big building (on the left) when you drive into the main 
entrance (there are only two entrances), and is covered with large, 
painted marquees. They have lots of parking although there will be a play 
that night. The bus/shuttle stop is directly across from the theatre. 
There is another parking lot behind the bus/shuttle stop. The shuttle is 
free (they do not check ID) and the schedule is on a sign at the stop. 
Runs about every 15 minutes during the day.



>  Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com
> 
>  PS - No mention of fare on the schedule , but other folks have said $1.
>  I assume that's $2 for a round trip.

Fee is $1 for one way, $3 for an all day pass, no transfers.

 I really recommend coming early and hiking the campus!! It has some 
spectacular views of Santa Cruz, the pier, the Boardwalk and the Montery 
Bay. On a clear day you can see across to Monterey.

 Remember!!! After about 8:00 pm the guards come on duty. They will not 
let you in unless someone has called the gate to clear you ahead of time 
or if you have any UC campus ID (must be current) Again the guards do not 
check the shuttles or buses. =)



Lookin' foward to lotsa hugs!!


Ran
                             ( boogie oogie woogie )
                                      /
                                -=*=-/
                                  ~

>Ok! I think I have made a choice for the RANE MP-22 ($724.32).  The only
>question I have is for the Numark DM2160: it gives the option to assign the
>left ear to the left table and the right ear to the right table.  Rane
>doesn't give that option.  So is this option that big of an advantage or is
>it hardly used?  Comments?

Well, I must admit, that would be a VERY useful option for me personally. I
work third shift (11pm-8am) and on my days off (nights off, actually) I
like to spin but I don't want to wake up my whole apartment complex. So I
put on the headphones and go to it. If I could assign each headphone cup, I
could play the tunes as loud as I want (in the headphones only) and still
be able to beatmatch/cue/etc. without having to use my speakers.

Hugz,
-Chet

Black Adder offers:

>It also may well be that the viewing of raves as "spiritual" events is
>San Franciscocentric. I get the impression from talking to people from
>areas other than the Bay Area, and from reading posts from people that
>have gone to parties elsewhere that the "spiritual" aspect is not present(I
>won't say lacking,) or least as not as much an issue. Does this make any
>sense?

I think it has more to do with how deeply they are involved in the scene.
Here is Austin there's quite a few people who view raves as spiritual. They
usually have been going to parties for a while or are heavily involved in
DJing, promotion, etc. or hang out with those who do. It's often a process
of osmosis.

Hugz,
-Chet

          by SanFrancisco01.POP.InterNex.Net (post.office MTA v1.9.3
          ID# 0-11028) with SMTP id AAA11406;
          Fri, 31 May 1996 04:19:19 -0700
Message-Id: <2.2.32.19960531111933.00c38f9c@sanfrancisco01.pop.internex.net>
X-Sender: INX-10225b@sanfrancisco01.pop.internex.net
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 2.2 (32)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 31 May 1996 04:19:33 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "THX1138" <THX1138@planet-jubip.com>
Subject: My Memorial Day Weekend In Florida
Cc: Ulrike Laitko <laitko@hpbio1.Biologie.HU-Berlin.de>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello All;

        Well I spent my holiday weekend on the scene in North Central
Florida, at the Firestone in Orlando Saturday night, and Sunday at Simion's
in Gainesville; listening to Sasha spin on both nights; utterly fantastic.

        North Central Florida stills kicks, sorry SF but that's just my
honest opinion. The venues, drugs, DJ's, and people just stand a step above
what we have out here. 

        In a nutshell I feel this way because of the following, first the
venues. Real estate is no where near as valuable there as it is here; so
people are a lot more willing to rent out a piece of property to a bunch of
ravers. Second, the drugs; at one event alone I was offered over 20
DIFFERENT kinds of pills from people claiming them to be MDMA; no powder was
to be found anywhere. DJ's, in one month Gainesville, the smaller of the two
towns sees more out of town DJ's from all over the world than we see here in
SF, in an entire year. Lastly but certainly not least; the people. The
people of the South East  live the scene and the vibe and are a lot more
interested in you, rather than what they can get from you, and I think they
dance better ta boot. In addition, it's much more a multi cultural scene
there than here despite the race hate.

        Just my opinion based on my experience, yours is no doubt different
but nonetheless just as accurate with reference to you, so save your flames
for the fireplace. 

        Don't get me wrong, I chose to live here in the Bay area for it's
energy, opportunities, beauty and vibe which our scene contributes to in
many ways. But I have never, ever, gotten teary eyed over 1015, DV8, Acme,
or the many other vibeless unsafe venues here in Cali. like I did when I
walked into Simion's before the show started.

Peace
THX1138

Lately, Leslie Ayres wrote
 
> So, remember we're only seeing a partial vision of someone's ideas when we read
> them on email, much of the spirit and soul is not translatable in this medium
> .... so let's be careful out there!

well, this is quite right, but, hey, i wouldn't bother to post if i 
didn't have another fairly contrary point to share:

actually i think that through the cold  electronic medium of 
email the true self, the essence of a person often shines with extraordinary 
clarity.
i know this sounds paradoxical, but nowadays it apparently takes windy 
paradoxical roads to achieve authenticity .

there are some obvious points, like, no distraction by somebodies outer 
appearance (for example me, i'm, like, small and more on the cute 
side and everything, and people are normally pretty bummed if they hear 
me talking), but there's definitely way more than that about it, only i 
have trouble explaining it, especially in goddam english.

in the real world, every attitude, every pose, every feeling, every 
sentence is overly used by millions of people trying to find expression for 
their own, original self and sucking the meaning out of these 
attitudes, poses, feelings, sentences and emptying them, step by step, of 
their original content.  movies and commercials recycle and/or exploitthe 
already digested stuff again.
 (and you can't help it, this is just the way things go : 
everytime somebody managed to create a new, unique way to express a 
feeling or something it's a very happy moment, but it is also 
another step in that unwanted direction i been describing. the weird 
ways art goes illustrate that blatantly.) 

jess, in her very interesting post some days ago mentioned these young 
british people interacting with each other in a very rough way, bitch being 
the name for their best friend and so on. 
maybe they felt that it was the only fresh authentic way, the only 
way that really belonged to *them* and didn't have that taste of 
worn-out-ness = meaningless-ness that every normal, traditional way would 
maybe have. i know this explanation is kinda adventurous, and it 
definitely is not the whole story, bla bla bla, but i like it, and 
actually there are not too many explanations for phenomena like that
(or are there?).

in the internet, everything is fresh and shiny.
every word that appears on the screen after making it through all the 
wires and circuits seems to be gone through some sort of 
meaning-refreshing system (IMO of course).

another thing about the electronic medium:
somebody (sorry i couldn't find that post to quote it in original, 
hopefully i'm reporting it ok) in that E to enjoy techno? thread said that 
he appreciated techno exactly for its artificial quality, for it being 
emptied of any personal expression, because this enabled him to insert 
*his* feelings into the music without being disturbed by anything somebody 
else has left there.  i think the analogy to what i said above about 
language and other means of personal expression is, well, not perfect, but 
there seems to be some relation.  

boys and girls: if this doesn't make sense to you - lucky you, and 
don't bother, for heavens sake. anyway this whole authenticity thing 
seems to be  more of a european problem, no wonder, since europe was pretty 
old already when you guys over there just started the whole thing. 
but still there seem to be some people that feel it anyway. 
anybody heard of walker percy?

by the way: i'm no big friend of smiley faces and 
Insert-Heavy-Sarcasm-Here's.
so if you miss something - just insert smiley faces and whatever 
all over the place.

finally: i read that inspiring SF-Centric - and related topics - thread 
with the utmost interest. to add to the general oh-how-wonderful-this-list-is :
this list is really neat, most of the time.

thanks for making it through this dazed post, at least it helped me a 
bit to collect my thougts.

love and all kinds of authentic candy - 
ulrike

At 12:09 PM 5/31/96, peter fogel wrote:
>Just got the news and was wondering if this happened live in
>cyberspace, and did anyone tune in and see him tune out.
>
>peter

it was a private affair.  check out leary.com for details.  or read this
lovely letter...

 ***Long Live Timothy Leary by John Perry Barlow

  A couple of hours ago, at 12:45 am Beverly Hills time, my old friend and
  the corrupter of my youth Timothy Leary made good on his promise to
  "give death a better name or die trying." Willingly, peacefully, and
  unafraid, he headed off on his last trip.

  He spoke his last words a few hours before. On the phone to the mordant
  William S. Burroughs he said, "I hope that someday I'm as funny as you
  are."

  He didn't, as threatened, commit suicide on the Net. Or have his head
  cut off and frozen. Or engage in any other the other spectacles of
  departure I had dreaded. In the end, he surrounded himself with the
  angelic band of twenty-somethings who have been uploading him into
  the Web these last few months and drifted peacefully out of here.

  I was headed his way when he died. When I was with him earlier this month
  he said, "When I leave here, Barlow, I want your face to be one of the
  last things I see." I think that was one of the sweetest things anyone
  ever said to me, and I was trying to make it possible, but death proved
  itself once again to be bigger and faster than either of us. The phone
  just rang in the middle of this rainy Wyoming night, and now I'm here
  naked in the dark trying to think of something to follow him out with.

  Two years ago, Cynthia and I spent our last day together with Timmy.
  When she died the next day and it became so shockingly clear to both of
  us how strange this culture has become on the subject of the second
  commonest event in the world, how weirdly shameful is dying in
  America, we both thought it time to bring death out of the closet. I did
  so by grieving her, and continuing to grieve her, more publicly than
  is polite in a culture that claims for itself the ability to conquer
  and control everything.

  But Timmy beat me to the barricades. He flat died. And he died, without
  pretending that he was "really going to get well any day now," without
  permitting himself to become a ghoulish and futile medical
  experiment, without contributing to the stupefying mass denial
  that causes almost 80% of America's health care dollars to be blown on
  the last six months of life.

  He died unashamed and having, as usual, a great time.

  A few weeks ago, the denizens of leary.com and I rented a phalanx of
  wheel chairs and rode them with him into the House of Blues on Sunset
  Strip, a place that likely had never seen fifteen people in wheel
  chairs before. After a truly merry time, we were headed back to his
  house and on the way came within a smile of Tim Leary's Last Bust.

  We cruised west on Sunset. And the sun was setting. The top was down on
  my metallic mauve rent-a-convertible. A couple of the web girls,
  Trudy and Camilla, were sitting on the trunk like psychedelic prom
  queens, shoop-de-booping to the funk station on the radio, volume at
  eleven. Both the girls were beautiful, Trudy like a character from
  Neuromancer, Camilla like a character from Botticelli. The air was
  sweet and soft as a negligee on our faces, and the light had that
  elegiac quality that makes people think LA might not be so bad after
  all.

  Timmy gave me a high five and grinned. "Life is good!" he shouted over
  the music. As I looked up to meet his raised hand, I saw in my rear view
  mirror, past the swaying torsos of the girls, the rotating reds of a
  real Beverly Hills cop.

  Of course we were in possession of several of those substances that we
  considered safe and effective but which this culture, in another of
  its dangerous madnesses, has declared lethal, probably to distract
  heat from its own deadly drugs of choice. Furthermore, I had only
  recently paid an astonishingly steep California fine for allowing a
  friend to stand up through the sunroof of a car I was driving.

  He pulled us over in front of the Beverly Hills Hotel. He looked like an
  Eagle Scout.

  "Officer," I said, nodding back at the still improperly seated
  girls, "I know what we were doing was wrong. But you see, my friend here
  is dying, and we're trying to show him a good time." Timmy, without
  saying anything, smiled sheepishly at the cop and nodded, caught in
  the act.

  He looked like hell but he sure looked happy.

  The officer gazed into Timmy's beatific skull-face and lost his
  starch. "Well," he said to the girls, "I'd be lying if I didn't say that
  looks like fun, but just because he's dying doesn't mean you should.
  Now get down in the seat and buckle up and I'll let you go." I felt like
  honest death had just made one of its first converts.

  In thirty years of following Tim Leary around, he's given me some
  wonderful and hair-raising moments. He has been father,
  anti-father, partner-in-crime, and devout fellow-worshipper of
  all that is female in this world. We loved each other, and shared more
  memories than I will ever relate. But I think the look he gave that cop
  is the memory I will cherish most.

  As usual he was "cocking snooks at authority," as Aldous Huxley once
  accused him. But he was doing it, also as usual, with wit. And with
  love.

  America managed to forgive Richard Nixon when he died. I hope they
  will extend the same amnesty to a real hero, Dr. Timothy Leary.

  Yrs,

  John Perry

Subject: Re: Techno Music and Who Loves It (LONG!)
In-Reply-To: <960531002136_71165.755_GHL83-1@CompuServe.COM>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.960531131535.2811F-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On 30 May 1996, Leslie Ayres wrote:

> 
> Now, Person B may hear that same music and say ... "I don't get it" ... but THEY
> get that emotional response to something totally different, let's say country
> music.   We call this "having different tastes in music" but I really think it's
> much more than that.

I also believe that to appreciate different kinds of music, one has to 
learn about them.  If someone has an open mind, that someone can learn to 
appreciate much more about life.  Love of music often reaches snobbery 
and elitism.  I'm talking about putting down another because they don't 
know something about certain types of music or the "you listen to THAT 
shit" kind of attitude.  I think I was once that type of person.  When I 
was an adolescent, alining yourself with a type of music was also alining 
yourself with a group of people.  So, when you put down another kind of 
music it was a way of indirectly putting down the type of life of another 
and thereby validating YOUR lifestyle.  

I'm glad to say that I'm not like that any more, and have opened my eyes 
to tons of music.  But, to do this, I had to get out of a very narrow 
mind-set (which is also part of growing up i.e. things cease to be black 
or white).  I now enjoy lots of different kinds of music, techno being on 
the top of my list right now along with a couple of other things.  I also 
try and check myself when I start thinking one type of music is 
inherently "better."  I do think some music is more "advanced" (maybe 
that's the word:) and requires more talent to perform, e.g. jazz, but I 
don't think anything is inherently "better."  

Like Leslie said, people like music for different reasons.  To name a 
few: feeling, alignment with a certain movement, association with the 
lyrics, etc.  To invalidate a type of music as inferior is, to me, to 
invalidate the aforementioned things.  

I have a big dark secret to tell that ALWAYS gets me lots of slack.  I 
use to totally love Heavy Metal.  AC/DC was my favorite band.  I can 
already hear some of your groans!!!  I used to listen to this music 
because it was high energy.  It made me feel energized and ready to 
conquer the world.  It was also a result of growing up in Middle 
America.  Although, with rare exception, do I listen to that kind of 
music any more, it holds a feeling for me.  That feeling has passed now, 
but very few people even attempt to understand the feeling behind the 
actions.  I think people should stop to appreciate what others enjoy 
and share with them a part of their life.  My result of this has led me 
to like jazz, choral music, hip hop, folk music, and, OF COURSE, 
techno; the love of which I share with all of you.

cheers, have a great weekend, and I'll see you in the mtns...

Kirsten


              ****Shit, goddamn, get off your ass and jam****

course.  I plan to spend the summer studying at home and working outside 
of the home occasionally. Right now I have an evening teaching gig 
three nights a week. Raving a certainty.

Just kidding ;)  

Actually, I was just thinking back to third grade when the 
hyperventilation fad swept my class.  You remember -- you'd deeply 
inhale and exhale five times each with your back against the wall.  Then, 
holding your breath as you took your last big inhale, the person you 
designated to activate the oxygen-deprivation trip would push against 
your chest, a hand over each breast region (with the girls, palms were 
tactfully placed above the nipples), until your eyes involuntarily closed 
shut and your body became lava lamp limp.  Coming to, you gazed upward 
from the ground at a bunch of smiling faces who, with glee, retell the 
history of your body during the ten post-Tysonian seconds your ass was 
knocked out.

Seriously, for about a week or two, whenever the teacher wasn't around in 
class, we'd be doin' this shit.  Everyone kinda chilled out, tho', after 
this one time Karen Amanse started trippin' like Helen Keller before the 
Miracle-worker kicked in the special ed..  Karen, ahead of her time, was 
anachronistically kickin' junglistic convulsions when she should 
have been mellowing out on a soft beatless ambient beanbag cloud.  

Currently suffering from sleep-deprivation, Rok.

See you in Mendocino!
